messages.content: What misconception do teachers and coaches often convey about the relationship between effort and success in competitive markets?

Teachers and coaches implicitly told us the returns were linear. "You get out," I heard a thousand times, "what you put in." They meant well, but this is rarely true. If your product is only half as good as your competitor's, you don't get half as many customers. You get no customers, and you go out of business.
What is the nature of superlinear returns in various aspects of life, and how do they relate to capitalism?

It is obviously true that the returns for performance are superlinear in business. Some think this is a flaw of capitalism, and that if we changed the rules, it would stop being true. However, superlinear returns for performance are a feature of the world, not an artifact of rules we've invented. We see the same pattern in fame, power, military victories, knowledge, and even benefits to humanity. In all of these, the rich get richer.
What concept is essential for understanding the world and achieving ambition?
You can't understand the world without understanding the concept of superlinear returns. And if you're ambitious, you definitely should, because this will be the wave you surf on.
What are the two fundamental causes of superlinear returns?
It may seem as if there are a lot of different situations with superlinear returns, but as far as I can tell, they reduce to two fundamental causes: exponential growth and thresholds.
What is an example of a situation where superlinear returns can be observed, and what factors influence success in that context?

The most obvious case of superlinear returns is when you're working on something that grows exponentially. For example, growing bacterial cultures. When they grow at all, they grow exponentially. But they're tricky to grow, which means the difference in outcome between someone who's adept at it and someone who's not is very great.
What distinguishes successful startups from those that struggle to survive?

Startups can also grow exponentially, and we see the same pattern there. Some manage to achieve high growth rates, while most don't. As a result, you get qualitatively different outcomes: the companies with high growth rates tend to become immensely valuable, while the ones with lower growth rates may not even survive.
Why is it important for startups to prioritize growth rate over absolute numbers according to Y Combinator?

Y Combinator encourages founders to focus on growth rate rather than absolute numbers. This approach prevents them from being discouraged early on when the absolute numbers are still low. It also helps them decide what to focus on; you can use growth rate as a compass to tell you how to evolve the company. The main advantage is that by focusing on growth rate, you tend to achieve something that grows exponentially.
How does YC's approach suggest a relationship between growth rate and founder performance?

YC doesn't explicitly tell founders that with growth rate "you get out what you put in," but it's not far from the truth. If growth rate were proportional to performance, then the reward for performance would also increase accordingly.
Why do people find exponential growth surprising or unnatural?

Whenever how well you do depends on how well you've done, you'll get exponential growth. But neither our DNA nor our customs prepare us for it. No one finds exponential growth natural; every child is surprised, the first time they hear it, by the story of the man who asks the king for a single grain of rice on the first day and doubles the amount each successive day.
Why do humans lack established customs for dealing with exponential growth?

What we don't understand, we naturally develop customs to deal with; however, we don't have many customs about exponential growth either, because there have been so few instances of it in human history. In principle, herding should have been one: the more animals you had, the more offspring they'd have. But in practice, grazing land was the limiting factor, and there was no plan for growing that exponentially.
What does the term "winner take all" illustrate about the relationship between performance and returns in competitive scenarios?

The other source of superlinear returns is embodied in the expression "winner take all." In a sports match, the relationship between performance and return is a step function: the winning team gets one win whether they do much better or just slightly better.
What factors can lead to the emergence of thresholds in outcomes besides competition?

The source of the step function is not competition per se; however, it's that there are thresholds in the outcome. You don't need competition to get those. There can be thresholds in situations where you're the only participant, like proving a theorem or hitting a target.
How do superlinear returns influence competitive dynamics in markets and conflicts?

It's remarkable how often a situation with one source of superlinear returns also has the other. Crossing thresholds leads to exponential growth: the winning side in a battle usually suffers less damage, which makes them more likely to win in the future. Exponential growth helps you cross thresholds; in a market with network effects, a company that grows fast enough can shut out potential competitors.
What factors contribute to the exponential growth and concentration of fame?

Fame is an interesting example of a phenomenon that combines both sources of superlinear returns. Fame grows exponentially because existing fans bring you new ones. However, the fundamental reason it's so concentrated is thresholds: there's only so much room on the A-list in the average person's head.
How does the concept of thresholds in learning contribute to exponential growth in knowledge and the discovery of new fields?

The most important case combining both sources of superlinear returns may be learning. Knowledge grows exponentially, but there are also thresholds in it. Learning to ride a bicycle, for example. Some of these thresholds are akin to machine tools: once you learn to read, you're able to learn anything else much faster. But the most important thresholds of all are those representing new discoveries. Knowledge seems to be fractal in the sense that if you push hard at the boundary of one area of knowledge, you sometimes discover a whole new field. And if you do, you get first crack at all the new discoveries to be made in it. Newton did this, and so did DÃ¼rer and Darwin.
What are the two ways work can compound, and how can learning influence this process?

There are two ways work can compound. It can compound directly, in the sense that doing well in one cycle causes you to do better in the next. That happens, for example, when you're building infrastructure or growing an audience or brand. Or work can compound by teaching you, since learning compounds. This second case is an interesting one because you may feel you're doing badly as it's happening. You may be failing to achieve your immediate goal. But if you're learning a lot, then you're getting exponential growth nonetheless.
Why does Silicon Valley maintain a culture that accepts failure?

Silicon Valley maintains a culture that accepts failure for several reasons. People in Silicon Valley aren't blindly tolerant of failure; they'll only continue to bet on you if you're learning from your failures. If you are learning, you are, in fact, a good bet: maybe your company didn't grow the way you wanted, but you yourself have, and that should yield results eventually.
What is the importance of continuous learning in achieving exponential growth?

Indeed, the forms of exponential growth that don't consist of learning are so often intermixed with it that we should probably treat this as the rule rather than the exception. This yields another heuristic: always be learning. If you're not learning, you're probably not on a path that leads to superlinear returns.
Why is it important to explore unconventional or lesser-known topics while learning?

It's important to explore unconventional or lesser-known topics while learning because you shouldn't limit yourself to things that are already known to be valuable. You're learning; you don't know for sure yet what's going to be valuable, and if you're too strict, you'll lop off the outliers.
What principle can be applied to identify opportunities for creating better products in a competitive market?

A principle for taking advantage of thresholds includes a test to ensure the game is worth playing. Here's one that does: if you come across something that's mediocre yet still popular, it could be a good idea to replace it. For example, if a company makes a product that people dislike yet still buy, then presumably they'd buy a better alternative if you made one.
What approach should researchers take to foster genuine curiosity and potentially make new discoveries?

Researchers should be driven by curiosity rather than careerism to foster genuine curiosity and potentially make new discoveries. The kinds of inquiries that lead to new discoveries often seem mystifying and perhaps unimportant. If they were both mystifying and obviously important, they would be famous open questions with many people already working on them. Therefore, one heuristic is to give free rein to your curiosity instead of focusing solely on what you're supposed to work on.
What are the current trends regarding superlinear returns in various fields of work?

The prospect of superlinear returns for performance is an exciting one for the ambitious. And there's good news in this department: this territory is expanding in both directions. There are more types of work in which you can get superlinear returns, and the returns themselves are growing.
How has the necessity of being part of an organization for ambitious projects changed over the past fifty years?

Fifty years ago, it was much more necessary to be part of an organization to work on ambitious projects. It was the only way to get the resources you needed, the only way to have colleagues, and the only way to get distribution. So in 1970, your prestige was, in most cases, the prestige of the organization you belonged to. Prestige was an accurate predictor because if you weren't part of an organization, you weren't likely to achieve much. There were a handful of exceptions, most notably artists and writers, who worked alone using inexpensive tools and had their own brands. But even they were at the mercy of organizations for reaching audiences.
How has the landscape of opportunities and freedom for individuals changed in recent years compared to the past?

A world dominated by organizations dampened variation in the returns for performance. But this world has eroded significantly just in my lifetime. Now, a lot more people can have the freedom that artists and writers had in the 20th century. There are lots of ambitious projects that don't require much initial funding, and many new ways to learn, make money, find colleagues, and reach audiences.
Who is best suited to pursue superlinear returns in a system with greater outcome variation?

Without the damping effect of institutions, there will be more variation in outcomes. This doesn't imply everyone will be better off: people who do well will do even better, but those who do badly will do worse. That's an important point to bear in mind. Exposing oneself to superlinear returns is not for everyone. Most people will be better off as part of the pool. So who should shoot for superlinear returns? Ambitious people of two types: those who know they're so good that they'll be net ahead in a world with higher variation, and those, particularly the young, who can afford to risk trying it to find out.
How will the shift away from traditional institutions impact access to opportunities for new individuals?

The shift away from traditional institutions won't simply be an exodus of their current inhabitants. Many of the new winners will be people they would never have let in. So the resulting democratization of opportunity will be both greater and more authentic than any tame intramural version the institutions themselves might have cooked up.
What are the benefits of striving for exceptional work in a competitive environment?

The most obvious way to take advantage of superlinear returns for performance is by doing exceptionally good work. At the far end of the curve, incremental effort is a bargain. All the more so because there's less competition at the far endânot just for the obvious reason that it's hard to do something exceptionally well, but also because people find the prospect so intimidating that few even try. This means it's not just a bargain to do exceptional work, but a bargain even to try to.
What factors contribute to achieving exceptional work and standing out in a competitive environment?

There are many variables that affect how good your work is, and if you want to be an outlier, you need to get nearly all of them right. For example, to do something exceptionally well, you have to be interested in it. Mere diligence is not enough. So, in a world with superlinear returns, it's even more valuable to know what you're interested in and to find ways to work on it.
When is it most advantageous to pursue high-demand, time-consuming work?

It will also be important to choose work that suits your circumstances. For example, if there's a kind of work that inherently requires a huge expenditure of time and energy, it will be increasingly valuable to do it when you're young and don't yet have children.
How does luck influence success when working independently?

Luck is, of course, one other thing you need to be successful. Luck is always a factor, but it's even more significant when you're working on your own rather than as part of an organization. Although there are some valid aphorisms about luck being where preparedness meets opportunity, there's also a component of true chance that you can't do anything about. The solution is to take multiple shots, which is another reason to start taking risks early.
What field is characterized by superlinear returns due to exponential growth and performance thresholds?

The best example of a field with superlinear returns is probably science. It has exponential growth, in the form of learning, combined with thresholds at the extreme edge of performanceâliterally at the limits of knowledge.
What does the paragraph suggest about the disparity in contributions to scientific discovery throughout history?

The result has been a level of inequality in scientific discovery that makes the wealth inequality of even the most stratified societies seem mild by comparison. Newton's discoveries were arguably greater than all his contemporaries' combined.
What is the relationship between superlinear returns and inequality in outcomes?
Superlinear returns imply inequality. The steeper the return curve, the greater the variation in outcomes.
What characteristics of a field indicate the potential for superlinear returns?

In fact, the correlation between superlinear returns and inequality is so strong that it yields another heuristic for finding work of this type: look for fields where a few big winners outperform everyone else. A kind of work where everyone does about the same is unlikely to be one with superlinear returns.
What are some fields where a small number of individuals achieve significantly higher success than the majority?

What are fields where a few big winners outperform everyone else? Here are some obvious ones: sports, politics, art, music, acting, directing, writing, math, science, starting companies, and investing. In sports, the phenomenon is due to externally imposed thresholds; you only need to be a few percent faster to win every race. In politics, power grows much as it did in the days of emperors. And in some of the other fields (including politics), success is driven largely by fame, which has its own source of superlinear growth. But when we exclude sports and politics and the effects of fame, a remarkable pattern emerges: the remaining list is exactly the same as the list of fields where you have to be.
Why is it important for investors to have unique insights about a company's potential for success?

This is obviously the case in science. You can't publish papers saying things that other people have already said. But it's just as true in investing, for example. It's only useful to believe that a company will do well if most other investors don't; if everyone else thinks the company will do well, then its stock price will already reflect that, and there's no room to make money.
What is the significance of focusing on initial efforts in the growth of startups and learning processes?

In the startup world, the name for this principle is "do things that don't scale." If you pay a ridiculous amount of attention to your tiny initial set of customers, ideally, you'll kick off exponential growth by word of mouth. But this same principle applies to anything that grows exponentially, such as learning. When you first start learning something, you feel lost. However, it's worth making the initial effort to get a toehold because the more you learn, the easier it will get.
How has the perception of work evolved beyond traditional employment in creative and academic fields?

There's another, more subtle lesson in the list of fields with superlinear returns: not to equate work with a job. For most of the 20th century, the two were identical for nearly everyone, and as a result, we've inherited a custom that equates productivity with having a job. Even now, to most people, the phrase "your work" means their job. But to a writer, artist, or scientist, it means whatever they're currently studying or creating. For someone like that, their work is something they carry with them from job to job, if they have jobs at all. It may be done for an employer, but it's part of their portfolio.
What is the relationship between curiosity and success in fields with high potential returns?

It's an intimidating prospect to enter a field where a few big winners outperform everyone else. Some people do this deliberately, but you don't need to. If you have sufficient natural ability and you follow your curiosity sufficiently far, you'll end up in one. Your curiosity won't let you be interested in boring questions, and interesting questions tend to create fields with superlinear returns if they're not already part of one.
What role do ambition and curiosity play in achieving superlinear returns?

The territory of superlinear returns is by no means static. Indeed, the most extreme returns come from expanding it. So, while both ambition and curiosity can get you into this territory, curiosity may be the more powerful of the two. Ambition tends to make you climb existing peaks, but if you stick close enough to an interesting enough question, it may grow into a mountain beneath you.
What challenges arise in defining the concepts of effort, performance, and return in various contexts?

Thereâs a limit to how sharply you can distinguish between effort, performance, and return, because theyâre not sharply distinguished in fact. What counts as return to one person might be performance to another. But though the borders of these concepts are blurry, theyâre not meaningless. Iâve tried to write about them as precisely as I could without crossing into error.
How did knowledge and technique contribute to human life before the Industrial Revolution?

Knowledge did, of course, have a practical effect before the Industrial Revolution. The development of agriculture changed human life completely. But this kind of change was the result of broad, gradual improvements in technique, not the discoveries of a few exceptionally learned people.
How does a step function represent the reward curve for effort in rational decision-making?

It's not mathematically correct to describe a step function as superlinear, but a step function starting from zero works like a superlinear function when it describes the reward curve for effort by a rational actor. If it starts at zero, then the part before the step is below any linearly increasing return, and the part after the step must be above the necessary return at that point, or no one would bother.
What are the potential benefits and limitations of seeking competition when identifying promising problems to work on?

Seeking competition could be a good heuristic in the sense that some people find it motivating. It's also somewhat of a guide to promising problems because it's a sign that other people find them promising. However, it's a very imperfect sign: often there's a clamoring crowd chasing some problem, and they all end up being trumped by someone quietly working on another one.
What factors can contribute to the popularity of mediocre products or services?

Not always, though. You have to be careful with this rule. When something is popular despite being mediocre, there's often a hidden reason why. Perhaps a monopoly or regulation makes it hard to compete. Perhaps customers have bad taste or have broken procedures for deciding what to buy. There are huge swathes of mediocre things that exist for such reasons.
What motivated you to study painting at art school?
I went to art school to study painting mostly because I liked art, but a nontrivial part of my motivation came from the fact that artists seemed least at the mercy of organizations.
What factors contributed to the emergence of this concept during a time of increasing performance variation?

It may seem like bad luck for this concept that it arose at just the moment when the world was shifting in the opposite direction, but I don't think this was a coincidence. I think one reason it arose now is that its adherents feel threatened by rapidly increasing variation in performance.
What prompted the author to pause their current essay and expand a specific paragraph into its own piece?

As soon as I wrote it, I realized it was a more important topic than superlinear returns, so I paused the present essay to expand this paragraph into its own. Practically nothing remains of the original version because, after I finished "How to Do Great Work," I rewrote it based on that.
How has the method of acquiring wealth evolved from the pre-Industrial Revolution era to modern advanced economies?

Before the Industrial Revolution, people who got rich usually did it like emperors: capturing some resource made them more powerful and enabled them to capture more. Now it can be done like a scientist, by discovering or building something uniquely valuable. Most people who get rich use a mix of the old and the new ways, but in the most advanced economies, the ratio has changed significantly.
Why do conventional-minded individuals often perceive high performance variation as a result of cheating or external factors?

It's not surprising that conventional-minded people would dislike inequality if independent-mindedness is one of the biggest drivers of it. But it's not simply that they don't want anyone to have what they can't. The conventional-minded literally can't imagine what it's like to have novel ideas. So, the whole phenomenon of great variation in performance seems unnatural to them, and when they encounter it, they assume it must be due to cheating or to some malign external influence.
What is the purpose of collecting lists of techniques from various fields?
The purpose of collecting lists of techniques from various fields is to explore what the intersection of these techniques looks like. I decided to find out by creating such a compilation.
What were the goals behind creating the guide on the intersection of various fields?

Partly, my goal was to create a guide that could be used by someone working in any field. But I was also curious about the shape of the intersection. One thing this exercise shows is that it does have a definite shape; it's not just a point labeled "work hard."
What qualities should you consider when selecting a project to work on?

The first step is to decide what to work on. The work you choose needs to have three qualities: it has to be something you have a natural aptitude for, something you have a deep interest in, and something that offers scope to do great work.
What should ambitious individuals focus on when pursuing their goals?

In practice, you don't have to worry much about the third criterion. Ambitious people are, if anything, already too conservative about it. So all you need to do is find something you have an aptitude for and great interest in.
What challenges do young people face when trying to determine their future career paths?

That sounds straightforward, but it's often quite difficult. When you're young, you don't know what you're good at or what different kinds of work are like. Some kinds of work you end up doing may not even exist yet. So, while some people know what they want to do at 14, most have to figure it out.
What is the best approach to determine what projects or areas to focus on when unsure?

The way to figure out what to work on is by working. If you're not sure what to work on, guess. But pick something and get going. You'll probably guess wrong some of the time, but that's fine. It's good to know about multiple things; some of the biggest discoveries come from noticing connections between different fields.
Why is it important to focus on personal projects in your work?

Develop a habit of working on your own projects. Don't let "work" mean something other people tell you to do. If you do manage to do great work one day, it will probably be on a project of your own. It may be within some bigger project, but you'll be driving your part of it.
What criteria should you consider when choosing projects throughout different stages of life?

What should your projects be? Whatever seems excitingly ambitious to you. As you grow older and your taste in projects evolves, exciting and important will converge. At 7, it may seem excitingly ambitious to build huge things out of Lego; then at 14, to teach yourself calculus; until at 21, you're starting to explore unanswered questions in physics. But always preserve excitingness.
What role does curiosity play in driving and guiding great work?
There's a kind of excited curiosity that's both the engine and the rudder of great work. It will not only drive you, but if you let it have its way, it will also show you what to work on.
What should you do after discovering a deep interest in a subject to advance your understanding?

Once you've found something you're excessively interested in, the next step is to learn enough about it to get you to one of the frontiers of knowledge. Knowledge expands fractally, and from a distance, its edges look smooth, but once you learn enough to get close to one, they turn out to be full of gaps.
What is the importance of questioning assumptions in making new discoveries?

The next step is to notice them. This takes some skill because your brain wants to ignore such gaps in order to make a simpler model of the world. Many discoveries have come from asking questions about things that everyone else took for granted.
Why is strangeness considered a valuable quality in great work?

If the answers seem strange, so much the better. Great work often has a tincture of strangeness. You see this from painting to math. It would be affected to try to manufacture it, but if it appears, embrace it.
Why is it important to pursue unconventional ideas even when others show disinterest?

Boldly chase outlier ideas, even if other people aren't interested in them â in fact, especially if they aren't. If you're excited about some possibility that everyone else ignores, and you have enough expertise to say precisely what they're all overlooking, that's as good a bet as you'll find.
What is the process for making significant contributions in any field?

Four steps: choose a field, learn enough to get to the frontier, notice gaps, and explore promising ones. This is how practically everyone who's done great work has done it, from painters to physicists.
Why is it important to work on something you are deeply interested in?

Steps two and four will require hard work. It may not be possible to prove that you have to work hard to do great things, but the empirical evidence is on the scale of the evidence for mortality. That's why it's essential to work on something you're deeply interested in. Interest will drive you to work harder than mere diligence ever could.
What are the three most powerful motives that can drive human behavior?
The three most powerful motives are curiosity, delight, and the desire to do something impressive. Sometimes they converge, and that combination is the most powerful of all.
What challenges do individuals face when deciding on a career path?

Deciding on a career path presents several challenges. The main reason it's hard is that you can't tell what most kinds of work are like except by doing them. This means the four steps of career exploration overlap: you may have to work at something for years before you know how much you like it or how good you are at it. In the meantime, you're not doing, and thus not learning about, most other kinds of work. So, in the worst case, you choose late based on very incomplete information.
How does the dual nature of ambition impact decision-making in pursuing great work?

The dual nature of ambition exacerbates this problem. Ambition comes in two forms: one that precedes interest in the subject and one that grows out of it. Most people who do great work have a mix, and the more you have of the former, the harder it will be to decide what to do.
Why do educational systems often misrepresent the ease of committing to a career path?

The educational systems in most countries misrepresent the ease of committing to a career path. They expect you to commit to a field long before you could know what it's really like. As a result, an ambitious person on an optimal trajectory will often appear to the system as an instance of breakage.
What are the limitations of the current system in helping teenagers determine their career paths?

It would be better if they at least admitted it â if they admitted that the system not only can't do much to help you figure out what to work on, but is designed on the assumption that you'll somehow magically guess as a teenager. They don't tell you, but I will: when it comes to figuring out what to work on, you're on your own. Some people get lucky and do guess correctly, but the rest will find themselves scrambling diagonally across tracks laid down on the assumption that everyone does.
How can one increase their chances of success and opportunity in life?

To increase your chances of success and opportunity in life, do not drift along passively, assuming the problem will solve itself. You need to take action. However, there is no systematic procedure you can follow. When you read biographies of people who've done great work, it's remarkable how much luck is involved. They discover what to work on as a result of a chance meeting or by reading a book they happen to pick up. Therefore, you need to make yourself a big target for luck, and the way to do that is to be curious. Try lots of things, meet lots of people, read lots of books, and ask lots of questions.
What should you prioritize when exploring new fields of study?

When in doubt, optimize for interestingness. Fields change as you learn more about them. What mathematicians do, for example, is very different from what you do in high school math classes. So, you need to give different types of work a chance to show you what they're like. But a field should become clearer as you explore it.
Why is it beneficial to have unique interests and tastes?

Don't worry if you find you're interested in different things than other people. The stranger your tastes in interestingness, the better. Strange tastes are often strong ones, and a strong taste for work means you'll be productive. Additionally, you're more likely to find new things if you're looking where few have looked before.
What should you consider when choosing between multiple projects or fields of work?
"But fields aren't people; you don't owe them any loyalty. If, in the course of working on one thing, you discover another that's more exciting, don't be afraid to switch."
What is the best approach to ensure that your creation resonates with an audience?

If you're making something for people, make sure it's something they actually want. The best way to do this is to create something you yourself want. Write the story you want to read; build the tool you want to use. Since your friends probably have similar interests, this will also help you find your initial audience.
What is the key principle to consider when writing a story that will resonate with readers?

The key principle to consider when writing a story that will resonate with readers is to follow the excitement rule. Obviously, the most exciting story to write will be the one you want to read. The reason I mention this case explicitly is that so many people get it wrong. Instead of making what they want, they try to create what some imaginary, more sophisticated audience wants. And once you go down that route, you're lost.
What should you prioritize when deciding what projects to pursue?

There are a lot of forces that will lead you astray when you're trying to figure out what to work on: pretentiousness, fashion, fear, money, politics, other people's wishes, and eminent frauds. But if you stick to what you find genuinely interesting, you'll be proof against all of them. If you're interested, you're not astray.
What does pursuing your interests require beyond mere enthusiasm?

Following your interests may sound like a rather passive strategy, but in practice, it usually means following them past all sorts of obstacles. You usually have to risk rejection and failure, so it does take a good deal of boldness.
What is the recommended approach for achieving great work according to the paragraph?

But while you need boldness, you don't usually need much planning. In most cases, the recipe for doing great work is simply: work hard on excitingly ambitious projects, and something good will come of it. Instead of making a plan and then executing it, you just try to preserve certain invariants.
What are the limitations of planning when it comes to achieving unexpected discoveries?

The trouble with planning is that it only works for achievements you can describe in advance. You can win a gold medal or get rich by deciding to do so as a child and then tenaciously pursuing that goal, but you can't discover natural selection that way.
What approach do successful individuals often take to achieve great work?

I think for most people who want to do great work, the right strategy is not to plan too much. At each stage, do whatever seems most interesting and gives you the best options for the future. I call this approach "staying upwind." This is how most people who've done great work seem to have done it.
What challenges might one face when pursuing a new and exciting project?

Even when you've found something exciting to work on, pursuing it is not always straightforward. There will be times when a new idea makes you leap out of bed in the morning and get straight to work. However, there will also be plenty of times when things aren't like that.
What does the comparison between sailing and working suggest about the nature of achieving inspiration?
"You don't just put out your sail and get blown forward by inspiration. There are headwinds, currents, and hidden shoals. So there's a technique to working, just as there is to sailing."
What are the potential consequences of working excessively hard?

For example, while you must work hard, it's possible to work too hard, and if you do that, you'll find you get diminishing returns: fatigue will make you stupid and eventually even damage your health. The point at which work yields diminishing returns depends on the type. Some of the hardest types you might only be able to do for four or five hours a day.
Why is it important to have contiguous blocks of time for focused work?

Ideally, those hours will be contiguous. To the extent you can, try to arrange your life so you have big blocks of time to work in. You'll shy away from hard tasks if you know you might be interrupted.
What strategies can help overcome the initial resistance to starting a task?

It will probably be harder to start working than to keep working. You'll often have to trick yourself to get over that initial threshold. Don't worry about this; it's the nature of work, not a flaw in your character. Work has a sort of activation energy, both per day and per project. And since this threshold is fake in the sense that it's higher than the energy required to keep going, it's okay to tell yourself a lie of corresponding magnitude to get over it.
What strategy can help overcome reluctance to start work in the morning?

It's usually a mistake to lie to yourself if you want to do great work, but this is one of the rare cases where it isn't. When I'm reluctant to start work in the morning, I often trick myself by saying, "I'll just read over what I've got so far." Five minutes later, I've found something that seems mistaken or incomplete, and I'm off.
What mindset can be beneficial when initiating new projects?

Similar techniques work for starting new projects. It's okay to lie to yourself about how much work a project will entail, for example. Lots of great things began with someone saying, "How hard could it be?"
What advantages do young people have in situations requiring optimism?
This is one case where the young have an advantage. They're more optimistic, and even though one of the sources of their optimism is ignorance, in this case, ignorance can sometimes beat knowledge.
Why is it important to complete projects even when they require more effort than anticipated?

It is important to finish what you start, even if it turns out to be more work than you expected. Finishing things is not just an exercise in tidiness or self-discipline. In many projects, a lot of the best work happens in what was meant to be the final stage.
What is the potential benefit of exaggerating the importance of your work?

Another permissible lie is to exaggerate the importance of what you're working on, at least in your own mind. If that helps you discover something new, it may turn out not to have been a lie after all.
What are the different forms of procrastination, and which one is considered more dangerous?

There are two senses of starting work â per day and per project â and therefore, there are also two forms of procrastination. Per-project procrastination is far more dangerous. You put off starting that ambitious project from year to year because the time isn't quite right. When you're procrastinating in units of years, you can get a lot not done.
What makes per-project procrastination particularly deceptive compared to per-day procrastination?

One reason per-project procrastination is so dangerous is that it usually camouflages itself as work. You're not just sitting around doing nothing; you're working industriously on something else. So, per-project procrastination doesn't set off the alarms that per-day procrastination does. You're too busy to notice it.
How can one ensure they are focusing on their true passions as they age?

The way to beat it is to stop occasionally and ask yourself: Am I working on what I most want to work on? When you're young, it's okay if the answer is sometimes no, but this gets increasingly dangerous as you get older.
What mindset is necessary to appreciate the time investment required for great work?

Great work usually entails spending what would seem to most people an unreasonable amount of time on a problem. You can't think of this time as a cost, or it will seem too high. You have to find the work sufficiently engaging as it's happening.
What is the key to achieving great work according to the paragraph?

Great work happens by focusing consistently on something you're genuinely interested in. There may be some jobs where you have to work diligently for years at things you hate before you get to the good part, but this is not how great work happens. When you pause to take stock, you're surprised how far you've come.
How does consistency contribute to achieving significant goals over time?

The reason we're surprised is that we underestimate the cumulative effect of work. Writing a page a day doesn't sound like much, but if you do it every day, you'll write a book a year. That's the key: consistency. People who do great things don't get a lot done every day; they get something done, rather than nothing.
What are some examples of activities that lead to exponential growth?

If you do work that compounds, you'll get exponential growth. Most people who do this do it unconsciously, but it's worth stopping to think about. Learning, for example, is an instance of this phenomenon: the more you learn about something, the easier it is to learn more. Growing an audience is another: the more fans you have, the more new fans theyâll bring you.
Why do people often underestimate the impact of exponential growth in its early stages?

The trouble with exponential growth is that the curve feels flat in the beginning. It isn't; it's still a wonderful exponential curve. However, we can't grasp that intuitively, so we underrate exponential growth in its early stages.
Why do people often underestimate the value of investing in exponential growth during the initial phase?

Something that grows exponentially can become so valuable that it's worth making an extraordinary effort to get it started. However, since we underestimate exponential growth early on, this is often done unconsciously: people push through the initial, unrewarding phase of learning something new because they know from experience that learning new things always takes an initial push, or they grow their audience one fan at a time because they have nothing better to do. If people consciously realized they could invest in exponential growth, many more would do it.
How can undirected thinking contribute to problem-solving?

Work doesn't just happen when you're trying to. There's a kind of undirected thinking you do when walking, taking a shower, or lying in bed that can be very powerful. By letting your mind wander a little, you'll often solve problems you were unable to solve by frontal attack.
How can daydreaming enhance creativity and problem-solving in the context of focused work?

You have to be working hard in the normal way to benefit from this phenomenon, though. You can't just walk around daydreaming. The daydreaming has to be interleaved with deliberate work that feeds it questions.
What is the importance of developing a discerning taste in your professional field?
Consciously cultivate your taste in the work done in your field. Until you know which is the best and what makes it so, you don't know what you're aiming for.
Why is aiming to be the best considered essential for achieving success?

What you're aiming for is essential because if you don't try to be the best, you won't even be good. This observation has been made by so many people in so many different fields that it might be worth thinking about why it's true. It could be because ambition is a phenomenon where almost all the error is in one direction â where almost all the shells that miss the target miss by falling short. Or it could be because ambition to be the best is a qualitatively different thing from ambition to be good. Or maybe being good is simply too vague a standard. Probably all three are true.
How can striving to be the best lead to unexpected benefits and simplifications in one's efforts?

Fortunately, there's a kind of economy of scale here. Though it might seem like you'd be taking on a heavy burden by trying to be the best, in practice, you often end up net ahead. It's exciting and also strangely liberating. It simplifies things. In some ways, it's easier to try to be the best than to try merely to be good.
What is a strategy for creating lasting impact in your work?

One way to aim high is to try to make something that people will care about in a hundred years. Not because their opinions matter more than your contemporaries', but because something that still seems good in a hundred years is more likely to be genuinely good.
How can young people overcome feelings of insignificance and build their identity?

The temptation to be someone else is greatest for the young. They often feel like nobodies. But you never need to worry about that problem because it's self-solving if you work on sufficiently ambitious projects. If you succeed at an ambitious project, you're not a nobody; you're the person who did it. So just do the work, and your identity will take care of itself.
What is a positive way to express the idea of avoiding affectation?

"Avoid affectation" is a useful rule so far as it goes, but how would you express this idea positively? How would you say what to be, instead of what not to be? The best answer is earnest. If you're earnest, you avoid not just affectation but a whole set of similar vices.
What is the significance of intellectual honesty in the pursuit of new ideas?

The core of being earnest is being intellectually honest. We're taught as children to be honest as an unselfish virtue â as a kind of sacrifice. But in fact, it's a source of power too. To see new ideas, you need an exceptionally sharp eye for the truth. You're trying to see more truth than others have seen so far. And how can you have a sharp eye for the truth if you're intellectually dishonest?
How can admitting mistakes contribute to intellectual honesty?

One way to avoid intellectual dishonesty is to maintain a slight positive pressure in the opposite direction. Be aggressively willing to admit that you're mistaken. Once you've admitted you were mistaken about something, you're free. Until then, you have to carry it.
What role does informality play in expressing earnestness?

Another, more subtle component of earnestness is informality. Informality is much more important than its grammatically negative name implies. It's not merely the absence of something; it means focusing on what matters instead of what doesn't.
How do formality and affectation impact the quality of work compared to the approach taken by "nerds"?

Formality and affectation have in common that, as well as doing the work, you're trying to seem a certain way while doing it. However, any energy that goes into how you seem detracts from the quality of the work. That's one reason nerds have an advantage in producing great work: they expend little effort on seeming anything. In fact, that's basically the definition of a nerd.
What mindset or attitude is essential for achieving great work, according to the paragraph?

Nerds have a kind of innocent boldness that's exactly what you need in doing great work. It's not learned; it's preserved from childhood. So hold onto it. Be the one who puts things out there rather than the one who sits back and offers sophisticated-sounding criticisms of them. "It's easy to criticize" is true in the most literal sense, and the route to great work is never easy.
What is the value of optimism in the pursuit of great work, despite the risks involved?

There may be some jobs where it's an advantage to be cynical and pessimistic, but if you want to do great work, it's an advantage to be optimistic, even though that means you'll risk looking like a fool sometimes. There's an old tradition of doing the opposite. The Old Testament says it's better to keep quiet lest you look like a fool. But that's advice for those who may not aspire to greatness.
Why is earnestness considered essential for achieving great work?

Some people are naturally earnest, and for others, it takes a conscious effort. Either kind of earnestness will suffice. However, I doubt it would be possible to do great work without being earnest. It's so hard to do even if you are. You don't have enough margin for error to accommodate the distortions introduced by being affected, intellectually dishonest, orthodox, fashionable, or cool.
How can one determine the best decision while working on a project?
Great work is consistent not only with who did it, but with itself. It's usually all of a piece. So, if you face a decision in the middle of working on something, ask which choice is more consistent.
What mindset shift can help overcome resistance to making necessary changes?

You may have to throw things away and redo them. You won't necessarily have to, but you have to be willing to. And that can take some effort; when there's something you need to redo, status quo bias and laziness will combine to keep you in denial about it. To beat this, ask: If I'd already made the change, would I want to revert to what I have now?
Why is it beneficial to simplify a task to its fundamental components?

Indeed, in some kinds of work, it's good to strip whatever you're doing to its essence. The result will be more concentrated; you'll understand it better; and you won't be able to lie to yourself about whether there's anything real there.
What is the relationship between mathematical elegance and artistic elegance?

Mathematical elegance may sound like a mere metaphor drawn from the arts. That's what I thought when I first heard the term "elegant" applied to a proof. But now I suspect it's conceptually prior â that the main ingredient in artistic elegance is mathematical elegance. At any rate, it's a useful standard well beyond math.
Why might complicated solutions be more valued in the short term compared to elegant ones?

Elegance can be a long-term bet, though. Laborious solutions will often have more prestige in the short term. They cost a lot of effort, and they're hard to understand, both of which impress people, at least temporarily.
What does it mean when a creative process feels more like discovery than creation?

Whereas some of the very best work will seem like it took comparatively little effort, because it was, in a sense, already there. It didn't have to be built, just seen. It's a very good sign when it's hard to say whether you're creating something or discovering it.
What mindset should you adopt when engaging in work that involves both creation and discovery?
When you're doing work that could be seen as either creation or discovery, err on the side of discovery. Try thinking of yourself as a mere conduit through which the ideas take their natural shape.
What is the relationship between choosing a problem to work on and the process of exploration in research?

Strangely enough, one exception is the problem of choosing a problem to work on. This is usually seen as a search, but in the best case, it's more like creating something. In the best case, you create the field in the process of exploring it.
Why is it important to minimize restrictions when designing powerful tools?

Similarly, if you're trying to build a powerful tool, make it gratuitously unrestrictive. A powerful tool, almost by definition, will be used in ways you didn't expect, so err on the side of eliminating restrictions, even if you don't know what the benefit will be.
What qualities make an idea valuable for future development and exploration by others?

Great work will often be tool-like in the sense of being something others can build on. So it's a good sign if you're creating ideas that others could use or exposing questions that others could answer. The best ideas have implications in many different areas.
What qualities do great ideas need to possess in order to be impactful?
Great ideas need to be both true and new. It takes a certain amount of ability to see new ideas, even once you've learned enough to reach one of the frontiers of knowledge.
What is the author's perspective on the concept of the creative process?

I've never liked the term "creative process." It seems misleading. Originality isn't a process but a habit of mind. Original thinkers throw off new ideas about whatever they focus on, like an angle grinder throwing off sparks. They can't help it.
How can one increase the likelihood of generating original ideas?

I don't know if it's possible to cultivate originality, but there are definitely ways to make the most of however much you have. For example, you're much more likely to have original ideas when you're working on something. Original ideas don't come from trying to have original ideas; they come from trying to build or understand something slightly too difficult.
What are the benefits of expressing your thoughts through talking or writing?

Talking or writing about the things you're interested in is a good way to generate new ideas. When you try to put ideas into words, a missing idea creates a sort of vacuum that draws it out of you. Indeed, there's a kind of thinking that can only be done by writing.
How can changing your environment influence your creativity and idea generation?

Changing your context can help. If you visit a new place, you'll often find you have new ideas there. The journey itself often dislodges them. But you may not have to go far to get this benefit; sometimes it's enough just to go for a walk.
How can exploring diverse topics enhance creativity and idea generation?

Exploring diverse topics helps to travel in topic space. You'll have more new ideas if you explore lots of different topics, partly because it gives the angle grinder more surface area to work on, and partly because analogies are an especially fruitful source of new ideas.
How do curiosity and originality influence each other in the creative process?

Curiosity and originality are closely related. Curiosity feeds originality by giving it new things to work on. But the relationship is closer than that. Curiosity is itself a kind of originality; it's roughly to questions what originality is to answers. And since questions, at their best, are a big component of answers, curiosity, at its best, is a creative force.
Why is it difficult to generate new ideas despite them seeming obvious once recognized?

Seeing something obvious sounds easy. And yet, empirically, having new ideas is hard. What's the source of this apparent contradiction? It's that seeing the new idea usually requires you to change the way you look at the world. We see the world through models that both help and constrain us. When you fix a broken model, new ideas become obvious. But noticing and fixing a broken model is hard. That's how new ideas can be both obvious and yet hard to discover: they're easy to see after you do something hard.
How can one identify flawed models of understanding in their worldview?

One way to discover broken models is to be stricter than other people. Broken models of the world leave a trail of clues where they clash against reality. Most people don't want to see these clues. It would be an understatement to say that they're attached to their current model; it's what they think in, so they'll tend to ignore the trail of clues left by its breakage, however conspicuous it may seem in retrospect.
What approach did Einstein take to discover new ideas in physics?

To find new ideas, you have to seize on signs of breakage instead of looking away. That's what Einstein did. He was able to see the wild implications of Maxwell's equations not so much because he was looking for new ideas, but because he was stricter.
Why is it important to be willing to break rules when trying to develop a new model of the world?

The other thing you need is a willingness to break rules. Paradoxical as it sounds, if you want to fix your model of the world, it helps to be the sort of person who's comfortable breaking rules. From the point of view of the old model, which everyone, including you, initially shares, the new model usually breaks at least implicit rules.
Why do successful new ideas often appear more conservative in hindsight?

Few understand the degree of rule-breaking required because new ideas seem much more conservative once they succeed. They appear perfectly reasonable once you're using the new model of the world they brought with them. However, they did not seem reasonable at the time; it took the greater part of a century for the heliocentric model to be generally accepted, even among astronomers, because it felt so wrong.
What characteristics differentiate a promising new idea from one that is simply bad?

Indeed, if you think about it, a good new idea has to seem bad to most people, or someone would have already explored it. So what you're looking for is ideas that seem crazy, but the right kind of crazy. How do you recognize these? You can't with certainty. Often, ideas that seem bad are bad. But ideas that are the right kind of crazy tend to be exciting; they're rich in implications, whereas ideas that are merely bad tend to be depressing.
What are the two types of independence described in relation to breaking rules?
There are two ways to be comfortable breaking rules: to enjoy breaking them and to be indifferent to them. I call these two cases being aggressively and passively independent-minded.
What motivates aggressively independent-minded individuals to pursue audacious projects?

The aggressively independent-minded are the naughty ones. Rules don't merely fail to stop them; breaking rules gives them additional energy. For this sort of person, delight at the sheer audacity of a project sometimes supplies enough activation energy to get it started.
How can a lack of awareness of established norms contribute to innovation and new discoveries?

The other way to break rules is not to care about them, or perhaps even to know they exist. This is why novices and outsiders often make new discoveries; their ignorance of a field's assumptions acts as a source of temporary passive independent-mindedness. Aspies also seem to have a kind of immunity to conventional beliefs. Several I know say that this helps them to have new ideas.
How can overcoming subconscious filters lead to the discovery of innovative ideas?

An overlooked idea often doesn't lose until the semifinals. You do see it, subconsciously, but then another part of your subconscious shoots it down because it would be too weird, too risky, too much work, or too controversial. This suggests an exciting possibility: if you could turn off such filters, you could see more new ideas.
What is a strategy for uncovering valuable ideas that may be hidden due to prevailing misconceptions?

You could also discover overlooked ideas by working in the other direction: by starting from what's obscuring them. Every cherished but mistaken principle is surrounded by a dead zone of valuable ideas that are unexplored because they contradict it.
What value can be found in the overlooked ideas of religions, according to the paragraph?

Religions are collections of cherished but mistaken principles. Therefore, anything that can be described either literally or metaphorically as a religion will have valuable unexplored ideas in its shadow. Copernicus and Darwin both made discoveries of this type.
Why do individuals often lack originality in choosing the problems they focus on?

People show much more originality in solving problems than in deciding which problems to solve. Even the smartest can be surprisingly conservative when deciding what to work on. People who would never dream of being fashionable in any other way get sucked into working on fashionable problems.
Why might individuals be more cautious in selecting problems to tackle compared to solutions?

One reason people are more conservative when choosing problems than solutions is that problems are bigger bets. A problem could occupy you for years, while exploring a solution might only take days. But even so, I think most people are too conservative. They're not merely responding to risk, but to fashion as well. Unfashionable problems are undervalued.
What should you consider when pursuing research in a field that seems fully explored?

One of the most interesting kinds of unfashionable problems is the problem that people think has been fully explored, but hasn't. Great work often takes something that already exists and shows its latent potential. DÃ¼rer and Watt both did this. So if you're interested in a field that others think is tapped out, don't let their skepticism deter you. People are often wrong about this.
What are the benefits of focusing on unfashionable problems in work or research?

Working on an unfashionable problem can be very pleasing. There's no hype or hurry. Opportunists and critics are both occupied elsewhere. The existing work often has an old-school solidity, and there's a satisfying sense of economy in cultivating ideas that would otherwise be wasted.
How can one identify overlooked problems that are often deemed less significant?

The most common type of overlooked problem is not explicitly unfashionable in the sense of being out of fashion. It just doesn't seem to matter as much as it actually does. How do you find these? By being self-indulgent â by letting your curiosity have its way and tuning out, at least temporarily, the little voice in your head that says you should only be working on "important" problems.
What should you consider when looking for important problems to work on?

You do need to work on important problems, but almost everyone is too conservative about what counts as one. If there's an important but overlooked problem in your neighborhood, it's probably already on your subconscious radar screen. So try asking yourself: if you were going to take a break from "serious" work to work on something just because it would be really interesting, what would you do? The answer is probably more important than it seems.
Why is the choice of problems to work on considered crucial for innovation and discovery?

Originality in choosing problems seems to matter even more than originality in solving them. That's what distinguishes the people who discover whole new fields. So, what might seem to be merely the initial step â deciding what to work on â is, in a sense, the key to the whole game.
What is a common misconception about the nature of big ideas?

Few grasp this. One of the biggest misconceptions about new ideas is the ratio of question to answer in their composition. People think big ideas are answers, but often the real insight is in the question.
Why are questions often undervalued in educational settings?

Part of the reason we underrate questions is the way they're used in schools. In schools, they tend to exist only briefly before being answered, like unstable particles. But a really good question can be much more than that. A really good question is a partial discovery. How do new species arise? Is the force that makes objects fall to Earth the same as the one that keeps planets in their orbits? By even asking such questions, you are already in excitingly novel territory.
What are the potential benefits of holding onto unanswered questions?

Unanswered questions can be uncomfortable things to carry around with you. However, the more you carry, the greater the chance of noticing a solution â or perhaps even more excitingly, noticing that two unanswered questions are the same.
Why is it important to revisit questions from our childhood?

Sometimes you carry a question for a long time. Great work often comes from returning to a question you first noticed years before â in your childhood, even â and couldn't stop thinking about. People talk a lot about the importance of keeping your youthful dreams alive, but it's just as important to keep your youthful questions alive.
What is the relationship between expertise and uncertainty according to the paragraph?

This is one of the places where actual expertise differs most from the popular picture of it. In the popular picture, experts are certain. But actually, the more puzzled you are, the better, so long as (a) the things you're puzzled about matter, and (b) no one else understands them either.
What role does puzzlement play in the process of discovering new ideas?

Think about what's happening at the moment just before a new idea is discovered. Often, someone with sufficient expertise is puzzled about something, which means that originality consists partly of puzzlement â of confusion! You have to be comfortable enough with the world being full of puzzles that you're willing to see them, but not so comfortable that you don't want to solve them.
How do unanswered questions contribute to the pursuit of knowledge?

It's a great thing to be rich in unanswered questions. This is one of those situations where the rich get richer because the best way to acquire new questions is to try answering existing ones. Questions don't just lead to answers, but also to more questions.
How can the process of answering questions lead to deeper insights?

The best questions grow in the answering. You notice a thread protruding from the current paradigm and try pulling on it, and it just gets longer and longer. So don't require a question to be obviously big before you try answering it. You can rarely predict that. It's hard enough even to notice the thread, let alone to predict how much will unravel if you pull on it.
Why is it beneficial to explore multiple small ideas or projects rather than focusing solely on one?

It's better to be promiscuously curious â to pull a little bit on a lot of threads and see what happens. Big things start small. The initial versions of big things were often just experiments, side projects, or talks, which then grew into something bigger. So, start lots of small things.
Why is it important to embrace a wide range of experiences and ideas in the creative process?

Being prolific is underrated. The more different things you try, the greater the chance of discovering something new. Understand, though, that trying lots of things will mean trying lots of things that don't work. You can't have a lot of good ideas without also having a lot of bad ones.
What approach can enhance learning and enjoyment when tackling new projects?

Though it sounds more responsible to begin by studying everything that's been done before, you'll learn faster and have more fun by trying things. And you'll understand previous work better when you do look at it. So err on the side of starting. Which is easier when starting means starting small; those two ideas fit together like two puzzle pieces.
What is the process for achieving greatness in a project or idea?

How do you get from starting small to doing something great? By making successive versions. Great things are almost always made in successive versions. You start with something small and evolve it, and the final version is both cleverer and more ambitious than anything you could have planned.
Why is it important to create successive versions of a product when designing for an audience?
It's particularly useful to make successive versions when you're creating something for people â to get an initial version in front of them quickly and then evolve it based on their response.
What does it indicate when an early version of a new project is referred to as a "toy"?
An early version of a new project is sometimes dismissed as a "toy." It's a good sign when people do this. That means it has everything a new idea needs except scale, and that tends to follow.
What are the drawbacks of planning in project management, and how can flexibility reduce the need for it?

Planning, per se, isn't good. It's sometimes necessary, but it's a necessary evil â a response to unforgiving conditions. It's something you have to do because you're working with inflexible media or because you need to coordinate the efforts of a lot of people. If you keep projects small and use flexible media, you don't have to plan as much, and your designs can evolve instead.
What is the relationship between risk and reward in an efficient market?

In an efficient market, risk is proportionate to reward, so take as much risk as you can afford. Don't look for certainty, but for a bet with high expected value. If you're not failing occasionally, you're probably being too conservative.
What benefits can come from working on a challenging project, even if it doesn't succeed?

Even a project that fails can be valuable. In the process of working on it, you'll have crossed territory few others have seen and encountered questions few others have asked. And there's probably no better source of questions than the ones you encounter in trying to do something slightly too hard.
What are the key advantages of youth and age, and how can one leverage them throughout life?

Use the advantages of youth when you have them, and the advantages of age once you have those. The advantages of youth are energy, time, optimism, and freedom. The advantages of age are knowledge, efficiency, money, and power. With effort, you can acquire some of the latter when young and keep some of the former when old.
What advantages do young people have that they may not fully appreciate?

The old also have the advantage of knowing which advantages they have. The young often have them without realizing it. The biggest is probably time. The young have no idea how rich they are in time. The best way to turn this time to advantage is to use it in slightly frivolous ways: to learn about something you don't need to know about just out of curiosity, or to try building something just because it would be cool, or to become freakishly good at something.
What distinction does the author make between spending time on uncertain pursuits versus clearly wasteful activities?

That "slightly" is an important qualification. Spend time lavishly when you're young, but don't simply waste it. There's a big difference between doing something you worry might be a waste of time and doing something you know for sure will be. The former is at least a bet, and possibly a better one than you think.
What unique perspective does inexperience provide when encountering new ideas?

The most subtle advantage of youth, or more precisely of inexperience, is that you're seeing everything with fresh eyes. When your brain embraces an idea for the first time, sometimes the two don't fit together perfectly. Usually, the problem is with your brain, but occasionally it's with the idea. A piece of it sticks out awkwardly and jabs you when you think about it. People who are used to the idea have learned to ignore it, but you have the opportunity not to.
What strategies can help learners identify potential gaps or misconceptions in their understanding of a new subject?

When you're learning about something for the first time, pay attention to things that seem wrong or missing. You'll be tempted to ignore them since there's a 99% chance the problem is with you. You may have to set aside your misgivings temporarily to keep progressing, but don't forget about them. When you've gotten further into the subject, come back and check if they're still there. If they're still viable in the light of your present knowledge, they probably represent an undiscovered idea.
What is a common issue young people face regarding their concerns and priorities?

Young people often have to worry about many things. They know all the issues that could matter, but they do not understand their relative importance. As a result, they worry equally about everything, when they should focus much more on a few key concerns and hardly at all about the rest.
What are the challenges of inexperience that can hinder one's ability to succeed in adulthood?

But what you don't know is only half the problem with inexperience. The other half is what you do know that isn't so. You arrive at adulthood with your head full of nonsense â bad habits you've acquired and false things you've been taught â and you won't be able to do great work until you clear away at least the nonsense in the way of whatever type of work you want to do.
How do schools influence our perceptions of learning and thinking?

Much of the nonsense left in your head is left there by schools. We're so used to schools that we unconsciously treat going to school as identical with learning. In fact, schools have all sorts of strange qualities that warp our ideas about learning and thinking.
How do traditional school structures affect student engagement and learning?

For example, schools induce passivity. Since you were a small child, there was an authority at the front of the class telling all of you what you had to learn and then measuring whether you did. But neither classes nor tests are intrinsic to learning; they're just artifacts of the way schools are usually designed.
How can students take more ownership of their education to enhance their learning experience?

The sooner you overcome this passivity, the better. If you're still in school, try thinking of your education as your project and your teachers as working for you rather than vice versa. That may seem a stretch, but it's not merely some weird thought experiment. It's the truth economically, and in the best case, it's the truth intellectually as well. The best teachers don't want to be your bosses. They'd prefer it if you pushed ahead, using them as a source of advice rather than being pulled by them through the material.
How do the challenges faced in school differ from those encountered in real-world work environments?

Schools also give you a misleading impression of what work is like. In school, they tell you what the problems are, and they're almost always soluble using no more than you've been taught so far. In real life, you have to figure out what the problems are, and you often don't know if they're soluble at all.
What is a fundamental flaw in the way schools prepare students for success?

But perhaps the worst thing schools do to you is train you to win by hacking the test. You can't do great work by doing that. You can't trick God. So stop looking for that kind of shortcut. The way to beat the system is to focus on problems and solutions that others have overlooked, not to skimp on the work itself.
What mindset should you adopt to increase your chances of success in your career?

Don't think of yourself as dependent on some gatekeeper giving you a "big break." Even if this were true, the best way to get it would be to focus on doing good work rather than chasing influential people.
What should one keep in mind when facing rejection from admissions or prize committees?

Don't take rejection by committees to heart. The qualities that impress admissions officers and prize committees are quite different from those required to do great work. The decisions of selection committees are only meaningful to the extent that they're part of a feedback loop, and very few are.
What role does copying existing work play in the learning process for newcomers in a field?

People new to a field will often copy existing work. There's nothing inherently bad about that. There's no better way to learn how something works than by trying to reproduce it. Nor does copying necessarily make your work unoriginal. Originality is the presence of new ideas, not the absence of old ones.
What distinguishes productive copying from detrimental copying in creative work?

Thereâs a good way to copy and a bad way. If youâre going to copy something, do it openly instead of furtively, or worse still, unconsciously. This is whatâs meant by the famously misattributed phrase âGreat artists steal.â The really dangerous kind of copying, the kind that gives copying a bad name, is the kind thatâs done without realizing it, because youâre nothing more than a train running on tracks laid down by someone else. But at the other extreme, copying can be a sign of superiority rather than subordination.
Why is it common for early work in many fields to be influenced by the work of others?

In many fields, it's almost inevitable that your early work will be, in some sense, based on other people's. Projects rarely arise in a vacuum; they're usually a reaction to previous work. When you're first starting out, you don't have any previous work; if you're going to react to something, it has to be someone else's. Once you're established, you can react to your own. But while the former gets called derivative and the latter doesn't, structurally, the two cases are more similar than they seem.
How can the perception of novelty in new ideas lead to misconceptions about their originality?

Oddly enough, the very novelty of the most novel ideas sometimes makes them seem, at first, to be more derivative than they are. New discoveries often have to be conceived initially as variations of existing things.
What are the potential risks of relying on copying as a method of learning or innovation?
There are definitely some dangers to copying, though. One is that you'll tend to copy old thingsâthings that were, in their day, at the frontier of knowledge but no longer are.
What should you consider when imitating someone else's style or features?

When you imitate someone else's style or features, consider that you shouldn't copy every aspect of it. Some features may make you look ridiculous if you do. For example, don't adopt the mannerisms of an eminent 50-year-old professor if you're only 18, or the idiom of a Renaissance poem from hundreds of years ago.
What misconception might inexperienced individuals have about the relationship between talent and behavior?

This is particularly true for behavior. Some talented people are jerks, and this sometimes makes it seem to the inexperienced that being a jerk is part of being talented. It isn't; being talented is merely how they get away with it.
How can exploring ideas from different fields enhance creativity and innovation?

One of the most powerful kinds of copying is to copy something from one field into another. History is so full of chance discoveries of this type that it's probably worth giving chance a hand by deliberately learning about other kinds of work. You can take ideas from quite distant fields if you let them be metaphors.
How can negative examples contribute to valuable learning experiences?

Negative examples can be as inspiring as positive ones. In fact, you can sometimes learn more from things done badly than from things done well; sometimes it only becomes clear what's needed when it's missing.
Why is it beneficial to spend time in environments with highly accomplished individuals?

If many of the best people in your field are gathered in one place, it's usually a good idea to spend some time there. It will increase your ambition, and also, by showing you that these people are human, it will boost your self-confidence.
How can showing genuine interest influence your interactions with experts?

If you're earnest, you'll probably get a warmer welcome than you might expect. Most people who are very good at something are happy to talk about it with anyone who's genuinely interested. If they're really good at their work, then they probably have a hobbyist's interest in it, and hobbyists always want to talk about their hobbies.
How does the perception of research quality differ among various departments in universities?

It may take some effort to find the people who are really good, though.
