Who's in a better position than you to judge whether it's important, and what's a better predictor of its importance than whether it's interesting?
What are the key factors that contribute to effective and productive hard work?

Working hard is not just a dial you turn up to 11. It's a complicated, dynamic system that has to be tuned just right at each point. You have to understand the shape of real work, see clearly what kind you're best suited for, aim as close to the true core of it as you can, accurately judge at each moment both what you're capable of and how you're doing, and put in as many hours each day as you can without harming the quality of the result. This network is too complicated to trick. But if you're consistently honest and clear-sighted, it will automatically assume an optimal shape, and you'll be productive in a way few people are.
What are the key ingredients that contribute to producing great work according to "The Bus Ticket Theory of Genius"?

In "The Bus Ticket Theory of Genius," I said the three ingredients in great work were natural ability, determination, and interest. That's the formula in the preceding stage; determination and interest yield practice and effort.
What is the importance of taking breaks for problem-solving?

Taking breaks is important for problem-solving, particularly over the course of days rather than hours. Often, you can make progress even when you're not actively working on a problem, as the solution may come to you during a break.
What aspect of school activities closely resembles adult life?

The aspect of school activities that closely resembles adult life is sports. Admittedly, many sports originated as games played in schools. But in this one area, at least, kids are doing exactly what adults do.
What are the potential drawbacks of performative hard work in certain cultures?

Some cultures have a tradition of performative hard work. I don't love this idea because (a) it makes a parody of something important and (b) it causes people to wear themselves out doing things that don't matter. I don't know enough to say for sure whether it's net good or bad, but my guess is bad.
What impact does working on a personal project have on a child's engagement and productivity?

A few days ago, on the way home from school, my nine-year-old son told me he couldn't wait to get home to write more of the story he was working on. This made me as happy as anything I've heard him say â not just because he was excited about his story, but because he'd discovered this way of working. Working on a project of your own is as different from ordinary work as skating is from walking. It's more fun, but also much more productive.
What emotions and challenges are commonly experienced when working on a personal project like writing an essay?

There is something special about working on a project of your own. I wouldn't say exactly that you're happier; a better word would be excited or engaged. You're happy when things are going well, but often they aren't. When I'm writing an essay, most of the time I'm worried and puzzled: worried that the essay will turn out badly, and puzzled because I'm groping for some idea that I can't see clearly enough. Will I be able to pin it down with words? In the end, I usually can if I take long enough, but I'm never sure; the first few attempts often fail.
What motivates individuals to embrace challenging work despite its temporary rewards?

You have moments of happiness when things work out, but they don't last long because then you're on to the next problem. So why do it at all? Because to the kind of people who like working this way, nothing else feels as right. You feel as if you're an animal in its natural habitat, doing what you were meant to do â not always happy, maybe, but awake and alive.
How do societal views on play and hobbies impact children's understanding of career paths?

Many kids experience the excitement of working on projects of their own. The hard part is making this converge with the work you do as an adult. Our customs make it harder. We treat "playing" and "hobbies" as qualitatively different from "work." It's not clear to a kid building a treehouse that there's a direct (though long) route from that to architecture or engineering. Instead of pointing out the route, we conceal it by implicitly treating the stuff kids do as different from real work.
How does the traditional education system impact children's ability to engage in personal projects?

Instead of telling kids that their treehouses could be on the path to the work they do as adults, we tell them the path goes through school. Unfortunately, schoolwork tends to be very different from working on projects of one's own. It's usually neither a project nor one's own. So, as school gets more serious, working on projects of one's own is something that survives, if at all, as a thin thread off to the side.
What activity did Darwin and Newton engage in that resembles building treehouses more than traditional classroom learning?

It's a bit sad to think of all the high school kids turning their backs on building treehouses and sitting in class dutifully learning about Darwin or Newton to pass some exam when the work that made Darwin and Newton famous was actually closer in spirit to building treehouses than studying for exams.
What do you believe is more valuable for a child's future success: good grades or independent projects?

If I had to choose between my kids getting good grades and working on ambitious projects of their own, I'd pick the projects. And not because I'm an indulgent parent, but because I've been on the other end, and I know which has more predictive value. When I was picking startups for Y Combinator, I didn't care about applicants' grades. But if they'd worked on projects of their own, I wanted to hear all about those.
How does the traditional school system influence our attitudes toward work and competition?

It may be inevitable that school is the way it is. I'm not saying we have to redesign it (though I'm not saying we don't), just that we should understand what it does to our attitudes toward work â that it steers us toward the dutiful, plodding kind of work, often using competition as bait, and away from skating.
What are the two key aspects that define whether a project can be considered one's own?

So where exactly is the edge of projects of one's own? That's an interesting question, partly because the answer is so complicated, and partly because there's so much at stake. There turn out to be two senses in which work can be one's own: 1) that you're doing it voluntarily, rather than merely because someone told you to, and 2) that you're doing it by yourself.
What factors determine whether work feels like a choice or an obligation?

The edge of the former is quite sharp. People who care a lot about their work are usually very sensitive to the difference between pulling and being pushed, and work tends to fall into one category or the other. But the test isn't simply whether you're told to do something. You can choose to do something you're told to do. Indeed, you can own it far more thoroughly than the person who told you to do it.
How did the author's father perceive math homework differently from most people?

For example, math homework is, for most people, something they're told to do. But for my father, who was a mathematician, it wasn't. Most of us think of the problems in a math book as a way to test or develop our knowledge of the material explained in each section. But to my father, the problems were the part that mattered, and the text was merely a sort of annotation. Whenever he got a new math book, it was to him like being given a puzzle: here was a new set of problems to solve, and he'd immediately set about solving all of them.
What are the different ways collaboration can occur in project work?

Collaboration in project work can occur in two different ways. One way to collaborate is to share a single project. For example, when two mathematicians collaborate on a proof that takes shape in the course of a conversation between them. The other way is when multiple people work on separate projects of their own that fit together like a jigsaw puzzle. For example, when one person writes the text of a book and another does the graphic design.
How can organizations maintain individual motivation and excitement in collaborative projects?

These two paths into collaboration can, of course, be combined. But under the right conditions, the excitement of working on a project of one's own can be preserved for quite a while before disintegrating into the turbulent flow of work in a large organization. Indeed, the history of successful organizations is partly the history of techniques for preserving that excitement.
How did the team behind the original Macintosh demonstrate collaboration and individual creativity in their work?

The team that made the original Macintosh was a great example of this phenomenon. People like Burrell Smith, Andy Hertzfeld, Bill Atkinson, and Susan Kare were not just following orders. They were not tennis balls hit by Steve Jobs, but rockets let loose by Steve Jobs. There was a lot of collaboration between them, but they all seemed to have individually felt the excitement of working on a project of their own.
How can the approach of children to projects inform adults' attitudes towards their work?

If your projects are the kind that make money, it's easy to work on them. It's harder when they're not. And the hardest part, usually, is morale. That's where adults have it harder than kids. Kids just plunge in and build their treehouse without worrying about whether they're wasting their time or how it compares to other treehouses. Frankly, we could learn a lot from kids here. The high standards most grownups have for "real" work do not always serve us well.
What is the significance of the initial phase in starting a personal project?

The most important phase in a project of one's own is at the beginning: when you go from thinking it might be cool to do X to actually doing X. At that point, high standards are not merely useless but positively harmful. There are a few people who start too many new projects, but far more, I suspect, who are deterred by fear of failure from starting projects that would have succeeded if they had.
How can recalling childhood experiences, like building treehouses, influence our approach to adult projects?

Recollecting childhood experiences, like building treehouses, can significantly influence our approach to adult projects. While we may not have recognized as kids that our treehouses were stepping stones toward more complex endeavors, we can appreciate as adults that our current projects are connected to those early experiences. Remember that carefree confidence you had as a child when starting something new? Recapturing that mindset could be a powerful asset in our adult pursuits.
How does the experience of adults in choosing work differ from that of children?

If it's harder as adults to retain that kind of confidence, we at least tend to be more aware of what we're doing. Kids bounce, or are herded, from one kind of work to the next, barely realizing what's happening to them. Whereas we know more about different types of work and have more control over which we do. Ideally, we can have the best of both worlds: to be deliberate in choosing to work on projects of our own and carelessly confident in starting new ones.
What is the significance of the term "hobby" in relation to the value of early-stage projects?

The term "hobby" originally referred to an obsession in a fairly general sense, even encompassing political opinions, which one metaphorically rode like a child rides a hobby-horse. Its recent, narrower meaning raises the question of whether this change is for the better or worse. There are many false positivesâprojects that ultimately prove important but are initially dismissed as mere hobbies. However, the concept of a hobby also provides valuable cover for projects in their early, "ugly duckling" phase.
What is the relationship between the concept of the "lone genius" and collaboration in creative work?

The complicated, gradual edge between working on one's own projects and collaborating with others is one reason there is so much disagreement about the idea of the "lone genius." In practice, people collaborate (or not) in all kinds of different ways, but the idea of the lone genius is definitely not a myth. There's a core of truth to it that goes with a certain way of working.
How do companies and university departments differ in their approach to balancing collaboration and individual ownership in research and work?

Collaboration is powerful too. The optimal organization would combine collaboration and ownership in such a way as to do the least damage to each. Interestingly, companies and university departments approach this ideal from opposite directions: companies insist on collaboration and occasionally also manage both to recruit skaters and allow them to skate, while university departments insist on the ability to do independent research (which is by custom treated as skating, whether it is or not), and the people they hire collaborate as much as they choose.
What misconceptions do people have about the social behavior of nerds?

Most people think of nerds as quiet, diffident people. In ordinary social situations, they are â as quiet and diffident as the star quarterback would be if he found himself in the middle of a physics symposium. And for the same reason: they are fish out of water. But the apparent diffidence of nerds is an illusion due to the fact that when non-nerds observe them, it's usually in ordinary social situations. In fact, some nerds are quite fierce.
What characteristics define the competitive nature of the fierce nerds compared to non-nerds?

The fierce nerds are a small but interesting group. They are, as a rule, extremely competitive â more competitive, I'd say, than highly competitive non-nerds. Competition is more personal for them, partly perhaps because they're not emotionally mature enough to distance themselves from it, but also because there's less randomness in the kinds of competition they engage in, and they are thus more justified in taking the results personally.
What is a common characteristic of fierce nerds?

Another quality you find in most fierce nerds is intelligence. Not all nerds are smart, but the fierce ones are always at least moderately so. If they weren't, they wouldn't have the confidence to be fierce.
What traits characterize the communication style and problem-solving approach of fierce nerds?

Fierce nerds are characterized by impatience, which is evident in their communication style. They tend to interrupt others during conversations, which can be annoying. However, in the more promising fierce nerds, this impatience is connected to a deeper urgency about solving problems. Perhaps the competitiveness and impatience of fierce nerds are not separate qualities, but rather two manifestations of a single underlying drivenness.
Why is being a fierce nerd advantageous in the business world compared to traditional scholarship?

Indeed, being a fierce nerd is probably even more helpful in business than in nerds' original territory of scholarship. Fierceness seems optional there; Darwin, for example, doesn't seem to have been especially fierce. Whereas it's impossible to be the CEO of a company over a certain size without being fierce, so now that nerds can win at business, fierce nerds will increasingly monopolize the really big successes.
What happens to your fierceness if it is not properly exercised?
The bad news is that if it's not exercised, your fierceness will turn to bitterness, and you will become an intellectual playground bully: the grumpy sysadmin, the forum troll, the critic.
What strategies can help prevent feelings of bitterness in life?

How do you avoid this fate? Work on ambitious projects. If you succeed, it will bring you a kind of satisfaction that neutralizes bitterness. But you don't need to have succeeded to feel this; merely working on hard projects gives most fierce nerds some feeling of satisfaction. And for those it doesn't, it at least keeps them busy.
What advice can be given to fierce nerds to balance their effectiveness with social interactions in a work environment?

The same qualities that make fierce nerds so effective can also make them very annoying. Fierce nerds would do well to remember this and (a) try to keep a lid on it, and (b) seek out organizations and types of work where getting the right answer matters more than preserving social harmony. In practice, that means small groups working on hard problems, which fortunately is the most fun kind of environment anyway.
Why do some moderately successful individuals still experience bitterness?

If success neutralizes bitterness, why are there some people who are at least moderately successful and yet still quite bitter? Because people's potential bitterness varies depending on how naturally bitter their personality is and how ambitious they are. Someone who's naturally very bitter will still have a lot left after success neutralizes some of it, and someone who's very ambitious will need proportionally more success to satisfy that ambition.
What is a situation in which someone might hesitate to openly disagree with a knowledgeable person's idea?

There's one kind of opinion I'd be very afraid to express publicly. If someone I knew to be both a domain expert and a reasonable person proposed an idea that sounded preposterous, I'd be very reluctant to say, "That will never work."
What is the process through which revolutionary ideas often gain acceptance in society?

Anyone who has studied the history of ideas, and especially the history of science, knows that's how big things start. Someone proposes an idea that sounds crazy; most people dismiss it, then it gradually takes over the world.
Why should we consider seemingly implausible ideas proposed by experts in their field?

Most implausible-sounding ideas are, in fact, bad and could be safely dismissed. But not when they're proposed by reasonable domain experts. If the person proposing the idea is reasonable, then they know how implausible it sounds. And yet they're proposing it anyway. That suggests they know something you don't. And if they have deep domain expertise, that's probably the source of it.
Why might implausible-sounding ideas from domain experts be more valuable than those from the average person?

Such ideas are not merely unsafe to dismiss, but disproportionately likely to be interesting. When the average person proposes an implausible-sounding idea, its implausibility is evidence of their incompetence. But when a reasonable domain expert does it, the situation is reversed. There's something like an efficient market here: on average, the ideas that seem craziest will, if correct, have the biggest effect. So if you can eliminate the theory that the person proposing an implausible-sounding idea is incompetent, its implausibility switches from evidence that it's boring to evidence that it's exciting.
What is the rationale behind investing in seemingly implausible ideas proposed by experts?

Such ideas are not guaranteed to work, but they don't have to be. They just have to be sufficiently good bets â to have sufficiently high expected value. On average, I think they do. If you bet on the entire set of implausible-sounding ideas proposed by reasonable domain experts, you'd end up net ahead.
Why do new ideas often struggle to gain acceptance in current discussions?

The reason is that everyone is too conservative. The word "paradigm" is overused, but this is a case where it's warranted. Everyone is too much in the grip of the current paradigm. Even the people who have the new ideas undervalue them initially, which means that before they reach the stage of proposing them publicly, they've already subjected them to an excessively strict filter.
What should be the approach when encountering a differing opinion from a knowledgeable individual?

The wise response to such an idea is not to make statements but to ask questions, because there's a real mystery here. Why has this smart and reasonable person proposed an idea that seems so wrong? Are they mistaken, or are you? One of you has to be. If you're the one who's mistaken, that would be good to know, because it means there's a hole in your model of the world. But even if they're mistaken, it should be interesting to learn why. A trap that an expert falls into is one you have to worry about too.
What motivates some people to oppose or criticize radical new ideas?

One reason some people oppose or criticize radical new ideas is envy. If you propose a radical new idea and it succeeds, your reputation (and perhaps also your wealth) will increase proportionally. Some people would be envious if that happened, and this potential envy propagates back into a conviction that you must be wrong.
Why do some people tend to reject new ideas in favor of established beliefs?

Another reason people dismiss new ideas is that it's an easy way to seem sophisticated. When a new idea first emerges, it usually seems pretty feeble; it's a mere hatchling. Received wisdom is a full-grown eagle by comparison. So, it's easy to launch a devastating attack on a new idea, and anyone who does will seem clever to those who don't understand this asymmetry.
How do the rewards differ for those innovating new ideas compared to those critiquing them?

This phenomenon is exacerbated by the difference between how those working on new ideas and those critiquing them are rewarded. The rewards for working on new ideas are weighted by the value of the outcome. So, it's worth working on something that only has a 10% chance of succeeding if it would make things more than 10 times better. Whereas the rewards for critiquing new ideas are roughly constant; such critiques seem roughly equally clever regardless of the target.
Why do individuals often resist new ideas?

People will also attack new ideas when they have a vested interest in the old ones. It's not surprising, for example, that some of Darwin's harshest critics were churchmen. People build whole careers on certain ideas. When someone claims they're false or obsolete, they feel threatened.
What is the lowest form of dismissing an idea in a debate or discussion?
The lowest form of dismissal is mere factionalism: to automatically dismiss any idea associated with the opposing faction. The lowest form of all is to dismiss an idea because of who proposed it.
What factors contribute to the difficulty of proposing and accepting new ideas within an established paradigm?

The main factor that leads reasonable people to dismiss new ideas is the same thing that holds people back from proposing them: the sheer pervasiveness of the current paradigm. It doesn't just affect the way we think; it is the Lego blocks we build thoughts out of. Popping out of the current paradigm is something only a few people can do. Even they usually have to suppress their intuitions at first, like a pilot flying through clouds who has to trust his instruments over his sense of balance.
How do established paradigms influence the acceptance of new scientific ideas?

Paradigms don't just define our present thinking. They also vacuum up the trail of crumbs that led to them, making our standards for new ideas impossibly high. The current paradigm seems so perfect to us, its offspring, that we imagine it must have been accepted completely as soon as it was discovered â that whatever the church thought of the heliocentric model, astronomers must have been convinced as soon as Copernicus proposed it. Far, in fact, from it. Copernicus published the heliocentric model in 1532, but it wasn't until the mid-seventeenth century that the balance of scientific opinion shifted in its favor.
What is an effective way to cultivate new ideas according to the challenges they face in their early stages?

Few understand how feeble new ideas look when they first appear. So, if you want to have new ideas yourself, one of the most valuable things you can do is to learn what they look like when they're born. Read about how new ideas happened, and try to get yourself into the heads of people at the time. How did things look to them when the new idea was only half-finished, and even the person who had it was only half-convinced it was right?
Why is it important to support individuals with new ideas?

If you're nice, as well as wise, you won't merely resist attacking such people but encourage them. Having new ideas is a lonely business. Only those who've tried it know how lonely. These people need your help. And if you help them, you'll probably learn something in the process.
How does Noora measure the impact of their programs in hospitals?

Noora has been saving lives for 7 years. They run programs in hospitals in South Asia to teach new mothers how to take care of their babies once they get home. They are in 165 hospitals now. Because they know the numbers before and after they start at a new hospital, they can measure the impact they have. It is massive. For every 1,000 live births, they save 9 babies.
What was the scope and context of Noora's research involving families at hospitals?

Noora's research involved 133,733 families at 28 different hospitals, conducted in collaboration with the Better Birth team at Ariadne Labs, a joint center for health systems innovation at Brigham and Womenâs Hospital and Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health.
What is the cost-effectiveness of Noora in terms of lives saved?

Noora is so effective that even if you measure their costs in the most conservative way, by dividing their entire budget by the number of lives saved, the cost of saving a life is the lowest I've seen: $1,235.
How will the funds from this NFT be utilized and reported?
For this NFT, they are going to issue a public report tracking how this specific tranche of money is spent and estimating the number of lives saved as a result.
What makes the auction of this particular NFT unique compared to traditional NFTs?

NFTs are a new territory, and this way of using them is especially new, but I'm excited about its potential. I'm excited to see what happens with this particular auction because, unlike an NFT representing something that has already happened, this NFT gets better as the price gets higher.
What fundamental concern underlies the debate about the death penalty beyond its deterrent effect and fairness?

When intellectuals talk about the death penalty, they discuss whether it is permissible for the state to take someone's life, whether the death penalty acts as a deterrent, and whether more death sentences are given to some groups than others. What led to the exoneration of Kenneth Adams and the other men after 18 years in prison?

Kenneth Adams and three other men spent 18 years in prison on a murder conviction. They were exonerated after DNA testing implicated three different men, two of whom later confessed. The police had been told about the other men early in the investigation but never followed up on the lead.
What led to Keith Harward's exoneration after spending 33 years in prison?

Keith Harward spent 33 years in prison on a murder conviction. He was convicted because "experts" said his teeth matched photos of bite marks on one victim. He was exonerated after DNA testing showed that the murder had been committed by another man, Jerry Crotty.
What circumstances led to the exoneration of Ricky Jackson and two other men after nearly four decades in prison?

Ricky Jackson and two other men spent 39 years in prison after being convicted of murder on the testimony of a 12-year-old boy, who later recanted and said he had been coerced by police. What led to Alfred Brown's exoneration after spending 12 years in prison?

Alfred Brown spent 12 years in prison on a murder conviction, including 10 years on death row. He was exonerated after it was discovered that the assistant district attorney had concealed phone records proving he could not have committed the crime.
What were the circumstances surrounding Glenn Ford's wrongful conviction and subsequent exoneration?

Glenn Ford spent 29 years on death row after being convicted of murder. He was exonerated after new evidence proved he was not even at the scene when the murder occurred. The attorneys assigned to represent him had never tried a jury case before.
What were the findings of the re-examination of Cameron Willingham's case ordered by Texas in 2009?

Cameron Willingham was executed in 2004 by lethal injection. The "expert" who testified that he deliberately set fire to his house has since been discredited. A re-examination of the case ordered by the state of Texas in 2009 concluded that "a finding of arson could not be sustained."
What factors contribute to wrongful convictions in the criminal justice system?

Police are under pressure to solve a crime that has gotten a lot of attention. When they find a suspect, they want to believe he's guilty and ignore or even destroy evidence suggesting otherwise. District attorneys want to be seen as effective and tough on crime, and in order to win convictions, they are willing to manipulate witnesses and withhold evidence. Court-appointed defense attorneys are overworked and often incompetent. There's a ready supply of criminals willing to give false testimony in return for a lighter sentence, suggestible witnesses who can be made to say whatever police want, and bogus "experts" eager to claim that science proves the defendant is guilty. And juries want to believe them, since otherwise some terrible crime remains unsolved.
What is the main concern regarding the death penalty as highlighted in the paragraph?

This circus of incompetence and dishonesty is the real issue with the death penalty. We don't even reach the point where theoretical questions about the moral justification or effectiveness of capital punishment start to matter because so many of the people sentenced to death are actually innocent. Whatever it means in theory, in practice, capital punishment means killing innocent people.
How has the source of wealth among the richest individuals changed from 1982 to 2020?

In 1982, the most common source of wealth was inheritance. Of the 100 richest people, 60 inherited from an ancestor, including 10 du Pont heirs alone. By 2020, the number of heirs had been cut in half, accounting for only 27 of the biggest 100 fortunes.
What factors have contributed to the decrease in the percentage of heirs receiving inheritances?

Why would the percentage of heirs decrease? Not because inheritance taxes increased. In fact, they decreased significantly during this period. The reason the percentage of heirs has decreased is not that fewer people are inheriting great fortunes, but that more people are making them.
What are the primary sources of new fortunes created in 2020?

How are people making these new fortunes? Roughly 3/4 by starting companies and 1/4 by investing. Of the 73 new fortunes in 2020, 56 derive from founders' or early employees' equity (52 founders, 2 early employees, and 2 wives of founders), and 17 from managing investment funds.
What factors contributed to the rise of fund managers among the wealthiest Americans after 1982?

There were no fund managers among the 100 richest Americans in 1982. Hedge funds and private equity firms existed in 1982, but none of their founders were rich enough yet to make it into the top 100. Two things changed: fund managers discovered new ways to generate high returns, and more investors were willing to trust them with their money.
How has the source of wealth creation changed from 1982 to the present?

The main source of new fortunes now is starting companies, and when you look at the data, you see big changes there too. People get richer from starting companies now than they did in 1982 because the companies do different things.
What were the primary sources of new wealth in 1982 compared to 2020?

In 1982, there were two dominant sources of new wealth: oil and real estate. Of the 40 new fortunes in 1982, at least 24 were due primarily to oil or real estate. Now, only a small number are: of the 73 new fortunes in 2020, 4 were due to real estate and only 2 to oil.
What role did tech companies play in the emergence of new wealth by 2020?

By 2020, the biggest source of new wealth was what are sometimes called "tech" companies. Of the 73 new fortunes, about 30 derived from such companies. These are particularly common among the richest of the rich: 8 of the top 10 fortunes in 2020 were new fortunes of this type.
What differentiates the tech companies in the top 100 fortunes from others in terms of investment appeal?

The tech companies behind the top 100 fortunes also form a well-differentiated group in the sense that they're all companies that venture capitalists would readily invest in, while the others are mostly not. And there's a reason why: these are mostly companies that win by having better technology, rather than just a CEO who's really driven and good at making deals.
What are some historical methods of acquiring wealth that existed before the Industrial Revolution?

The methods of acquiring wealth that existed before the Industrial Revolution are quite ancient. For instance, courtiers who became wealthy in the nominal service of European royal houses during the 16th and 17th centuries were typically driven individuals skilled at making deals.
How did the sources of wealth for the richest individuals in 1982 compare to those in today's tech-driven economy?

In 1982, 84% of the richest 100 people got rich by inheritance, extracting natural resources, or doing real estate deals. What percentage of millionaires in America in 1892 inherited their wealth, and what factors contributed to the creation of new fortunes during that time?

In 1892, a list was compiled of all the millionaires in America, totaling 4,047 individuals. Of these, only about 20% had inherited their wealth, which is less than the proportion of heirs today. When investigating the sources of the new fortunes, 1892 looks even more like today. Hugh Rockoff found that "many of the richest ... gained their initial edge from the new technology of mass production."
What year is considered an anomaly in terms of wealth generation from starting companies, and why?

So it's not 2020 that's the anomaly here, but 1982. The real question is why so few people had gotten rich from starting companies in 1982. And the answer is that even as the economy was recovering, the market conditions were not conducive to wealth generation for new entrepreneurs.
How did the consolidation of companies in the late 19th and early 20th centuries affect the American economy by the end of World War II?

The consolidation of companies was sweeping through the American economy. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, financiers like J. P. Morgan combined thousands of smaller companies into a few hundred giant ones with commanding economies of scale. By the end of World War II, as Michael Lind writes, "the major sectors of the economy were either organized as government-backed cartels or dominated by a few oligopolistic corporations."
What was the prevailing career path for aspiring professionals in 1960 compared to other decades?

In 1960, most of the people who would start startups today would have gone to work for one of them. You could get rich from starting your own company in 1890 and in 2020, but in 1960 it was not really a viable option. You couldn't break through the oligopolies to get at the markets. So the prestigious route in 1960 was not to start your own company, but to work your way up the corporate ladder at an existing one.
How did the shift in corporate employment models from the mid 20th century onwards affect economic inequality?

The shift in corporate employment models from the mid-20th century onwards initially decreased economic inequality, as it created a more uniform corporate workforce. However, if your model of normal is the mid-20th century, you have a very misleading perspective in that respect. J.P. Morgan's economy turned out to be just a phase, and starting in the 1970s, it began to break up, leading to increased economic disparities.
What factors contributed to the decline of major companies and the push for deregulation in the 1970s?

The decline of major companies in the 1970s can be attributed to several factors. Partly, there was senescence; the big companies that had seemed models of scale and efficiency in 1930 had, by 1970, become slack and bloated. By that time, the rigid structure of the economy was full of cozy nests that various groups had built to insulate themselves from market forces. During the Carter administration, the federal government realized something was amiss and began, in a process they called "deregulation," to roll back the policies that propped up the oligopolies.
What trends can be expected in the future regarding entrepreneurship and wealth creation?

While the breakup of J. P. Morgan's economy created a new world in the technological sense, it was a reversion to the norm in the social sense. If you only look back as far as the mid-20th century, it seems like people getting rich by starting their own companies is a recent phenomenon. Indeed, we should expect both the number and wealth of founders to grow, because every decade it gets easier to start a startup.
What factors have contributed to the increasing ease of starting a startup today compared to previous generations?

Part of the reason it's getting easier to start a startup is social. Society is (re)assimilating the concept. If you start one now, your parents won't freak out the way they would have a generation ago, and knowledge about how to do it is much more widespread. But the main reason it's easier to start a startup now is that it's cheaper. Technology has driven down the cost of both building products and acquiring customers.
How has the decreasing cost of starting a startup affected the relationship between founders and investors?

The decreasing cost of starting a startup has, in turn, changed the balance of power between founders and investors. Back when starting a startup meant building a factory, you needed investors' permission to do it at all. But now, investors need founders more than founders need investors, and that, combined with the increasing amount of venture capital available, has driven up valuations.
How does the decreasing cost of starting a startup contribute to the increase in the number of wealthy individuals?
The decreasing cost of starting a startup increases the number of wealthy individuals in two ways: it means that more people start them, and those who do can raise money on better terms.
What impact has technology had on the growth rate of newly founded companies?

However, there's also a third factor at work: the companies themselves are more valuable because newly founded companies grow faster than they used to. Technology hasn't just made it cheaper to build and distribute things, but faster too.
How has the time it takes for companies to reach a billion dollars in revenue changed over the years?

This trend has been running for a long time. IBM, founded in 1896, took 45 years to reach a billion 2020 dollars in revenue. Hewlett-Packard, founded in 1939, took 25 years. Microsoft, founded in 1975, took 13 years. Now, the norm for fast-growing companies is 7 or 8 years.
How does fast growth impact the value of a company's stock for its founders?

Fast growth has a double effect on the value of founders' stock. The value of a company is a function of its revenue and its growth rate. So, if a company grows faster, you not only get to a billion dollars in revenue sooner, but the company is more valuable when it reaches that point than it would be if it were growing slower.
What factors contribute to the rapid wealth accumulation of young startup founders today?

That's why founders sometimes get so rich so young now. The low initial cost of starting a startup means founders can start young, and the fast growth of companies today means that if they succeed, they could be surprisingly rich just a few years later.
How has the ease of starting and growing a company contributed to the increase in America's Gini coefficient?

It's easier now to start and grow a company than it has ever been. That means more people start them, that those who do get better terms from investors, and that the resulting companies become more valuable. Once you understand how these mechanisms work, and that startups were suppressed for most of the 20th century, you don't have to resort to some vague right turn the country took under Reagan to explain why America's Gini coefficient is increasing. Of course, the Gini coefficient is increasing. With more people starting more valuable companies, how could it not be?
What impact did the 1978 regulatory change by the Labor Department have on the visibility of investment firms in the top 100 fortunes by 1982?

Investment firms grew rapidly after a regulatory change by the Labor Department in 1978 that allowed pension funds to invest in them, but the effects of this growth were not yet visible in the top 100 fortunes by 1982.
What notable contribution did George Mitchell make to the natural gas industry?
George Mitchell deserves mention as an exception. Though he was really driven and good at making deals, he was also the first to figure out how to use fracking to extract natural gas from shale.
What trend has been observed in the number of new small retail and service businesses in recent decades?

There has actually been a decrease in the last couple of decades in the overall number of new companies. However, the vast majority of these companies are small retail and service businesses. What does a declining graph labeled "startups" indicate about the definition of startups being referenced?

When they see a graph labeled "startups" that's going down, it is important to understand that there are two senses of the word "startup": (1) the founding of a company, and (2) a particular type of company designed to grow big fast. The statistics refer to startups in sense (1), not sense (2).
How did mid 20th century tax rates influence entrepreneurship?

It's also likely that the high tax rates in the mid-20th century deterred people from starting their own companies. Starting one's own company is risky, and when risk isn't rewarded, people opt for safer employment options instead.
How did the economic conditions of the mid 20th century influence tax policies and entrepreneurship?

The economic conditions of the mid-20th century influenced tax policies and entrepreneurship in a complex manner. The oligopolies and high tax rates of that era were interconnected. Lower taxes are not just a cause of entrepreneurship but an effect as well: the people getting rich in the mid-20th century from real estate and oil exploration lobbied for and obtained huge tax loopholes that made their effective tax rates much lower. Presumably, if it had been more common to grow large companies by building new technology, the individuals involved in that would have lobbied for their own loopholes as well.
What were the main industries that contributed to wealth accumulation in the mid 20th century?
The people who got rich in the mid-20th century often did so through oil exploration or real estate. These were the two major areas of the economy that weren't susceptible to consolidation.
What are the implications of higher valuations for startups in terms of stock and fundraising?

Higher valuations mean you either sell less stock to get a given amount of money or get more money for a given amount of stock. The typical startup does some of each. Obviously, you end up richer if you keep more stock, but you should also end up richer if you raise more money because (a) it should make the company more successful and (b) you should be able to last longer before the next round or not even need one. Notice all those "shoulds," though. In practice, a lot of money slips through them.
Why do some startups raise large amounts of funding despite the notion that starting a business has become cheaper?

It might seem that the huge rounds raised by startups nowadays contradict the claim that it has become cheaper to start one. But there's no contradiction here; the startups that raise the most are the ones doing it by choice in order to grow faster, not the ones doing it because they need the money to survive. There's nothing like not needing money to make people offer it to you.
What were the origins and early financial status of IBM?

How does the readability of writing impact reader engagement with ideas?
Writing that is easier to read allows readers to engage more deeply with the content. The less energy they expend on your prose, the more they will have left for your ideas.
What factors influence a reader's likelihood to finish an article or essay?
Most readers' energy tends to flag partway through an article or essay. If the friction of reading is low enough, more readers will continue until the end.
Why is it important to prioritize simplicity in writing?

Itâs more considerate to write simply. When you write in a fancy way to impress people, you're making them do extra work just so you can seem cool. It's like trailing a long train behind you that readers have to carry.
How should you approach writing on complex topics for a diverse audience with varying levels of English proficiency?

When writing in English, remember that many of your readers may not be native English speakers. Their understanding of ideas may be far ahead of their understanding of English. Therefore, you cannot assume that writing about a difficult topic allows you to use difficult words.
Why is simple writing considered to have greater longevity and accessibility for future readers?

Simple writing also lasts better. People reading your work in the future will be in much the same position as people from other countries reading it today. The culture and the language will have changed. It's not vain to care about that, any more than it's vain for a woodworker to build a chair to last.
What motivates the author to prioritize simplicity in their writing?

But although these are all real advantages of writing simply, none of them are why I do it. The main reason I write simply is that it offends me not to. When I write a sentence that seems too complicated or that uses unnecessarily intellectual words, it doesn't seem fancy to me. It seems clumsy.

What is a common challenge faced by nonprofits regarding their funding?

The secret curse of the nonprofit world is restricted donations. If you haven't been involved with nonprofits, you may never have heard this phrase before. But if you have been, it probably made you wince.
Why are restricted donations often considered detrimental to nonprofits?

Restricted donations refer to contributions where the donor limits how the funds can be used. This is common with large donations and is often the default arrangement. However, it is usually a bad idea. Typically, the way the donor wants the money spent is not aligned with how the nonprofit would have chosen to allocate those funds. If it were, there would be no need to restrict the donation. Ultimately, who has a better understanding of where the money needs to be spent: the nonprofit or the donor?
What are the exceptions to the principle of making unrestricted donations to nonprofits?

There are a couple of exceptions to this principle. One is when the nonprofit is an umbrella organization. It's reasonable to make a restricted donation to a university, for example, because a university is only nominally a single nonprofit. Another exception is when the donor actually does know as much as the nonprofit about where money needs to be spent. The Gates Foundation, for example, has specific goals and often makes restricted donations to individual nonprofits to accomplish them. But unless you're a domain expert yourself or donating to an umbrella organization, your donation would do more good if it were unrestricted.
What motivates donors to make restricted donations despite their lesser impact compared to unrestricted ones?

If restricted donations do less good than unrestricted ones, why do donors so often make them? Partly because doing good isn't the donors' only motive. They often have other motives as well â to make a mark or to generate good publicity.
What factors contribute to donors' misunderstanding of restricted versus unrestricted donations in the nonprofit sector?

Many donors may simply never have considered the distinction between restricted and unrestricted donations. They may believe that donating money for some specific purpose is just how donations work. To be fair, nonprofits don't try very hard to discourage such illusions; they can't afford to. People running nonprofits are almost always anxious about money and can't afford to talk back to big donors.
What type of donations do nonprofits prefer and why?

You can't expect candor in a relationship so asymmetric. So I'll tell you what nonprofits wish they could tell you: If you want to donate to a nonprofit, donate unrestricted. If you trust them to spend your money, trust them to decide how.
Why do restricted donations often receive more publicity than unrestricted donations?

Unfortunately, restricted donations tend to generate more publicity than unrestricted ones. "X donates money to build a school in Africa" is not only more interesting than "X donates money to Y nonprofit to spend as Y chooses," but also focuses more attention on X.
What types of writing did the author focus on before college, and how does he perceive the quality of his early work?

What programming language and method were commonly used in early computing before modern interfaces?

The language we used was an early version of Fortran. You had to type programs on punch cards, then stack them in the card reader and press a button to load the program into memory and run it. The result would ordinarily be to print something on the spectacularly loud printer.
What challenges did the author face while trying to program on the 1401?

How did the advent of microcomputers transform personal computing?

What was your reaction when you first saw a friend building and using a microcomputer?

What was your experience with programming and computer usage when you first acquired a TRS-80?

What was the author's initial perception of studying philosophy in college compared to programming?

How did the lack of formal AI classes at Cornell influence the author's self-directed learning and programming skills?

What project did you work on for your undergraduate thesis, and what was your perspective on its potential for intelligence?

What was your experience with choosing a degree at Cornell, and how did it affect your perception of your diploma?

I got into a program at Cornell that didn't require me to choose a major. I could take whatever classes I liked and choose whatever I wanted to put on my degree. Which graduate school did the author ultimately attend, and what influenced their decision?

What realization did the author have about AI during their first year of grad school?

What limitations were identified in early natural language processing programs like SHRDLU?

Early natural language processing programs like SHRDLU demonstrated that there is a subset of natural language that functions as a formal language, but it is a very limited subset. What motivates individuals to pursue a career in the practical aspects of computer science rather than its theoretical components?

What are the limitations of creating software systems in terms of their longevity and relevance?

What realization did the author have during their visit to the Carnegie Institute?

What were the narrator's feelings about their situation in grad school compared to a friend's experience?

What topic did the author choose for their dissertation, and what do they wish they had focused on instead?

Which art schools did you apply to, and what were the outcomes of those applications?
