Your opinions about taxation can be predicted from your opinions about sex. Although intentional moderates might seem to be the opposite of ideologues, their beliefs (though in their case the word "positions" might be more accurate) are also acquired in bulk. If the median opinion shifts to the right or left, the intentional moderate must shift with it. Otherwise, they stop being moderate.
What distinguishes accidental moderates from traditional political groups in terms of their engagement with political questions?

Accidental moderates, on the other hand, not only choose their own answers but also choose their own questions. They may not care at all about questions that the left and right both think are terribly important. Therefore, you can only measure the politics of an accidental moderate from the intersection of the questions they care about and those the left and right care about, and this can sometimes be vanishingly small.
What challenges do accidental moderates face compared to intentional moderates in a politically polarized environment?

Moderates are sometimes derided as cowards, particularly by the extreme left. While it may be accurate to call intentional moderates cowards, openly being an accidental moderate requires the most courage of all, because you get attacked from both the right and the left, and you don't have the comfort of being an orthodox member of a large group to sustain you.

What perspective on education did a philosophy grad student share with you in college?

New York has a big investor community because it's full of people who like money a lot and are quick to notice new ways to get it. But Pittsburgh has neither of these. And the cheap housing that draws other people here has no effect on investors.
What factors are contributing to the changing landscape of startup funding and investor communities?

If an investor community grows up here, it will happen the same way it did in Silicon Valley: slowly and organically. So I would not bet on having a big investor community in the short term. But fortunately, there are three trends that make that less necessary than it used to be. One is that startups are increasingly cheap to start, so you just don't need as much outside money as you used to. The second is that, thanks to things like Kickstarter, a startup can get to revenue faster. You can put something on Kickstarter from anywhere. The third is programs like Y Combinator. A startup from anywhere in the world can go to YC for three months, pick up funding, and then return home if they want.
What reflections might arise about the perception of life's length and its finiteness?

Life is short, as everyone knows. When I was a kid, I used to wonder about this. Is life actually short, or are we really complaining about its finiteness? Would we be just as likely to feel life was short if we lived 10 times as long?
What realization did the author come to about life after having children?
Since there didn't seem to be any way to answer this question, I stopped wondering about it. Then I had kids. That gave me a way to answer the question, and the answer is that life actually is short.
How does having children influence one's perception of time and its finite experiences?

Having kids showed me how to convert a continuous quantity, time, into discrete quantities. You only get 52 weekends with your 2-year-old. If Christmas-as-magic lasts from, say, ages 3 to 10, you only get to watch your child experience it 8 times. And while it's impossible to say what is a lot or a little of a continuous quantity like time, 8 is not a lot of something. If you had a handful of 8 peanuts or a shelf of 8 books to choose from, the quantity would definitely seem limited, no matter what your lifespan was.
What does the author believe is unworthy of their time and attention in life?

When I ask myself what I've found life is too short for, the word that pops into my head is "bullshit." I realize that answer is somewhat tautological. It's almost the definition of bullshit that it's the stuff that life is too short for. And yet, bullshit does have a distinctive character. There's something fake about it. It's the junk food of experience.
What are some common activities that waste our time?

If you ask yourself what you spend your time on thatâs unproductive, you probably already know the answer: unnecessary meetings, pointless disputes, bureaucracy, posturing, dealing with other people's mistakes, traffic jams, and addictive but unrewarding pastimes.
How can you minimize time spent on unproductive tasks in the workplace?

You can minimize time spent on unproductive tasks in the workplace on a smaller scale without moving. The amount of time you have to spend on unproductive tasks varies between employers. Most large organizations (and many small ones) are steeped in it. However, if you consciously prioritize avoiding unproductive tasks over other factors like money and prestige, you can probably find employers that will waste less of your time.
How can freelancers and small companies manage their customer relationships to improve their well-being?

If you're a freelancer or a small company, you can manage customer relationships at the level of individual customers. If you fire or avoid toxic customers, you can decrease the amount of negativity in your life by more than you decrease your income.
How can engaging in online arguments lead to a waste of time and personal energy?

While some amount of bullshit is inevitably forced on you, the bullshit that sneaks into your life by tricking you is no one's fault but your own. And yet the bullshit you choose may be harder to eliminate than the bullshit that's forced on you. Things that lure you into wasting your time have to be really good at tricking you. An example that will be familiar to a lot of people is arguing online. When someone contradicts you, they're, in a sense, attacking youâsometimes pretty overtly. Your instinct when attacked is to defend yourself. But like a lot of instincts, this one wasn't designed for the world we now live in. Counterintuitive as it feels, it's better most of the time not to defend yourself. Otherwise, these people are literally taking your life.
How do individuals come to understand what truly matters to them in life?

Individuals come to understand what truly matters to them in life by actively seeking out things that are meaningful. Different things matter to different people, and most have to learn what matters to them. A few are lucky and realize early on that they love math, taking care of animals, or writing, and then figure out a way to spend a lot of time doing it. However, most people start out with a life that's a mix of things that matter and things that don't, and only gradually learn to distinguish between them.
What common mistake do adults reflect on regarding their adolescent experiences?

For the young especially, much of this confusion is induced by the artificial situations they find themselves in. In middle school and high school, what the other kids think of you seems the most important thing in the world. But when you ask adults what they got wrong at that age, nearly all say they cared too much about what other kids thought of them.
How can you determine if something is truly important or just a temporary distraction?

One heuristic for distinguishing what matters is to ask yourself whether you'll care about it in the future. Fake things that matter usually have a sharp peak of seeming to matter. That's how they trick you. The area under the curve is small, but its shape jabs into your consciousness like a pin.
What types of experiences are often overlooked but hold significant value in our lives?
The things that matter aren't necessarily the ones people would call "important." Having coffee with a friend matters. You won't feel later like that was a waste of time.
What are some benefits of spending time with small children?

One great thing about having small children is that they make you spend time on things that matter: them. They grab your sleeve as you're staring at your phone and say, "Will you play with me?" And odds are that is, in fact, the bullshit-minimizing option.
What realization often comes with the loss of loved ones regarding the shortness of life?

If life is short, we should expect its shortness to take us by surprise. And that is just what tends to happen. You take things for granted, and then they're gone. You think you can always write that book, or climb that mountain, or whatever, and then you realize the window has closed. The saddest windows close when other people die. Their lives are short too. After my mother died, I wished I'd spent more time with her. I lived as if she'd always be there. And in her typical quiet way, she encouraged that illusion. But an illusion it was. I think a lot of people make the same mistake I did.
How can one effectively manage the fear of unexpected events in life?

The usual way to avoid being taken by surprise by something is to be consciously aware of it. Back when life was more precarious, people used to be aware of death to a degree that would now seem a bit morbid. I'm not sure why, but it doesn't seem the right answer to be constantly reminding oneself of the grim reaper hovering at everyone's shoulder. Perhaps a better solution is to look at the problem from the other end. Cultivate a habit of impatience about the things you most want to do. Don't wait before climbing that mountain, writing that book, or visiting your mother. You don't need to be constantly reminding yourself why you shouldn't wait. Just don't wait.
What are two common responses when someone has a limited amount of something?
I can think of two common responses when one doesn't have much of something: trying to get more of it and savoring what one has. Both make sense here.
How can spending time with small children influence our perception of time?
It is possible to slow time somewhat. I've gotten better at it. Kids help. When you have small children, there are a lot of moments that are so perfect that you can't help but notice them.
What emotions are intertwined with the author's reflections on past experiences with family?

It does help, too, to feel that you've squeezed everything out of some experience. The reason I'm sad about my mother is not just that I miss her, but that I think of all the things we could have done that we didn't. My oldest son will be 7 soon. And while I miss the 3-year-old version of him, I at least don't have any regrets over what might have been. We had the best time a daddy and a 3-year-old ever had.
What realization did the author come to about the word "bullshit" and its meanings?

At first, I didn't like that the word that came to mind was one that had other meanings. But then I realized the other meanings are fairly closely related. Bullshit, in the sense of things you waste your time on, is a lot like intellectual bullshit.
Why is it important to analyze the different components of economic inequality rather than treating it as a single issue?

To understand economic inequality â and, more importantly, to address its negative aspects â it is essential to analyze its various components. Yet, the trend in nearly everything written about the subject is to do the opposite: to conflate all aspects of economic inequality as if it were a single phenomenon.
What are some reasons writers may misinterpret or oversimplify economic inequality in their analyses?

Sometimes this is done for ideological reasons. Sometimes it's because the writer only has very high-level data and so draws conclusions from that, like the proverbial drunk who looks for his keys under the lamppost instead of where he dropped them, because the light is better there. Sometimes it's because the writer doesn't understand critical aspects of inequality, like the role of technology in wealth creation. Much of the time, perhaps most of the time, writing about economic inequality combines all three.
What is a common misconception about the nature of economic inequality?

The most common mistake people make about economic inequality is to treat it as a single phenomenon, the most naive version of which is the one based on the pie fallacy: that the rich get rich by taking money from the poor.
What impact does income inequality have on the share of income available to the general population?
Those at the top are grabbing an increasing fraction of the nation's income â so much of a larger share that what's left over for the rest is diminished.
What impact does the concept of the pie fallacy have on children's perceptions of wealth?

Other times it's more unconscious. But the unconscious form is very widespread. I think because we grow up in a world where the pie fallacy is actually true, to kids, wealth is perceived as a fixed quantity that can be divided among people. This belief can lead them to think that if one person becomes wealthier, it must be at the expense of another, shaping their understanding of economic dynamics and fairness in society.
What is the misconception about resource distribution that people often hold?

A common misconception about resource distribution is that it is a fixed pie that's shared out, and if one person gets more, it's at the expense of another. It takes a conscious effort to remind oneself that the real world doesn't work that way.
What is the difference between wealth creation and wealth extraction in economic activities?

In the real world, you can create wealth as well as take it from others. A woodworker creates wealth; he makes a chair, and you willingly give him money in return for it. A high-frequency trader does not create wealth. He makes a dollar only when someone on the other end of a trade loses a dollar.
What is the distinction between degenerate and non-degenerate cases of economic inequality?

If the rich people in a society got that way by taking wealth from the poor, then you have the degenerate case of economic inequality, where the cause of poverty is the same as the cause of wealth. However, instances of inequality don't have to be instances of the degenerate case. If one woodworker makes 5 chairs and another makes none, the second woodworker will have less money, but not because anyone took anything from him.
How does the way we describe economic inequality contribute to misunderstandings about income distribution?

Even people sophisticated enough to know about the pie fallacy are led toward it by the custom of describing economic inequality as a ratio of one quantile's income or wealth to another's. It's so easy to slip from talking about income shifting from one quantile to another, as a figure of speech, into believing that is literally what's happening.
What factors contribute to the complexity of understanding economic inequality in a country?

Economic inequality, except in the degenerate case, can't be described by a ratio or even a curve. In the general case, it consists of multiple ways people become poor and multiple ways people become rich. This means that to understand economic inequality in a country, you have to find individual people who are poor or rich and figure out why.
How has technological progress influenced the wealth of startup founders compared to those in the mid-20th century?

Before Mark Zuckerberg started Facebook, his default expectation was that he'd end up working at Microsoft. The reason he and most other startup founders are richer than they would have been in the mid-20th century is not because of some right turn the country took during the Reagan administration, but because progress in technology has made it much easier to start a new company.
What distinguishes wealth creation from rent-seeking in terms of its impact on economic inequality?

While there are a lot of people who get rich through rent-seeking of various forms, and a lot who get rich by playing zero-sum games, there are also a significant number who get rich by creating wealth. Creating wealth, as a source of economic inequality, is different from taking it â not just morally, but also practically, in the sense that it is harder to eradicate. One reason is that variation in productivity is accelerating. The rate at which individuals can create wealth depends on the technology available to them, and that grows exponentially. The other reason creating wealth is such a tenacious source of inequality is that it can expand to accommodate a lot of people.
How can wealth disparities persist even with measures against unethical wealth accumulation?

I'm all for shutting down the crooked ways to get rich. But that won't eliminate great variations in wealth, because as long as you leave open the option of getting rich by creating wealth, people who want to get rich will do that instead.
What motivates individuals to pursue careers in finance, and how might changes in financial policies affect their career choices?

Most people who get rich tend to be fairly driven. Whatever their other flaws, laziness is usually not one of them. Suppose new policies make it hard to make a fortune in finance. Does it seem plausible that the people who currently go into finance to make their fortunes will continue to do so, but be content to work for ordinary salaries? The reason they go into finance is not because they love finance but because they want to get rich. If the only way left to get rich is to start startups, they'll start startups. They'll do well at it too, because determination is the main factor in the success of a startup.
How might a shift from zero-sum games to wealth creation impact income inequality and productivity variations?

While it would probably be a good thing for the world if people who wanted to get rich switched from playing zero-sum games to creating wealth, that would not only not eliminate great variations in wealth, but might even exacerbate them. In a zero-sum game, there is at least a limit to the upside. Plus, a lot of the new startups would create new technology that further accelerated variation in productivity.
What are the potential consequences of trying to eliminate wealth disparities on startups and economic mobility?

Eliminating great variations in wealth would mean eliminating startups, and that doesn't seem a wise move. Especially since it would only mean you eliminated startups in your own country. Ambitious people already move halfway around the world to further their careers, and startups can operate from anywhere nowadays. So if you made it impossible to get rich by creating wealth in your country, people who wanted to do that would just leave and do it somewhere else. This would certainly result in a lower Gini coefficient, along with a lesson in being careful what you ask for.
How do founding ownership and investor involvement contribute to economic inequality in companies?

Both founding ownership and investor involvement further increase economic inequality. Founders own more stock, which contributes to their wealth accumulation. Additionally, investors have learned that founders tend to be better at running their companies than investors themselves, leading to a preference for founder-led businesses.
What historical evidence supports the idea that technological productivity has been accelerating over millennia?

While the surface manifestations change, the underlying forces are very, very old. The acceleration of productivity we see in Silicon Valley has been happening for thousands of years. If you look at the history of stone tools, technology was already accelerating in the Mesolithic. The acceleration would have been too slow to perceive in one lifetime. Such is the nature of the leftmost part of an exponential curve. But it was the same curve.
What has been the focus of public discussions regarding economic inequality, and what aspect has been overlooked?
The public conversation so far has been exclusively about the need to decrease economic inequality. We've barely given a thought to how to live with it.
What is the relationship between addressing underlying issues in the US and reducing economic inequality?

There are many issues in the US that have economic inequality as a symptom. We should fix those issues. In the process, we may decrease economic inequality. However, we can't start from the symptom and hope to fix the underlying causes.
What is the primary motivation behind efforts to decrease economic inequality?
The most obvious motivation is poverty. I'm sure most of those who want to decrease economic inequality want to do it mainly to help the poor, not to hurt the rich.
How does comparing your financial situation to a billionaire's impact your ability to pay bills?

Because you can't pay the bill, it doesn't make any difference what Larry Page's net worth is compared to yours. He might only be a few times richer than you, and it would still be just as much of a problem that your water was getting turned off.
What factors contribute to the lack of social mobility for individuals who grow up in poverty?

Closely related to poverty is the lack of social mobility. I've seen this myself: you don't have to grow up rich or even upper middle class to get rich as a startup founder, but few successful founders grew up desperately poor. However, the problem here is not simply economic inequality. There is an enormous difference in wealth between the household Larry Page grew up in and that of a successful startup founder, but that didn't prevent him from joining their ranks. It's not economic inequality per se that's blocking social mobility, but some specific combination of factors that go wrong when kids grow up sufficiently poor.
What does the principle "you make what you measure" imply about the selection of metrics in an organization?

One of the most important principles in Silicon Valley is that "you make what you measure." It means that if you pick some number to focus on, it will tend to improve, but you have to choose the right number because only the one you choose will improve; another that seems conceptually adjacent might not. For example, if you're a university president and you decide to focus on graduation rates, then you'll improve graduation rates. But only graduation rates, not how much students learn. Students could learn less if, to improve graduation rates, you made classes easier.
What should we focus on to effectively address the underlying issues related to economic inequality?

Economic inequality is sufficiently far from identical with the various problems that have it as a symptom that we'll probably only hit whichever of the two we aim at. If we aim at economic inequality, we won't fix these problems. So I say let's aim at the problems.
What is a more effective approach to addressing poverty according to the paragraph?
For example, let's attack poverty, and if necessary damage wealth in the process. That's much more likely to work than attacking wealth in the hope that you will thereby fix poverty.
What should be done about individuals who profit from deceptive practices and exploitative regulations?

If there are people getting rich by tricking consumers or lobbying the government for anti-competitive regulations or tax loopholes, then let's stop them. Not because it's causing economic inequality, but because it's stealing.
What is the importance of understanding the complexities behind economic inequality beyond just the statistics?

Understanding the complexities behind economic inequality is crucial because statistics alone do not capture the full picture. If all you have is statistics, it seems like that's what you need to fix. However, behind a broad statistical measure like economic inequality, there are factors that can be both positive and negative, some that are historical trends with immense momentum and others that are random accidents. If we want to address the issues behind the statistics, we must understand these complexities and focus our efforts where they'll do the most good.
How do outliers in economic inequality often achieve their status, according to the paragraph?

Particularly since economic inequality is a matter of outliers, and outliers are disproportionately likely to have gotten where they are by ways that have little to do with the sort of things economists usually think about, like wages and productivity, but rather by, say, ending up on the wrong side of the "War on Drugs."
What qualities differentiate successful startup founders from those who accept acquisition offers early on?

Determination is the most important factor in deciding between success and failure, which in startups tend to be sharply differentiated. But it takes more than determination to create one of the hugely successful startups. Though most founders start out excited about the idea of getting rich, purely mercenary founders will usually take one of the big acquisition offers most successful startups get on the way up. The founders who go on to the next stage tend to be driven by a sense of mission. They have the same attachment to their companies that an artist or writer has to their work. However, it is very hard to predict at the outset which founders will do that. It's not simply a function of their initial attitude. Starting a company changes people.
What was Richard Florida's reaction to Europeans' desire to emulate Silicon Valley in terms of entrepreneurship?

After reading a draft of this essay, Richard Florida told me how he had once talked to a group of Europeans who said they wanted to make Europe more entrepreneurial and more like Silicon Valley. I said, by definition, this will give you more inequality. They thought I was insane â they could not process it.
What role does injustice play in perpetuating economic inequality and its effects?

As well as problems that have economic inequality as a symptom, there are those that have it as a cause. But in most, if not all, cases, economic inequality is not the primary cause. There is usually some injustice that is allowing economic inequality to turn into other forms of inequality, and that injustice is what we need to fix. For example, the police in the US treat the poor worse than the rich. But the solution is not to make people richer; it's to make the police treat people more equitably. Otherwise, they'll continue to maltreat people who are weak in other ways.
What does the author argue is the primary issue in discussions about economic inequality?

Some who read this essay will say that I'm clueless or even being deliberately misleading by focusing so much on the richer end of economic inequalityâthat economic inequality is really about poverty. But that is exactly the point I'm making, though with sloppier language than I'd use to make it. The real problem is poverty, not economic inequality. And if you conflate them, you're aiming at the wrong target.
How have tax loopholes and economic inequality interacted throughout history?

Incidentally, tax loopholes are definitely not a product of some power shift due to recent increases in economic inequality. The golden age of economic equality in the mid-20th century was also the golden age of tax avoidance. Indeed, it was so widespread and so effective that I'm skeptical whether economic inequality was really so low then as we think. In a period when people are trying to hide wealth from the government, it will tend to be hidden from statistics too. One sign of the potential magnitude of the problem is the discrepancy between government receipts as a percentage of GDP, which have remained more or less constant during the entire period from the end of World War II to the present, and tax rates, which have varied dramatically.
Who are some individuals acknowledged for their contributions in reviewing drafts?

I would like to acknowledge Sam Altman, Tiffani Ashley Bell, Patrick Collison, Ron Conway, Richard Florida, Ben Horowitz, Jessica Livingston, Robert Morris, Tim O'Reilly, Max Roser, and Alexia Tsotsis for reading drafts of this.
What are some significant social and political changes observed over time, and what might be their underlying cause?

One advantage of being old is that you can see change happen in your lifetime. A lot of the change I've seen is fragmentation. US politics is much more polarized than it used to be. Culturally, we have ever less common ground. The creative class flocks to a handful of happy cities, abandoning the rest. And increasing economic inequality means the spread between rich and poor is growing too. I'd like to propose a hypothesis: that all these trends are instances of the same phenomenon. And moreover, that the cause is not some force that's pulling us apart, but rather the erosion of forces that had been pushing us together.
How did World War II impact income variation and wage structures in the United States?

The effects of World War II were both economic and social. Economically, it decreased variation in income. Like all modern armed forces, America's were socialist economically: from each according to his ability, to each according to his need, more or less. Higher-ranking members of the military got more (as higher-ranking members of socialist societies always do), but what they received was fixed according to their rank. The flattening effect wasn't limited to those under arms, because the US economy was conscripted too. Between 1942 and 1945, all wages were set by the National War Labor Board. Like the military, they defaulted to flatness. This national standardization of wages was so pervasive that its effects could still be seen years after the war ended.
What measures did FDR implement to prevent war profiteering during World War II?

Business owners weren't supposed to be making money either. FDR said, "not a single war millionaire" would be permitted. To ensure that, any increase in a company's profits over prewar levels was taxed at 85%. And when what was left after corporate taxes reached individuals, it was taxed again at a marginal rate of 93%.
How did the war impact social diversity among men and women from different backgrounds?

Socially, the war tended to decrease variation. Over 16 million men and women from all sorts of different backgrounds were brought together in a way of life that was literally uniform. Service rates for men born in the early 1920s approached 80%. Working toward a common goal, often under stress, brought them still closer together.
How did World War II influence the expansion of federal government powers in the United States in the years following the conflict?

Though strictly speaking, World War II lasted less than four years for the U.S., its effects lasted longer. Wars make central governments more powerful, and World War II was an extreme case of this. In the U.S., as in all the other Allied countries, the federal government was slow to give up the new powers it had acquired. Indeed, in some respects, the war didn't end in 1945; the enemy just switched to the Soviet Union. In tax rates, federal power, defense spending, conscription, and nationalism, the decades after the war looked more like wartime than prewar peacetime.
What characterized the economic landscape of the 20th century in relation to corporate structure and scale?

The 20th century was the century of the big, national corporation: General Electric, General Foods, General Motors. Developments in finance, communications, transportation, and manufacturing enabled a new type of company whose goal was, above all, scale. Version 1 of this world was low-res: a Duplo world of a few giant companies dominating each big market.
What were the characteristics of the major sectors of the economy by the end of World War II?

The consolidation that began in the late 19th century continued for most of the 20th. By the end of World War II, as Michael Lind writes, "the major sectors of the economy were either organized as government-backed cartels or dominated by a few oligopolistic corporations."
How has the variety of consumer choices changed over time?

For consumers, this new world meant the same choices everywhere, but only a few of them. When I grew up, there were only 2 or 3 of most things, and since they were all aiming at the middle of the market, there wasn't much to differentiate them.
What factors contributed to the homogenization of television programming among major networks in the past?

One of the most important instances of this phenomenon was in television. Here, there were three choices: NBC, CBS, and ABC, plus public TV for intellectuals and those with differing views. The programs that the three networks offered were indistinguishable. In fact, there was a triple pressure toward the center. If one show did try something daring, local affiliates in conservative markets would make them stop. Additionally, since televisions were expensive, whole families watched the same shows together, so they had to be suitable for everyone.
How did television viewing habits in the past create a sense of shared experience among families?

Not only did everyone get the same thing, they got it at the same time. It's difficult to imagine now, but every night, tens of millions of families would sit down together in front of their TV sets, watching the same show at the same time as their next-door neighbors. What happens now with the Super Bowl used to happen every night. We were literally in sync.
How did mid-century TV culture influence societal perceptions and behavior, according to Robert MacNeil?

Mid-century TV culture had both positive and negative influences on societal perceptions and behavior. On one hand, it presented a view of the world akin to that found in children's books, which likely encouraged better behavior, as parents hoped. However, like children's books, TV could also be misleadingâdangerously so for adults. In his autobiography, Robert MacNeil discusses witnessing gruesome images from Vietnam and reflects on the concern that such content could not be shown to families during dinner.
What personal experiences led the author to reject mainstream media at a young age?

I know how pervasive the common culture was because I tried to opt out of it, and it was practically impossible to find alternatives. When I was 13, I realized, more from internal evidence than any outside source, that the ideas we were being fed on TV were crap, and I stopped watching it.
What were the author's observations about the lack of authenticity in various aspects of society?

But it wasn't just TV. It seemed like everything around me was crap. The politicians all said the same things, the consumer brands made almost identical products with different labels stuck on to indicate how prestigious they were meant to be, the balloon-frame houses had fake "colonial" skins, the cars had several feet of gratuitous metal on each end that started to fall apart after a couple of years, and the "red delicious" apples were red but only in appearance.
What challenges did you face when trying to find alternatives during a time without the Internet?
When I went looking for alternatives to fill this void, I found practically nothing. There was no Internet then. The only place to look was in the chain bookstore in our local shopping mall.
What was your initial reaction to the magazine that hinted at a broader world beyond your experience?

I wish I could say it became a gateway into a wider world, but in fact, I found it boring and incomprehensible. Like a kid tasting whisky for the first time and pretending to like it, I preserved that magazine as carefully as if it had been a book. I'm sure I still have it somewhere. But though it was evidence that there was, somewhere, a world that wasn't Red Delicious, I didn't find it until college.
How did corporate culture in the mid-20th century influence societal norms regarding appearance and behavior?

It wasn't just as consumers that the big companies made us similar; they did so as employers too. Within companies, there were powerful forces pushing people toward a single model of how to look and act. IBM was particularly notorious for this, but they were only a little more extreme than other big companies. The models of how to look and act varied little between companies, meaning everyone within this world was expected to seem more or less the same. Not just those in the corporate world, but also everyone who aspired to it â which in the middle of the 20th century meant most people who weren't already in it. For most of the 20th century, working-class people tried hard to look middle class. You can see it in old photos; few adults aspired to look dangerous in 1950.
How did the relationship between national corporations and labor unions in the mid-20th century affect labor costs?

Along with giant national corporations, we got giant national labor unions. In the mid-20th century, the corporations cut deals with the unions where they paid over market price for labor, partly because the unions were monopolies.
Why were large corporations willing to accept higher labor costs in the mid-20th century?

Partly because, as components of oligopolies themselves, the corporations knew they could safely pass the cost on to their customers, because their competitors would have to as well. And partly because, in mid-century, most of the giant companies were still focused on finding new ways to milk economies of scale. Just as startups rightly pay AWS a premium over the cost of running their own servers so they can focus on growth, many of the big national corporations were willing to pay a premium for labor.
How does long-term employment and company loyalty influence an employee's approach to salary negotiations?

Your work was so illiquid that there was little chance of getting market price. But that same illiquidity also encouraged you not to seek it. If the company promised to employ you until you retired and give you a pension afterward, you didn't want to extract as much from it this year as you could. You needed to take care of the company so it could take care of you, especially when you'd been working with the same group of people for decades. If you tried to squeeze the company for more money, you were squeezing the organization that was going to take care of you.
What factors contributed to the perception of big companies as longstanding entities in the 20th century?

By the 1970s, no one stopped to wonder where the big prestigious companies had come from in the first place. It seemed like they'd always been there, like the chemical elements. And indeed, there was a double wall between ambitious kids in the 20th century and the origins of the big companies. Many of the big companies were roll-ups that didn't have clear founders. And when they did, the founders didn't seem like us. Nearly all of them had been uneducated, in the sense of not having been to college. They were what Shakespeare called rude mechanicals. College trained one to be a member of the professional classes. Its graduates didn't expect to do the sort of grubby menial work that Andrew Carnegie or Henry Ford started out doing.
How did the GI Bill and the rising number of college graduates in the 20th century influence societal perceptions of ambition and career choices?

In the 20th century, there were more and more college graduates. They increased from about 2% of the population in 1900 to about 25% in 2000. In the middle of the century, our two big forces intersected in the form of the GI Bill, which sent 2.2 million World War II veterans to college. Few thought of it in these terms, but the result of making college the canonical path for the ambitious was a world in which it was socially acceptable to work for Henry Ford, but not to be Henry Ford.
What factors contributed to the disintegration of the Duplo economy?

Change was coming soon. When the Duplo economy started to disintegrate, it disintegrated in several different ways at once. Vertically integrated companies literally dis-integrated because it was more efficient to do so. Incumbents faced new competitors as (a) markets went global and (b) technical innovation started to trump economies of scale, turning size from an asset into a liability. Smaller companies were increasingly able to survive as formerly narrow channels to consumers broadened. Markets themselves started to change faster, as whole new categories of products appeared. Last but not least, the federal government, which had previously smiled upon J. P. Morgan's world as the natural state of things, began to realize it wasn't the last word after all.
How has the approach to car manufacturing evolved from the time of Henry Ford to today?

Henry Ford's approach to car manufacturing was revolutionary for its time. He wanted to do everything himself, and the giant plant he built at River Rouge between 1917 and 1928 literally took in iron ore at one end and sent cars out the other. At its peak, 100,000 people worked there, and it seemed like the future of car manufacturing. However, that is not how car companies operate today. Now, much of the design and manufacturing happens in a long supply chain, with products that car companies ultimately assemble and sell. This approach works better because each company in the supply chain focuses on what they know best, and they must perform well or risk being replaced by another supplier.
What factors contributed to Henry Ford's preference for a single large company over a network of cooperating companies?

One reason Henry Ford preferred a single large company over a network of cooperating companies is that supplier networks take a while to evolve. In 1917, doing everything himself seemed to Ford the only way to achieve the scale he needed. Additionally, if you want to solve a problem using a network of cooperating companies, you have to be able to coordinate their efforts, which can be done much better with computers. Computers reduce the transaction costs that Coase argued are the raison d'Ãªtre of corporations. That is a fundamental change.
How did perceptions of big companies' efficiency change from the early to the late 20th century?

In the early 20th century, big companies were synonymous with efficiency. In the late 20th century, they were synonymous with inefficiency. To some extent, this was because the companies themselves had become sclerotic. But it was also because our standards were higher.
How did the evolution of industries impact the production of new products?

It wasn't just within existing industries that change occurred; the industries themselves changed. It became possible to make many new things, and sometimes the existing companies weren't the ones who did it best.
What was the impact of deregulation on industries like air travel and long-distance phone service during the Carter administration?

Gradually, the government realized that anti-competitive policies were doing more harm than good, and during the Carter administration, it started to remove them. The word used for this process was misleadingly narrow: deregulation. What was really happening was de-oligopolization. It happened to one industry after another. Two of the most visible to consumers were air travel and long-distance phone service, which both became dramatically cheaper after deregulation.
How did deregulation impact corporate management and mergers in the 1980s?

Deregulation also contributed to the wave of hostile takeovers in the 1980s. In the past, the only limit on the inefficiency of companies, short of actual bankruptcy, was the inefficiency of their competitors. Now, companies had to face absolute rather than relative standards. Any public company that didn't generate sufficient returns on its assets risked having its management replaced with one that would. Often, the new managers did this by breaking companies up into components that were more valuable separately.
How did the structure of the national economy evolve from Version 1 to Version 2?

Version 1 of the national economy consisted of a few big blocks whose relationships were negotiated in back rooms by a handful of executives, politicians, regulators, and labor leaders. Version 2 was higher resolution: there were more companies of more different sizes making more different things, and their relationships changed faster. In this world, there were still plenty of backroom negotiations, but more was left to market forces, which further accelerated the fragmentation.
How has the average tenure of companies in the S&P 500 changed from 1958 to 2012?

It's a little misleading to talk of versions when describing a gradual process, but not as misleading as it might seem. There was a lot of change in a few decades, and what we ended up with was qualitatively different. The companies in the S&P 500 in 1958 had been there an average of 61 years. By 2012, that number was 18 years.
How did the spread of computing power influence the breakup of the Duplo economy and the rise of startups?

The breakup of the Duplo economy happened simultaneously with the spread of computing power. To what extent were computers a precondition? It would take a book to answer that. Obviously, the spread of computing power was a precondition for the rise of startups. I suspect it was for most of what happened in finance too. But was it a precondition for globalization or the LBO wave? I don't know, but I wouldn't discount the possibility. It may be that the refragmentation was driven by computers in the way the industrial revolution was driven by steam engines. Whether or not computers were a precondition, they have certainly accelerated it.
How has the evolving nature of companies impacted career perceptions and salary structures?

The evolving nature of companies has changed people's relationships with their employers. Why climb a corporate ladder that might be yanked out from under you? Ambitious individuals have started to think of a career less as climbing a single ladder than as a series of jobs that might be at different companies. More movement (or even potential movement) between companies has introduced more competition in salaries. Additionally, as companies have become smaller, it has become easier to estimate how much an employee contributes to the company's revenue. Both changes have driven salaries toward market price. Since people vary dramatically in productivity, paying market price has meant salaries started to diverge.
What social changes in the early 1980s led to the emergence of the "yuppie" phenomenon?

By no coincidence, it was in the early 1980s that the term "yuppie" was coined. That word is not much used now because the phenomenon it describes is so taken for granted, but at the time, it was a label for something novel. Yuppies were young professionals who made lots of money. To someone in their twenties today, this wouldn't seem worth naming. Why wouldn't young professionals make lots of money? But until the 1980s, being underpaid early in your career was part of what it meant to be a professional. Young professionals were paying their dues, working their way up the ladder. The rewards would come later. What was novel about yuppies was that they wanted market price for the work they were doing now.
What are the potential consequences of widespread underpayment for entry-level positions in the job market?

Underpaying people at the beginning of their careers only works if everyone does it. Once some employer breaks ranks, everyone else has to, or they can't get good people. Once this process starts, it spreads through the whole economy because, at the beginnings of people's careers, they can easily switch not merely employers but industries.
What factors influenced individuals' decisions to pursue wealth in different eras?

More generally, an idea was returning whose name sounds old-fashioned precisely because it was so rare for so long: that you could make your fortune. As in the past, there were multiple ways to do it. Some made their fortunes by creating wealth, and others by playing zero-sum games. But once it became possible to make one's fortune, the ambitious had to decide whether or not to. A physicist who chose physics over Wall Street in 1990 was making a sacrifice that a physicist in 1960 didn't have to think about.
How did the fragmentation of companies affect workers' wages and union influence?

Meanwhile, a similar fragmentation was happening at the other end of the economic scale. As big companies' oligopolies became less secure, they were less able to pass costs on to customers and thus less willing to overpay for labor. As the Duplo world of a few big blocks fragmented into many companies of different sizes â some of them overseas â it became harder for unions to enforce their monopolies. As a result, workers' wages also tended toward market price, which (inevitably, if unions had been doing their job) tended to be lower. Perhaps dramatically so, if automation had decreased the need for some kind of work.
How did the breakup of the mid-century model influence social behaviors and lifestyle choices?

Just as the mid-century model induced social as well as economic cohesion, its breakup brought social as well as economic fragmentation. People started to dress and act differently. Those who would later be called the "creative class" became more mobile. People who didn't care much for religion felt less pressure to go to church for appearances' sake, while those who liked it a lot opted for increasingly colorful forms. Some switched from meatloaf to tofu, and others to Hot Pockets. Some switched from driving Ford sedans to driving small imported cars, and others to driving SUVs. Kids who went to private schools or wished they did started to dress "preppy," and kids who wanted to seem rebellious made a conscious effort to look disreputable. In a hundred ways, people spread apart.
What challenges does achieving social cohesion in the modern era present compared to the 20th century?

Achieving social cohesion in the modern era presents different challenges compared to the 20th century. In the 20th century, cohesion occurred somewhat naturally, as the wars were primarily due to external forces, and the economy was in an evolutionary phase. Today, if we want cohesion, it must be induced deliberately, and it's not obvious how to achieve that. I suspect the best we can do is address the symptoms of fragmentation, but that may be enough.
What factors have contributed to the increasing and accelerating variation in wealth creation since the mid-20th century?

The variation in the amount of wealth people can create has not only been increasing but also accelerating. The unusual conditions that prevailed in the mid-20th century masked this underlying trend. The ambitious had little choice but to join large organizations that made them march in step with lots of other people â literally in the case of the armed forces, figuratively in the case of big corporations. Even if the big corporations had wanted to pay people proportionate to their value, they couldn't have figured out how. But that constraint has gone now. Ever since it started to erode in the 1970s, we've seen the underlying forces at work again.
What are the underlying factors contributing to economic inequality despite efforts to mitigate it through subsidies and taxes?

As long as it's possible to get rich by creating wealth, the default tendency will be for economic inequality to increase. Even if you eliminate all the other ways to get rich, you can mitigate this with subsidies at the bottom and taxes at the top. However, unless taxes are high enough to discourage people from creating wealth, you're always going to be fighting a losing battle against increasing variation in productivity.
What does the paragraph suggest about the permanence of societal fragmentation and individualism?

That form of fragmentation, like the others, is here to stay. Or rather, back to stay. Nothing is forever, but the tendency toward fragmentation should be more forever than most things, precisely because it's not due to any particular cause. It's simply a reversion to the mean. When Rockefeller said individualism was gone, he was right for a hundred years. It's back now, and that's likely to be true for longer.
What potential dangers arise from the misconception that restoring 20th-century cohesion is possible through minor policy adjustments?

I worry that if we don't acknowledge this, we're headed for trouble. If we think 20th-century cohesion disappeared because of a few policy tweaks, we'll be deluded into thinking we can get it back (minus the bad parts, somehow) with a few counter-tweaks. And then we'll waste our time trying to eliminate fragmentation when we'd be better off thinking about how to mitigate its consequences.
What factors contributed to the persistence of wage differentials from the post-World War II era to the 1970s?

Lester Thurow, writing in 1975, said the wage differentials prevailing at the end of World War II had become so embedded that they "were regarded as 'just' even after the egalitarian pressures of World War II had disappeared. Basically, the same differentials exist to this day, thirty years later." However, Goldin and Margo think market forces in the postwar period also helped preserve the wartime compression of wages â specifically, increased demand for unskilled workers and an oversupply of educated ones.
How did the American practice of employer-paid health insurance originate in relation to wage controls?
The American custom of having employers pay for health insurance derives from efforts by businesses to circumvent NWLB wage controls in order to attract workers.
What factors influenced the tax contributions of wealthy individuals during World War II?

As always, tax rates don't tell the whole story. There were lots of exemptions, especially for individuals. During World War II, the tax codes were so new that the government had little acquired immunity to tax avoidance. If the rich paid high taxes during the war, it was more because they wanted to than because they had to.
How have federal tax receipts as a percentage of GDP changed since the war, and what does the data suggest about the impact of tax rates on actual payments?

After the war, federal tax receipts as a percentage of GDP were about the same as they are now. In fact, for the entire period since the war, tax receipts have stayed close to 18% of GDP, despite dramatic changes in tax rates. The lowest point occurred when marginal income tax rates were highest: 14.1% in 1950. Looking at the data, it's hard to avoid the conclusion that tax rates have had little effect on what people actually paid.
How did the New Deal foreshadow the federal government's actions during World War II?

Though in fact the decade preceding the war had been a time of unprecedented federal power in response to the Depression, which is not entirely a coincidence because the Depression was one of the causes of the war. In many ways, the New Deal was a sort of dress rehearsal for the measures the federal government took during wartime. The wartime versions were much more drastic and more pervasive, though. As Anthony Badger wrote, "for many Americans the decisive change in their experiences came not with the New Deal but with World War II."
What potential factor could be linked to the origins of the world wars according to the speaker?

I don't know enough about the origins of the world wars to say, but it's not inconceivable that they were connected to the rise of big corporations. If that were the case, 20th-century cohesion would have a single cause.
What are the two distinct economic groups described in Galbraith's analysis of the bimodal economy?

More precisely, there was a bimodal economy consisting, in Galbraith's words, of "the world of the technically dynamic, massively capitalized, and highly organized corporations on the one hand and the hundreds of thousands of small and traditional proprietors on the other." Money, prestige, and power were concentrated in the former, and there was near-zero crossover.
What significant cultural event left you feeling out of the loop during its premiere?
I remember when this happened because it was the season "Dallas" premiered. Everyone else was talking about what was happening on "Dallas," and I had no idea what they meant.
How can unions benefit the companies they represent in terms of political support?

The relationships between unions and unionized companies can even be symbiotic because unions will exert political pressure to protect their hosts. According to Michael Lind, when politicians tried to attack the A&P supermarket chain because it was putting local grocery stores out of business, "A&P successfully defended itself by allowing the unionization of its workforce in 1938, thereby gaining organized labor as a constituency." I've seen this phenomenon myself: hotel unions are responsible for more of the political pressure against Airbnb than hotel companies.
What did Galbraith find surprising about the motivations of corporate executives?

Galbraith was clearly puzzled that corporate executives would work so hard to make money for other people (the shareholders) instead of for themselves. He devoted much of his analysis to understanding this phenomenon.
What factors might influence modern corporate executives' motivations beyond financial rewards?

His theory was that professionalism had replaced money as a motive, and that modern corporate executives were, like (good) scientists, motivated less by financial rewards than by the desire to do good work and thereby earn the respect of their peers. There is something in this, though I think lack of movement between companies combined with self-interest explains much of the observed behavior.
What does Galbraith's 1952 study reveal about the tenure of the highest paid executives at major corporations?
Galbraith (p. 94) states that a 1952 study of the 800 highest-paid executives at 300 big corporations found that three-quarters of them had been with their company for more than 20 years.
What factors contributed to the relatively low executive salaries in the early 20th century?

It seems likely that in the first third of the 20th century, executive salaries were low partly because companies were more dependent on banks, who would have disapproved if executives received too much. This was certainly true in the beginning. The first big company CEOs were J. P. Morgan's hired hands.
When did companies begin to finance themselves with retained earnings instead of relying on bank capital?

Companies didn't start to finance themselves with retained earnings until the 1920s. Until then, they had to pay out their earnings in dividends and depended on banks for capital for expansion. Bankers continued to sit on corporate boards until the Glass-Steagall Act in 1933.
How did financial controls during World War II influence executive salaries and employee mobility in big companies by mid-century?

By mid-century, big companies funded three-quarters of their growth from earnings. However, the early years of bank dependence, reinforced by the financial controls of World War II, must have had a significant effect on social conventions regarding executive salaries. Therefore, it may be that the lack of movement between companies was as much the effect of low salaries as the cause.
What financial strategy in the 1920s contributed to the 1929 stock market crash?
The switch in the 1920s to financing growth with retained earnings was one cause of the 1929 crash. The banks now had to find someone else to lend to, so they made more margin loans.
What was the societal perception of founders and entrepreneurship when the author was a child?

Founders weren't celebrated in the press when I was a kid. "Our founder" meant a photograph of a severe-looking man with a walrus mustache and a wing collar who had died decades ago. The thing to be when I was a kid was an entrepreneur.
What evidence suggests that a CEO's impact on a company's success can justify high compensation?

CEOs of big companies may be overpaid. I don't know enough about big companies to say. But it is certainly not impossible for a CEO to make 200 times as much difference to a company's revenues as the average employee. Look at what Steve Jobs did for Apple when he came back as CEO. It would have been a good deal for the board to give him 95% of the company. Apple's market cap the day Steve came back in July 1997 was 1.73 billion. Five percent of Apple now (January 2016) would be worth about 30 billion. And it would not be if Steve hadn't come back; Apple probably wouldn't even exist anymore.
What distinguishes social upheaval from fragmentation in the context of the late 1960s?

The late 1960s were famous for social upheaval. However, that was more rebellion (which can happen in any era if people are provoked sufficiently) than fragmentation. You do not see fragmentation unless you see people breaking off to both the left and right.
What were the primary methods through which individuals built wealth in the mid 20th century despite high taxes?

There were a handful of ways to make a fortune in the mid-20th century. The main one was drilling for oil, which was open to newcomers because it was not something big companies could dominate through economies of scale. How did individuals accumulate large fortunes in an era of such high taxes? Giant tax loopholes defended by two of the most powerful men in Congress, Sam Rayburn and Lyndon Johnson.
Who were the founders of YC and what roles did they play in its operations?

YC had four founders. Jessica and I decided one night to start it, and the next day we recruited my friends Robert Morris and Trevor Blackwell. Jessica and I ran YC day-to-day, and Robert and Trevor read applications and did interviews with us.
What role did Jessica play in shaping the culture at Y Combinator, and why was this culture significant?

Early YC was a family, and Jessica was its mom. The culture she defined was one of YC's most important innovations. Culture is important in any organization, but at YC, culture wasn't just how we behaved when we built the product; at YC, the culture was the product.
How did the founders of YC integrate their personal lives with their work before having children?

Before we had kids, YC was more or less our life. There was no real distinction between working hours and not. We talked about YC all the time. And while there might be some businesses that it would be tedious to let infect your private life, we liked it. We started YC because it was something we were interested in. And some of the problems we were trying to solve were endlessly difficult. How do you recognize good founders? You could talk about that for years, and we did; we still do.
What qualities make Jessica a valuable asset in evaluating startup founders at Y Combinator?

Jessica is better at some things than I am, and I'm better at some things than she is. One of the things she is best at is judging people. She is one of those rare individuals with x-ray vision for character. She can see through any kind of faker almost immediately. Her nickname within YC was the Social Radar, and this special power of hers was critical in making YC what it is. The earlier you pick startups, the more you're picking the founders. Later-stage investors get to try products and look at growth numbers. At the stage where YC invests, there is often neither a product nor any numbers.
What was the key factor behind Y Combinator's success in selecting startups?

Others thought YC had some special insight about the future of technology. Mostly, we had the same sort of insight Socrates claimed: we at least knew we knew nothing. What made YC successful was being able to pick good founders. We thought Airbnb was a bad idea; we funded it because we liked the founders.
How did Jessica's role during the interviews differ from that of Robert and Trevor?

During interviews, Robert, Trevor, and I would pepper the applicants with technical questions. Jessica would mostly watch. A lot of the applicants probably read her as some kind of secretary, especially early on, because she was the one who'd go out and get each new group, and she didn't ask many questions. She was okay with that. It was easier for her to watch people if they didn't notice her. But after the interview, the three of us would turn to Jessica and ask, "What does the Social Radar say?"
How did the use of the Social Radar influence the selection process for founders at interviews?

Having the Social Radar at interviews wasn't just how we picked founders who would be successful; it was also how we picked founders who were good people. At first, we did this because we couldn't help it. Imagine what it would feel like to have x-ray vision for character. Being around bad people would be intolerable. So, we would refuse to fund founders whose characters we had doubts about, even if we thought they would be successful.
What unforeseen benefits arose from the initial selection process for YC's founders?

Though we initially did this out of self-indulgence, it turned out to be very valuable to YC. We didn't realize it in the beginning, but the people we were picking would become the YC alumni network. And once we picked them, unless they did something really egregious, they were going to be part of it for life. Some now think YC's alumni network is its most valuable feature. I personally think YC's advice is pretty good too, but the alumni network is certainly among the most valuable features. The level of trust and helpfulness is remarkable for a group of such size. And Jessica is the main reason why.
Why is Jessica's significant role at YC not widely recognized?

If Jessica was so important to YC, why don't more people realize it? Partly because I'm a writer, and writers always get disproportionate attention. YC's brand was initially my brand, and our applicants were people who'd read my essays. But there is another reason: Jessica hates attention. Talking to reporters makes her nervous. The thought of giving a talk paralyzes her. She was even uncomfortable at our wedding because the bride is always the center of attention.
Why does she dislike attention in social situations?
It's not just because she's shy that she hates attention, but because it throws off the social radar. She can't be herself. You can't watch people when everyone is watching you.
What are her feelings about public attention and how does it relate to her views on modesty?

Another reason attention worries her is that she hates bragging. In anything she does that is publicly visible, her biggest fear (after the obvious fear that it will be bad) is that it will seem ostentatious. She says being too modest is a common problem for women. But in her case, it goes beyond that. She has a horror of ostentation so visceral it's almost a phobia.
Why might someone struggle in a leadership role that involves public representation?
She also hates fighting. She can't do it; she just shuts down. Unfortunately, there is a good deal of fighting in being the public face of an organization.
What role did Jessica play in the founding and development of Y Combinator that is often overlooked in its history?

Although Jessica played a crucial role in making Y Combinator unique, the very qualities that enabled her to do so mean she tends to be overlooked in YC's history. Many people subscribe to the narrative that Paul Graham started YC and that his wife merely assisted him. Even critics of YC often perpetuate this story. A couple of years ago, when we faced criticism for not funding more female founders, the narrative treated YC as synonymous with Paul Graham. Acknowledging Jessica's central role would have complicated that narrative.
Why did she choose not to publicly respond to the criticisms surrounding female founders?

She chose not to publicly respond to the criticisms surrounding female founders due to the company of sexism. I've never seen her angrier about anything. But she did not contradict them. Not publicly. In private, there was a great deal of profanity. She wrote three separate essays about the question of female founders, but she could never bring herself to publish any of them. She'd seen the level of vitriol in this debate, and she shrank from engaging.
What are the reasons behind her aversion to engaging in conflicts, particularly with dishonest individuals?

It wasn't just because she disliked fighting; she is so sensitive to character that it repels her even to fight with dishonest people. The idea of mixing it up with linkbait journalists or Twitter trolls seems to her not merely frightening, but disgusting.
How did Jessica's experience with media coverage reflect the challenges faced by female founders in gaining recognition for their professional achievements?

But Jessica knew her example as a successful female founder would encourage more women to start companies, so last year she did something YC had never done before and hired a PR firm to get her some interviews. At one of the first she did, the reporter brushed aside her insights about startups and turned it into a sensationalistic story about how some guy had tried to chat her up as she was waiting outside the bar where they had arranged to meet. Jessica was mortified, partly because the guy had done nothing wrong, but more because the story treated her as a victim significant only for being a woman, rather than one of the most knowledgeable investors in the Valley.
How did Jessica contribute to the development and identity of YC?

Jessica contributed to the development and identity of YC by curating and nurturing a diverse collection of people. YC is fundamentally a nexus of individuals, much like a university; it doesn't make a product. What defines it is the people, and Jessica, more than anyone, played a crucial role in shaping that community. In that sense, she literally made YC.
What factors are the best predictors of startup success according to Jessica's research?

Jessica knows more about the qualities of startup founders than anyone else ever has. Her immense data set and x-ray vision are the perfect storm in that respect. The qualities of the founders are the best predictor of how a startup will do. Startups are, in turn, the most important source of growth in mature economies.
What skills did she possess that helped her identify issues within the team?
She was always good at sniffing out any red flags about the team or their determination and disarmingly asking the right questions, which usually revealed more than the founders realized.
How does the desire for recognition affect one's comfort with public scrutiny?

While she likes getting attention in the sense of receiving credit for what she has done, she doesn't like getting attention in the sense of being watched in real time. Unfortunately, not just for her but for a lot of people, how much you get of the former depends a lot on how much you get of the latter.
How does Jessica's behavior at public events contradict her feelings about attention?
If you saw Jessica at a public event, you would never guess she hates attention, because (a) she is very polite and (b) when she's nervous, she expresses it by smiling more.
What impact does incivility in conversations have on the willingness of thoughtful individuals, like Jessica, to engage in discussions about sensitive topics?

There's a sort of Gresham's Law of conversations. If a conversation reaches a certain level of incivility, the more thoughtful people start to leave. No one understands female founders better than Jessica. But it's unlikely anyone will ever hear her speak candidly about the topic. She ventured a toe in that water a while ago, and the reaction was so violent that she decided, "never again."
Who were some of the individuals involved in reviewing drafts for this work?

I would like to thank Sam Altman, Paul Buchheit, Patrick Collison, Daniel Gackle, Carolynn Levy, Jon Levy, Kirsty Nathoo, Robert Morris, Geoff Ralston, and Harj Taggar for reading drafts of this work. And yes, Jessica Livingston, who made me cut surprisingly little.
What conditions must be met to effectively use this technique for comparing applicant performance?

You can use this technique whenever (a) you have at least a random sample of the applicants that were selected, (b) their subsequent performance is measured, and (c) the groups of applicants you're comparing have a roughly equal distribution of ability.
What does it mean for a selection process to be biased against certain applicants?

What does it mean for a selection process to be biased against certain applicants? Think about what it means to be biased. What it means for a selection process to be biased against applicants of type x is that it's harder for them to make it through. This means applicants of type x have to be better to get selected than applicants not of type x.
How can performance testing be used to identify bias in a selection process?

Of course, the test you use to measure performance must be a valid one. In particular, it must not be invalidated by the bias you're trying to measure. However, there are some domains where performance can be measured, and in those, detecting bias is straightforward. Want to know if the selection process was biased against some type of applicant? Check whether they outperform the others. This is not just a heuristic for detecting bias; it's what bias means.
What factors contribute to the anticipated increase in the use of a specific technique in future studies?

I predict we'll see this technique used more in the future. The information needed to conduct such studies is increasingly available. Data about who applies for things is usually closely guarded by the organizations selecting them, but nowadays, data about who gets selected is often publicly available to anyone who takes the trouble to aggregate it.
What issue arises when selection criteria differ for various types of applicants?

This technique wouldn't work if the selection process looked for different things from different types of applicants; for example, if an employer hired men based on their ability but women based on their appearance.
Why did First Round exclude Uber from their study on startup investment returns?

As Paul Buchheit points out, First Round excluded their most successful investment, Uber, from the study. While it makes sense to exclude outliers from some types of studies, studies of returns from startup investing, which is all about hitting outliers, are not one of them.
Why do people often use different language styles when writing compared to speaking?

Something comes over most people when they start writing. They write in a different language than they'd use if they were talking to a friend. The sentence structure and even the words are different. No one uses "pen" as a verb in spoken English. You'd feel like an idiot using "pen" instead of "write" in a conversation with a friend.
Why is it important to simplify written language for effective communication?

If you want people to read and understand what you write, simplifying written language is important. Written language is more complex, which makes it more work to read. It's also more formal and distant, which gives the reader's attention permission to drift. But perhaps worst of all, the complex sentences and fancy words give you, the writer, the false impression that you're saying more than you actually are.
How do experts communicate complex ideas in their fields?

You don't need complex sentences to express complex ideas. When specialists in some abstruse topic talk to one another about ideas in their field, they don't use sentences any more complex than they do when talking about what to have for lunch. They use different words, certainly, but even those they use no more than necessary. In my experience, the harder the subject, the more informally experts speak. Partly, I think, because they have less to prove, and partly because the harder the ideas you're talking about, the less you can afford to let language get in the way.
In what contexts might writers choose to use complex language or poetic forms instead of straightforward communication?

I'm not saying spoken language always works best. Poetry is as much music as text, so you can say things you wouldn't say in conversation. There are a handful of writers who can get away with using fancy language in prose. Of course, there are cases where writers don't want to make it easy to understand what they're sayingâin corporate announcements of bad news, for example, or at the more complex levels of literary expression.
How can you improve your writing to sound more conversational?

It seems to be hard for most people to write in spoken language. So perhaps the best solution is to write your first draft the way you usually would, then afterward look at each sentence and ask, "Is this the way I'd say this if I were talking to a friend?" If it isn't, imagine what you would say and use that instead. After a while, this filter will start to operate as you write. When you write something you wouldn't say, you'll hear the clank as it hits the page.
What steps do you take to ensure your essays sound conversational before publishing?

Before I publish a new essay, I read it out loud and fix everything that doesn't sound like conversation. I even fix bits that are phonetically awkward; I don't know if that's necessary, but it doesn't cost much.
What is a recommended method for improving writing that feels disconnected from natural spoken language?

This trick may not always be enough. I've seen writing so far removed from spoken language that it couldn't be fixed sentence by sentence. For cases like that, there's a more drastic solution. After writing the first draft, try explaining to a friend what you just wrote. Then replace the draft with what you said to your friend.
Why do many people struggle to write in a way that reflects their natural spoken language?

People often tell me how much my essays sound like me talking. The fact that this seems worthy of comment shows how rarely people manage to write in spoken language. Otherwise, everyone's writing would sound like them talking.
What is one effective strategy to improve writing and connect with readers?
If you simply manage to write in spoken language, you'll be ahead of 95% of writers. And it's so easy to do: just don't let a sentence through unless it's the way you'd say it to a friend.
What key financial metric do you assess when evaluating the sustainability of a startup after several months of operation?

When I talk to a startup that's been operating for more than 8 or 9 months, the first thing I want to know is almost always the same. Assuming their expenses remain constant and their revenue growth is what it has been over the last several months, do they make it to profitability on the money they have left? Or, to put it more dramatically, by default, do they live or die?
What do many startup founders struggle to assess about their company's viability?
The startling thing is how often the founders themselves don't know. Half the founders I talk to don't know whether they're default alive or default dead.
Why is it important to determine if a startup is default alive or default dead before discussing its future?

The reason I want to know first whether a startup is default alive or default dead is that the rest of the conversation depends on the answer.
