If the company is default alive, we can talk about ambitious new things they could do. If it's default dead, we probably need to talk about how to save it. We know the current trajectory ends badly. How can they get off that trajectory?
Why is it important for founders to understand whether their startup is default alive or default dead as the company matures?

Why do so few founders know whether they're default alive or default dead? Mainly, I think, because they're not used to asking that. It's not a question that makes sense to ask early on, any more than it makes sense to ask a 3-year-old how he plans to support himself. But as the company grows older, the question switches from meaningless to critical. That kind of switch often takes people by surprise.
When is the right time to assess whether a project is on track or at risk of failure?

I propose the following solution: instead of starting to ask too late whether you're default alive or default dead, start asking too early. It's hard to say precisely when the question switches polarity. But it's probably not that dangerous to start worrying too early that you're default dead, whereas it's very dangerous to start worrying too late.
What are the key factors that lead founders to face a fatal pinch in their startups?
The fatal pinch is default dead, slow growth, and not enough time to fix it. The way founders end up in it is by not realizing that's where they're headed.
Why do founders often neglect to consider their financial sustainability?

There is another reason founders don't ask themselves whether they're default alive or default dead: they assume it will be easy to raise more money. But that assumption is often false, and worse still, the more you depend on it, the falser it becomes.
How can acknowledging the harsh realities of a situation help in preventing future crises?

Acknowledging the harsh realities of a situation can help separate facts from hopes. Instead of thinking of the future with vague optimism, it is important to explicitly separate the components. For example, one might say, "We're default dead, but we're counting on investors to save us." As you articulate this, it may trigger the same alarms in your head that it does in mine. If you set off those alarms sufficiently early, you may be able to avoid the fatal pinch.
What factors influence investor interest in a company, particularly regarding its growth and profitability?

It would be safe to be default dead if you could count on investors saving you. As a rule, their interest is a function of growth. If you have steep revenue growth, say over 5x a year, you can start to count on investors being interested even if you're not profitable.
Why is it important for businesses to have a backup plan for fundraising?

It is important for businesses to have a backup plan for fundraising because investors can be fickle, and you can never rely solely on them. Sometimes, something about your business may spook investors, even if your growth is strong. Therefore, no matter how good your growth is, you should never treat fundraising as more than a plan A. What factors contribute to a startup's growth rate beyond its spending habits?

What is one of the biggest mistakes startups make that can lead to their failure after raising funds?

One of the biggest mistakes startups make that can lead to their failure after raising funds is hiring too fast. Why do founders often overestimate the need to hire more employees for their startups?

Founders tell themselves they need to hire in order to grow. But most err on the side of overestimating this need rather than underestimating it. Why? Partly because there's so much work to do. What are the differing incentives between founders and venture capitalists after a funding round?

Founders who've just raised money are often encouraged to overhire by the VCs who funded them. Kill-or-cure strategies are optimal for VCs because they're protected by the portfolio effect. VCs want to blow you up, in one sense of the phrase or the other. But as a founder, your incentives are different. You want, above all, to survive.
What are common pitfalls that lead to the failure of startups?

Here's a common way startups die. They make something moderately appealing and have decent initial growth. They raise their first round fairly easily because the founders seem smart and the idea sounds plausible. But because the product is only moderately appealing, growth is okay but not great. The founders convince themselves that hiring a bunch of people is the way to boost growth. Their investors agree. But, because the product is only moderately appealing, the growth never comes. What is a more effective strategy for improving a product's appeal in its early stages?

What the company should have done is address the fundamental problem: that the product is only moderately appealing. Hiring people is rarely the way to fix that. What are some effective strategies for growth that founders can pursue for their startups?

Effective strategies for growth that founders can pursue for their startups include focusing on customer feedback, leveraging data analytics, or redesigning the product in the way only founders can. For many, if not most, startups, these paths to growth will be the ones that actually work.

How did your childhood perceptions of business success shape your understanding of real-world entrepreneurship?

Why is being overly aggressive not beneficial for the success of startups?

One case where it would help to be rapacious is when growth depends on that. What makes startups different is that usually it doesn't. Startups usually win by making something so great that people recommend it to their friends. Being rapacious not only doesn't help you do that, but probably hurts.
What mindset can founders adopt to balance kindness and business success?

If you're a founder, here's a deal you can make with yourself that will both make you happy and make your company successful. Tell yourself you can be as nice as you want, so long as you work hard on your growth rate to compensate. Most successful startups make that trade-off unconsciously. From running through their initial funding and then being unable to raise more, the underlying cause is usually slow growth or excessive spending rather than insufficient effort to extract money from existing customers.

How does transparency impact the relationship between investors and founders?

How does unpredictability in the startup world influence interpersonal behavior and relationships?

The effect of unpredictability is more subtle. It increases the work of being inconsistent. How is the trend of transparency and unpredictability manifesting beyond the startup world?
Fortunately, that future is not limited to the startup world. The startup world is more transparent and unpredictable than most, but almost everywhere, the trend is in that direction.
Is there a correlation between an investor's benevolence and their financial returns?

At what age did he discover his passion for math?

What motivates some students to engage with math problems differently than others?

What can help individuals identify their true passion or suitability for a career?

What is the primary function of the Corporate Development group within companies?
Corporate Development, also known as corp dev, is the group within companies that buys other companies. If you're talking to someone from corp dev, that's why, whether you realize it yet or not.
When is it appropriate for startups to engage with corporate development (corp dev)?

It's usually a mistake to talk to corp dev unless (a) you want to sell your company right now and (b) you're sufficiently likely to get an offer at an acceptable price. What common mistake do founders make when approached by corporate development teams?

But it's a mistake founders constantly make. When someone from corporate development wants to meet, the founders tell themselves they should at least find out what they want. Besides, they don't want to offend the big company by refusing to meet.
What should a company consider before meeting with corporate development representatives?

Why do founders often agree to meetings with corporate development representatives even when they don't intend to sell their company?

Most founders who get contacted by corporate development already know what it means. What strategies can help maintain motivation during challenging tasks?

How do corporate development professionals manipulate negotiation dynamics to their advantage?

Corporate development professionals often manipulate negotiation dynamics to their advantage by turning the tables on the other party. What strategies do corporate development teams use to acquire companies at lower prices?

Their tactics in pushing you down that slope are usually fairly brutal. Corp dev people's whole job is to buy companies, and they don't even get to choose which. What unethical tactics do corporate development professionals often use during negotiations?

What motivates startup investors to challenge outdated beliefs about potential investments?

Startup investors have extraordinary incentives for correcting obsolete beliefs. If they can realize before other investors that some apparently unpromising startup isn't, they can make a huge amount of money. But the incentives are more than just financial. Investors' opinions are explicitly tested: startups come to them, and they have to say yes or no, and then, fairly quickly, they learn whether they guessed right. The investors who say no to a Google (and there were several) will remember it for the rest of their lives.
How can turning comments into bets influence the accuracy of one's ideas?

Anyone who must, in some sense, bet on ideas rather than merely commenting on them has similar incentives. This means anyone who wants such incentives can have them by turning their comments into bets: if you write about a topic in some fairly durable and public form, you'll find you worry much more about getting things right than most people would in a casual conversation.
How can one guard against outdated beliefs in the face of unpredictable future discoveries?

Another trick I've found to protect myself against obsolete beliefs is to focus initially on people rather than ideas. Though the nature of future discoveries is hard to predict, I've found I can predict quite well what sort of people will make them. Good new ideas come from earnest, energetic, and independent-minded people.
What factors influenced your decision to invest in Airbnb despite initially believing it was a bad idea?

Betting on people over ideas has saved me countless times as an investor. We thought Airbnb was a bad idea, for example. But we could tell the founders were earnest, energetic, and independent-minded (indeed, almost pathologically so). So we suspended disbelief and funded them.
How can surrounding yourself with innovative individuals help you stay aware of the obsolescence of your beliefs?

This too seems a technique that should be generally applicable. Surround yourself with the sort of people from whom new ideas come. If you want to notice quickly when your beliefs become obsolete, you can't do better than to be friends with the people whose discoveries will make them so.
What should you be cautious about when your hypotheses become associated with your identity?

You should be cautious when your hypotheses become associated with your identity, especially if they become well-known enough that people start to identify them with you. You have to be extra skeptical about things you want to believe, and once a hypothesis starts to be identified with you, it will almost certainly start to fall into that category.
What criteria determine whether someone is considered "sufficiently expert" in a field?

In practice, "sufficiently expert" doesn't require one to be recognized as an expertâwhich is a trailing indicator in any case. In many fields, a year of focused work plus caring a lot would be enough.
What concerns does the author express about the effectiveness of reading multiple books?

I've read Villehardouin's chronicle of the Fourth Crusade at least two times, maybe three. And yet, if I had to write down everything I remember from it, I doubt it would amount to much more than a page. Multiply this times several hundred, and I get an uneasy feeling when I look at my bookshelves. What use is it to read all these books if I remember so little from them?
What prompted you to reflect on a specific question while reading Constance Reid's biography of Hilbert?

A few months ago, as I was reading Constance Reid's excellent biography of Hilbert, I figured out, if not the answer to this question, at least something that made me feel better about it. She writes:
What was Hilbert's perspective on the importance of problem formulation in mathematics education?

Hilbert had no patience with mathematical lectures that filled the students with facts but did not teach them how to frame a problem and solve it. He often used to tell them that "a perfect formulation of a problem is already half its solution."
What factors contributed to the author's belief in the idea discussed in the book?

But how had I come to believe in this idea in the first place? A combination of my own experience and other things I'd readânone of which I could at that moment remember! Eventually, I'd forget that Hilbert had confirmed it too. However, my increased belief in the importance of this idea would remain something I'd learned from this book, even after I'd forgotten I'd learned it.
How do reading and experiences shape our understanding of the world, even if we forget them?

Reading and experience train your model of the world. Even if you forget the experience or what you read, its effect on your model of the world persists. Your mind is like a compiled program whose source youâve lost. It works, but you don't know why.
What realization did the author come to regarding their memory of what they have read?
This is one of those things that seems obvious in retrospect. But it was a surprise to me and presumably would be to anyone else who felt uneasy about (apparently) forgetting so much they'd read.
Why is it valuable to reread important books at different stages of life?

For example, reading and experience are usually "compiled" at the time they happen, using the state of your brain at that time. The same book would get compiled differently at different points in your life, which means it is very much worth reading important books multiple times. I always used to feel some misgivings about rereading books; I unconsciously lumped reading together with work like carpentry, where having to do something again is a sign you did it wrong the first time. Whereas now, the phrase "already read" seems almost ill-formed.
How might advancements in technology change the way people engage with their past experiences?

Intriguingly, this implication isn't limited to books. Technology will increasingly make it possible to relive our experiences. When people do that today, it's usually to enjoy them again (e.g., when looking at pictures of a trip) or to find the origin of some bug in their compiled code (e.g., when Stephen Fry succeeded in remembering the childhood trauma that prevented him from singing). But as technologies for recording and playing back your life improve, it may become common for people to relive experiences without any goal in mind, simply to learn from them again as one might when rereading a book.
What challenges do startups face when they have limited runway despite having funds in the bank?

Many startups go through a point a few months before they die where, although they have a significant amount of money in the bank, they're also losing a lot each month, and revenue growth is either nonexistent or mediocre. The company has, say, 6 months of runway. Or, to put it more brutally, 6 months before they're out of business. They expect to avoid that by raising more from investors.
What is the current perception of the company's performance after its initial fundraising?

The company is now starting to read as a failure. The first time it raised money, it was neither a success nor a failure; it was too early to ask. Now it's possible to ask that question, and the default answer is failure because, at this point, that is the default outcome.
What term does the author use to describe a critical situation that founders may encounter?

I'm going to call the situation I described in the first paragraph "the fatal pinch." I try to resist coining phrases, but making up a name for this situation may snap founders into realizing when they're in it.
What is the impact of overestimating fundraising opportunities on a startup's path to profitability?

One of the things that makes the fatal pinch so dangerous is that it's self-reinforcing. Founders overestimate their chances of raising more money, and so are slack about reaching profitability, which further decreases their chances of raising money.
How can startup founders prevent falling into the trap of the fatal pinch when raising funds?

Now that you know about the fatal pinch, how do you avoid it? Y Combinator tells founders who raise money to act as if it's the last they'll ever get. The self-reinforcing nature of this situation works the other way too: the less you need further investment, the easier it is to get.
When is it advisable to consider shutting down a company?

You should shut down the company if you're certain it will fail no matter what you do. Then, at least you can give back the money you have left and save yourself however many months you would have spent riding it down.
When is it appropriate to make the decision to fire an employee?
Deciding to fire people is usually hard, but there's one case in which it shouldn't be: when there are people you already know you should fire but you're in denial about it. If so, now's the time.
What are the potential solutions for managing a budget shortfall in a company?
You have three options: you either have to fire good people, get some or all of the employees to take less salary for a while, or increase revenues.
What are the potential drawbacks of cutting salaries as a solution to financial issues in a company?

Cutting salaries as a solution to financial issues in a company is a weak approach that will only work when the problem isn't too severe. If your current trajectory won't quite get you to profitability but you can get over the threshold by cutting salaries a little, you might be able to make the case to everyone for doing it. Otherwise, you're probably just postponing the problem, and that will be obvious to the people whose salaries you're proposing to cut.
What should a company do if it realizes it has overhired before establishing a clear direction for its product?

You should lean more toward firing people if the source of your trouble is overhiring. If you went out and hired 15 people before you even knew what you were building, you've created a broken company. You need to figure out what you're building, and it will probably be easier to do that with a handful of people than with 15. Plus, those 15 people might not even be the ones you need for whatever you end up building. So the solution may be to shrink and then figure out what direction to grow in. After all, you're not doing those 15 people any favors if you fly the company into the ground with them aboard. They'll all lose their jobs eventually, along with all the time they expended on this doomed company.
What strategy should a startup with a small team consider to improve its revenue generation?

If you only have a handful of people, it may be better to focus on trying to make more money. It may seem facile to suggest a startup make more money, as if that could be done for the asking. Usually, a startup is already trying as hard as it can to sell whatever it sells. What I'm suggesting here is not so much to try harder to make money but to try to make money in a different way. For example, if you have only one person selling while the rest are writing code, consider having everyone work on selling. What good will more code do you when you're out of business? If you have to write code to close a certain deal, go ahead; that follows from everyone working on selling. But only work on whatever will get you the most revenue the soonest.
How can startups leverage their expertise to generate revenue beyond traditional product sales?

Another way to make money differently is to sell different things, and in particular, to do more consulting work. I say "consulting" because there is a long slippery slope from making products to pure consulting, and you don't have to go far down it before you start to offer something really attractive to customers. Although your product may not be very appealing yet, if you're a startup, your programmers will often be way better than the ones your customers have. Or you may have expertise in some new field they don't understand. So if you change your sales conversations just a little from "Do you want to buy our product?" to "What do you need that you'd pay a lot for?" you may find it's suddenly a lot easier to extract money from customers.
What should you focus on while exploring individual users' needs for your company?

As you explore individual users' needs for your company, keep your eyes open for narrow openings that have wide vistas beyond. This approach may help you uncover insights that define your company. Don't expect it to be straightforward, but remain attentive to the nuances of user experiences.
What challenges do consultants face due to the high demand for custom work?

There is usually so much demand for custom work that, unless you're really incompetent, there has to be some point down the slope of consulting at which you can survive. But I didn't use the term slippery slope by accident; customers' insatiable demand for custom work will always be pushing you toward the bottom. So while you'll probably survive, the problem now becomes to survive with the least damage and distraction.
What challenges do companies face when they are not expected to generate revenue in their early years?

There are a handful of companies that can't reasonably expect to make money for the first year or two because what they're building takes so long. For these companies, substitute "progress" for "revenue growth." You're not one of these companies unless your initial investors agreed in advance that you were. And frankly, even these companies wish they weren't, because the illiquidity of "progress" puts them at the mercy of investors.
What should a startup do if they have 8 months of runway or less and are unsure about their fundraising prospects?

If you have 8 months of runway or less and are unsure about your fundraising prospects, the best approach is to seek funding immediately. There's a variant of the fatal pinch where your existing investors help you along by promising to invest more, or rather, where you read them as promising to invest more while they think they're just mentioning the possibility. By trying to secure the money right now, you'll either receive the funds, which solves the immediate problem, or at least prevent your investors from helping you remain in denial about your fundraising prospects.
How has the internet changed the way we perceive and encounter meanness in public discourse?

Meanness isn't rare. In fact, one of the things the internet has shown us is how mean people can be. A few decades ago, only famous people and professional writers got to publish their opinions. Now everyone can, and we can all see the consequences of this shift in public discourse.
What insights does Jessica, cofounder of Y Combinator, have about the relationship between character and success in startup founders?

My wife and Y Combinator cofounder Jessica is one of those rare people who have x-ray vision for character. Being married to her is like standing next to an airport baggage scanner. She came to the startup world from investment banking, and she has always been struck by how consistently successful startup founders turn out to be good people and how consistently bad people fail as startup founders.
Why does the author believe that engaging in fights is unproductive?

I think there are several reasons. One is that being mean makes you stupid. That's why I hate fights. You never do your best work in a fight because fights are not sufficiently general. Winning is always a function of the situation and the people involved. You don't win fights by thinking of big ideas but by thinking of tricks that work in one particular case. And yet fighting is just as much work as thinking about real problems, which is particularly painful to someone who cares how their brain is used: your brain goes fast, but you get nowhere, like a car spinning its wheels.
How do successful startups typically achieve victory in their industry?
Startups don't win by attacking; they win by transcending. There are exceptions, of course, but usually the way to win is to race ahead, not to stop and fight.
Why do mean founders struggle to build successful teams?

Another reason mean founders lose is that they can't get the best people to work for them. They can hire people who will put up with them because they need a job. However, the best people have other options. A mean person can't convince the best people to work for him unless he is super convincing. While having the best people helps any organization, it's critical for startups.
What motivates individuals to persist in their efforts to make a difference?

The ones who keep going are driven by something else. They may not say so explicitly, but they're usually trying to improve the world. This means that people with a desire to improve the world have a natural advantage.
How has the concept of success evolved in relation to resource control throughout history?

For most of history, success meant control of scarce resources. One achieved that by fighting, whether literally in the case of pastoral nomads driving hunter-gatherers into marginal lands, or metaphorically in the case of Gilded Age financiers contending with one another to assemble railroad monopolies. For most of history, success meant success at zero-sum games. In most of them, meanness was not a handicap but probably an advantage.
What is the importance of innovation in today's competitive landscape compared to traditional zero-sum games?
That is changing. Increasingly, the games that matter are not zero-sum. You win not by fighting to get control of a scarce resource, but by having new ideas and building new things.
What conditions are necessary for new ideas to flourish and be valued in society?

There have long been games where you won by having new ideas. In the third century BC, Archimedes won by doing that, at least until an invading Roman army killed him. This illustrates why this change is happening: for new ideas to matter, you need a certain degree of civil order. And not just the absence of war; you also need to prevent the sort of economic violence that nineteenth-century magnates practiced against one another and that communist countries practiced against their citizens. People need to feel that what they create can't be stolen.
How is the relationship between meanness and success evolving in contemporary society?

The relationship between meanness and success is evolving in contemporary society. That has always been the case for thinkers, which is why this trend began with them. When you think of successful people from history who weren't ruthless, you get mathematicians, writers, and artists. The exciting thing is that their modus operandi seems to be spreading. The games played by intellectuals are leaking into the real world, and this is reversing the historical polarity of the relationship between meanness and success.
What lesson did the author learn about the impact of meanness on success while raising their children?

Iâm really glad I stopped to think about this. Jessica and I have always worked hard to teach our kids not to be mean. We tolerate noise, mess, and junk food, but not meanness. And now I have both an additional reason to crack down on it and an additional argument to use when I do: that being mean makes you fail.
What motivates founders to believe in the impact of their startups, despite the likelihood that not all improve the world?

It's unlikely that every successful startup improves the world. But their founders, like parents, truly believe they do. Successful founders are in love with their companies. And while this sort of love is as blind as the love people have for one another, it is genuine.
What happened to Archimedes during the Roman conquest of Syracuse?
To be fair, the Romans didn't mean to kill Archimedes. The Roman commander specifically ordered that he be spared, but he got killed in the chaos anyway.
What is the total valuation and funding raised by Y Combinator's startups?

Y Combinator has now funded 564 startups, including the current batch, which has 53. The total valuation of the 287 that have valuations (either by raising an equity round, getting acquired, or dying) is about $11.7 billion, and the 511 prior to the current batch have collectively raised about $1.7 billion.
What is the distribution of funding among startups in the current market?

As usual, those numbers are dominated by a few big winners. The top 10 startups account for 8.6 of that 11.7 billion. However, there is a peloton of younger startups behind them. There are about 40 more that have a shot at being really big.
What led to the recent improvements in YC's operational efficiency and scalability?

Several journalists have tried to interpret that as evidence for some macro story they were telling, but the reason had nothing to do with any external trend. The reason was that we discovered we were using an nÂ² algorithm, and we needed to buy time to fix it. Fortunately, we've come up with several techniques for sharding YC, and the problem now seems to be fixed. With a new, more scalable model and only 53 companies, the current batch feels like a walk in the park. I'd guess we can grow another 2 or 3x before hitting the next bottleneck.
How does funding a large number of startups enable the identification of early investment trends?

One consequence of funding such a large number of startups is that we see trends early. Since fundraising is one of the main things we help startups with, we're in a good position to notice trends in investing.
What are the key factors contributing to the changes in startup funding?
There are two big forces driving change in startup funding: it's becoming cheaper to start a startup, and startups are becoming a more normal thing to do.
How has the perception of entrepreneurship changed from 1986 to the present day?

When I graduated from college in 1986, there were essentially two options: get a job or go to grad school. Now there's a third: start your own company. That's a big change. In principle, it was possible to start your own company in 1986 too, but it didn't seem like a real possibility. It seemed possible to start a consulting company or a niche product company, but it didn't seem possible to start a company that would become big.
What type of social change is the paragraph referring to, and how significant is its potential impact?

That kind of change, from 2 paths to 3, is the sort of big social shift that only happens once every few generations. I think we're still at the beginning of this one. It's hard to predict how big a deal it will be. As big a deal as the Industrial Revolution? Maybe. Probably not. But it will be a big enough deal that it takes almost everyone by surprise because those big social shifts always do.
What is the significance of smaller companies forming networks in various industries, and how long has this trend been occurring?

Networks of smaller companies are significant as they foster collaboration and innovation across various industries. This process is not just something happening now in Silicon Valley; it started decades ago and is occurring as far afield as the car industry. It has a long way to run.
What factors contribute to the increasing prevalence of startups in today's economy?

The other big driver of change is that startups are becoming cheaper to start. In fact, the decreasing cost of starting a startup is one of the reasons startups are becoming a more normal thing to do.
How does the reduced financial requirement for startups affect the power dynamics between founders and investors?

The fact that startups need less money means founders will increasingly have the upper hand over investors. You still need just as much of their energy and imagination, but they don't need as much of your money. Because founders have the upper hand, they'll retain an increasingly large share of the stock in their companies.
Will the potential decrease in startup ownership percentages for investors lead to lower overall profits?

Does that mean investors will make less money? Not necessarily, because there will be more good startups. The total amount of desirable startup stock available to investors will probably increase because the number of desirable startups will probably grow faster than the percentage they sell to investors shrinks.
What impact could the emergence of more talented founders have on the number of successful startups each year?
There might be 10x or even 50x more good founders out there. As more of them go ahead and start startups, those 15 big hits a year could easily become 50 or even 100.
Will high valuations limit investment returns, or can top firms still achieve high returns through strategic selections?

What about returns, though? Are we heading for a world in which returns will be pinched by increasingly high valuations? I think the top firms will actually make more money than they have in the past. High returns don't come from investing at low valuations; they come from investing in the companies that do really well. So if there are more of those to be had each year, the best pickers should have more hits.
How will increased variability in the VC business impact firms' ability to attract startups?

Increased variability in the VC business means that firms that can recognize and attract the best startups will do even better, as there will be more opportunities to identify and engage with them. Conversely, less capable firms will continue to receive the leftovers, as they do now, but will likely pay a higher price for these less desirable startups.
How has the landscape for angel investing changed in recent years?

The landscape for angel investing has changed significantly in recent years. It used to be challenging to be an angel investor; you couldn't access the best deals unless you got lucky, like Andy Bechtolsheim. When you did invest in a startup, VCs might try to strip you of your stock when they arrived later. Now, an angel can go to something like Demo Day or AngelList and have access to the same deals VCs do. The days when VCs could wash angels out of the cap table are long gone.
How does the decreasing cost of failure influence the number of startups and their success rates?

The number of big hits will probably not grow linearly with the total number of new startups for two reasons. One is that the scariness of starting a startup in the old days was a pretty effective filter. Now that the cost of failing is becoming lower, we should expect founders to pursue it more. That's not a bad thing. It's common in technology for an innovation that decreases the cost of failure to increase the number of failures and yet leave you net ahead.
Why might the growth in the number of startups not lead to a proportional increase in successful big hits?

The other reason the number of big hits won't grow proportionately to the number of startups is that there will start to be an increasing number of idea clashes. Although the finiteness of the number of good ideas is not the reason there are only 15 big hits a year, the number has to be finite. The more startups there are, the more we'll see multiple companies doing the same thing at the same time. It will be interesting, in a bad way, if idea clashes become a lot more common.
How will the structure of successful startups evolve in response to early failures?

Mostly because of the increasing number of early failures, the startup business of the future won't simply be the same shape, scaled up. What used to be an obelisk will become a pyramid. It will be a little wider at the top, but a lot wider at the bottom.
Why do venture capitalists tend to invest excessively at the series A stage?

Right now, VCs often knowingly invest too much money at the series A stage. They do it because they feel they need to get a big chunk of each series A company to compensate for the opportunity cost of the board seat it consumes. This means that when there is a lot of competition for a deal, the number that moves is the valuation (and thus the amount invested) rather than the percentage of the company being sold. Consequently, especially in the case of more promising startups, series A investors often make companies take more money than they want.
What factors have contributed to the changing dynamics between venture capitalists and founders in funding rounds?

The dynamics between venture capitalists and founders have changed due to several factors. Like a lot of bad things, this didn't happen intentionally. The VC business backed into it as their initial assumptions gradually became obsolete. The traditions and financial models of the VC business were established when founders needed investors more. In those days, it was natural for founders to sell VCs a big chunk of their company in the Series A round. Now, founders would prefer to sell less, and VCs are digging in their heels because they're not sure if they can make money buying less than 20% of each Series A company.
What potential shift in Series A investment strategies could benefit early-stage venture capitalists?

The reason I describe this as a danger is that Series A investors are increasingly at odds with the startups they supposedly serve, and that tends to come back to bite you eventually. The reason I describe it as an opportunity is that there is now a lot of potential energy built up, as the market has moved away from VCs' traditional business model. This means the first VC to break ranks and start to do Series A rounds for as much equity as founders want to sell (and with no "option pool" that comes only from the founders' shares) stands to reap huge benefits.
How could a top-tier VC firm alter its investment strategy to gain a competitive advantage in attracting the best startups?

If one top-tier VC firm started to do Series A rounds that began from the amount the company needed to raise and let the percentage acquired vary with the market, instead of the other way around, they'd instantly get almost all the best startups. And that's where the money is.
What should investors focus on to identify new investment opportunities?

If you want to find new opportunities for investing, look for things founders complain about. Founders are your customers, and the things they complain about are unsatisfied demand. I've given two examples of things founders complain about mostâinvestors who take too long to make up their minds and excessive dilution in Series A roundsâso those are good places to look now. But the more general recipe is: do something founders want.
What is the primary indicator of success for a startup, according to the author?

I realize that revenue, and not fundraising, is the proper test of success for a startup. The reason we quote statistics about fundraising is that those are the numbers we have. We couldn't talk meaningfully about revenues without including the numbers from the most successful startups, and we don't have those. We often discuss revenue growth with earlier-stage startups because that's how we gauge their progress, but when companies reach a certain size, it gets presumptuous for a seed investor to do that.
How do market capitalizations relate to company revenues and funding round valuations?

In any case, companies' market caps do eventually become a function of revenues, and post-money valuations of funding rounds are at least guesses by professionals about where those market caps will end up.
Why do only 287 companies have established valuations despite many having raised funds?

The reason only 287 companies have valuations is that the rest have mostly raised money on convertible notes. Although convertible notes often have valuation caps, a valuation cap is merely an upper bound on a valuation.
What role has the shift from corporate employment to entrepreneurship played in the rising economic inequality in the US since the mid-twentieth century?

This trend is one of the main causes of the increase in economic inequality in the US since the mid-twentieth century. The person who would have been the general manager of the X division of Megacorp in 1950 is now the founder of the X company and owns significant equity in it.
How might increasing idea clashes among startups redefine the competitive landscape for them?

If idea clashes got bad enough, it could change what it means to be a startup. We currently advise startups mostly to ignore competitors. We tell them startups are competitive like running, not like soccer; you don't have to go and steal the ball away from the other team. But if idea clashes became common enough, maybe you'd start to have to. That would be unfortunate.
What is the core advice derived from the common regrets of individuals reflecting on their lives?

If you had to compress them into a single piece of advice, it might be: don't be a cog. The five regrets paint a portrait of post-industrial man, who shrinks himself into a shape that fits his circumstances, then turns dutifully until he stops.
What types of mistakes often lead to feelings of regret in life?

The alarming thing is that the mistakes that produce these regrets are all errors of omission. You forget your dreams, ignore your family, suppress your feelings, neglect your friends, and forget to be happy. Errors of omission are a particularly dangerous type of mistake because you make them by default.
What does the speaker prioritize more in their communication skills, speaking or having good ideas?

I'm not a very good speaker. I say "um" a lot. Sometimes I have to pause when I lose my train of thought. I wish I were a better speaker. But I don't wish I were a better speaker like I wish I were a better writer. What I really want is to have good ideas, and that's a much bigger part of being a good writer than being a good speaker.
What realization did the speaker have after comparing their presentation to another speaker's performance?

I first noticed this at a conference several years ago. There was another speaker who was much better than me. He had all of us roaring with laughter. I seemed awkward and halting by comparison. Afterward, I put my talk online like I usually do. As I was doing it, I tried to imagine what a transcript of the other guy's talk would be like, and it was only then I realized he hadn't said very much.
What realization did the speaker have about the importance of ideas in speaking compared to writing?
Maybe this would have been obvious to someone who knew more about speaking, but it was a revelation to me how much less ideas mattered in speaking than in writing.
What realization did the speaker have after listening to a famous speaker?

A few years later, I heard a talk by someone who was not merely a better speaker than me, but a famous speaker. Boy, was he good. So I decided I'd pay close attention to what he said to learn how he did it. After about ten sentences, I found myself thinking, "I don't want to be a good speaker."
How does the process of writing compare to speaking in front of a live audience in terms of idea generation?

Occasionally, the stimulation of talking to a live audience makes you think of new things, but in general, this is not going to generate ideas as well as writing does, where you can spend as long on each sentence as you want.
What unique value do talks provide compared to written sources?

So are talks useless? They're certainly inferior to the written word as a source of ideas. But that's not all talks are good for. When I go to a talk, it's usually because I'm interested in the speaker. Listening to a talk is the closest most of us can get to having a conversation with someone like the president, who doesn't have time to meet individually with all the people who want to meet him.
What role does public speaking play in motivation and emotional influence?

Talks are also good at motivating me to do things. It's probably no coincidence that so many famous speakers are described as motivational speakers. That may be what public speaking is really for; it's probably what it was originally for. The emotional reactions you can elicit with a talk can be a powerful force. I wish I could say that this force was more often used for good than ill, but I'm not sure.
What distinguishes the audience's expectations at academic talks from those at other types of presentations?

While the audience at an academic talk might appreciate a joke, they will (or at least should) make a conscious effort to see what new ideas you're presenting. This distinguishes their expectations from those at other types of presentations, where entertainment or engagement might take precedence over the introduction of new concepts.
How can reading a talk out loud improve its quality?

Robert Morris points out that there is a way in which practicing talks makes them better: reading a talk out loud can expose awkward parts. I agree, and in fact, I read most things I write out loud at least once for that reason.
At what audience size does participation begin to negatively impact individual intelligence during discussions?

For sufficiently small audiences, it may not be true that being part of an audience makes people dumber. The real decline seems to set in when the audience gets too big for the talk to feel like a conversationâmaybe around 10 people.
Why was Y Combinator established in Mountain View instead of Berkeley?

If we'd had enough time to do what we wanted, Y Combinator would have been in Berkeley. That was our favorite part of the Bay Area. But we didn't have time to get a building in Berkeley. We didn't have time to get our own building anywhere. The only way to get enough space in time was to convince Trevor to let us take over part of his (as it then seemed) giant building in Mountain View. Yet again we lucked out because Mountain View turned out to be the ideal place to put something like YC. But even then we barely made it. The first dinner in California, we had to warn all the founders not to touch the walls because the paint was still wet.
What was the unique legal case involving a food shop owner and a student in Ooka Tadasuke's court?

As a child, I read a book of stories about a famous judge in eighteenth-century Japan called Ooka Tadasuke. One of the cases he decided was brought by the owner of a food shop. A poor student, who could afford only rice, was eating his rice while enjoying the delicious cooking smells coming from the food shop. The owner wanted the student to pay for the smells he was enjoying.
How could the commercialization of smells be applied in a future scenario, such as living on a moon base?

It sounds ridiculous to us to treat smells as property. However, I can imagine scenarios in which one could charge for smells. Imagine we were living on a moon base where we had to buy air by the liter. I could envision air suppliers adding scents at an extra charge.
How has the concept of property evolved over time?

The concept of property depends on what society treats as property. This can change over time, and it has changed significantly. Humans may have always treated small items carried on one's person as property. However, hunter-gatherers did not treat land, for example, as property in the same way we do today.
What motivates the decision-making of executives in labels and studios, and how does it impact their response to technological change?

The reason I say short-term greed is that the underlying problem with the labels and studios is that the people who run them are driven by bonuses rather than equity. If they were driven by equity, they'd be looking for ways to take advantage of technological change instead of fighting it. But building new things takes too long. Their bonuses depend on this year's revenues, and the best way to increase those is to extract more money from stuff they do already.
What does it indicate about someone's definition of property when they engage in mass lawsuits and advocate for laws that could disrupt the Internet?

Ultimately, it comes down to common sense. When you're abusing the legal system by trying to use mass lawsuits against randomly chosen people as a form of exemplary punishment, or lobbying for laws that would break the Internet if they passed, that's ipso facto evidence you're using a definition of property that doesn't work.
How does technological progress influence the definition of property and society's ability to adapt to these changes?

The change in the definition of property is driven mostly by technological progress. Since technological progress is accelerating, the rate of change in the definition of property will presumably increase as well. This makes it all the more important for societies to respond gracefully to such changes, as they will come at an ever-increasing rate.
How does the definition of property impact technological development, according to historical examples?

The state of technology isn't simply a function of the definition of property; they each constrain the other. However, you can't mess with the definition of property without affecting (and probably harming) the state of technology. The history of the USSR offers a vivid illustration of that.
How did the size of web pages in 1998 compare to modern screens?
The first thing one notices is how tiny the pages are. Screens were a lot smaller in 1998. If I remember correctly, our front page used to just fit in the size window people typically used then.
What challenges did web designers face in terms of typography before the introduction of antialiased fonts in browsers?
Browsers at the time (with IE 6 still three years in the future) had few fonts, and they weren't antialiased. If you wanted to make pages that looked good, you had to render display text as images.
Why did the directory of web designers include a ringer among the listings?

In our directory of web designers, merchants could hire to build stores for them. We inserted him as a ringer in case some competitor tried to spam our web designers. We assumed his logo would deter any actual customers, but it did not.
How did businesses in the 90s primarily attract users before the rise of online marketing?

Back in the 90s, to get users, you had to get mentioned in magazines and newspapers. There were not the same ways to get found online that there are today. So, we used to pay a lot for advertising in print media to attract attention and gain users.
What were the major search engines before the rise of Google?

Before the rise of Google, there were only seven major search engines that mattered: Yahoo, AltaVista, Excite, WebCrawler, InfoSeek, Lycos, and HotBot. (I don't think the term SEO had been coined yet.) Notice anything missing? Google was incorporated that September.
What was the financial impact of Frederick's of Hollywood on the bandwidth costs for the service provider?

Needless to say, Frederick's of Hollywood got the most traffic. We charged a flat fee of $300/month for big stores, so it was a little alarming to have users who generated lots of traffic. I once calculated how much Frederick's was costing us in bandwidth, and it was about $300/month.
What were the challenges faced by the team in managing server resources in their office environment during the late 1990s?

Since we hosted all the stores, which together were getting just over 10 million page views per month in June 1998, we consumed what at the time seemed a lot of bandwidth. We had 2 T1s (3 Mb/sec) coming into our offices. In those days, there was no AWS. Even colocating servers seemed too risky, considering how often things went wrong with them. So we had our servers in our offices. Or more precisely, in Trevor's office. In return for the unique privilege of sharing his office with no other humans, he had to share it with 6 shrieking tower servers. His office was nicknamed the Hot Tub on account of the heat they generated. Most days, his stack of window air conditioners could keep up.
How did continuous releases impact the way software versioning was perceived in the trade press?

Since we did continuous releases, our software didn't actually have versions. But in those days, the trade press expected versions, so we made them up. If we wanted to get lots of attention, we made the version number higher.
How do patents impact technological progress, and what concerns have arisen regarding their misuse?

I have never been 100% sure whether patents help or hinder technological progress. When I was a kid, I thought they helped. I believed they protected inventors from having their ideas stolen by big companies. Maybe that was truer in the past, when more things were physical. But regardless of whether patents are, in general, a good thing, there do seem to be bad ways of using them. Since bad uses of patents seem to be increasing, there is an increasing call for patent reform.
What alternative approach can be taken to address issues related to patent reform?

The problem with patent reform is that it has to go through the government. That tends to be slow. But recently, I realized we can also attack the problem downstream. As well as pinching off the stream of patents at the point where they're issued, we may, in some cases, be able to pinch it off at the point where they're used.
How can companies be encouraged to avoid unethical competitive practices?

The way to do it is to get the companies that are above pulling this sort of trick to pledge publicly not to. Then the ones that won't make such a pledge will be very conspicuous. Potential employees won't want to work for them. And investors, too, will be able to see that they're the sort of company that competes by litigation rather than by making good products.
What is the significance of a company's public ethical standards in attracting top talent?

A company's public ethical standards are significant in attracting top talent. The patent pledge is not legally binding; it's like Google's "Don't be evil." They don't define what evil is, but by publicly stating that, they're indicating their willingness to be held to a standard that, say, Altria is not. Though constraining, "Don't be evil" has been good for Google. Technology companies win by attracting the most productive people, and the most productive individuals are drawn to employers who hold themselves to a higher standard than the law requires.
Why do leading technology companies like Google and Facebook refrain from suing startups for patent infringement?

Most technology companies wouldn't sink to using patents on startups. You don't see Google or Facebook suing startups for patent infringement. They don't need to. For the better technology companies, the patent pledge requires no change in behavior. They're just promising to do what they'd do anyway. When all the companies that won't use patents on startups have said so, the holdouts will be very conspicuous.
What issue does the patent pledge address that is considered more serious than the problem of patent trolls?

The patent pledge doesn't fix every problem with patents. It won't stop patent trolls, for example; they're already pariahs. But the problem the patent pledge does fix may be more serious than the problem of patent trolls. Patent trolls are just parasites. A clumsy parasite may occasionally kill the host, but that's not its goal. Whereas companies that sue startups for patent infringement generally do it with the explicit goal of keeping their product off the market.
How can individuals take action against companies that hinder innovation through patent practices?

Companies that use patents on startups are attacking innovation at the root. Now there's something any individual can do about this problem, without waiting for the government: ask companies where they stand.
Why is common sense important in interpreting the pledge?

Because the pledge is deliberately vague, we're going to need common sense when interpreting it. And even more vice versa: the pledge is vague in order to make people use common sense when interpreting it.
What insights did you gain from reviewing your email exchange with Fred regarding the Airbnb investment?

Reading Fred's post made me go back and look at the emails I exchanged with him at the time, trying to convince him to invest in Airbnb. It was quite interesting to read; you can see Fred's mind at work as he circles the deal.
What unique insight does the email exchange between Fred and the Airbnb founders provide about the startup investment process?

Fred and the Airbnb founders have generously agreed to let me publish this email exchange (with one sentence redacted about something that's strategically important to Airbnb and not an important part of the conversation). It's an interesting illustration of an element of the startup ecosystem that few, except the participants, ever see: investors trying to convince one another to invest in their portfolio companies. Hundreds, if not thousands, of conversations of this type are happening now, but if one has ever been published, I haven't seen it. The Airbnbs themselves never even saw these emails at the time.
Which startup is currently meeting users in New York City, and why is this significant?

One of the startups from the batch that just started, AirbedAndBreakfast, is in NYC right now meeting their users. NYC is their biggest market, which makes this significant. I'd recommend meeting them if your schedule allows.
What is the current status of the airbed project discussion among your team?
We are having a bit of a debate within our partnership about the airbed concept. We'll finish that debate tomorrow in our weekly meeting and get back to you with our thoughts.
What does winning the first poll among YC startups indicate about the Airbeds' potential for success?

The Airbeds just won the first poll among all the YC startups in their batch by a landslide. In the past, this has not been a 100% indicator of success (if only anything were), but it is much better than random.
What types of accommodations contribute to a significant market opportunity in short-term rentals?
However, if you include short-term room rentals, second home rentals, bed and breakfasts, and other similar classes of accommodations, you arrive at a significant market opportunity.
What did users in NYC indicate about their need for rentals in relation to their financial situations?

Users in NYC indicated that many of them actually needed to do these rentals to pay their rents. This observation was made after I asked them about the most significant thing they had observed during their recent trip to NYC, highlighting the counter-cyclical nature of the rental market.
What progress has been made in the transition from private accommodations to hotel options?
I know you're skeptical they'll ever get hotels, but there's a continuum between private sofas and hotel rooms, and they have just moved one step further along it.
What challenges arise when trying to categorize devices like iPhones and iPads under a single term?

I was thinking recently about how inconvenient it is not to have a general term for iPhones, iPads, and the corresponding devices running Android. The closest to a general term seems to be "mobile devices," but that (a) applies to any mobile phone and (b) doesn't really capture what's distinctive about the iPad.
How has the introduction of the iPhone influenced our perception of the iPad and mobile devices?

After a few seconds, it struck me that what we'll end up calling these things is tablets. The only reason we even consider calling them "mobile devices" is that the iPhone preceded the iPad. If the iPad had come first, we wouldn't think of the iPhone as a phone; we'd think of it as a tablet small enough to hold up to your ear.
How is the iPhone changing the way we perceive traditional devices?

The iPhone isn't so much a phone as a replacement for a phone. That's an important distinction because it's an early instance of what will become a common pattern. Many, if not most, of the special-purpose objects around us are going to be replaced by apps running on tablets.
What innovative features of the iPad could potentially replace traditional reading glasses and bathroom scales?

The fact that you can change font sizes easily means the iPad effectively replaces reading glasses. I wouldn't be surprised if, by playing some clever tricks with the accelerometer, you could even replace the bathroom scale.
What impact has the rise of software-driven devices like the iPhone and iPad had on the evolution of technology?

The rise of software-driven devices like the iPhone and iPad has significantly impacted the evolution of technology by describing the increasing tendency of physical machinery to be replaced by what we would now call software. The reason tablets are going to take over the world is not (just) that Steve Jobs and Co. are industrial design wizards, but because they have this force behind them. The iPhone and the iPad have effectively drilled a hole that will allow ephemeralization to flow into a lot of new areas. No one who has studied the history of technology would want to underestimate the power of that force.
What concerns arise regarding Apple's influence in the tech industry, and how can competitors effectively challenge it?

I worry about the power Apple could have with this force behind them. I don't want to see another era of client monoculture like the Microsoft one in the 80s and 90s. But if ephemeralization is one of the main forces driving the spread of tablets, that suggests a way to compete with Apple: be a better platform for it.
How can tablet manufacturers enhance their devices to foster innovative uses by developers?

It has turned out to be a great thing that Apple tablets have accelerometers in them. Developers have used the accelerometer in ways Apple could never have imagined. That's the nature of platforms. The more versatile the tool, the less you can predict how people will use it. So tablet makers should be thinking: what else can we put in there? Not merely hardware, but software too. What else can we give developers access to? Give hackers an inch and they'll take you a mile.
What is the relationship between technological progress and societal values regarding desirable and undesirable outcomes?

We wouldn't want to stop it. It's the same process that cures diseases: technological progress. Technological progress means making things do more of what we want. When the thing we want is something we want to want, we consider technological progress good. If some new technique makes solar cells x% more efficient, that seems strictly better. When progress concentrates something we don't want to want â when it transforms opium into heroin â it seems bad. But it's the same process at work.
How has the level of addiction in the world changed over the past 40 years, and what might this imply for the future?

The world is more addictive than it was 40 years ago. Unless the forms of technological progress that produced these things are subject to different laws than technological progress in general, the world will get more addictive in the next 40 years than it did in the last 40.
What does the paragraph suggest about societal perceptions of living well versus living poorly?

These two senses are already quite far apart. Already, someone trying to live well would seem eccentrically abstemious in most of the US. That phenomenon is only going to become more pronounced. You can probably take it as a rule of thumb from now on that if people don't think you're weird, you're living badly.
How has the perception of smoking evolved over the past two decades?

As knowledge spread about the dangers of smoking, customs changed. In the last 20 years, smoking has been transformed from something that seemed totally normal into a rather seedy habit: from something movie stars did in publicity shots to something small huddles of addicts do outside the doors of office buildings. A lot of the change was due to legislation, of course, but the legislation couldn't have happened if customs hadn't already changed.
What is the relationship between the evolution of social antibodies and the pace of technological progress?

It took a while, thoughâon the order of 100 years. Unless the rate at which social antibodies evolve can increase to match the accelerating rate at which technological progress throws off new addictions, we'll be increasingly unable to rely on customs to protect us.
Why has the author shifted from running to hiking as their preferred form of exercise?

My latest trick is taking long hikes. I used to think running was a better form of exercise than hiking because it took less time. Now, the slowness of hiking seems an advantage because the longer I spend on the trail, the longer I have to think without interruption.
How does the author view the relationship between addiction and productivity in a rapidly changing world?

Sounds pretty eccentric, doesn't it? It always will when you're trying to solve problems where there are no customs yet to guide you. Maybe I can't plead Occam's razor; maybe I'm simply eccentric. But if I'm right about the acceleration of addictiveness, then this kind of lonely squirming to avoid it will increasingly be the fate of anyone who wants to get things done. We'll increasingly be defined by what we say no to.
What are the challenges of imposing restrictions on technological progress?

Could you restrict technological progress to areas where you wanted it? Only in a limited way, without becoming a police state. And even then, your restrictions would have undesirable side effects. "Good" and "bad" technological progress aren't sharply differentiated, so you'd find you couldn't slow the latter without also slowing the former. And in any case, as Prohibition and the "war on drugs" show, bans often do more harm than good.
What concerns are raised about individual freedom and choice in the future of travel?

I worry we may be heading for a future in which only a few people plot their own itinerary through no-land, while everyone else books a package tour. Or, worse still, has one booked for them by the government.
What term might better describe excessive Internet use that distracts from work compared to procrastination?

People commonly use the word "procrastination" to describe what they do on the Internet. It seems to me too mild to describe what's happening as merely not doing work. We don't call it procrastination when someone gets drunk instead of working.
What advantages do users find in using an iPad over a laptop in social situations?

Several people have told me they like the iPad because it lets them bring the Internet into situations where a laptop would be too conspicuous. In other words, it's a hip flask. (This is true of the iPhone too, of course, but this advantage isn't as obvious because it reads as a phone, and everyone's used to those.)
What is the primary reason that people lose their wealth, according to the paragraph?

So I started to pay attention to how fortunes are lost. If you'd asked me as a kid how rich people became poor, I'd have said by spending all their money. That's how it happens in books and movies, because that's the colorful way to do it. But in fact, the way most fortunes are lost is not through excessive expenditure, but through bad investments.
What financial activities can lead to significant losses without immediate awareness?

It's hard to spend a fortune without noticing. Someone with ordinary tastes would find it hard to blow through more than a few tens of thousands of dollars without thinking, "Wow, I'm spending a lot of money." Whereas if you start trading derivatives, you can lose a million dollars (as much as you want, really) in the blink of an eye.
Why do people often perceive spending on luxuries differently than making investments?

In most people's minds, spending money on luxuries sets off alarms that making investments doesn't. Luxuries seem self-indulgent, and unless you got the money by inheriting it or winning a lottery, you've already been thoroughly trained that self-indulgence leads to trouble. Investing bypasses those alarms. You're not spending the money; you're just moving it from one asset to another, which is why people trying to sell you expensive things say, "it's an investment."
What challenges are associated with creating effective alarms for preventing bad investments?

The solution is to develop new alarms. This can be a tricky business because, while the alarms that prevent you from overspending are so basic that they may even be in our DNA, the ones that prevent you from making bad investments have to be learned and are sometimes fairly counterintuitive.
What is the most dangerous way to lose time, according to the author's realization?

A few days ago, I realized something surprising: the situation with time is much the same as with money. The most dangerous way to lose time is not to spend it having fun, but to spend it doing fake work. When you spend time having fun, you know you're being self-indulgent. Alarms start to go off fairly quickly. If I woke up one morning and sat down on the sofa and watched TV all day, I'd feel like something was terribly wrong. Just thinking about it makes me wince. I'd start to feel uncomfortable after sitting on a sofa watching TV for two hours, let alone a whole day.
What are the psychological differences between spending a day doing unproductive tasks versus watching TV?

I have definitely had days when I might as well have sat in front of a TV all day â days at the end of which, if I asked myself what I got done that day, the answer would have been: basically, nothing. I feel bad after these days too, but nothing like as bad as I'd feel if I spent the whole day on the sofa watching TV. If I spent a whole day watching TV, I'd feel like I was descending into perdition. But the same alarms don't go off on the days when I get nothing done, because I'm doing stuff that seems, superficially, like real work. Dealing with email, for example. You do it sitting at a desk. It's not fun. So it must be work.
What challenges do modern individuals face regarding self-indulgence compared to pre-industrial societies?

With time, as with money, avoiding pleasure is no longer enough to protect you. It probably was enough to protect hunter-gatherers and perhaps all pre-industrial societies. So, nature and nurture combine to make us avoid self-indulgence. But the world has gotten more complicated: the most dangerous traps now are new behaviors that bypass our alarms about self-indulgence by mimicking more virtuous types. And the worst thing is, they're not even fun.
Why do people often act extra friendly when meeting someone new?

When meeting people you don't know very well, the convention is to seem extra friendly. You smile and say "pleased to meet you," whether you are or not. There's nothing dishonest about this. Everyone knows that these little social lies aren't meant to be taken literally, just as everyone knows that "Can you pass the salt?" is only grammatically a question.
Why is it important for writers to adopt an ingratiating tone in persuasive essays?

The reason there's a convention of being ingratiating in print is that most essays are written to persuade. As any politician could tell you, the way to persuade people is not just to baldly state the facts; you have to add a spoonful of sugar to make the medicine go down.
What factors are contributing to the decline of labor unions if not the qualities of current union leaders?

Early union organizers made heroic sacrifices to improve conditions for workers. But though labor unions are shrinking now, it's not because present union leaders are any less courageous. An employer couldn't get away with hiring thugs to beat up union leaders today, but if they did, I see no reason to believe today's union leaders would shrink from the challenge. So I think it would be a mistake to attribute the decline of unions to some kind of decline in the people who run them. Early union leaders were heroic, certainly, but we should not suppose that if unions have declined, it's because present union leaders are somehow inferior. The cause must be external.
What argument does the paragraph make about the factors contributing to the success of early union organizers compared to present-day leaders?

It makes the same point: that it can't have been the personal qualities of early union organizers that made unions successful, but must have been some external factor; otherwise, present-day union leaders would have to be inferior people. However, written this way, it seems like a defense of present-day union organizers rather than an attack on early ones. That makes it more persuasive to people who like unions because it seems sympathetic to their cause.
What is the author's perspective on the sacrifices made by union leaders and the notion of generational greatness?

I believe everything I wrote in the second version. Early union leaders did make heroic sacrifices, and present union leaders probably would rise to the occasion if necessary. People tend to; however, I'm skeptical about the idea of "the greatest generation."
What motivates the author's writing approach, as opposed to the typical goal of persuasion?

Most writers do. Most writers write to persuade, if only out of habit or politeness. But I don't write to persuade; I write to figure out. I write to persuade a hypothetical perfectly unbiased reader.
How does the perception of an essay's intent differ between readers with opposing viewpoints?

Since the custom is to write to persuade the actual reader, someone who doesn't will seem arrogant. In fact, worse than arrogant: since readers are used to essays that try to please someone, an essay that displeases one side in a dispute reads as an attempt to pander to the other. To a lot of pro-union readers, the first paragraph sounds like the sort of thing a right-wing radio talk show host would say to stir up his followers. But it's not. Something that curtly contradicts one's beliefs can be hard to distinguish from a partisan attack on them, but though they can end up in the same place, they come from different sources.
What are the risks of elaborating too much in writing?

The danger of elaborating too much in writing is not merely that it results in longer paragraphs. It's that you start to lie to yourself. The ideas begin to get mixed together with the spin you've added to get them past the readers' misconceptions.
What challenges do writers face when attempting to persuade readers whose beliefs differ significantly from their conclusions?

Writers face significant challenges when attempting to persuade readers whose beliefs differ greatly from their conclusions. The more your conclusions disagree with readers' present beliefs, the more effort you'll have to expend on selling your ideas rather than having them accept your perspective. Writing to persuade and writing to discover are diametrically opposed. As you accelerate in your arguments, the resistance you encounter increases, until eventually, you reach a point where 100% of your energy is devoted to overcoming this resistance, and you can't go any faster.
What challenges does the author face when trying to express new ideas?

It's hard enough to overcome one's own misconceptions without having to think about how to get the resulting ideas past other people's. I worry that if I wrote to persuade, I'd start to shy away unconsciously from ideas I knew would be hard to sell. When I notice something surprising, it's usually very faint at first. There's nothing more than a slight stirring of discomfort. I don't want anything to get in the way of noticing it consciously.
What emotions and memories did the author experience while writing in a familiar academic style?

I had a strange feeling of being back in high school while writing this. To get a good grade, you had to both write the sort of pious crap you were expected to and also seem to be writing with conviction. The solution was a kind of method acting. It was revoltingly familiar to slip back into it.
What writing technique does the author use to engage readers without increasing word count?

"Come to think of it, there is one way in which I deliberately pander to readers, because it doesn't change the number of words: I switch person. This flattering distinction seems so natural to the average reader that they probably don't notice even when I switch in mid-sentence, though you tend to notice when it's done as conspicuously as this."
Why do the prices of books, music, and movies vary based on format rather than content quality?

In fact, consumers never really were paying for content, and publishers weren't really selling it either. If the content was what they were selling, why has the price of books, music, or movies always depended mostly on the format? Why didn't better content cost more?
How do traditional publishing practices prioritize medium over content in pricing and value?

Almost every form of publishing has been organized as if the medium was what they were selling and the content was irrelevant. Book publishers, for example, set prices based on the cost of producing and distributing books. They treat the words printed in the book the same way a textile manufacturer treats the patterns printed on its fabrics.
What emotions can arise when offering someone something that may seem insignificant?

As I was leaving, I offered it to him, as I've done countless times before in the same situation. But this time something new happened. I felt that sheepish feeling you get when you offer someone something worthless. "Do you, er, want a printout of yesterday's news?" I asked. (He didn't.)
How does iTunes operate as a business model compared to traditional content stores?

What about iTunes? Doesn't that show people will pay for content? Well, not really. iTunes is more of a tollbooth than a store. Apple controls the default path onto the iPod. They offer a convenient list of songs, and whenever you choose one, they ding your credit card for a small amount, just below the threshold of attention. Basically, iTunes makes money by taxing people, not selling them stuff. You can only do that if you own the channel, and even then you don't make much from it because a toll has to be ignorable to work. Once a toll becomes painful, people start to find ways around it, and that's pretty easy with digital content.
