Why can software companies charge high prices for their products?

Software companies can charge high prices for their products because many of their customers are businesses, who are willing to pay more for the value that software provides. While some may argue that software is just information, the demand from businesses and the unique features of software products justify the higher prices.
How does the necessity of software like Photoshop differ from the necessity of songs or articles for users?

If they use pirated versions, and though in form merely information, software is treated by both maker and purchaser as a different type of thing from a song or an article. A Photoshop user needs Photoshop in a way that no one needs a particular song or article.
What distinguishes the revenue stability of the movie business from that of the news and music industries?

The most promising countertrend is the premium cable channel; people still pay for those. However, broadcasting isn't publishing: you're not selling a copy of something. That's one reason the movie business hasn't seen its revenues decline the way the news and music businesses haveâthey only have one foot in publishing.
What are the potential strategies for monetizing content in publishing when direct sales are not possible?
What happens to publishing if you can't sell content? You have two choices: give it away and make money from it indirectly, or find ways to embody it in things people will pay for.
What potential changes could the movie industry undergo to attract audiences back to theaters?

It's harder to say what will happen to movies. They could evolve into ads, or they could return to their roots and make going to the theater a treat. If they made the experience good enough, audiences might start to prefer it to watching pirated movies at home.
How might the shift to digital reading options impact the market for printed books?

The shift to digital reading options may impact the market for printed books significantly. As long as buying printed books was the only way to read them, they maintained a strong market presence. However, if printed books become optional, publishers will have to work harder to entice people to buy them. There should be some market for printed books, but it's hard to foresee how big it will be, as its size will depend not on macro trends like the amount people read, but on the ingenuity of individual publishers.
What is the author's perspective on the impact of change on the future?

I don't know exactly what the future will look like, but I'm not too worried about it. This sort of change tends to create as many good things as it kills. Indeed, the really interesting question is not what will happen to existing forms, but what new forms will appear.
What criteria can be used to identify potential winners and losers in emerging technologies?

What new forms will appear? But though I can't predict specific winners, I can offer a recipe for recognizing them. When you see something that's taking advantage of new technology to give people something they want that they couldn't have before, you're probably looking at a winner. And when you see something that's merely reacting to new technology in an attempt to preserve some existing source of revenue, you're probably looking at a loser.
Why does the author prefer to avoid the word "content"?
I don't like the word "content" and have tried for a while to avoid using it, but I have to admit there's no other word that means the right thing. "Information" is too general.
What is the author's perspective on the value of "content" in relation to its treatment by publishers and audiences?

Ironically, the main reason I don't like "content" is the thesis of this essay. The word suggests an undifferentiated slurry, but economically, that's how both publishers and audiences treat it. Content is information you don't need.
Why do some magazines feature articles with titles that begin with numbers on their covers?

Some magazines feature articles with titles that begin with numbers on their covers, such as "7 Things He Won't Tell You about Sex." Popular magazines often include articles of this type on the cover of every issue. That can't be happening by accident; editors must know that these titles attract readers.
What distinguishes a list of items from a traditional essay in terms of structure and content?

Structurally, the list of n things is a degenerate case of an essay. An essay can go anywhere the writer wants. In a list of n things, the writer agrees to constrain himself to a collection of points of roughly equal importance, and he tells the reader explicitly what they are.
What are the characteristics of the structure described in the paragraph?
The structure is characterized by being explicit and guaranteed to be of the simplest possible type: a few main points with few to no subordinate ones, and no particular connection between them.
What are the advantages of presenting information in a list format?

Because the main points are unconnected, the list of n things is random access. There's no thread of reasoning you have to follow. You could read the list in any order. And because the points are independent of one another, they work like watertight compartments in an unsinkable ship. If you get bored with, or can't understand, or don't agree with one point, you don't have to give up on the article. You can just abandon that one and skip to the next. A list of n things is parallel and therefore fault tolerant.
What motivated the author to create a catalog with a numbered title despite receiving criticism?

A few people made fun of me for writing something whose title began with a number. But in that case, I really was trying to make a complete catalog of a number of independent things. In fact, one of the questions I was trying to answer was how many there were.
What are the advantages of using a list format in writing essays?

The list of advantages is easier for writers as well as readers. When you're writing a real essay, there's always a chance you'll hit a dead end. A real essay is a train of thought, and some trains of thought just peter out. That's an alarming possibility when you have to give a talk in a few days. What if you run out of ideas? The compartmentalized structure of a list protects the writer from his own stupidity in much the same way it protects the reader. If you run out of ideas on one point, no problem: it won't kill the essay. You can take out the whole point if you need to, and the essay will still survive.
What are the benefits of creating a list as a method for organizing thoughts?

Writing a list of n things is so relaxing. You think of n/2 of them in the first 5 minutes. So bang, there's the structure, and you just have to fill it in. As you think of more points, you just add them to the end. Maybe you take out or rearrange or combine a few, but at every stage, you have a valid (though initially low-res) list of n things. It's like the sort of programming where you write a version 1 very quickly and then gradually modify it, but at every point have working codeâor the style of painting where you begin with a complete but very blurry sketch done in an hour, then spend a week cranking up the resolution.
Why are list essays considered a suitable format for beginning writers?

Because the list of n things is the easiest essay form, it should be a good one for beginning writers. In fact, it is what most beginning writers are taught. The classic five-paragraph essay is really a list of n things for n = 3. However, the students writing them don't realize they're using the same structure as the articles they read.
Why should students be encouraged to create open lists of n things without transitions or conclusions?

It seems a fine plan to start students off with a list of n things. It's the easiest form. But if we're going to do that, why not do it openly? Let them write lists of n things like the pros, with numbers and no transitions or conclusions.
What should you consider when using "The" in the title of a list?
It's fine to put "The" before the number if you really believe you've made an exhaustive list. However, evidence suggests that most things with titles like this are linkbait.
What are the limitations of the 5 paragraph essay format for beginner writers?

Another advantage of admitting to beginning writers that the 5 paragraph essay is really a list of n things is that we can warn them about this. It only lets you experience the defining characteristic of essay writing on a small scale: in thoughts of a sentence or two. And it's particularly dangerous that the 5 paragraph essay buries the list of n things within something that looks like a more sophisticated type of essay. If you don't know you're using this form, you don't know you need to escape it.
What motivates users to utilize Delicious for bookmarking?

Delicious users are motivated by their desire to bookmark and collect information. They are not using the platform because they lack intelligence; rather, they are collectors. A list of items seems particularly collectible because it forms a collection itself.
What role has Kate Courteau taken on at Y Combinator alongside her architectural work?

Kate Courteau is the architect who designed Y Combinator's office. Recently, we managed to recruit her to help us run YC when she's not busy with architectural projects. Though she'd heard a lot about YC since the beginning, the last nine months have been a total immersion.
What realization did Kate have about the risk of failure in startups?

Kate knew in principle that startups were very risky, but she was surprised to see how constant the threat of failure wasânot just for the minnows, but even for the famous startups whose founders came to speak at YC dinners.
Why is it common for startups to pivot significantly by Demo Day?

By Demo Day, about half the startups were doing something significantly different than they started with. We encourage that. Starting a startup is like science in that you have to follow the truth wherever it leads. In the rest of the world, people don't start things until they're sure what they want to do, and once started, they tend to continue on their initial path even if it's mistaken.
How do you feel about the consistency between speakers and the guidance provided to startups?
Actually, I've noticed this too. I always worry that the speakers will put us in an embarrassing position by contradicting what we tell the startups, but it happens surprisingly rarely.
What key lessons about startup success did she highlight from her experience with speakers?

When I asked her what specific things she remembered speakers always saying, she mentioned that the way to succeed was to launch something fast, listen to users, and then iterate; that startups required resilience because they were always an emotional rollercoaster; and that most VCs were sheep.
How has the approach to launching and iterating business ideas changed over the past decade?
I have been impressed by how consistently the speakers advocate launching fast and iterating. That was contrarian advice 10 years ago, but it's clearly now the established practice.
What characteristics are common among many successful founders in Silicon Valley?

Most of the famous founders in Silicon Valley are people you'd overlook on the street. It's not merely that they don't dress up; they don't project any kind of aura of power either. They're not trying to impress anyone.
What characteristics does Kate use to identify venture capitalists compared to founders?
Interestingly, while Kate said that she could never pick out successful founders, she could recognize VCs, both by the way they dressed and the way they carried themselves.
How does the culture within Y Combinator support new startups?

Without advice, "they'd just be sort of lost." Fortunately, there are a lot of people to help them. There's a strong tradition within YC of helping other YC-funded startups. But we didn't invent that idea; it's just a slightly more concentrated form of existing Valley culture.
What are the key differences in work environments between architects and technology startup founders?

Architects are constantly interacting face-to-face with other people, whereas working in a technology startup tends to require long stretches of uninterrupted time to focus. "You could do it in a box."
What characteristics define the interactions and behaviors of individuals in a "normal" world according to the inverted list?

By inverting this list, we can get a portrait of the "normal" world. It's populated by people who talk a lot with one another as they work slowly but harmoniously on conservative, expensive projects whose destinations are decided in advance, and who carefully adjust their manner to reflect their position in the hierarchy.
What are the public's reactions to different types of personal transportation devices, as observed by the rider?

He has ridden them both to downtown Mountain View to get coffee. When he rides the Eunicycle, people smile at him. But when he rides the Segwell, they shout abuse from their cars: "Too lazy to walk, ya fuckin homo?"
What are the perceptions of effort associated with different modes of transportation?

Someone riding a motorcycle isn't working any harder, but because he's sitting astride it, he seems to be making an effort. When you're riding a Segway, you're just standing there. And someone who's being whisked along while seeming to do no work â someone in a sedan chair, for example â can't help but look smug.
What design changes could help Segway attract a broader market?

There may be a way to capture more of the market Segway hoped to reach: make a version that doesn't look so easy for the rider. It would also be helpful if the styling were in the tradition of skateboards or bicycles rather than medical devices.
How did Segway's initial success and lack of real-world feedback contribute to their eventual challenges?

Curiously enough, what got Segway into this problem was that the company was itself a kind of Segway. It was too easy for them; they were too successful raising money. If they'd had to grow the company gradually, by iterating through several versions they sold to real users, they'd have learned pretty quickly that people looked stupid riding them. So, they never realized they were zooming confidently down a blind alley.
What potential impact could a concentration of startups in a few dominant centers have compared to previous widespread revolutions?

If so, this revolution is going to be particularly revolutionary. All previous revolutions have spread. Agriculture, cities, and industrialization all spread widely. If startups end up being like the movie business, with just a handful of centers and one dominant one, that is going to have novel consequences.
Why do startups struggle to replicate their success in different locations compared to traditional industries?

Startups don't seem to spread as well, partly because they're more of a social than a technical phenomenon, and partly because they're not tied to geography. An individual European manufacturer could import industrial techniques, and they'd work fine. This doesn't seem to work so well with startups: you need a community of expertise, as you do in the movie business.
What factors differentiate the expansion of startups from the historical spread of essential infrastructure like railroads and electric power?

There aren't the same forces driving startups to spread. Once railroads or electric power grids were invented, every region had to have them. An area without railroads or power was a rich potential market. But this isn't true with startups. There's no need for a Microsoft of France or a Google of Germany.
What factors contributed to the development of major tech hubs like Silicon Valley, Seattle, and Boston?

Silicon Valley is where it is because William Shockley wanted to move back to Palo Alto, where he grew up, and the experts he lured west to work with him liked it so much they stayed. Seattle owes much of its position as a tech center to the same cause: Gates and Allen wanted to move home. Otherwise, Albuquerque might have Seattle's place in the rankings. And if Battery Ventures hadn't turned down Facebook, Boston would be significantly bigger now on the startup radar screen.
Why did Facebook receive funding in Silicon Valley rather than Boston?
It is not a coincidence that Facebook received funding in Silicon Valley rather than Boston. There are more and bolder investors in Silicon Valley than in Boston, and even undergrads know it.
What challenges might arise when attempting to establish a new startup hub in a competitive environment?

Boston's case illustrates the difficulty you'd have establishing a new startup hub this late in the game. If you wanted to create a startup hub by reproducing the way existing ones happened, the challenges would include intense competition for resources, talent, and investment, as well as the need to differentiate from established hubs.
What factors contributed to the establishment of Silicon Valley, and why would it be more challenging to create a similar startup hub today?

To establish a first-rate research university in a place so nice that rich people wanted to live there would be essential. Then the town would be hospitable to both groups you need: both founders and investors. That's the combination that yielded Silicon Valley. However, Silicon Valley didn't have Silicon Valley to compete with. If you tried now to create a startup hub by planting a great university in a nice place, it would have a harder time getting started because many of the best startups it produced would be sucked away to existing startup hubs.
What is the impact of clustering successful startups in a specific location?

Once you have enough good startups in one place, it creates a self-sustaining chain reaction. Founders start to move there without being paid because that is where their peers are, and investors appear too because that is where the deals are.
What distinguishes type I startups from type II startups in terms of their evolution and contribution to startup culture?

There are two very different types of startups: one kind that evolves naturally, and one kind that's called into being to "commercialize" a scientific discovery. Most computer/software startups are now the first type, and most pharmaceutical startups are the second. When I talk about startups in this essay, I mean type I startups. There is no difficulty in making type II startups spread; all you have to do is fund medical research labs. Commercializing whatever new discoveries the boffins throw off is as straightforward as building a new airport. Type II startups neither require nor produce startup culture. But that means having type II startups won't get you type I startups. Philadelphia is a case in point: lots of type II startups, but hardly any type I.
What distinguishes Google's success in the search engine market from other startups that may have relied solely on a specific algorithm?

Incidentally, Google may appear to be an instance of a type II startup, but it wasn't. Google is not just PageRank commercialized. They could have used another algorithm, and everything would have turned out the same. What made Google Google is that they cared about doing search well at a critical point in the evolution of the web.
What was James Watt's significant contribution to the development of the steam engine?

Watt didn't invent the steam engine. His critical invention was a refinement that made steam engines dramatically more efficient: the separate condenser. But that oversimplifies his role. He had such a different attitude toward the problem and approached it with such energy that he transformed the field. Perhaps the most accurate way to put it would be to say that Watt reinvented the steam engine.
What role did geographical location play in the success of companies like Kazaa and Skype?

Geographical location played a significant role in the success of companies like Kazaa and Skype. If you're doing something that would get shut down in the US, it becomes an advantage to be located elsewhere. That's why Kazaa took the place of Napster. Additionally, the expertise and connections the founders gained from running Kazaa helped ensure the success of Skype.
What makes the new messaging protocol mentioned in the paragraph significant in the context of existing communication protocols?

The significance of the new messaging protocol lies in the fact that it does not require specifying recipients. New protocols are rare, and more precisely, those that gain widespread adoption are even rarer. Additionally, Twitter is a protocol owned by a private company, which makes it even rarer.
How might Twitter's slow approach to monetization contribute to its widespread adoption?

Curiously, the fact that the founders of Twitter have been slow to monetize it may, in the long run, prove to be an advantage. Because they haven't tried to control it too much, Twitter feels to everyone like previous protocols. One forgets it's owned by a private company. That must have made it easier for Twitter to spread.
What is the primary obstacle to the creation of new startups in the US?

The biggest constraint on the number of new startups that get created in the US is not tax policy, employment law, or even Sarbanes-Oxley. It's that we won't let the people who want to start them into the country.
How would allowing 10,000 founders to start new companies impact job creation for Americans?

By definition, these 10,000 founders wouldn't be taking jobs from Americans; it could be part of the terms of the visa that they couldn't work for existing companies, only new ones they'd founded. In fact, they'd cause there to be more jobs for Americans because the companies they started would hire more employees as they grew.
How can the definition of a startup be effectively determined?

The tricky part might seem to be how one defines a startup. But that could be solved quite easily: let the market decide. Startup investors work hard to find the best startups. The government could not do better than to piggyback on their expertise and use investment by recognized startup investors as the test of whether a company is a real startup.
What impact could increasing the number of immigrant startup founders have on the economy?

Increasing the number of immigrant startup founders could have a significant impact on the economy. While 10,000 people may seem like a small number in terms of immigration, it would represent a substantial increase in the pool of startup founders. I believe this would have such a visible effect on the economy that it could make the legislator who introduced the bill famous. The only way to know for sure would be to try it, and that would cost practically nothing.
Who is considered the most influential founder in startup culture and why?

I would guess Steve Jobs is the most influential founder, not just for me but for most people you could ask. A lot of startup culture is Apple culture. He was the original young founder, and while the concept of "insanely great" already existed in the arts, it was a novel idea to introduce into a company in the 1980s.
What impact has Steve Jobs had on the anticipation of Apple product releases over the years?

More remarkable still, he's stayed interesting for 30 years. People await new Apple products the way they'd await new books by a popular novelist. Steve may not literally design them, but they wouldn't happen if he weren't CEO.
What qualities make TJ Rodgers a notable figure in Silicon Valley, according to the author?

TJ Rodgers isn't as famous as Steve Jobs, but he may be the best writer among Silicon Valley CEOs. I've probably learned more from him about the startup way of thinking than from anyone else. Not so much from specific things he's written as by reconstructing the mind that produced them: brutally candid, aggressively garbage-collecting outdated ideas, and yet driven by pragmatism rather than ideology.
What is the key to achieving success in problem-solving according to the paragraph?

You need good hackers: if you hire all the smartest people and put them to work on a problem where their success can be measured, you win. All the other stuffâwhich includes all the stuff that business schools think business consists ofâyou can figure out along the way. The results won't be perfect, but they'll be optimal. If this was their hypothesis, it's now been verified experimentally.
What significant contributions did Paul Buchheit make to Google?

Few know this, but one person, Paul Buchheit, is responsible for three of the best things Google has done. He was the original author of Gmail, which is the most impressive thing Google has after search. He also wrote the first prototype of AdSense and was the author of Google's mantra, "Don't be evil."
What is a key piece of advice for startups regarding user engagement?

PB made a point in a talk once that I now mention to every startup we fund: that it's better, initially, to make a small number of users really love you than a large number kind of like you. If I could tell startups only one thing, it would be to focus on deepening engagement with a core group of users.
Who are the two founders that the speaker frequently references when advising startups?

Honestly, Sam is, along with Steve Jobs, the founder I refer to most when I'm advising startups. On questions of design, I ask, "What would Steve do?" but on questions of strategy or ambition, I ask, "What would Sam do?"
How does the doctrine of the elect relate to startup investing, according to the author's experience with Sama?

What I learned from meeting Sama is that the doctrine of the elect applies to startups. It applies way less than most people think: startup investing does not consist of trying to pick winners the way you might in a horse race. But there are a few people with such force of will that they're going to get whatever they want.
What was the author's initial perception of angel investing and how did it change over time?

When we sold our startup in 1998, I thought one day I'd do some angel investing. Seven years later, I still hadn't started. I put it off because it seemed mysterious and complicated. It turns out to be easier than I expected and also more interesting.
What are the basic mechanics of investing in a startup?

The part I thought was hard, the mechanics of investing, really isn't. You give a startup money, and they give you stock. You'll probably get either preferred stock, which means stock with extra rights like getting your money back first in a sale, or convertible debt, which means (on paper) you're lending the company money, and the debt converts to stock at the next sufficiently big funding round.
What should novice angel investors focus on instead of the specifics of deal terms?

Don't spend much time worrying about the details of deal terms, especially when you first start angel investing. That's not how you win at this game. When you hear people talking about a successful angel investor, they're not saying, "He got a 4x liquidation preference." They're saying, "He invested in Google."
What is the key factor for success in startup investments?

The key factor for success in startup investments is investing in the right startups. That is so much more important than anything else that I worry I'm misleading you by even talking about other things.
What is the typical structure of a syndicate formed by angel investors when investing in a startup?

Angel investors often syndicate deals, which means they join together to invest on the same terms. In a syndicate, there is usually a "lead" investor who negotiates the terms with the startup. However, this is not always the case; sometimes the startup cobbles together a syndicate of investors who approach them independently, and the startup's lawyer supplies the paperwork.
What is a simple way for beginners to start angel investing?
The easiest way to get started in angel investing is to find a friend who already does it and try to get included in his syndicates. Then, all you have to do is write checks.
What should startups consider regarding legal agreements when working with lawyers?

Startups should consider the legal agreements published online by Wilson Sonsini and Y Combinator. You should, of course, have your lawyer review everything. Both you and the startup should have lawyers, but the lawyers don't have to create the agreement from scratch.
What factors should you consider when negotiating investment terms with a startup?

When you negotiate terms with a startup, there are two numbers you care about: how much money you're putting in and the valuation of the company. The valuation determines how much stock you get. How does raising additional funds affect the ownership percentage of existing shareholders?

If the company raises more money later, the new investor will take a chunk of the company away from all the existing shareholders, just as you did. If, in the next round, they sell 10% of the company to a new investor, your 4.76% will be reduced to 4.28%.
How can multiple rounds of investment increase the value of a startup while reducing an investor's ownership percentage?

In theory, each further round of investment leaves you with a smaller share of an even more valuable company. After several more rounds, you might end up with 0.5% of the company at the point where it IPOs, and you are very happy because your $50,000 has become $5 million.
What should be included in an investment agreement to prevent dilution of ownership percentage?
The agreement by which you invest should have provisions that let you contribute to future rounds to maintain your percentage. So, it's your choice whether you get diluted.
What is the typical range of investment amounts from angel investors?

How much does an angel invest? That varies enormously, from $10,000 to hundreds of thousands or, in rare cases, even millions. What is the typical range for valuations in angel rounds?
Valuations don't vary as much. For angel rounds, it's rare to see a valuation lower than half a million or higher than 4 or 5 million. Four million is starting to be VC territory.
What factors contribute more to the financial success of angel investments than initial valuation?

Ultimately, it doesn't matter much. When angels make a lot of money from a deal, it's not because they invested at a valuation of $1.5 million instead of $3 million. It's because the company was really successful.
What should you prioritize when evaluating a company for investment?
I can't emphasize that enough. Don't get hung up on mechanics or deal terms. What you should spend your time thinking about is whether the company is good.
What role do angel investors typically play in the startups they invest in?

There's a second, less obvious component of an angel investment: how much you're expected to help the startup. Like the amount you invest, this can vary a lot. You don't have to do anything if you don't want to; you could simply be a source of money. Or you can become a de facto employee of the company. Just make sure that you and the startup agree in advance about roughly how much you'll do for them.
What is the key strategy for investors in identifying successful startups?

The central issue is picking the right startups. What "Make something people want" is for startups, "Pick the right startups" is for investors. Combined, they yield "Pick the startups that will make something people want."
What is the key strategy for angel investors when selecting startups to invest in?

The key strategy for angel investors when selecting startups to invest in is to identify promising ventures before they achieve widespread popularity. It's not as simple as picking startups that are already making something wildly popular; by then, it's too late for angels, as venture capitalists will already be onto them. As an angel, you have to pick startups before they've got a hitâeither because they've created something great that users don't realize is valuable yet, like Google early on, or because they're still an iteration or two away from the big hit, like PayPal when they were developing software for transferring money between PDAs.
What is the key skill that distinguishes successful angel investors from venture capitalists?

To be a good angel investor, you have to be a good judge of potential. That's what it comes down to. VCs can be fast followers. Most of them don't try to predict what will win; they just try to notice quickly when something already is winning. But angels have to be able to predict.
How can empathy contribute to identifying successful startup founders?

Empathy can contribute to identifying successful startup founders by allowing you to resonate with them on a deeper level. If you can recognize good startup founders by empathizing with themâif you both resonate at the same frequencyâthen you may already be a better startup picker than the median professional VC.
How does experience compare to empathy in evaluating startup investments?

Paul Buchheit, for example, started angel investing about a year after I did, and he was pretty much immediately as good as I was at picking startups. My extra year of experience was a rounding error compared to our ability to empathize with founders.
What qualities should investors look for in a successful founder?

What makes a good founder? If there were a word that meant the opposite of hapless, that would be the one. Bad founders seem hapless. They may be smart or not, but somehow events overwhelm them, and they get discouraged and give up. Good founders make things happen the way they want. Which is not to say they force things to happen in a predefined way. Good founders have a healthy respect for reality. But they are relentlessly resourceful. That's the closest I can get to the opposite of hapless. You want to fund people who are relentlessly resourceful.
What is the debate among investors regarding the importance of people versus ideas in a company's success?

There is an ongoing debate among investors regarding which is more important: the people or the ideaâor more precisely, the market. Some, like Ron Conway, argue that it's the people, stating that the idea will change, but the people are the foundation of the company. In contrast, Marc Andreessen believes he would back mediocre founders in a hot market over great founders in a bad one.
How can an investor effectively source high-quality startup opportunities?

The problem is not finding startups, exactly, but finding a stream of reasonably high-quality ones. The traditional way to do this is through contacts. If you're friends with a lot of investors and founders, they'll send deals your way. The Valley basically runs on referrals. Once you start to become known as a reliable, useful investor, people will refer lots of deals to you. I certainly will.
What is an effective method for investors to discover new startups?

An effective method for investors to discover new startups is to attend events like Y Combinator's Demo Day, where a batch of newly created startups presents to investors all at once. We have two Demo Days a year, one in March and one in August. These are basically mass referrals.
What is the most effective way to discover new startups?

Events like Demo Day only account for a fraction of matches between startups and investors. The personal referral is still the most common route. So, if you want to hear about new startups, the best way to do it is to get lots of referrals.
What is the relationship between investing in startups and gaining referrals in the venture capital community?

The best way to get lots of referrals is to invest in startups. No matter how smart and nice you seem, insiders will be reluctant to send you referrals until you've proven yourself by making a couple of investments. Some smart, nice guys turn out to be flaky, high-maintenance investors. However, once you prove yourself as a good investor, the deal flow, as they call it, will increase rapidly in both quality and quantity. At the extreme, for someone like Ron Conway, it is basically identical to the deal flow of the whole Valley.
What role do angel investors play in the success of startups in Silicon Valley?

If you want to invest seriously, the way to get started is to bootstrap yourself off your existing connections, be a good investor in the startups you meet that way, and eventually, you'll start a chain reaction. Good investors are rare, even in Silicon Valley. There probably aren't more than a couple of hundred serious angels in the whole Valley, and yet they're probably the single most important ingredient in making the Valley what it is. Angels are the limiting reagent in startup formation.
What impact can an individual angel investor have on the startup ecosystem in Silicon Valley?

If there are only a couple of hundred serious angels in the Valley, then by deciding to become one, you could single-handedly make the pipeline for startups in Silicon Valley significantly wider. That is kind of mind-blowing.
What qualities are essential for being a successful angel investor?

To be a good angel investor, the first thing you need is to be decisive. It means he makes up his mind quickly and follows through. You may be thinking, how hard could that be? You'll see when you try it. You have to guess early, at the stage when the most promising ideas still seem counterintuitive, because if they were obviously good, VCs would already have funded them.
What strategy can inexperienced investors use to make decisions about investing in startups?

There's a hack for being decisive when you're inexperienced: ratchet down the size of your investment until it's an amount you wouldn't care too much about losing. For every rich person (you probably shouldn't try angel investing unless you think of yourself as rich), there's some amount that would be painless, though annoying, to lose. Until you feel comfortable investing, don't invest more than that per startup.
What is a practical approach to gaining experience in angel investing?

For example, if you have $5 million in investable assets, it would probably be painless (though annoying) to lose $15,000. That's less than 0.3% of your net worth. So start by making 3 or 4 $15,000 investments. Nothing will teach you about angel investing like experience. Treat the first few as an educational expense. $60,000 is less than a lot of graduate programs. Plus, you get equity.
What is considered an unprofessional behavior in the context of working with startup founders?
What's really uncool is to be strategically indecisive: to string founders along while trying to gather more information about the startup's trajectory.
What is the importance of resisting the temptation to cut corners in decision-making?

Thereâs always a temptation to cut corners in decision-making because you often have so little to go on, but you have to consciously resist it. In the long term, itâs to your advantage to be good.
What qualities are essential for being a successful angel investor beyond financial acumen?

The other component of being a good angel investor is simply to be a good person. Angel investing is not a business where you make money by screwing people over. Startups create wealth, and creating wealth is not a zero-sum game. No one has to lose for you to win. In fact, if you mistreat the founders you invest in, they'll just get demoralized, and the company will do worse. Plus, your referrals will dry up. So I recommend being good.
What qualities do successful angel investors share in their approach to helping startups?

The most successful angel investors I know are all basically good people. Once they invest in a company, all they want to do is help it. And they'll help people they haven't invested in too. When they do favors, they don't seem to keep track of them; it's too much overhead. They just try to help everyone and assume good things will flow back to them somehow. Empirically, that seems to work.
What are the advantages of using capped versus discounted convertible debt for investors?

Convertible debt can be either capped at a particular valuation or can be done at a discount to whatever the valuation turns out to be when it converts. For example, convertible debt at a discount of 30% means that when it converts, you get stock as if you'd invested at a 30% lower valuation. This can be useful in cases where you can't or don't want to figure out what the valuation should be; you leave it to the next investor. On the other hand, a lot of investors want to know exactly what they're getting, so they will only do convertible debt with a cap.
What is the primary cost associated with creating legal agreements, and how does the series AA paperwork address this issue?

The expensive part of creating an agreement from scratch is not writing the agreement, but bickering at several hundred dollars an hour over the details. That's why the series AA paperwork aims at a middle ground. You can just start from the compromise you'd have reached after lots of back and forth.
Why is it important to use specialized lawyers when funding a startup?

When you fund a startup, both your lawyers should be specialists in startups. Do not use ordinary corporate lawyers for this. Their inexperience makes them overbuild; they'll create huge, overcomplicated agreements and spend hours arguing over irrelevant things.
What are the top startup law firms in Silicon Valley and Boston?
In the Valley, the top startup law firms are Wilson Sonsini, Orrick, Fenwick & West, Gunderson Dettmer, and Cooley Godward. In Boston, the best are Goodwin Procter, Wilmer Hale, and Foley Hoag.
What are the potential consequences for existing shareholders if VCs decide to recapitalize a company?

The reason you don't want to give them up is the following scenario: the VCs recapitalize the company, meaning they give it additional funding at a pre-money valuation of zero. This wipes out the existing shareholders, including both you and the founders. They then grant the founders lots of options because they need them to stay around, but you get nothing.
What are the ethical considerations for venture capitalists when recapitalizing a company?

The ethical considerations for venture capitalists when recapitalizing a company can be complex. It is generally viewed as unethical to recapitalize a company solely to take advantage of earlier investors, such as angels, by diluting their ownership. While reputable, brand-name VCs typically would not engage in such practices, there exists a continuum of behavior among VCs. A less scrupulous, lower-tier VC might be tempted to recapitalize in a way that unjustly benefits them at the expense of earlier investors, potentially stealing a significant portion of stock.
When might it be acceptable for an investor to forgo anti-dilution protections?

I'm not saying you should always absolutely refuse to give up your anti-dilution protections. Everything is a negotiation. If you're part of a powerful syndicate, you might be able to give up legal protections and rely on social ones. If you invest in a deal led by a big angel like Ron Conway, for example, you're pretty well protected against being mistreated because any VC would think twice before crossing him. This kind of protection is one of the reasons angels like to invest in syndicates.
What are the potential consequences of investing too much in a startup at a low valuation?

Don't invest so much, or at such a low valuation, that you end up with an excessively large share of a startup, unless you're sure your money will be the last they ever need. Later-stage investors won't invest in a company if the founders don't have enough equity left to motivate them. I talked to a VC recently who said he'd met with a company he really liked, but he turned them down because investors already owned more than half of it. Those investors probably thought they'd been pretty clever by getting such a large chunk of this desirable company, but in fact, they were shooting themselves in the foot.
What is the typical financial performance of venture capital firms, and how does it relate to their existence in the market?

The typical financial performance of venture capital firms is somewhat surprising, as the median VC loses money. This is one of the most surprising things I've learned about VC while working at Y Combinator. Only a fraction of VCs even have positive returns. The rest exist to satisfy demand among fund managers for venture capital as an asset class. Learning this explained a lot about some of the VCs I encountered when we were working on Viaweb.
What do venture capitalists prioritize when selecting investments?

VCs also generally say they prefer great markets to great people. But what they're really saying is they want both. They're so selective that they only even consider great people. So when they say they care above all about big markets, they mean that's how they choose between great people.
Why do founders prefer investors who are willing to lead in funding rounds?

Founders rightly dislike the sort of investor who says he's interested in investing but doesn't want to lead. There are circumstances where this is an acceptable excuse, but more often than not, what it means is, "No, but if you turn out to be a hot deal, I want to be able to claim retroactively I said yes."
How has the relationship between computers and television evolved over the past two decades?

About twenty years ago, people noticed that computers and TV were on a collision course and started to speculate about what they'd produce when they converged. We now know the answer: computers. It's clear now that even by using the word "convergence," we were giving TV too much credit. This won't be convergence so much as replacement. People may still watch things they call "TV shows," but they'll watch them mostly on computers.
What advantage does the Internet's open platform provide for innovation and competition?

One predictable cause of victory is that the Internet is an open platform. Anyone can build whatever they want on it, and the market picks the winners. So, innovation happens at hacker speeds instead of big company speeds.
How has piracy influenced the preference for watching shows on computers?

The third reason computers won is piracy. Users prefer it not just because it's free, but because it's more convenient. BitTorrent and YouTube have already trained a new generation of viewers that the place to watch shows is on a computer screen.
How have innovations in communication changed the way teenagers interact with their friends compared to previous generations?

The somewhat more surprising force was one specific type of innovation: social applications. The average teenage kid has a pretty much infinite capacity for talking to their friends, but they can't physically be with them all the time. When I was in high school, the solution was the telephone. Now it's social networks, multiplayer games, and various messaging applications. The way you reach them all is through a computer.
What are the key motivations and behaviors of teenagers regarding computer and internet usage?
Every teenage kid (a) wants a computer with an Internet connection, (b) has an incentive to figure out how to use it, and (c) spends countless hours in front of it.
What was the main motivation that drove widespread interest in computers among various groups of people?

The main motivation that drove widespread interest in computers among various groups of people was the desire to connect with others. This was the most powerful force of all. Nerds got computers because they liked them, gamers got them to play games, but it was the ability to connect to other people that attracted everyone else: that's what made even grandmas and 14-year-old girls want computers.
How has the perception of audience engagement in the entertainment industry evolved over time?

After decades of running an IV drip right into their audience, people in the entertainment business had understandably come to think of them as rather passive. They thought they could dictate the way shows reached audiences. However, they underestimated the force of their desire to connect with one another.
What challenges are traditional TV networks facing in adapting to the rise of online content consumption?

The TV networks already seem, grudgingly, to see where things are going and have responded by putting their content online. However, they are still dragging their heels. They still seem to wish people would watch shows on TV instead, just as newspapers that put their stories online still seem to wish people would wait until the next morning to read them printed on paper. They should both just face the fact that the Internet is the primary medium.
What should companies do when a new, potentially disruptive medium emerges?

When a new medium arises that's powerful enough to make incumbents nervous, then it's probably powerful enough to win. The best thing companies can do is jump in immediately. They'd be in a better position if they'd done that earlier.
How is the rise of the Internet impacting traditional broadcast media, particularly local television?

Whether they like it or not, big changes are coming because the Internet dissolves the two cornerstones of broadcast media: synchronicity and locality. On the Internet, you don't have to send everyone the same signal, and you don't have to send it to them from a local source. People will watch what they want when they want it and group themselves according to whatever shared interest they feel most strongly. Maybe their strongest shared interest will be their physical location, but I'm guessing not. This means local TV is probably dead. It was an artifact of limitations imposed by old technology. If someone were creating an Internet-based TV company from scratch now, they might have some plan for shows aimed at specific regions, but it wouldn't be a top priority.
Why are TV networks struggling to adapt to changing trends in the industry?

TV networks will fight these trends because they don't have sufficient flexibility to adapt to them. They're hemmed in by local affiliates in much the same way car companies are hemmed in by dealers and unions. Inevitably, the people running the networks will take the easy route and try to keep the old model running for a couple more years, just as the record labels have done.
What is the limitation of networks in their understanding of their role in communication?
The networks are prevented from seeing this whole line of reasoning because they still think of themselves as being in the broadcast businessâas sending one signal to everyone.
What factors indicate that now is an opportune moment for startups to compete with traditional TV networks?

Now would be a good time to start any company that competes with TV networks. That's what a lot of Internet startups are, though they may not have had this as an explicit goal. People only have so many leisure hours a day, and TV is premised on such long sessions (unlike Google, which prides itself on sending users on their way quickly) that anything that takes up their time is competing with it. In addition to such indirect competitors, I think TV companies will increasingly face direct ones.
How has the role of networks in show distribution evolved with the rise of self-distribution by producers?

The rise of self-distribution by producers has changed the balance of power between networks and show creators. Networks used to be the gatekeepers; they distributed content and sold advertising for it. Now, producers can distribute their shows themselves. The main value that networks provide now is ad sales, which tends to position them as service providers rather than publishers.
How is the future of entertainment on the Internet expected to evolve in terms of format and content?

Shows will change even more. On the Internet, there's no reason to keep their current format, or even the fact that they have a single format. Indeed, the more interesting sort of convergence that's coming is between shows and games. But on the question of what sort of entertainment gets distributed on the Internet in 20 years, I wouldn't dare to make any predictions, except that things will change a lot. We'll get whatever the most imaginative people can cook up. That's why the Internet won.
What were the misconceptions of phone companies in the early 90s regarding the future of video on-demand and internet bandwidth?

Thanks to Trevor Blackwell for this point. He adds: "I remember the eyes of phone companies gleaming in the early 90s when they talked about convergence. They thought most programming would be on demand, and they would implement it and make a lot of money. It didn't work out. They assumed that their local network infrastructure would be critical to do video on demand because you couldn't possibly stream it from a few data centers over the internet. At the time (1992), the entire cross-country Internet bandwidth wasn't enough for one video stream. But wide-area bandwidth increased more than they expected, and they were beaten by iTunes and Hulu."
What factors contribute to users choosing piracy over legal options like iTunes?

Copyright owners tend to focus on the aspect they see of piracy, which is the lost revenue. They therefore think what drives users to do it is the desire to get something for free. However, iTunes shows that people will pay for content online if you make it easy. A significant component of piracy is simply that it offers a better user experience.
What features are expected in the future device that may replace traditional televisions?

A device that may replace traditional televisions is likely to have features such as a browser and the ability to access data via the Internet. I'm not making any predictions about the size of the device, but these functionalities will be essential.
What does Emmett Shear suggest about the potential for broadcasting less mainstream sports content compared to other types of media?

Emmett Shear writes, "I'd argue the long tail for sports may be even larger than the long tail for other kinds of content. Anyone can broadcast a high school football game that will be interesting to 10,000 people or so, even if the quality of production is not so good."
What strategies can a town implement to retain its startups and prevent them from relocating to areas like Silicon Valley?

To retain startups and prevent them from relocating to areas like Silicon Valley, a town must provide enough incentives that make it less appealing for startups to accept offers from Silicon Valley VCs that require them to move. A startup would be able to refuse such an offer if they had grown to the point where they were (a) rooted in your town and/or (b) so successful that VCs would fund them even if they didn't move.
Why is it unrealistic to expect a local Silicon Valley to develop by providing startups with only $15-20k each?

It seems unrealistic to expect a local Silicon Valley to develop by providing startups with only $15-20k each, like Y Combinator. This is because to make them stick around, you'd have to give them at least 20 times that much.
How much investment would it take to attract a thousand startups to a town, and what position might that achieve relative to Silicon Valley?

However, even that is an interesting prospect. Suppose, to be on the safe side, it would cost a million dollars per startup. If you could get startups to stick to your town for a million apiece, then for a billion dollars you could bring in a thousand startups. That probably wouldn't push you past Silicon Valley itself, but it might get you second place.
How can a city develop a thriving startup ecosystem within five years?

It wouldn't take very long; you could probably do it in five years during the term of one mayor. It would get easier over time because the more startups you had in town, the less it would take to get new ones to move there. By the time you had a thousand startups in town, the VCs wouldn't be trying so hard to get them to move to Silicon Valley; instead, they'd be opening local offices. Then you'd really be in good shape. You'd have started a self-sustaining chain reaction like the one that drives the Valley.
What challenges do investors face when selecting promising startups?

Selecting promising startups presents several challenges for investors. The process of picking startups is a rare and valuable skill, and the handful of people who possess it are not readily hireable. Additionally, this skill is so difficult to measure that if a government attempted to hire individuals with it, they would almost certainly select the wrong candidates.
What is the key distinction between successful and unsuccessful venture capitalists?

The key distinction between successful and unsuccessful venture capitalists lies in their ability to choose and advise startups. While all VCs may appear impressive to limited partners, the difference becomes evident in their performance in these critical areas. Unsuccessful VCs may seem impressive to city officials but struggle in selecting the right startups, which is a characteristic failure mode. Ultimately, the effectiveness of a VC is revealed in their capacity to make sound investment choices and provide valuable guidance to the companies they support.
What challenges do emerging startup cities face in attracting local angel investors?

What you really want is a pool of local angel investorsâpeople investing money they made from their own startups. But unfortunately, you run into a chicken-and-egg problem here. If your city isn't already a startup hub, there won't be people there who got rich from startups. And there is no way I can think of that a city could attract angels from outside. By definition, they're rich. There's no incentive that would make them move.
How can a city attract startups from outside its region?

However, a city could attract startups by piggybacking on the expertise of investors who aren't local. It would be pretty straightforward to make a list of the most eminent Silicon Valley angels and from that to generate a list of all the startups they've invested in. If a city offered these companies a million dollars each to move, a lot of the earlier stage ones would probably take it.
What are the potential impacts on startups if they receive additional funding but lose their original investors?
It would hurt the startups somewhat to be separated from their original investors. On the other hand, the extra million dollars would give them a lot more runway.
What is a proposed method to test the viability of transplanted startups in a new city?

Would the transplanted startups survive? Quite possibly. The only way to find out would be to try it. It would be a pretty cheap experiment, as civil expenditures go. Pick 30 startups that eminent angels have recently invested in, give them each a million dollars if they'll relocate to your city, and see what happens after a year. If they seem to be thriving, you can try importing startups on a larger scale.
Why is it important for startups to engage with a larger group rather than conducting small-scale experiments?

Startups should not attempt to conduct their initial experiments on a small scale by selecting only 10 participants. If they do this, they are likely to guarantee failure. It is important for startups to engage with a larger group, as being around other startups fosters a sense of community. A group of 30 would be sufficient to create that environment.
How do hackers typically approach agreements and challenges in their work?
Hackers are much more constrained by gentlemen's agreements than regulations. If they shake your hand on a promise, they'll keep it. But show them a lock, and their first thought is how to pick it.
What implications would a successful 30-startup experiment have on a city?

The 30-startup experiment could be conducted by any sufficiently wealthy private citizen. If successful, it would put significant pressure on the city to adapt and respond to the innovative changes and economic growth that such an initiative could bring.
What factors should be considered when assessing the feasibility of starting a business similar to those in San Francisco?

It will be easier in proportion to how much your town resembles San Francisco. Do you have good weather? Do people live downtown, or have they abandoned the center for the suburbs? Would the city be described as "hip" and "tolerant," or as reflecting "traditional values?" Are there good universities nearby? Are there walkable neighborhoods? Would nerds feel at home? If you answered yes to all these questions, you might be able not only to pull off this scheme but to do it for less than a million per startup.
How does the applicant pool for local seed firms get influenced by the geographic distribution of applicants?

What people who start these supposedly local seed firms always find is that (a) their applicants come from all over, not just the local area, and (b) the local startups also apply to the other seed firms. So what ends up happening is that the applicant pool gets partitioned by quality rather than geography.
What common mistake do ineffective venture capitalists make when selecting startups?

Interestingly, the bad VCs fail by choosing startups run by people like themâpeople who are good presenters but have no real substance. It's a case of the fake leading the fake. And since everyone involved is so plausible, the LPs who invest in these funds have no idea what's happening until they measure their returns.
What was the original purpose of Hacker News when it was created?

Hacker News was two years old last week. Initially, it was supposed to be a side projectâan application to sharpen Arc on and a place for current and future Y Combinator founders to exchange news. It's grown bigger and taken up more time than I expected, but I don't regret that because I've learned so much from working on it.
What are the author's concerns regarding the growth of their website?

The growth rate is a bit higher than I'd like. I'd like the site to grow, since a site that isn't growing at least slowly is probably dead. However, I wouldn't want it to grow as large as Digg or Redditâmainly because that would dilute the character of the site, but also because I don't want to spend all my time dealing with scaling.
What is the author's perspective on the evolution and potential of online discussion platforms like Hacker News?

Hacker News is an experiment, and an experiment in a very young field. Sites of this type are only a few years old. Internet conversation generally is only a few decades old. So we've probably only discovered a fraction of what we eventually will.
What impact did a significant mistake have on the unity of the culture?

That was a mistake. Suddenly, a culture that had been more or less united was divided into haves and have-nots. I didn't realize how united the culture had been until I saw it divided. It was painful to watch.
How does the broken windows theory relate to the behavior of online communities, as illustrated by changes in Reddit?

It's pretty clear now that the broken windows theory applies to community sites as well. The theory is that minor forms of bad behavior encourage worse ones: that a neighborhood with lots of graffiti and broken windows becomes one where robberies occur. I was living in New York when Giuliani introduced the reforms that made the broken windows theory famous, and the transformation was miraculous. I was a Reddit user when the opposite happened there, and the transformation was equally dramatic.
What were the key factors that contributed to Reddit's rapid growth compared to Hacker News?

I'm not criticizing Steve and Alexis. What happened to Reddit didn't occur out of neglect. From the start, they had a policy of censoring nothing except spam. Plus, Reddit had different goals from Hacker News. Reddit was a startup, not a side project; its goal was to grow as fast as possible. Combine rapid growth and zero censorship, and the result is a free-for-all. But I don't think they'd do much differently if they were doing it again. Measured by traffic, Reddit is much more successful than Hacker News.
How do user behaviors on online platforms like HN differ based on the community dynamics compared to Reddit?

User behaviors on online platforms like HN differ based on community dynamics compared to Reddit. What happened to Reddit won't inevitably happen to HN. There are several local maxima. There can be places that are free-for-alls and places that are more thoughtful, just as there are in the real world; and people will behave differently depending on which they're in, just as they do in the real world.
What strategies do some users employ when sharing content on different online platforms?
Iâve observed this in the wild. Iâve seen people cross-posting on Reddit and Hacker News who actually took the trouble to write two versions: a flame for Reddit and a more subdued version for HN.
What types of problems does Hacker News aim to prevent in its community?

There are two major types of problems a site like Hacker News needs to avoid: bad stories and bad comments. So far, the danger of bad stories seems smaller. The stories on the front page now are still roughly the ones that would have been there when HN started.
What factors contribute to the quality of content on the frontpage of a voting platform?

I once thought I'd have to weight votes to keep poor content off the front page, but I haven't had to yet. I wouldn't have predicted the front page would hold up so well, and I'm not sure why it has. Perhaps only the more thoughtful users care enough to submit and upvote links, so the marginal cost of one random new user approaches zero. Or perhaps the front page protects itself by advertising what type of submission is expected.
What factors contribute to the quality of content that gets upvoted on the frontpage?

The most dangerous thing for the front page is content that's too easy to upvote. If someone proves a new theorem, it takes some work by the reader to decide whether or not to upvote it. An amusing cartoon takes less effort. A rant with a rallying cry as the title takes zero effort, because people vote it up without even reading it.
What is the Fluff Principle in the context of user-voted news sites?
The Fluff Principle refers to the phenomenon on user-voted news sites where the links that are easiest to judge tend to dominate unless specific measures are taken to prevent this outcome.
What measures does Hacker News implement to minimize off-topic content?

Hacker News has two kinds of protections against fluff. The most common types of fluff links are banned as off-topic. Pictures of kittens, political diatribes, and so on are explicitly banned. This keeps out most fluff, but not all of it. Some links are both fluff, in the sense of being very short, and also on topic.
What criteria do editors use to evaluate and manage content on a platform related to hacking?

There's no single solution to that. If a link is just an empty rant, editors will sometimes kill it even if it's on topic in the sense of being about hacking, because it's not on topic by the real standard, which is to engage one's intellectual curiosity. If the posts on a site are characteristically of this type, I sometimes ban it, which means new stuff at that URL is auto-killed. If a post has a linkbait title, editors sometimes rephrase it to be more matter-of-fact. This is especially necessary with links whose titles are rallying cries, because otherwise they become implicit "vote up if you believe such-and-such" posts, which are the most extreme form of fluff.
How have aggregators influenced the way writers create content online?

The techniques for dealing with links have to evolve because the links do. The existence of aggregators has already affected what they aggregate. Writers now deliberately write things to draw traffic from aggregatorsâsometimes even specific ones. (No, the irony of this statement is not lost on me.) Then there are the more sinister mutations, like linkjackingâposting a paraphrase of someone else's article and submitting that instead of the original. These can get a lot of upvotes because a lot of what's good in an article often survives; indeed, the closer the paraphrase is to plagiarism, the more survives.
How can users of a submission-based site ensure transparency regarding rejected submissions?

I think it's important that a site that kills submissions provides a way for users to see what got killed if they want to. That keeps editors honest, and just as importantly, makes users confident they'd know if the editors stopped being honest. HN users can do this by flipping a switch called showdead in their profile.
What challenges does Hacker News face regarding user-generated content?
Bad comments seem to be a harder problem than bad submissions. While the quality of links on the front page of HN hasn't changed much, the quality of the median comment may have decreased somewhat.
What are the two main types of negative comments, and how can they be addressed?

There are two main kinds of negativity in comments: meanness and stupidity. There is a lot of overlap between the twoâmean comments are disproportionately likely also to be dumbâbut the strategies for dealing with them are different. Meanness is easier to control. You can have rules stating that one shouldn't be mean, and if you enforce them, it seems possible to keep a lid on meanness.
Why is it more challenging to manage or control stupidity compared to meanness?

Keeping a lid on stupidity is harder, perhaps because stupidity is not so easily distinguishable. Mean people are more likely to know they're being mean than stupid people are to know they're being stupid.
What type of comment is considered most harmful in online discussions, and why?

The most dangerous form of a stupid comment is not the long but mistaken argument, but the dumb joke. Long but mistaken arguments are actually quite rare. There is a strong correlation between comment quality and length; if you wanted to compare the quality of comments on community sites, average length would be a good predictor. Probably the cause is human nature rather than anything specific to comment threads. It is likely that stupidity more often takes the form of having few ideas than wrong ones.
What is a common characteristic of stupid comments and how do people try to make them stand out?

Whatever the cause, stupid comments tend to be short. Since it's hard to write a short comment that's distinguished for the amount of information it conveys, people try to distinguish them instead by being funny. The most tempting format for stupid comments is the supposedly witty put-down, probably because put-downs are the easiest form of humor.
How do negative comments influence the quality of subsequent discussions in online forums?

Negative comments are like kudzu: they take over rapidly. Comments have much more effect on new comments than submissions have on new submissions. If someone submits a lame article, the other submissions don't all become lame. But if someone posts a stupid comment on a thread, that sets the tone for the region around it. People reply to dumb jokes with dumb jokes.
How can we improve the quality of online discussions and reduce the prevalence of low-quality comments?

One potential solution is to add a delay before people can respond to a comment, making the length of the delay inversely proportional to some prediction of its quality. This way, low-quality threads would grow more slowly.
What is the primary focus of the techniques described for managing online communities?

The primary focus of the techniques described for managing online communities is conservative; they are aimed at preserving the character of the site rather than enhancing it. I don't think that's a bias of mine; it's due to the shape of the problem. Hacker News had the good fortune to start out good, so in this case, it's literally a matter of preservation. However, I think this principle would also apply to sites with different origins.
What is more important for the quality of a community site, the users or the technology?

The good things in a community site come from people more than technology; it's mainly in the prevention of bad things that technology comes into play. Technology certainly can enhance discussion; nested comments do, for example. But I'd rather use a site with primitive features and smart, nice users than a more advanced one whose users were idiots.
What strategies can a community site implement to attract and retain a specific subset of users?

The most important thing a community site can do is attract the kind of people it wants. A site trying to be as big as possible wants to attract everyone. But a site aiming at a particular subset of users has to attract just thoseâand just as importantly, repel everyone else. I've made a conscious effort to do this on HN. The graphic design is as plain as possible, and the site rules discourage dramatic link titles. The goal is that the only thing to interest someone arriving at HN for the first time should be the ideas expressed there.
Why can online distractions be more harmful than physical ones?

An online distraction can be more dangerous than a physical one. If I spent half the day loitering on University Ave, I would notice. I have to walk a mile to get there, and sitting in a cafÃ© feels different from working. However, visiting an online forum takes just a click and feels superficially very much like working. You may be wasting your time, but you're not idle.
What are the potential downsides of using Hacker News despite its usefulness?

Hacker News is definitely useful. I've learned a lot from things I've read on HN. I've written several essays that began as comments there. So I wouldn't want the site to go away. However, I would like to be sure it's not a net drag on productivity. What a disaster that would be, to attract thousands of smart people to a site that caused them to waste lots of time. I wish I could be 100% sure that's not a description of HN.
What parallels can be drawn between the addictive nature of modern games and social applications and the issues surrounding crack cocaine in the 1980s?

The addictiveness of games and social applications is still a mostly unsolved problem. The situation now is like it was with crack in the 1980s: we've invented terribly addictive new things, and we haven't yet evolved ways to protect ourselves from them. We will eventually, and that's one of the problems I hope to focus on next.
What methods were used to evaluate the effectiveness of user comment scores in determining quality?

I tried ranking users by both average and median comment score, and average (with the high score thrown out) seemed to be the more accurate predictor of high quality. Median may be the more accurate predictor of low quality, though.
What lesson can be drawn about accuracy in distinguishing between individuals in an experiment?
Another thing I learned from this experiment is that if you're going to distinguish between people, you better be sure you do it right. This is one problem where rapid prototyping doesn't work.
What is the reason for the lack of transparency in Digg's frontpage algorithm compared to Reddit's?

Digg is notorious for its lack of transparency. The root of the problem is not that the people running Digg are especially sneaky, but that they use the wrong algorithm for generating their front page. Instead of bubbling up from the bottom as they get more votes, as on Reddit, stories start at the top and get pushed down by new arrivals.
What are the origins of Digg and Reddit, and how do they differ in their design and functionality?

The reason for the difference is that Digg is derived from Slashdot, while Reddit is derived from Delicious/popular. Digg is Slashdot with voting instead of editors, and Reddit is Delicious/popular with voting instead of bookmarking. You can still see fossils of their origins in their graphic design.
How did Digg's algorithm and editorial decisions influence the selection of top stories on the platform?

Digg's algorithm is very vulnerable to gaming because any story that makes it onto the front page becomes the new top story. This, in turn, forces Digg to respond with extreme countermeasures. Many startups have some kind of secret about the subterfuges they had to resort to in the early days, and I suspect Digg's is the extent to which the top stories were de facto chosen by human editors.
What innovative strategies can be used to reduce repetitive or unproductive comments in online discussions?

I suspect most of the techniques for discouraging unproductive comments have yet to be discovered. Xkcd implemented a particularly clever one in its IRC channel: don't allow the same thing twice. Once someone has said "fail," no one can ever say it again. This would penalize short comments especially, because they have less room to avoid collisions in.
What is a potential solution for managing negative comments in online discussions?

You may not have to kill bad comments to solve the problem. Comments at the bottom of a long thread are rarely seen, so it may be enough to incorporate a prediction of quality in the comment sorting algorithm.
Why do discussions about religion tend to attract more participation than technical discussions, like those about Javascript?

Whatâs different about religion is that people donât feel they need to have any particular expertise to have opinions about it. All they need is strongly held beliefs, and anyone can have those. No thread about Javascript will grow as fast as one about religion because people feel they have to be over some threshold of expertise to post comments about that. But on religion, everyoneâs an expert.
What parallels can be drawn between politics and religion regarding the expression of opinions?
Then it struck me: this is the problem with politics too. Politics, like religion, is a topic where there's no threshold of expertise for expressing an opinion. All you need is strong convictions.
What commonality exists between religion and politics in terms of how they influence people's opinions?

Do religion and politics have something in common that explains this similarity? One possible explanation is that they deal with questions that have no definite answers, so there's no back pressure on people's opinions. Since no one can be proven wrong, every opinion is equally valid, and sensing this, everyone lets fly with theirs.
What factors influence whether a discussion about historical events becomes contentious?

The topics that engage people's identities depend on the individuals involved, not the subject matter itself. For example, a discussion about a battle that included citizens from one or more of the countries involved would probably degenerate into a political argument. However, a discussion today about a battle that took place in the Bronze Age probably wouldn't. No one would know which side to be on. Therefore, it's not politics that is the source of the trouble, but identity.
