When people say a discussion has degenerated into a religious war, what they really mean is that it has started to be driven mostly by people's identities.
Why is it a mistake to assume that certain questions have no answer due to the passionate debates they provoke?

Because the point at which this happens depends on the people rather than the topic, it's a mistake to conclude that because a question tends to provoke religious wars, it must have no answer. For example, the question of the relative merits of programming languages often degenerates into a religious war because so many programmers identify as X programmers or Y programmers. This sometimes leads people to conclude the question must be unanswerableâthat all languages are equally good. Obviously, that's false: anything else people make can be well or badly designed; why should this be uniquely impossible for programming languages? And indeed, you can have a fruitful discussion about the relative merits of programming languages, so long as you exclude people who respond from identity.
What factors determine whether a discussion on a particular topic can be productive?

A productive discussion on a particular topic can occur only if it does not engage the identities of any of the participants. What makes politics and religion such minefields is that they engage so many people's identities. However, it is possible to have a useful conversation about these subjects with some individuals. Conversely, there are other topics that might seem harmless, like the relative merits of Ford and Chevy pickup trucks, that you couldn't safely talk about with certain people.
How can minimizing personal identity influences lead to improved idea generation and clearer thinking?

The most intriguing thing about this theory, if it's right, is that it explains not merely which kinds of discussions to avoid, but how to have better ideas. If people can't think clearly about anything that has become part of their identity, then all other things being equal, the best plan is to let as few things into your identity as possible.
What effect does a sudden influx of participants in a discussion have on the nature of the conversation?

When that happens, it tends to happen fast, like a core going critical. The threshold for participating goes down to zero, which brings in more people. They tend to say incendiary things, which draw more and angrier counterarguments.
What does the paragraph suggest about the perception of societal changes in the US over time?
It was striking how old-fashioned this sounded. And yet, when I was in high school, it wouldn't have seemed too far off as a description of the US, which means things must have been changing here.
How has the importance of educational credentials in determining life outcomes in the US changed over the past 25 years?
The course of people's lives in the US now seems to be determined less by credentials and more by performance than it was 25 years ago. Where you go to college still matters, but not like it used to.
What historical significance did academic credentials hold in the selection process for civil service candidates in China?

Judging people by their academic credentials was, in its time, an advance. The practice seems to have begun in China, where, starting in 587, candidates for the imperial civil service had to take an exam on classical literature.
How did the Chinese civil service exam system in 587 differ from the European approach to civil service testing?

The Chinese civil service exam system in 587 differed from the European approach to civil service testing in several ways. It was also a test of wealth because the knowledge it tested was so specialized that passing required years of expensive training. However, while wealth was a necessary condition for passing, it was not a sufficient one. By the standards of the rest of the world in 587, the Chinese system was very enlightened. Europeans didn't introduce formal civil service exams until the nineteenth century, and even then, they seem to have been influenced by the Chinese example.
How do cram schools influence the transfer of power and wealth between generations?

Cram schools are, in effect, leaks in a seal. The use of credentials was an attempt to seal off the direct transmission of power between generations, and cram schools represent that power finding holes in the seal. Cram schools turn wealth in one generation into credentials in the next.
What is the relationship between standardized testing and the evolution of educational institutions?

It's hard to beat this phenomenon because the schools adjust to suit whatever the tests measure. When the tests are narrow and predictable, you get cram schools on the classic model, like those that prepared candidates for Sandhurst (the British West Point) or the classes American students take now to improve their SAT scores. But as the tests get broader, the schools do too. Preparing a candidate for the Chinese imperial civil service exams took years, as prep school does today. But the raison d'Ãªtre of all these institutions has been the same: to beat the system.
How does parental influence impact societal prosperity and children's success?

History suggests that, all other things being equal, a society prospers in proportion to its ability to prevent parents from influencing their children's success directly. It's a fine thing for parents to help their children indirectlyâfor example, by helping them to become smarter or more disciplined, which then makes them more successful. The problem comes when parents use direct methods: when they are able to use their own wealth or power as a substitute for their children's qualities.
What are the benefits of diverting parental ambitions from direct methods to focusing on raising their children effectively?

Sealing off this force has a double advantage. Not only does a society get "the best man for the job," but parents' ambitions are diverted from direct methods to indirect onesâactually trying to raise their kids well.
Why is it challenging to prevent parents from seeking unfair advantages for their children?

It is very hard to contain parents' efforts to obtain an unfair advantage for their kids. We're dealing with one of the most powerful forces in human nature. We shouldn't expect naive solutions to work, any more than we'd expect naive solutions for keeping heroin out of a prison to work.
How can society improve its credentialing system to reduce the effectiveness of cram schools?

The obvious way to solve the problem is to make credentials better. If the tests a society uses are currently hackable, we can study the way people beat them and try to plug the holes. You can use the cram schools to show you where most of the holes are. They also tell you when you're succeeding in fixing them: when cram schools become less popular.
How can increased transparency in college admissions address the issues of corruption, such as legacy admissions?

Increased transparency in college admissions can address issues of corruption, such as legacy admissions. In the US, this process still shows many outward signs of corruption. For example, legacy admissions. The official story is that legacy status doesn't carry much weight because all it does is break ties: applicants are bucketed by ability, and legacy status is only used to decide between the applicants in the bucket that straddles the cutoff. But what this means is that a university can make legacy status have as much or as little weight as they want by adjusting the size of the bucket that straddles the cutoff.
What is the primary purpose of credentials in evaluating individuals?
Let's think about what credentials are for. What they are, functionally, is a way of predicting performance. If you could measure actual performance, you wouldn't need them.
Why did credentialism emerge as a factor in candidate selection for large organizations?

Credentialism emerged as a factor in candidate selection for large organizations because individual performance is hard to measure in such settings. The harder performance is to measure, the more important it becomes to predict it. If an organization could immediately and cheaply measure the performance of recruits, they wouldn't need to examine their credentials; they could take everyone and keep just the good ones.
How does the size of organizations in a market impact their approach to evaluating individuals' credentials?

Large organizations can't do this. But a bunch of small organizations in a market can come close. A market takes every organization and keeps just the good ones. As organizations get smaller, this approaches taking every person and keeping just the good ones. So all other things being equal, a society consisting of more, smaller organizations will care less about credentials.
How does the structure of the US economy influence career paths and the importance of credentials?

The structure of the US economy significantly influences career paths and the importance of credentials. In the past, the US economy was dominated by a few large companies, creating an environment where ambitious individuals sought to join these organizations and climb to the top. In such a culture, credentials matter a lot; an elite pedigree becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy within large organizations.
Why might impressive credentials be less valued in small companies compared to larger organizations?

Impressive credentials may be less valued in small companies compared to larger organizations because, in small companies, performance is critical. Even if your colleagues are initially impressed by your credentials, they would soon part ways with you if your performance didn't match expectations. This is because the company relies heavily on each individual's contributions to survive, and poor performance could lead to the business going out of operation, resulting in everyone being dispersed.
What factors are driving the shift in hiring priorities from credentials to performance in today's job market?

In a world of small companies, performance is all anyone cares about. People hiring for a startup don't care whether you've even graduated from college, let alone which one. All they care about is what you can do, which is in fact all that should matter, even in a large organization. The reason credentials have such prestige is that for so long the large organizations in a society tended to be the most powerful. But in the U.S. at least, they don't have the monopoly on power they once did, precisely because they can't measure (and thus reward) individual performance. Why spend twenty years climbing the corporate ladder when you can get rewarded directly by the market?
How has the perception of evaluating talent shifted in the past 25 years?

I realize I see a more exaggerated version of the change than most other people. As a partner at an early-stage venture funding firm, I'm like a jumpmaster shoving people out of the old world of credentials and into the new one of performance. I'm an agent of the change I'm seeing. But I don't think I'm imagining it. It was not so easy 25 years ago for an ambitious person to choose to be judged directly by the market. You had to go through bosses, and they were influenced by where you'd been to college.
What factors contribute to the success of small organizations in America?

What made it possible for small organizations to succeed in America? I'm still not entirely sure. Startups are certainly a large part of it. Small organizations can develop new ideas faster than large ones, and new ideas are increasingly valuable.
How has the approach to employee compensation in law firms changed from the 1950s to today?

The approach to employee compensation in law firms has changed significantly from the 1950s to today. My friend Julian Weber told me that when he went to work for a New York law firm in the 1950s, they paid associates far less than firms do today. Law firms then made no pretense of paying people according to the value of the work they had done; pay was based on seniority. Younger employees were expected to pay their dues, with the promise of rewards later.
What factors contributed to the rise of high salaries for young professionals in the 1980s?

The rise of high salaries for young professionals in the 1980s can be attributed to several factors. One reason was the skepticism about working to accumulate deferred rewards at companies that might go bankrupt or be taken over, which could wipe out their implicit obligations. Additionally, some companies broke ranks and began paying young employees large amounts, particularly in consulting, law, and finance. This led to the phenomenon of "yuppies." While the term is rarely used today, as it is no longer surprising to see a 25-year-old with money, in 1985, the sight of a 25-year-old earning a high salary was notable.
What type of companies did the classic yuppie typically work for?

The classic yuppie worked for a small organization. He didn't work for General Widget, but for the law firm that handled General Widget's acquisitions or the investment bank that floated their bond issues.
What factors contributed to the emergence of startups and yuppies in the late 1970s and early 1980s?

Startups and yuppies entered the American conceptual vocabulary roughly simultaneously in the late 1970s and early 1980s. I don't think there was a causal connection. Startups happened because technology started to change so fast that big companies could no longer keep a lid on the smaller ones. I don't think the rise of yuppies was inspired by it; it seems more as if there was a change in the social conventions (and perhaps the laws) governing the way big companies worked. But the two phenomena rapidly fused to produce a principle that now seems obvious: paying energetic young people market rates and getting correspondingly high performance from them.
How does the introduction of performance-based pay in certain sectors influence overall economic behavior and wage standards?

The introduction of performance-based pay in certain sectors can significantly influence overall economic behavior and wage standards. All it takes is a few beachheads in your economy that pay for performance. Measurement spreads like heat. If one part of a society is better at measurement than others, it tends to push the others to do better. If young, smart, and driven individuals can make more by starting their own companies than by working for existing ones, the existing companies are forced to pay more to keep them. Thus, market rates gradually permeate every organization, even the government.
What is a more effective method to prevent the transmission of power between generations, beyond using credentials?

Credentials are a step beyond bribery and influence. But they're not the final step. There's an even better way to block the transmission of power between generations: to encourage the trend toward an economy made of more, smaller units. Then you can measure what credentials merely predict.
What is the primary purpose of prep schools according to the author?

When I say the raison d'Ãªtre of prep schools is to get kids into better colleges, I mean this in the narrowest sense. I'm not saying that's all prep schools do, just that if they had zero effect on college admissions, there would be far less demand for them.
Why was the author's piece on entrepreneurship not included in the company's report?
I originally wrote this at the request of a company producing a report about entrepreneurship. Unfortunately, after reading it, they decided it was too controversial to include.
How might the current recession impact the number of new startups and venture capital funding?

VC funding will probably dry up somewhat during the present recession, like it usually does in bad times. But this time, the result may be different. The number of new startups may not decrease, and that could be dangerous for VCs.
How has the relationship between venture capital funding and startup creation changed since the Internet Bubble?

When VC funding dried up after the Internet Bubble, startups dried up too. There were not a lot of new startups being founded in 2003. But startups aren't tied to VC the way they were 10 years ago. It's now possible for VCs and startups to diverge. And if they do, they may not reconverge once the economy gets better.
What factors have contributed to the decreased reliance of startups on venture capital funding?

The reason startups no longer depend so much on VCs is one that everyone in the startup business knows by now: it has gotten much cheaper to start a startup. There are four main reasons: Moore's law has made hardware cheap; open source has made software free; the web has made marketing and distribution free; and more powerful programming languages mean development teams can be smaller. These changes have pushed the cost of starting a startup down into the noise. In a lot of startupsâprobably most startups funded by Y Combinatorâthe biggest expense is simply the founders' living expenses. We've had startups that were profitable on revenues of $3,000 a month.
What metaphor illustrates the current relationship between venture capitalists and founders, and what potential event could disrupt this dynamic?

VCs and founders are like two components that used to be bolted together. Around 2000, the bolt was removed. Because the components have so far been subjected to the same forces, they still seem to be joined together, but really one is just resting on the other. A sharp impact would make them fly apart, and the present recession could be that impact.
What trends are emerging in startup applications in response to recent market conditions?

Because of Y Combinator's position at the extreme end of the spectrum, we'd be the first to see signs of a separation between founders and investors, and we are, in fact, seeing it. For example, though the stock market crash does seem to have made investors more cautious, it doesn't seem to have had any effect on the number of people who want to start startups. We take applications for funding every six months. Applications for the current funding cycle closed on October 17, well after the markets tanked, and even so, we got a record number, up 40% from the same cycle a year before.
How does the current entrepreneurial sentiment compare to the climate during the 2001 economic downturn?

The current entrepreneurial sentiment is markedly different from the climate during the 2001 economic downturn. While there may be concerns about the economy worsening in the future, there is currently no slackening of interest among potential founders. In 2001, there was a widespread feeling among aspiring entrepreneurs that startups were over, and many opted to pursue graduate school instead. This time, however, that sentiment is absent. One reason for this is that even in a bad economy, it is not particularly difficult to build something that generates $3,000 a month. If investors stop writing checks, many founders feel it is not a significant concern.
What sentiment are some YC founders expressing about working with investors?

I've detected this "investors aren't worth the trouble" vibe from several YC founders I've talked to recently. At least one startup from the most recent (summer) cycle may not even raise angel money, let alone VC.
What impact has Y Combinator's initial investment had on the success of startups?

Y Combinator's initial investment of $15,000 has allowed some startups to achieve profitability, and they hope not to need more funding. This outcome surprised even us. Although YC is based on the idea that it is cheap to start a startup, we never anticipated that founders would grow successful startups on nothing more than YC funding.
What are the potential long-term consequences for venture capitalists if founders choose to avoid working with them?

If founders decide that VCs aren't worth the trouble, that could be bad for VCs. When the economy bounces back in a few years and they're ready to write checks again, they may find that founders have moved on.
How does the founder community influence trends in technology and funding among startups?

There is a founder community just as there's a VC community. They all know one another, and techniques spread rapidly between them. If one tries a new programming language or a new hosting provider and gets good results, six months later, half of them are using it. The same is true for funding. The current generation of founders wants to raise money from VCs, and Sequoia specifically, because Larry and Sergey took money from VCs, and Sequoia specifically. Imagine what it would do to the VC business if the next hot company didn't take VC at all.
How do venture capitalists perceive competition within their industry?

Venture capitalists (VCs) think they're playing a zero-sum game. In fact, it's not even that. If you lose a deal to Benchmark, you lose that deal, but the VC industry still wins. If you lose a deal to none, all VCs lose.
How might the current recession impact the behavior of startup founders and venture capitalists compared to the recession following the Internet Bubble?

This recession may be different from the one after the Internet Bubble. This time, founders may keep starting startups. If they do, VCs will have to keep writing checks, or they could become irrelevant.
What factor has historically contributed to the success of societies?

For nearly all of history, the success of a society was proportionate to its ability to assemble large and disciplined organizations. Those who bet on economies of scale generally won, which meant the largest organizations were the most successful ones.
How has the perception of large organizations compared to small businesses changed over the decades?

Things have already changed so much that this is hard for us to believe, but until just a few decades ago, the largest organizations tended to be the most progressive. An ambitious kid graduating from college in 1960 wanted to work in the huge, gleaming offices of Ford, General Electric, or NASA. Small meant small-time. Small in 1960 didn't mean a cool little startup; it meant Uncle Sid's shoe store.
What was the prevailing career aspiration for young people in the 1970s?

When I grew up in the 1970s, the idea of the "corporate ladder" was still very much alive. The standard plan was to try to get into a good college, from which one would be drafted into some organization and then rise to positions of gradually increasing responsibility. The more ambitious merely hoped to climb the same ladder faster.
What shift occurred in the late twentieth century regarding the advantages of size versus speed in technology?

In the late twentieth century, something changed. It turned out that economies of scale were not the only force at work. Particularly in technology, the increase in speed one could achieve from smaller groups started to trump the advantages of size.
How has the vision of the future changed since 1970 in terms of societal structure and technology?

The future turned out to be different from the one we were expecting in 1970. The domed cities and flying cars we expected have failed to materialize. But fortunately, so have the jumpsuits with badges indicating our specialty and rank. Instead of being dominated by a few giant, tree-structured organizations, it's now looking like the economy of the future will be a fluid network of smaller, independent units.
How has the rapid pace of technological change affected the effectiveness of large organizations in competition?

It's not so much that large organizations stopped working. There's no evidence that famously successful organizations like the Roman army or the British East India Company were any less afflicted by protocol and politics than organizations of the same size today. But they were competing against opponents who couldn't change the rules on the fly by discovering new technology. Now it turns out the rule "large and disciplined organizations win" needs to have a qualification appended: "at games that change slowly." No one knew until change reached a sufficient speed.
What factors are influencing ambitious college graduates to avoid traditional big companies in favor of startups?

Ambitious college graduates today are increasingly avoiding traditional big companies in favor of startups. For the first time in history, these graduates are no longer drawn to the stability of large corporations. Instead, they are attracted to the excitement and rapid growth potential of hot startups. If they are particularly ambitious, they may even aspire to start their own companies.
How do startups impact the existence of big companies in the business landscape?

This doesn't mean big companies will disappear. To say that startups will succeed implies that big companies will exist because startups that succeed either become big companies or are acquired by them.
What strategies can ambitious individuals use to capitalize on outdated ideas?

Ambitious individuals can capitalize on outdated ideas that are now obsolete but extremely deeply rooted. This means they can engage in arbitrage on these ideas. It will be very valuable to understand precisely which ideas to keep and which can now be discarded.
What factors contributed to the rarity of educated individuals starting their own businesses before the rise of technology and Internet startups?

There have always been occasional cases, particularly in the US, of ambitious people who grew the ladder under them instead of climbing it. But until recently, this was an anomalous route that tended to be followed only by outsiders. It was no coincidence that the great industrialists of the nineteenth century had so little formal education. As huge as their companies eventually became, they were all essentially mechanics and shopkeepers at first. That was a social step no one with a college education would take if they could avoid it. Until the rise of technology startups, and in particular, Internet startups, it was very unusual for educated people to start their own businesses.
What led the founders of Fairchild Semiconductor to start their own company?

The eight men who left Shockley Semiconductor to found Fairchild Semiconductor, the original Silicon Valley startup, weren't even trying to start a company at first. They were just looking for a company willing to hire them as a group. Then one of their parents introduced them to a small investment bank that offered to find funding for them to start their own, so they did. However, starting a company was an alien idea to them; it was something they backed into.
What trend is observed among university students regarding entrepreneurship and programming skills?

Now, I would guess that practically every Stanford or Berkeley undergrad who knows how to program has at least considered the idea of starting a startup. East Coast universities are not far behind, and British universities only a little behind them. This pattern suggests that attitudes at Stanford and Berkeley are not an anomaly, but a leading indicator. This is the way the world is going.
How can innovations in technology lead to significant economic growth?

Innovations in technology can lead to significant economic growth because there seems to be no limit to the amount of work that can be done in this area. Like science, wealth appears to expand fractally. Steam power was a small part of the British economy when Watt started working on it, but his efforts led to more work until that small segment expanded into something larger than the entire economy of which it had initially been a part.
What impact could ambitious individuals starting Internet startups have on the economy?
If Internet startups offer the best opportunity for ambitious people, then a lot of ambitious individuals will start them, and this part of the economy will balloon in the usual fractal way.
How might the growth of Internet-related applications influence broader economic trends?

Even if Internet-related applications only become a tenth of the world's economy, this component will set the tone for the rest. The most dynamic part of the economy always does, in everything from salaries to standards of dress. Not just because of its prestige, but because the principles underlying the most dynamic part of the economy tend to be ones that work.
What type of organizational structure is predicted to be most successful in the future?
For the future, the trend to bet on seems to be networks of small, autonomous groups whose performance is measured individually. The societies that win will be the ones with the least impedance.
What factors influenced the spread of the Industrial Revolution across different societies?

As with the original Industrial Revolution, some societies are going to be better at this than others. Within a generation of its birth in England, the Industrial Revolution had spread to continental Europe and North America. However, it didn't spread everywhere. This new way of doing things could only take root in places that were prepared for it. It could only spread to places that already had a vigorous middle class.
What impact did the transformation in Silicon Valley in the 1960s have on the development of integrated circuits and startup companies globally?

There is a similar social component to the transformation that began in Silicon Valley in the 1960s. Two new kinds of techniques were developed there: techniques for building integrated circuits and techniques for building a new type of company designed to grow fast by creating new technology. The techniques for building integrated circuits spread rapidly to other countries, but the techniques for building startups didn't. Fifty years later, startups are ubiquitous in Silicon Valley and common in a handful of other U.S. cities, but they're still an anomaly in most of the world.
What factors contribute to the limited spread of startups compared to the Industrial Revolution?

Part of the reasonâpossibly the main reasonâthat startups have not spread as broadly as the Industrial Revolution did is their social disruptiveness. Though it brought many social changes, the Industrial Revolution was not fighting the principle that bigger is better. Quite the opposite: the two dovetailed beautifully. The new industrial companies adapted the customs of existing large organizations like the military and the civil service, and the resulting hybrid worked well. "Captains of industry" issued orders to "armies of workers," and everyone knew what they were supposed to do.
Why do startups struggle to thrive in certain social environments?

Startups seem to go more against the grain socially. It's hard for them to flourish in societies that value hierarchy and stability, just as it was hard for industrialization to flourish in societies ruled by people who stole at will from the merchant class. However, there were already a handful of countries past that stage when the Industrial Revolution happened. There do not seem to be that many ready this time.
What is a key difference in operational approaches between big companies and startups?

One of the differences between big companies and startups is that big companies tend to have developed procedures to protect themselves against mistakes. A startup walks like a toddler, bashing into things and falling over all the time. A big company is more deliberate.
How do organizations learn from past disasters to improve their supplier selection process?

The gradual accumulation of checks in an organization is a kind of learning based on disasters that have happened to it or others like it. After giving a contract to a supplier who goes bankrupt and fails to deliver, for example, a company might require all suppliers to prove they are solvent before submitting bids.
What factors contribute to the increase in disaster preparedness checks within growing companies?

As companies grow, they invariably get more such checks, either in response to disasters they've suffered or, probably more often, by hiring people from bigger companies who bring with them customs for protecting against new types of disasters.
What is a common oversight when organizations implement new checks to prevent mistakes?
It's natural for organizations to learn from mistakes. The problem is that people who propose new checks almost never consider that the check itself has a cost.
What are the hidden costs associated with requiring suppliers to verify their solvency?

For example, consider the case of making suppliers verify their solvency. Surely that's mere prudence? But in fact, it could have substantial costs. There's obviously the direct cost in time of the people on both sides who supply and check proofs of the supplier's solvency. But the real costs are the ones you never hear about: the company that would be the best supplier but doesn't bid because they can't spare the effort to get verified. Or the company that would be the best supplier but falls just short of the threshold for solvencyâwhich will, of course, have been set on the high side since there is no apparent cost of increasing it.
What should be considered when proposing a new check in an organization?

Whenever someone in an organization proposes to add a new check, they should have to explain not just the benefit but the cost. No matter how poorly they analyze it, this meta-check would at least remind everyone that there had to be a consideration of both aspects.
What pricing strategy should software vendors consider when selling to corporate customers to avoid the high costs of the approval process?

If companies started doing that, they'd find some surprises. Joel Spolsky recently spoke at Y Combinator about selling software to corporate customers. He said that in most companies, software costing up to about $1,000 could be bought by individual managers without any additional approvals. Above that threshold, software purchases generally had to be approved by a committee. However, babysitting this process was so expensive for software vendors that it didn't make sense to charge less than $50,000. This means if you're making something you might otherwise have charged $5,000 for, you have to sell it for $50,000 instead.
Why do checks on purchases tend to be costly and lead to inefficiency in the market?

Checks on purchases tend to be costly because the harder it is to sell something to you, the more it has to cost. And not merely linearly, either. If you're hard enough to sell to, the people who are best at making things don't want to bother. The only people who will sell to you are companies that specialize in selling to you. Then you've sunk to a whole new level of inefficiency. Market mechanisms no longer protect you because the good suppliers are no longer in the market.
How can government restrictions impact a country's economic development and global influence?

Government restrictions can significantly impact a country's economic development and global influence. Such things happen constantly to the biggest organizations of all, governments. However, checks instituted by governments can cause much worse problems than merely overpaying. These restrictions can cripple a country's whole economy. Up until about 1400, China was richer and more technologically advanced than Europe. One reason Europe pulled ahead was that the Chinese government restricted long trading voyages. As a result, it was left to the Europeans to explore and eventually dominate the rest of the world, including China.
How has the Sarbanes-Oxley Act affected the US IPO market, particularly for younger companies?

In more recent times, the Sarbanes-Oxley Act has practically destroyed the US IPO market. That wasn't the intention of the legislators who wrote it; they just wanted to add a few more checks on public companies. However, they forgot to consider the cost. They overlooked that companies about to go public are usually rather stretched, and that the weight of a few extra checks that might be easy for General Electric to bear is enough to prevent younger companies from being public at all.
What motivates programmers to write and release more code?
Programmers, though, like it better when they write more code. Or, more precisely, when they release more code. Programmers like to make a differenceâgood ones, anyway.
What advantages do good programmers experience when working at a startup compared to larger companies?

For good programmers, one of the best things about working for a startup is that there are few checks on releases. In true startups, there are no external checks at all. If you have an idea for a new feature in the morning, you can write it and push it to the production servers before lunch. When you can do that, you have more ideas.
What challenges do programmers face when transitioning from a startup to a big company regarding software release timelines?

At big companies, software has to go through various approvals before it can be launched. The cost of doing this can be enormousâin fact, discontinuous. I was talking recently to a group of three programmers whose startup had been acquired a few years before by a big company. When they had been independent, they could release changes instantly. Now, they said, the absolute fastest they could get code released on the production servers was two weeks.
What is the potential consequence of imposing excessive checks on programmers in a hiring context?

Just as the greatest danger of being hard to sell to is not that you overpay, but that the best suppliers won't even sell to you, the greatest danger of applying too many checks to your programmers is not that you'll make them unproductive, but that good programmers won't even want to work for you.
Why is it important to allow artists to ship their work?
Steve Jobs's famous maxim "artists ship" works both ways. Artists aren't merely capable of shipping; they insist on it. So, if you don't let people ship, you won't have any artists.
What is a key challenge of relying on your business revenues for personal income?

One disadvantage of living off the revenues of your company is that you have to keep running it. As anyone who runs their own business can tell you, that requires your complete attention. You can't just start a business and check out once things are going well, or they stop going well surprisingly fast.
What are the primary economic motivations of startup founders, and how do these motivations contrast with the realities of running a business?

The main economic motives of startup founders seem to be freedom and security. They want enough money that (a) they don't have to worry about running out of money and (b) they can spend their time how they want. Running your own business offers neither. You certainly don't have freedom; no boss is so demanding. Nor do you have security, because if you stop paying attention to the company, its revenues go away, and with them your income.
What are the potential benefits of hiring a manager for a growing business?

The best case, for most people, would be if you could hire someone to manage the company for you once you'd grown it to a certain size. Suppose you could find a really good manager. Then you would have both freedom and security. You could pay as little attention to the business as you wanted, knowing that your manager would keep things running smoothly. And, that being so, revenues would continue to flow in, so you'd have security as well.
Why might some founders struggle to align their personal interests with customer needs in their business?

Some founders might struggle to align their personal interests with customer needs because they are so passionate about running their company that they prioritize their own desires over the demands of the market. However, this group is likely small. To succeed in most businesses, one must be fanatically attentive to customers' needs. What are the odds that your own desires would coincide exactly with the demands of this powerful, external force?
What should founders consider doing with their company as it grows?
As the company grows, founders should consider eventually handing it over to a professional manager, provided they can find one who is competent enough to take on the role.
What is the benefit of having a management company instead of relying on an individual manager?

Having a management company instead of relying on an individual manager has significant benefits. For instance, what if your manager was hit by a bus? With a management company, you ensure that your operations continue smoothly without depending on any one person.
How could a management company structure its ownership and profit distribution among the companies it manages?

A management company could be organized in a straightforward manner. The simplest way would be to have a new kind of stock representing the total pool of companies they manage. When a company signs up, it would trade its stock for shares of this pool, in proportion to an estimate of its value that both parties have agreed upon. Then, the company would automatically receive its share of the returns from the whole pool.
How could management companies enable clients to change their investment strategies more flexibly?

The catch is that because this kind of trade would be hard to undo, you couldn't switch management companies. But there's a way they could fix that: suppose all the management companies got together and agreed to allow their clients to exchange shares in all their pools. Then you could, in effect, simultaneously choose all the management companies to run yours for you, in whatever proportion you wanted, and change your mind later as often as you wanted.
What would be an ideal plan for most people following David's advocated route?
If such pooled-risk management companies existed, signing up with one would seem the ideal plan for most people following the route David advocated.
Should startups prioritize charging customers or focus on product development initially?

Startups should try charging customers right away. Yet, some of the most successful startups, including Google, ignored revenue at first and concentrated exclusively on development. The answer probably depends on the type of company you're starting. I can imagine some where trying to make sales would be a good heuristic for product design, and others where it would just be a distraction. The test is probably whether it helps you to understand your users.
What is the importance of profitability in determining a revenue strategy for a new company?

Profitability is crucial in determining a revenue strategy for a new company because it allows you to choose whichever revenue strategy you think is best for the type of company you're starting. Being profitable ensures you'll get at least the average of the acquisition market, in which public companies behave as pooled-risk management companies.
What is the relationship between starting a company to generate revenue and the option of selling it for profit?

David isn't mistaken in saying you should start a company to live off its revenues. The mistake is thinking this is somehow opposed to starting a company and selling it. In fact, for most people, the latter is merely the optimal case of the former.
What impact do great cities have on the mindset and ambitions of their inhabitants?
Great cities attract ambitious people. You can sense it when you walk around one. In a hundred subtle ways, the city sends you a message: you could do more; you should try harder.
What is the primary message conveyed by New York regarding personal success?

The surprising thing is how different these messages can be. New York tells you, above all, that you should make more money. There are other messages too, of course. You should be hipper. You should be better looking. But the clearest message is that you should be richer.
What is the attitude towards intellectual growth in Cambridge, as expressed in the paragraph?
What I like about Boston (or rather Cambridge) is that the message there is: you should be smarter. You really should get around to reading all those books you've been meaning to.
What message does Silicon Valley convey about power and influence?
When you ask what message a city sends, you sometimes get surprising answers. As much as they respect brains in Silicon Valley, the message the Valley sends is that you should be more powerful.
How do attitudes toward wealth and influence differ between New York and Silicon Valley?

That's not quite the same message New York sends. Power matters in New York too, of course, but New York is pretty impressed by a billion dollars even if you merely inherited it. In Silicon Valley, no one would care except a few real estate agents. What matters in Silicon Valley is how much effect you have on the world. The reason people there care about Larry and Sergey is not their wealth but the fact that they control Google, which affects practically everyone.
How significant is the impact of one's environment on achieving greatness?

How much does it matter what message a city sends? Empirically, the answer seems to be: a lot. You might think that if you had enough strength of mind to do great things, you'd be able to transcend your environment. Where you live should make at most a couple percent difference. But if you look at the historical evidence, it seems to matter more than that. Most people who did great things were clumped together in a few places where that sort of thing was done at the time.
What are the author's thoughts on the lifestyle and atmosphere in Berkeley compared to their expectations?

I'd always imagined Berkeley would be the ideal placeâthat it would basically be Cambridge with good weather. But when I finally tried living there a couple of years ago, it turned out not to be. The message Berkeley sends is: you should live better. Life in Berkeley is very civilized. It's probably the place in America where someone from Northern Europe would feel most at home. But it's not humming with ambition.
What motivates people to choose to live in Cambridge despite its high cost and poor weather?

In retrospect, it shouldn't have been surprising that a place so pleasant would attract people interested above all in quality of life. Cambridge, with good weather, it turns out, is not Cambridge. The people you find in Cambridge are not there by accident. You have to make sacrifices to live there. It's expensive and somewhat grubby, and the weather's often bad. So the kind of people you find in Cambridge are the kind of people who want to live where the smartest people are, even if that means living in an expensive, grubby place with bad weather.
How might the evolution of the Internet impact the importance of physical communities compared to virtual ones?

The Internet may change things further. Maybe one day the most important community you belong to will be a virtual one, and it won't matter where you live physically. But I wouldn't bet on it. The physical world is very high bandwidth, and some of the ways cities send you messages are quite subtle.
How do the evening atmospheres of Cambridge and Palo Alto differ in terms of social and cultural indicators?

One of the exhilarating things about coming back to Cambridge every spring is walking through the streets at dusk when you can see into the houses. When you walk through Palo Alto in the evening, you see nothing but the blue glow of TVs. In Cambridge, you see shelves full of promising-looking books. Palo Alto was probably much like Cambridge in 1960, but you'd never guess now that there was a university nearby. Now it's just one of the richer neighborhoods in Silicon Valley.
What unique aspects of living in Cambridge contribute to the experience of understanding the city's character?

A city speaks to you mostly by accident â in things you see through windows, in conversations you overhear. It's not something you have to seek out, but something you can't turn off. One of the occupational hazards of living in Cambridge is overhearing the conversations of people who use interrogative intonation in declarative sentences. But on average, I'll take Cambridge conversations over New York or Silicon Valley ones.
What impact does the quality of eavesdropping have on one's experience of living in a particular area?

A friend who moved to Silicon Valley in the late 90s said the worst thing about living there was the low quality of the eavesdropping. At the time, I thought she was being deliberately eccentric. Sure, it can be interesting to eavesdrop on people, but is good quality eavesdropping so important that it would affect where you chose to live? Now I understand what she meant. The conversations you overhear tell you what sort of people you're among.
How can the attitudes of those around you impact your motivation and interests?

No matter how determined you are, it's hard not to be influenced by the people around you. It's not so much that you do whatever a city expects of you, but that you get discouraged when no one around you cares about the same things you do.
How does the concept of loss aversion relate to motivation and social influence in people's efforts?

Thereâs an imbalance between encouragement and discouragement, similar to that between gaining and losing money. Most people overvalue negative amounts of money; theyâll work much harder to avoid losing a dollar than to gain one. Similarly, although there are plenty of people strong enough to resist doing something just because thatâs what one is supposed to do, there are few strong enough to keep working on something no one around them cares about.
What factors contribute to Cambridge being recognized as the intellectual capital?

The reason Cambridge is recognized as the intellectual capital is not just that there's a concentration of smart people there, but that there's a unique ecosystem that fosters innovation and collaboration among various disciplines. This environment attracts top talent and resources, further enhancing its status as a hub of intellectual activity.
What perception exists regarding the status of professors in New York and the Bay area compared to their involvement in hedge funds or startups?

Professors in New York and the Bay Area are perceived as second-class citizens until they start hedge funds or startups, which suggests that people there value entrepreneurial involvement more than academic status.
Why might New York struggle to become a startup hub like Silicon Valley?

This suggests an answer to a question people in New York have wondered about since the Bubble: whether New York could grow into a startup hub to rival Silicon Valley. One reason that's unlikely is that someone starting a startup in New York would feel like a second-class citizen.
How has the representation of New York residents in the Forbes 400 changed compared to California residents from 1982 to 2007?

In fact, it has been losing to Silicon Valley at its own game: the ratio of New York to California residents in the Forbes 400 has decreased from 1.45 (81:56) when the list was first published in 1982 to 0.83 (73:88) in 2007.
What cultural values and social dynamics are prominent in Los Angeles compared to New York?

The big thing in LA seems to be fame. There's an A-list of people who are most in demand right now, and what's most admired is to be on it or friends with those who are. Beneath that, the message is much like New York's, though perhaps with more emphasis on physical attractiveness.
What factors determine social status and influence in Washington, DC compared to Los Angeles?

In DC, the message seems to be that the most important thing is who you know. You want to be an insider. In practice, this seems to work much as in LA. There's an A List, and you want to be on it or close to those who are. The only difference is how the A List is selected. And even that is not that different.
How might the location choices of startups influence the future dynamics of Silicon Valley?

At the moment, San Francisco's message seems to be the same as Berkeley's: you should live better. But this will change if enough startups choose SF over the Valley. During the Bubble, that was a predictor of failure â a self-indulgent choice, like buying expensive office furniture. Even now, I'm suspicious when startups choose SF. But if enough good ones do, it stops being a self-indulgent choice because the center of gravity of Silicon Valley will shift there.
What does the author suggest about the persistence of aristocratic ideals in modern cities?

There's one more message I've heard from cities: in London, you can still (barely) hear the message that one should be more aristocratic. If you listen for it, you can also hear it in Paris, New York, and Boston. But this message is everywhere very faint. It would have been strong 100 years ago, but now I probably wouldn't have picked it up at all if I hadn't deliberately tuned in to that wavelength to see if there was any signal left.
What messages or values are commonly associated with urban environments?

The complete list of messages I've picked up from cities includes wealth, style, hipness, physical attractiveness, fame, political power, economic power, intelligence, social class, and quality of life.
What is the author's perspective on ambition when considering its various manifestations?

My immediate reaction to this list is that it makes me slightly queasy. I'd always considered ambition a good thing, but I realize now that was because I'd always implicitly understood it to mean ambition in the areas I cared about. When you list everything ambitious people are ambitious about, it's not so pretty.
How has the perception of physical attractiveness as a desirable trait evolved for men over the past century?

On closer examination, I see a couple of things on the list that are surprising in light of history. For example, physical attractiveness wouldn't have been there 100 years ago (though it might have been 2400 years ago). It has always mattered for women, but in the late twentieth century, it seems to have started to matter for men as well. I'm not sure why â probably some combination of the increasing power of women, the increasing influence of actors as models, and the fact that so many people work in offices now: you can't show off by wearing clothes too fancy to wear in a factory, so you have to show off with your body instead.
How has the concept of hipness evolved in relation to social class and cultural understanding?

Hipness is another concept you wouldn't have seen on the list 100 years ago. Or wouldn't you? What it means is to know what's what. So maybe it has simply replaced the component of social class that consisted of being "au fait." That could explain why hipness seems particularly admired in London: it's a version 2 of the traditional English delight in obscure codes that only insiders understand.
How has the concept of economic power evolved over the past century?

Economic power would have been on the list 100 years ago, but what we mean by it is changing. It used to mean the control of vast human and material resources. But increasingly, it means the ability to direct the course of technology, and some of the people in a position to do that are not even rich â leaders of important open-source projects, for example. The Captains of Industry of times past had laboratories full of clever people cooking up new technologies for them. The new breed are themselves those people.
Can great work be accomplished outside of major cities?

Does anyone who wants to do great work have to live in a great city? No; all great cities inspire some sort of ambition, but they aren't the only places that do. For some kinds of work, all you need is a handful of talented colleagues.
Why are cities less important for networking in fields like math and physics compared to other disciplines?

What cities provide is an audience and a funnel for peers. These aren't so critical in something like math or physics, where no audience matters except your peers, and judging ability is sufficiently straightforward that hiring and admissions committees can do it reliably. In a field like math or physics, all you need is a department with the right colleagues in it. It could be anywhere â in Los Alamos, New Mexico, for example.
Why is the environment particularly important for practitioners in fields like the arts, writing, and technology?

In fields like the arts, writing, and technology, the larger environment matters significantly. In these areas, the best practitioners aren't conveniently collected in a few top university departments and research labsâpartly because talent is harder to judge, and partly because people pay for these things, so one doesn't need to rely on teaching or research funding to support oneself. It's in these more chaotic fields that it helps most to be in a great city: you need the encouragement of feeling that people around you care about the kind of work you do, and since you have to find peers for yourself, you need the much larger intake mechanism of a great city.
Why is the social environment important for artists progressing in their careers?

The social environment is important for artists progressing in their careers because it provides a space where they can find peers and encouragement. It is often during the transition to more challenging stages in their work that this support becomes crucial. Artists seem to be able to leave their initial environments once they have found both community and inspiration. The Impressionists exemplify this pattern: they were born all over France (Pissarro was born in the Caribbean) and died all over France, but what defined them were the years they spent together in Paris.
What are the benefits of living in different cities during your youth?

Unless you're sure what you want to do and where the leading center for it is, your best bet is probably to try living in several places when you're young. You can never tell what message a city sends until you live there, or even whether it still sends one. Often your information will be wrong: I tried living in Florence when I was 25, thinking it would be an art center, but it turned out I was 450 years too late.
How do ambitious individuals often discover their true career paths?

Some people know at 16 what sort of work they're going to do, but in most ambitious kids, ambition seems to precede anything specific to be ambitious about. They know they want to do something great; they just haven't decided yet whether they're going to be a rock star or a brain surgeon. There's nothing wrong with that. But it means if you have this most common type of ambition, you'll probably have to figure out where to live by trial and error. You'll probably have to find the city where you feel at home to know what sort of ambition you have.
What are the benefits of having independent universities not controlled by the government?

One of the advantages of having universities in your country that are not controlled by the government is that when governments decide how to allocate resources, political deal-making causes things to be spread out geographically. No central government would put its two best universities in the same town unless it was the capital (which would cause other problems). However, scholars seem to like to cluster together, just as people in any other field do, and when given the freedom to do so, they derive the same advantages from it.
What is happening to the homes of aging professors in Palo Alto as they pass away?
There are still a few old professors in Palo Alto, but one by one they die, and their houses are transformed by developers into McMansions and sold to VPs of Bus Dev.
How does the perception of personal appearance and lifestyle differ between startup founders in New York and San Francisco?

How many times have you read about startup founders who continued to live inexpensively as their companies took off? Who continued to dress in jeans and t-shirts, to drive the old car they had in grad school, and so on? If you did that in New York, people would treat you like shit. If you walk into a fancy restaurant in San Francisco wearing jeans and a t-shirt, they're nice to you; who knows who you might be? Not in New York.
What does the number of restaurants requiring jackets for men indicate about a city's status as a technology hub?

One sign of a city's potential as a technology center is the number of restaurants that still require jackets for men. According to Zagat, there are none in San Francisco, LA, Boston, or Seattle; 4 in DC; 6 in Chicago; 8 in London; 13 in New York; and 20 in Paris.
Which restaurant on the West Coast is known for still requiring jackets for dining?

Zagat's lists the Ritz Carlton Dining Room in San Francisco as requiring jackets, but I couldn't believe it, so I called to check, and in fact, they don't. Apparently, there's only one restaurant left on the entire West Coast that still requires jackets: The French Laundry in Napa Valley.
What potential advantages could intellectual centers like Cambridge have over Silicon Valley in the future?

Ideas are one step upstream from economic power, so it's conceivable that intellectual centers like Cambridge will one day have an edge over Silicon Valley, similar to the one the Valley has over New York.
Why is New York considered the center of the art business despite Paris's reputation for artistic appreciation?

If Paris is where people care most about art, why is New York the center of gravity of the art business? Because in the twentieth century, art as brand split apart from art as stuff. New York is where the richest buyers are, but all they demand from art is brand, and since you can base brand on anything with a sufficiently identifiable style, you may as well use the local stuff.
How does the concept of distractions evolve in relation to technological advancements?

Chesterfield described dirt as matter out of place. Distracting is, similarly, desirable at the wrong time. Technology is continually being refined to produce more and more desirable things, which means that as we learn to avoid one class of distractions, new ones constantly appear, like drug-resistant bacteria.
How can seemingly harmless activities like browsing the Internet lead to increased distractions and decreased productivity over time?

After years of carefully avoiding classic time sinks like TV, games, and Usenet, I still managed to fall prey to distraction because I didn't realize that it evolves. Something that used to be safe, using the Internet, gradually became more and more dangerous. Some days I'd wake up, get a cup of tea, and check the news, then check email, then check the news again, then answer a few emails, and then suddenly notice it was almost lunchtime and I hadn't gotten any real work done. And this started to happen more and more often.
What realization did the author come to about the impact of the Internet on their productivity?

It took me surprisingly long to realize how distracting the Internet had become because the problem was intermittent. I ignored it the way you let yourself ignore a bug that only appears intermittently. When I was in the middle of a project, distractions weren't really a problem. It was when I finished one project and was deciding what to do next that they always bit me.
Why was it difficult for people to recognize the risks associated with excessive Internet use?

Another reason it was hard to notice the danger of this new type of distraction was that social customs hadn't yet caught up with it. If I had spent a whole morning sitting on a sofa watching TV, I would have noticed very quickly. That's a known danger sign, like drinking alone. But using the Internet still looked and felt a lot like work.
What prompted the author to change their approach to using the Internet?

Eventually, though, it became clear that the Internet had become so much more distracting that I had to start treating it differently. Basically, I had to add a new application to my list of known time sinks: Firefox.
What challenges did the author face in trying to limit their Internet usage?

At first, I tried rules. For example, I'd tell myself I was only going to use the Internet twice a day. But these schemes never worked for long. Eventually, something would come up that required me to use it more than that. And then I'd gradually slip back into my old ways.
How should one approach overcoming addictive behaviors?

Addictive behaviors must be treated as if they were sentient adversariesâas if there were a little man in your head always cooking up the most plausible arguments for doing whatever you're trying to stop doing. If you leave a path to it, he'll find it.
What solution did the author find to effectively manage their Internet usage?
I have found a more drastic solution that definitely works: to set up a separate computer for using the Internet.
What personal rules do you have to manage your online time effectively?

My rule is that I can spend as much time online as I want, as long as I do it on that computer. And this turns out to be enough. When I have to sit on the other side of the room to check email or browse the web, I become much more aware of it. Sufficiently aware, in my case at least, that it's hard to spend more than about an hour a day online.
How does disconnecting from the Internet affect your productivity and perception of time spent on your computer?

Disconnecting from the Internet has significantly impacted my productivity and perception of time spent on my computer. My main computer is now freed for work. If you try this trick, you'll probably be struck by how different it feels when your computer is disconnected from the Internet. It was alarming to me how foreign it felt to sit in front of a computer that could only be used for work, because that showed how much time I must have been wasting.
How can studying adult lies to children help individuals confront the falsehoods they were taught in their youth?

There may also be a benefit to us. We were all lied to as kids, and some of the lies we were told still affect us. By studying the ways adults lie to kids, we may be able to clear our heads of the lies we were told.
What are some examples of questions that adults typically avoid answering directly for children?

One of the most remarkable things about the way we lie to kids is how broad the conspiracy is. All adults know what their culture lies to kids about: they're the questions you answer with "Ask your parents." If a kid asked who won the World Series in 1982 or what the atomic weight of carbon was, you could just tell him. But if a kid asks you, "Is there a God?" or "What's a prostitute?" you'll probably say, "Ask your parents."
What impact did reading popular scientific books have on the author's beliefs about the Bible and the influence of the state on youth?

Through the reading of popular scientific books, I soon reached the conviction that much in the stories of the Bible could not be true. The consequence was a positively fanatic freethinking coupled with the impression that youth is intentionally being deceived by the state through lies; it was a crushing impression.
Why do adults often feel the need to lie to children?

If you ask adults why they lie to kids, the most common reason they give is to protect them. And kids do need protecting. The environment you want to create for a newborn child will be quite unlike the streets of a big city.
How can overprotective parenting negatively impact a teenager's understanding of the world?

Imagine if you tried to keep someone in as protected an environment as a newborn until age 18. To mislead someone so grossly about the world would seem not protection but abuse. That's an extreme example, of course; when parents do that sort of thing, it becomes national news. But you see the same problem on a smaller scale in the malaise teenagers feel in suburbia.
What are the perceived advantages and disadvantages of growing up in suburbia?

The main purpose of suburbia is to provide a protected environment for children to grow up in. It seems great for 10-year-olds. I liked living in suburbia when I was 10. I didn't notice how sterile it was. My whole world was no bigger than a few friends' houses I bicycled to and some woods I ran around in. On a log scale, I was midway between crib and globe. A suburban street was just the right size. But as I grew older, suburbia started to feel suffocatingly fake.
What concerns do parents have about urban environments that lead them to choose suburban living for their children?

What do parents hope to protect their children from by raising them in suburbia? A friend who moved out of Manhattan said merely that her 3-year-old daughter "saw too much." Off the top of my head, that might include: people who are high or drunk, poverty, madness, gruesome medical conditions, sexual behavior of various degrees of oddness, and violent anger.
What concerns might a parent have about exposing a young child to adult conflicts?

I think it's the anger that would worry me most if I had a 3-year-old. I was 29 when I moved to New York, and I was surprised even then. I wouldn't want a 3-year-old to see some of the disputes I saw; it would be too frightening. A lot of the things adults conceal from smaller children, they conceal because they'd be frightening, not because they want to conceal the existence of such things. Misleading the child is just a byproduct.
What are some common misconceptions that parents may unintentionally instill in their children as they grow up?

This seems one of the most justifiable types of lying adults do to kids. But because the lies are indirect, we don't keep a very strict accounting of them. Parents know they've concealed the facts about sex, and many at some point sit their kids down and explain more. However, few tell their kids about the differences between the real world and the cocoon they grew up in. Combine this with the confidence parents try to instill in their kids, and every year you get a new crop of 18-year-olds who think they know how to run the world.
How has the perception of teenagers' understanding of the world changed over the last century?

Don't all 18-year-olds think they know how to run the world? Actually, this seems to be a recent innovation, no more than about 100 years old. In preindustrial times, teenage kids were junior members of the adult world and comparatively well aware of their shortcomings. They could see they weren't as strong or skillful as the village smith. In past times, people lied to kids about some things more than we do now, but the lies implicit in an artificial, protected environment are a recent invention. Like a lot of new inventions, the rich got this first. Children of kings and great magnates were the first to grow up out of touch with the world. Suburbia means half the population can live like kings in that respect.
What concerns might a parent have about raising teenage children in an urban environment like New York?

Iâd have different worries about raising teenage kids in New York. Iâd worry less about what theyâd see and more about what theyâd do. I went to college with a lot of kids who grew up in Manhattan, and as a rule, they seemed pretty jaded. They seemed to have lost their virginity at an average of about 14, and by college, had tried more drugs than Iâd even heard of.
What do children likely perceive about the information they receive regarding sex, pregnancy, and sexually transmitted diseases?
Kids can probably sense they aren't being told the whole story. After all, pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases are just as much a problem for adults, and they have sex.
What factors contribute to parents' discomfort with their teenage children engaging in sexual activity?

What really bothers parents about their teenage kids having sex? Their dislike of the idea is so visceral it's probably inborn. But if it's inborn, it should be universal, and there are plenty of societies where parents don't mind if their teenage kids have sexâindeed, where it's normal for 14-year-olds to become mothers. So what's going on? There does seem to be a universal taboo against sex with prepubescent children. One can imagine evolutionary reasons for that. I think this is the main reason parents in industrialized societies dislike teenage kids having sex. They still think of them as children, even though biologically they're not, so the taboo against child sex still has force.
What risks are associated with the pursuit of pleasure from sex and drugs, particularly among teenagers?

One thing adults conceal about sex, they also conceal about drugs: that it can cause great pleasure. That's what makes sex and drugs so dangerous. The desire for them can cloud one's judgmentâwhich is especially frightening when the judgment being clouded is the already wretched judgment of a teenage kid.
Why do some parents discourage their children from having sex?

Another reason parents don't want their kids having sex is that they want to keep them innocent. Adults have a certain model of how kids are supposed to behave, and it's different from what they expect of other adults.
What is a key difference in language use between adults and children?

One of the most obvious differences is the words kids are allowed to use. Most parents use words when talking to other adults that they wouldn't want their kids using. They try to hide even the existence of these words for as long as they can. And this is another of those conspiracies everyone participates in: everyone knows you're not supposed to swear in front of kids.
Why do parents often find it appealing to preserve the innocence and mispronunciations of their young children?

One reason parents often find it appealing to preserve the innocence of their young children is that we are programmed to like certain kinds of helplessness. I have several times heard mothers say they deliberately refrained from correcting their young children's mispronunciations because they were so cute. If you think about it, cuteness is a form of helplessness. Toys and cartoon characters meant to be cute always have clueless expressions and stubby, ineffectual limbs.
Why is it important for children to maintain a sense of innocence as they learn about the world?

Innocence is also open-mindedness. We want kids to be innocent so they can continue to learn. Paradoxical as it sounds, there are some kinds of knowledge that get in the way of other kinds of knowledge. If you're going to learn that the world is a brutal place full of people trying to take advantage of one another, you're better off learning it last. Otherwise, you won't bother learning much more.
Why might some highly intelligent adults choose to remain unaware of certain knowledge?

Very smart adults often seem unusually innocent, and I don't think this is a coincidence. I think they've deliberately avoided learning about certain things. Certainly, I do. I used to think I wanted to know everything. Now I know I don't.
Why do adults often avoid discussing the topic of death with children?

After sex, death is the topic adults lie most conspicuously about to kids. Sex, I believe, is concealed because of deep taboos. But why do we conceal death from kids? Probably because small children are particularly horrified by it. They want to feel safe, and death is the ultimate threat.
What elaborate story did the narrator's parents create about the death of their first cat?

One of the most spectacular lies our parents told us was about the death of our first cat. Over the years, as we asked for more details, they were compelled to invent more, so the story grew quite elaborate. The cat had died at the vet's office. Of what? Of the anesthesia itself. Why was the cat at the vet's office? To be fixed. And why had such a routine operation killed it? It wasn't the vet's fault; the cat had a congenitally weak heart; the anesthesia was too much for it; but there was no way anyone could have known this in advance. It was not until we were in our twenties that the truth came out: my sister, then about three, had accidentally stepped on the cat and broken its back.
How did the author's parents approach discussions about death and the afterlife with their children?

They didn't feel the need to tell us that the cat was now happily in cat heaven. My parents never claimed that people or animals who died had "gone to a better place," or that we'd meet them again. It didn't seem to harm us.
What was the experience of the narrator's grandmother on the day of the grandfather's death?

My grandmother told us an edited version of the death of my grandfather. She said they'd been sitting reading one day, and when she said something to him, he didn't answer. He seemed to be asleep, but when she tried to rouse him, she couldn't. "He was gone." Having a heart attack sounded like falling asleep. Later, I learned it hadn't been so neat, and the heart attack had taken most of a day to kill him.
Why do children often prefer to believe comforting falsehoods about their world?

On this topic, especially, they're met halfway by kids. Kids often want to be lied to. They want to believe they're living in a comfortable, safe world as much as their parents want them to believe it.
What impact does labeling a child's ethnic or religious identity have on their personal development?

Labeling a child with a particular ethnic or religious identity is one of the stickiest things you can do. Almost anything else you tell a kid, they can change their mind about later when they start to think for themselves. But if you tell a kid they're a member of a certain group, that seems nearly impossible to shake.
How do parents' religious choices influence their children's identity formation?

Parents' religious choices can significantly influence their children's identity formation. When parents are of different religions, they often agree between themselves that their children will be "raised as Xes." This approach works; the children grow up considering themselves as Xes, despite the fact that if their parents had chosen differently, they would have grown up considering themselves as Ys.
What are some reasons adults hide their flaws from children?

Most adults make some effort to conceal their flaws from children. Usually, their motives are mixed. For example, a father who has an affair generally conceals it from his children. His motive is partly that it would worry them, partly that this would introduce the topic of sex, and partly (a larger part than he would admit) that he doesn't want to tarnish himself in their eyes.
How does the behavior of adults influence children's self-perception and feelings of guilt?

Adults often conceal their flaws while insisting on high standards of behavior for children. As a result, many kids grow up feeling that they fall hopelessly short. They walk around feeling horribly guilty for having used a swear word, while in fact, most of the adults around them are engaging in much worse behavior.
Why do some people feel compelled to provide answers even when they don't know them?

This happens in intellectual as well as moral questions. The more confident people are, the more willing they seem to be to answer a question with "I don't know."
