Less confident people feel they have to have an answer or they'll look bad. My parents were pretty good about admitting when they didn't know things, but I must have been told a lot of lies of this type by teachers because I rarely heard a teacher say "I don't know" until I got to college. I remember because it was so surprising to hear someone say that in front of a class.
What realization did the author have about teachers during their sixth-grade experience?

The first hint I had that teachers weren't omniscient came in sixth grade, after my father contradicted something I'd learned in school. When I protested that the teacher had said the opposite, my father replied that the teacher had no idea what he was talking aboutâthat he was just an elementary school teacher, after all.
What does the author imply about the academic preparedness of US public school teachers and its impact on students' perceptions?

The sad fact is, US public school teachers don't generally understand the stuff they're teaching very well. There are some sterling exceptions, but as a rule, people planning to go into teaching rank academically near the bottom of the college population. So the fact that I still thought at age 11 that teachers were infallible shows what a job the system must have done on my brain.
What are the inherent biases present in public school textbooks regarding historical narratives?

Public school textbooks represent a compromise between what various powerful groups want kids to be told. The lies are rarely overt; usually, they consist either of omissions or of over-emphasizing certain topics at the expense of others. The view of history we got in elementary school was a crude hagiography, with at least one representative of each powerful group.
What impact does misrepresenting historical figures' achievements have on understanding racial barriers in science?

It's obvious now that he was on the list because he was black (and for that matter, that Marie Curie was on it because she was a woman), but as a kid, I was confused for years about him. I wonder if it wouldn't have been better just to tell us the truth: that there weren't any famous black scientists. Ranking George Washington Carver with Einstein misled us not only about science but about the obstacles blacks faced in his time.
How did the perception of historical figures change as one learned more about their personal lives?

As subjects got softer, the lies got more frequent. By the time you got to politics and recent history, what we were taught was pretty much pure propaganda. For example, we were taught to regard political leaders as saintsâespecially the recently martyred Kennedy and King. It was astonishing to learn later that they'd both been serial womanizers and that Kennedy was a speed freak to boot. (By the time King's plagiarism emerged, I'd lost the ability to be surprised by the misdeeds of famous people.)
What is a common misconception about success in schools regarding rules?
Probably the biggest lie told in schools, though, is that the way to succeed is through following "the rules." In fact, most such rules are just hacks to manage large groups efficiently.
Why do adults often lie to children?

Often, when we lie to people, it's not part of any conscious strategy, but because they'd react violently to the truth. Kids, almost by definition, lack self-control. They react violently to thingsâand so they get lied to a lot.
How can early experiences and parental reassurances shape our perception of environmental issues?

One consequence of this sort of calming lie is that we grow up thinking horrible things are normal. It's hard for us to feel a sense of urgency as adults over something we've literally been trained not to worry about. When I was about 10, I saw a documentary on pollution that put me into a panic. It seemed the planet was being irretrievably ruined. I went to my mother afterward to ask if this was so. I don't remember what she said, but she made me feel better, so I stopped worrying about it.
What physiological changes occur in a sprinter's body during a race that lead to the need for recovery afterward?

A sprinter in a race almost immediately enters a state called "oxygen debt." His body switches to an emergency source of energy that's faster than regular aerobic respiration. However, this process builds up waste products that ultimately require extra oxygen to break down, so at the end of the race, he has to stop and pant for a while to recover.
What challenges do individuals face regarding the truths and lies they were taught during childhood as they transition into adulthood?

We arrive at adulthood with a kind of truth debt. We were told a lot of lies to get us (and our parents) through our childhood. Some may have been necessary; some probably weren't. But we all arrive at adulthood with heads full of lies.
What is the initial step to achieving mental clarity and objectivity?

The first step in clearing your head is to realize how far you are from a neutral observer. When I left high school, I thought I was a complete skeptic. I had realized high school was crap and believed I was ready to question everything I knew. However, among the many other things I was ignorant of was how much debris there already was in my head. It's not enough to consider your mind a blank slate; you have to consciously erase it.
What is the author's stance on the use of euphemisms for lies in writing?

"I can't predict which these will be, and I don't want to write an essay that will seem dumb in 100 years. So instead of using special euphemisms for lies that seem excusable according to present fashions, I'm just going to call all our lies lies."
How do small children's perception of time affect their understanding of life and mortality?

As a friend with small children pointed out, it's easy for small children to consider themselves immortal because time seems to pass so slowly for them. To a 3-year-old, a day feels like a month might to an adult. So, 80 years sounds to him like 2,400 years would to us.
What is the author's perspective on the nature of religion in relation to truth and societal beliefs?

I realize I'm going to get endless grief for classifying religion as a type of lie. Usually, people skirt that issue with some equivocation, implying that lies believed for a sufficiently long time by sufficiently large numbers of people are immune to the usual standards for truth. But because I can't predict which lies future generations will consider inexcusable, I can't safely omit any type we tell. Yes, it seems unlikely that religion will be out of fashion in 100 years, but no more unlikely than it would have seemed to someone in 1880 that schoolchildren in 1980 would be taught that masturbation was perfectly normal and not to feel guilty about it.
Why do teenagers often withhold information from their parents?

The ironic thing is, this is also the main reason kids lie to adults. If you freak out when people tell you alarming things, they won't tell you them. Teenagers don't tell their parents what happened that night they were supposed to be staying at a friend's house for the same reason parents don't tell 5-year-olds the truth about the Thanksgiving turkey: they'd freak if they knew.
Who contributed feedback on the drafts of this work, and what was their stance on the ideas presented?

I would like to thank Sam Altman, Marc Andreessen, Trevor Blackwell, Patrick Collison, Jessica Livingston, Jackie McDonough, Robert Morris, and David Sloo for reading drafts of this work. Since there are some controversial ideas here, I should add that none of them agreed with everything in it.
What motto did the founders of Y Combinator adopt to guide their startup philosophy?

About a month after we started Y Combinator, we came up with the phrase that became our motto: "Make something people want." We've learned a lot since then, but if I were choosing now, that's still the one I'd pick.
Why should founders focus more on building a great product than on their initial business model?

Another thing we tell founders is not to worry too much about the business model, at least at first. Not because making money is unimportant, but because it's so much easier than building something great.
What concept emerges when combining the ideas of creating demand and prioritizing purpose over profit?

A couple of weeks ago, I realized that if you put those two ideas together, you get something surprising: make something people want. Don't worry too much about making money. What you've got is a description of a charity.
How does Craigslist maintain a competitive advantage in generating revenue compared to other companies?

Craigslist maintains a competitive advantage in generating revenue by effectively positioning itself "upwind" of enormous revenues. This strategic advantage allows them to decide when and if to engage with competitors. While they may face challenges if they wanted to increase their revenue further, these challenges differ significantly from those encountered by companies that struggle to sell inferior products to indifferent users, often spending ten times as much on sales as on development.
What can startups learn from the early phases of Craigslist?
I'm not saying startups should aim to end up like Craigslist. They're a product of unusual circumstances, but they are a good model for the early phases.
How did Google's early approach to advertising and its mission resemble that of a nonprofit organization?

Google looked a lot like a charity in the beginning. They didn't have ads for over a year. At year one, Google was indistinguishable from a nonprofit. If a nonprofit or government organization had started a project to index the web, Google at year one is the limit of what they'd have produced.
What motivated the idea of creating a web-based email service with effective spam filtering?

Back when I was working on spam filters, I thought it would be a good idea to have a web-based email service with good spam filtering. I wasn't thinking of it as a company; I just wanted to keep people from getting spammed. But as I thought more about this project, I realized it would probably have to be a company. It would cost something to run, and it would be a pain to fund with grants and donations.
What surprising insight did the author have about the relationship between benevolence and company structure?
That was a surprising realization. Companies often claim to be benevolent, but it was surprising to realize that there were purely benevolent projects that had to be embodied as companies to work.
What opportunity was missed in the email service industry due to poor spam filtering during a specific time period?

There was a window of about two years when spam was increasing rapidly, but all the big email services had terrible filters. If someone had launched a new, spam-free mail service, users would have flocked to it. I didn't want to start another company, so I didn't do it. But if someone had, they'd probably be quite rich now.
How do successful startups and nonprofits exhibit similar behaviors and ideas?

Notice the pattern here? From either direction, we get to the same spot. If you start from successful startups, you find they often behave like nonprofits. And if you start from ideas for nonprofits, you find they often make good startups.
How did Microsoft's early approach to the PC market compare to that of IBM, and what impact did it have on hardware prices?

Initially, I thought maybe this principle only applied to Internet startups. Obviously, it worked for Google, but what about Microsoft? Surely Microsoft isn't benevolent? When I think back to the beginning, they were. Compared to IBM, they were like Robin Hood. When IBM introduced the PC, they thought they were going to make money selling hardware at high prices. However, by gaining control of the PC standard, Microsoft opened up the market to any manufacturer. Hardware prices plummeted, and lots of people got to have computers who couldn't otherwise have afforded them. It's the sort of thing you'd expect Google to do.
How does a company's size influence its treatment of customers?

You can see how there would be a difference. When you're small, you can't bully customers, so you have to charm them. Whereas when you're big, you can maltreat them at will, and you tend to, because it's easier than satisfying them. You grow big by being nice, but you can stay big by being mean.
How does benevolence contribute to the success of startups?

There's a lot of external evidence that benevolence works. But how does it work? One advantage of investing in a large number of startups is that you get a lot of data about how they work. From what we've seen, being good seems to help startups in three ways: it improves their morale, it makes other people want to help them, and above all, it helps them be decisive.
How does morale impact the success of a startup?

Morale is tremendously important to a startupâso important that morale alone is almost enough to determine success. Startups are often described as emotional roller coasters. One minute you're going to take over the world, and the next you're doomed. The problem with feeling you're doomed is not just that it makes you unhappy, but that it makes you less productive and can negatively affect team dynamics.
How do attitudes towards success and failure impact effort and outcomes?

The downhills of the roller coaster are more of a self-fulfilling prophecy than the uphills. If you feel you're going to succeed, that makes you work harder, which probably improves your chances of succeeding. However, if you feel you're going to fail, that can make you stop working, which practically guarantees you'll fail.
How does a sense of benevolence affect an entrepreneur's perseverance in the face of challenges?

Benevolence plays a crucial role in an entrepreneur's perseverance. If you feel you're genuinely helping people, you'll continue working even when it seems like your startup is doomed. Most of us have some amount of natural benevolence; the mere fact that someone needs you makes you want to help them. So, if you start a type of startup where users come back each day, you've essentially built yourself a giant Tamagotchi. You've created something that you need to take care of.
What motivated Evan Williams to continue running Blogger despite the company's financial struggles and staff departures?

Blogger is a famous example of a startup that went through really low lows and survived. At one point, they ran out of money, and everyone left. Evan Williams came in to work the next day, and there was no one but him. What kept him going? Partly that users needed him. He was hosting thousands of people's blogs, and he couldn't just let the site die.
What is the significance of acquiring users early in the product launch process?

There are many advantages to launching quickly, but the most important may be that once you have users, the Tamagotchi effect kicks in. Once you have users to take care of, you're forced to figure out what will make them happy, and that's actually very valuable information.
What motivated the founders to commit to their service despite potential personal sacrifices?

He told me recently that he and his cofounder had decided that this service was something the world needed, so they were going to keep working on it no matter what, even if they had to move back to Canada and live in their parents' basements.
How did the Chatterouses' attitude towards investors change, and what impact did it have on investor interest?

Once they realized this, they stopped caring so much about what investors thought of them. They still met with them, but they weren't going to die if they didn't get their money. And you know what? The investors got a lot more interested. They could sense that the Chatterouses were going to do this startup with or without them.
How does a strong sense of mission contribute to the resilience of a startup?

A strong sense of mission contributes to the resilience of a startup by making the founders deeply committed to their goals. If you're really committed and your startup is cheap to run, you become very hard to kill. Practically all startups, even the most successful, come close to death at some point. So, if doing good for people gives you a sense of mission that makes you harder to kill, that alone more than compensates for whatever you lose by not choosing a more selfish project.
What role does Octopart play in the search for industrial components?
Octopart is a search site for industrial components. A lot of people need to search for components, and before Octopart, there was no good way to do it. That, it turned out, was no coincidence.
What challenges has Octopart faced from Digi-Key in terms of pricing transparency?

Octopart built the right way to search for components. Users like it, and they've been growing rapidly. And yet, for most of Octopart's life, the biggest distributor, Digi-Key, has been trying to force them to take their prices off the site. Octopart is sending them customers for free, and yet Digi-Key is trying to make that traffic stop. Why? Because their current business model depends on overcharging people who have incomplete information about prices. They don't want search to work.
What qualities do the best hackers possess that make them valuable to companies like Google?

The best hackers possess qualities that make them much better than mediocre ones. If you can attract the best hackers to work for you, as Google has, you have a big advantage. The very best hackers tend to be idealistic; they are not desperate for a job and can work wherever they want. Therefore, most want to work on things that will make the world better.
What principle should guide your decision-making to ensure success in serving your audience?

Here's the answer: Do whatever's best for your users. You can hold onto this like a rope in a hurricane, and it will save you if anything can. Follow it, and it will take you through everything you need to do.
How can a strong user base influence investor confidence?

A strong user base can significantly influence investor confidence. If you make something that users love enough to tell their friends, you can grow exponentially. This growth can be a more reliable way to convince investors than simply trying to sell them on your idea. When investors see a product that has a passionate and expanding user base, it reassures them of the potential for success and profitability.
Why is being honest considered a beneficial approach in complex decision-making scenarios?

Being honest is a particularly useful strategy for making decisions in complex situations because it's stateless. It's like telling the truth. The trouble with lying is that you have to remember everything you've said in the past to make sure you don't contradict yourself. If you tell the truth, you don't have to remember anything, and that's a really useful property in domains where things happen fast.
What approach does Y Combinator take when advising multiple startups simultaneously?

Y Combinator takes a stateless algorithm approach when advising multiple startups simultaneously. With 80 startups invested in, 57 of which are still operational, it becomes essential to avoid ulterior motives. When managing 57 startups, it is impossible to remember all the details. Therefore, the guiding principle is to do whatever is best for the founders. This approach is not based on benevolence but is the only algorithm that works effectively at that scale.
What is the author's perspective on the concept of being "good"?

When you write something telling people to be good, you seem to be claiming to be good yourself. So I want to say explicitly that I am not a particularly good person. When I was a kid, I was firmly in the camp of bad. The way adults used the word good, it seemed to be synonymous with quiet, so I grew up very suspicious of it.
Why is it important to prioritize being good over simply avoiding evil in decision-making and design?

I'm not suggesting you be good in the usual sanctimonious way. I'm suggesting it because it works. It will work not just as a statement of "values," but as a guide to strategy and even a design spec for software. Don't just not be evil. Be good.
How has the perception of dividend payments for public companies, particularly in the tech sector, evolved over the past fifty years?

Fifty years ago, it would have seemed shocking for a public company not to pay dividends. Now, many tech companies don't. The markets seem to have figured out how to value potential dividends. Maybe that isn't the last step in this evolution. Perhaps markets will eventually get comfortable with potential earnings. (VCs already are, and at least some of them consistently make money.)
What distinguishes genuine growth from artificial growth in a company's success?

Genuine growth is distinguished from artificial growth in a company's success by the sustainability and authenticity of that growth. For example, it's okay to focus on growth instead of profitsâbut only if the growth is genuine. You can't be buying users; that's a pyramid scheme. However, a company with rapid, genuine growth is valuable, and eventually, markets learn how to value valuable things.
What is a common shortcoming of benevolent projects regarding accountability?
Most explicitly benevolent projects don't hold themselves sufficiently accountable. They act as if having good intentions were enough to guarantee good effects.
Why is Einstein not included in the author's list of admirable people?

Einstein isn't on the list, for example, even though he probably deserves to be on any shortlist of admirable people. I once asked a physicist friend if Einstein was really as smart as his fame implies, and she said that yes, he was. So why isn't he on the list? Because I had to ask. This is a list of people who've influenced me, not people who would have if I understood their work.
What criteria did the author use to determine if someone qualifies as a hero?

My test was to think of someone and ask, "Is this person my hero?" It often returned surprising answers. For example, it returned false for Montaigne, who was arguably the inventor of the essay. Why? When I thought about what it meant to call someone a hero, it meant I'd decide what to do by asking what they'd do in the same situation. That's a stricter standard than admiration.
What qualities do the individuals on your list share that contribute to their subversive nature?

After I made the list, I looked to see if there was a pattern, and there wasâa very clear one. Everyone on the list had two qualities: they cared almost excessively about their work, and they were absolutely honest. By honest, I don't mean trustworthy so much as that they never pander; they never say or do something because that's what the audience wants. They are all fundamentally subversive for this reason, though they conceal it to varying degrees.
How did the Pittsburgh Steelers influence the local community during the economic decline of the 1970s?

I grew up in Pittsburgh in the 1970s. Unless you were there, it's hard to imagine how that town felt about the Steelers. Locally, all the news was bad. The steel industry was dying. But the Steelers were the best team in football â and moreover, in a way that seemed to reflect the personality of the city. They didn't do anything fancy; they just got the job done.
What qualities contributed to his exceptional performance in the game?

He was utterly relentless, which contributed significantly to his exceptional performance in the game. He didn't just care about playing well; he cared almost too much. He seemed to regard it as a personal insult when someone from the other team had possession of the ball on his side of the line of scrimmage.
What qualities make Kenneth Clark stand out as a nonfiction writer in the field of art history?

Kenneth Clark is the best nonfiction writer I know of on any subject. Most people who write about art history don't really like art; you can tell from a thousand little signs. But Clark did, and not just intellectually, but in the way one anticipates a delicious dinner.
What distinguishes the author's writing style and the depth of his ideas?

What really makes him stand out, though, is the quality of his ideas. His style is deceptively casual, but there is more in his books than in a library of art monographs. Reading his work reveals a depth that is both engaging and thought-provoking.
What is the experience of reading a particularly thrilling and fast-paced book like?

Reading a particularly thrilling and fast-paced book is like a ride in a Ferrari. Just as you're getting settled, you're slammed back in your seat by the acceleration. Before you can adjust, you're thrown sideways as the car screeches into the first turn. The author's brain throws off ideas almost too fast to grasp them. Finally, at the end of the chapter, you come to a halt, with your eyes wide and a big smile on your face.
How did Larry Mihalko impact your educational experience?

A lot of people have a great teacher at some point in their childhood. Larry Mihalko was mine. When I look back, it's like there's a line drawn between third and fourth grade. After Mr. Mihalko, everything was different.
What qualities made the teacher's classroom experience exceptional for his students?

First of all, he was intellectually curious. I had a few other teachers who were smart, but I wouldn't describe them as intellectually curious. In retrospect, he was out of place as an elementary school teacher, and I think he knew it. That must have been hard for him, but it was wonderful for us, his students. His class was a constant adventure. I used to like going to school every day.
What impact did Mr. Mihalko have on his students compared to other teachers?

The other thing that made him different was that he liked us. Kids are good at telling that. The other teachers were, at best, benevolently indifferent. But Mr. Mihalko seemed like he actually wanted to be our friend. On the last day of fourth grade, he got out one of the heavy school record players and played James Taylor's "You've Got a Friend" for us. "Just call out my name, and you know wherever I am, I'll come running." He died at 59 of lung cancer. I've never cried like I cried at his funeral.
What is the relationship between creating art for oneself and the quality of the artwork produced?

One of the things I've learned about making things that I didn't realize when I was a kid is that much of the best stuff isn't made for audiences, but for oneself. You see paintings and drawings in museums and imagine they were made for you to look at. Actually, a lot of the best ones were made as a way of exploring the world, not as a way to please other people. The best of these explorations are sometimes more pleasing than stuff made explicitly to please.
What distinguishes these creations in their purpose and artistic value?

They are clearly made more as a way of studying the world than producing something beautiful. And yet, they can hold their own with any work of art ever made. No one else, before or since, was that good when no one was looking.
What strategy does Robert Morris use to ensure he is never wrong?

Robert Morris has a very unusual quality: he's never wrong. It might seem this would require you to be omniscient, but actually, it's surprisingly easy. Don't say anything unless you're fairly sure of it. If you're not omniscient, you just don't end up saying much.
What strategy has Robert used to minimize mistakes in his statements?

More precisely, the trick is to pay careful attention to how you qualify what you say. By using this trick, Robert has, as far as I know, managed to be mistaken only once, and that was when he was an undergrad. When the Mac came out, he said that little desktop computers would never be suitable for real hacking.
What qualities distinguish Robert's integrity from mere cleverness or trickery?

It's wrong to call it a trick in his case, though. If it were a conscious trick, he would have slipped in a moment of excitement. With Robert, this quality is wired in. He has an almost superhuman integrity. He's not just generally correct, but also correct about how correct he is.
Why is Wodehouse considered a particularly impressive writer despite the perception of popular and entertaining literature?

People are finally starting to admit that Wodehouse was a great writer. If you want to be thought a great novelist in your own time, you have to sound intellectual. If what you write is popular, or entertaining, or funny, you're ipso facto suspect. That makes Wodehouse doubly impressive because it meant that to write as he wanted to, he had to commit to being despised in his own lifetime.
How was Evelyn Waugh's assessment of a certain writer perceived by the literary community of his time?

Evelyn Waugh called him a great writer, but to most people at the time, that would have read as a chivalrous or deliberately perverse gesture. At the time, any random autobiographical novel by a recent college grad could count on more respectful treatment from the literary establishment.
Who are the three writers noted for their exceptional style in English literature?

Wodehouse may have begun with simple atoms, but the way he composed them into molecules was near faultless, particularly his rhythm. It makes me self-conscious to write about it. I can think of only two other writers who came near him for style: Evelyn Waugh and Nancy Mitford. Those three used the English language like they owned it.
What distinguishes Wodehouse's attitude towards public perception from that of Evelyn Waugh and Nancy Mitford?

But Wodehouse has something neither of them did. He's at ease. Evelyn Waugh and Nancy Mitford cared what other people thought of them: he wanted to seem aristocratic; she was afraid she wasn't smart enough. But Wodehouse didn't give a damn what anyone thought of him. He wrote exactly what he wanted.
What qualities of Modernism distinguished it from the art of the nineteenth century?

What was good about Modernism was its freshness. Art became stuffy in the nineteenth century. The paintings that were popular at the time were mostly the art equivalent of McMansionsâbig, pretentious, and fake. Modernism meant starting over, making things with the same earnest motives that children might. The artists who benefited most from this were the ones who had preserved a child's confidence, like Klee and Calder.
What qualities make Calder's art more appealing to some viewers compared to Klee's?

Klee was impressive because he could work in so many different styles. However, between the two, I like Calder better because his work seemed happier. Ultimately, the point of art is to engage the viewer. It's hard to predict what will engage; often, something that seems interesting at first will bore you after a month. How has the amount of personal possessions in households changed over the years?

It wasn't always this way. Stuff used to be rare and valuable. You can still see evidence of that if you look for it. For example, in my house in Cambridge, which was built in 1876, the bedrooms don't have closets. In those days, people's stuff fit in a chest of drawers. Even as recently as a few decades ago, there was a lot less stuff. When I look back at photos from the 1970s, I'm surprised how empty houses look. As a kid, I had what I thought was a huge fleet of toy cars, but they'd be dwarfed by the number of toys my nephews have. All together, my Matchboxes and Corgis took up about a third of the surface of my bed. In my nephews' rooms, the bed is the only clear space.
What challenges did the author face regarding material possessions during a time of financial hardship?

That was a big problem for me when I had no money. I felt poor, and stuff seemed valuable, so almost instinctively I accumulated it. Friends would leave something behind when they moved, or I'd see something as I was walking down the street on trash night (beware of anything you find yourself describing as "perfectly good"), or I'd find something in almost new condition for a tenth of its retail price at a garage sale. And pow, more stuff.
Why is accumulating free or nearly free items often not a good idea?
In fact, these free or nearly free items weren't bargains because they were worth even less than they cost. Most of the stuff I accumulated was worthless because I didn't need it.
What is the true measure of value when acquiring new items?

What I didn't understand was that the value of some new acquisition wasn't the difference between its retail price and what I paid for it. It was the value I derived from it. Stuff is an extremely illiquid asset. Unless you have some plan for selling that valuable thing you got so cheaply, what difference does it make what it's "worth?" The only way you're ever going to extract any value from it is to use it. And if you don't have any immediate use for it, you probably never will.
How can excessive accumulation of possessions affect a person's lifestyle and choices?

In fact, it's worse than worthless because once you've accumulated a certain amount of stuff, it starts to own you rather than the other way around. I know of one couple who couldn't retire to the town they preferred because they couldn't afford a place there big enough for all their stuff. Their house isn't theirs; it's their stuff's.
How does a cluttered environment affect mental well-being and energy levels?

A cluttered environment can significantly affect mental well-being and energy levels. Unless you're extremely organized, a house full of stuff can be very depressing. A cluttered room saps one's spirits. One reason, obviously, is that there's less room for people in a room full of stuff. But there's more going on than that. Humans constantly scan their environment to build a mental model of what's around them. The harder a scene is to parse, the less energy you have left for conscious thoughts. A cluttered room is literally exhausting.
Why might children be less affected by clutter compared to adults?
This could explain why clutter doesn't seem to bother kids as much as adults. Kids are less perceptive; they build a coarser model of their surroundings, and this consumes less energy.
What lesson did the author learn about material possessions during their year in Italy?

I first realized the worthlessness of stuff when I lived in Italy for a year. All I took with me was one large backpack of belongings. The rest of my things I left in my landlady's attic back in the US. And you know what? All I missed were some of the books. By the end of the year, I couldn't even remember what else I had stored in that attic.
What regret does the speaker express about their spending habits?
The really painful thing to recall is not just that I accumulated all this useless stuff, but that I often spent money I desperately needed on things that I didn't.
Why is shopping considered a leisure activity by many consumers?

Shopping is considered a leisure activity by many consumers because the people whose job it is to sell you stuff are really, really good at it. The average 25-year-old is no match for companies that have spent years figuring out how to get you to spend money on things. They make the experience of buying items so pleasant that "shopping" becomes a leisure activity.
What strategy can help you avoid being manipulated by salespeople?

How do you protect yourself from these people? It can't be easy. I'm a fairly skeptical person, and their tricks worked on me well into my thirties. But one thing that might work is to ask yourself, before buying something, "Is this going to make my life noticeably better?"
What strategy can help someone break a habit of unnecessary purchasing?

A friend of mine cured herself of a clothes-buying habit by asking herself before she bought anything, "Am I going to wear this all the time?" If she couldn't convince herself that something she was thinking of buying would become one of those few things she wore all the time, she wouldn't buy it. I think that would work for any kind of purchase. Before you buy anything, ask yourself: Will this be something I use constantly? Or is it just something nice? Or worse still, a mere bargain?
What are the challenges associated with owning fragile items like "good china"?

The worst aspect of owning fragile items, like "good china," may be that they are seldom used because they are considered too valuable. Nothing owns you like fragile items. For example, the "good china" that many households possess is often not fun to use, but rather requires extra caution to avoid breaking it.
What criteria should you use to determine the value of your possessions?

Every thing you own takes energy away from you. Some give more than they take. Those are the only things worth having. You should consider how much energy each possession requires versus what it contributes to your life. If a possession drains your energy without providing value, it may not be worth keeping.
What significant shift in societal values regarding material possessions has the speaker observed?

I'm not claiming this is because I've achieved some kind of zen-like detachment from material things. I'm talking about something more mundane. A historical change has taken place, and I've now realized it. Stuff used to be valuable, and now it's not.
How has the relationship between wealth and consumption changed in industrialized countries over the past century?

In industrialized countries, the same thing happened with food in the middle of the twentieth century. As food got cheaper (or we got richer; they're indistinguishable), eating too much started to be a bigger danger than eating too little. We've now reached that point with stuff. For most people, rich or poor, stuff has become a burden.
What criteria should you use to determine if trading stock in your company is beneficial?

Whenever you're trading stock in your company for anything, whether it's money, an employee, or a deal with another company, the test for whether to do it is the same. You should give up n% of your company if what you trade it for improves your average outcome enough that the (100 - n)% you have left is worth more than the whole company was before.
What is the minimum improvement in average outcome required for an investor's investment in half of a company to be worthwhile?

For example, if an investor wants to buy half your company, how much does that investment have to improve your average outcome for you to break even? Obviously, it has to double: if you trade half your company for something that more than doubles the company's average outcome, you're net ahead. You have half as big a share of something worth more than twice as much.
Why does Sequoia's investment strategy benefit startup founders?

The reason Sequoia's investment strategy benefits startup founders is that the percentage of the company they take is artificially low. They don't even try to get market price for their investment; they limit their holdings to leave the founders enough stock to feel the company is still theirs.
What are the chances of a startup receiving funding from Sequoia Capital?

The catch is that Sequoia receives about 6,000 business plans a year and funds about 20 of them, so the odds of getting this great deal are 1 in 300. The companies that make it through are not average startups.
What percentage of equity should a startup offer to a talented hacker to justify their potential contribution to the company's value?

For example, suppose you're just two founders and you want to hire an additional hacker who's so good you feel he'll increase the average outcome of the whole company by 20%. n = (1.2 - 1)/1.2 = 0.167. So you'll break even if you trade 16.7% of the company for him.
How can startups effectively convert employee salary and overhead costs into stock compensation?

To convert employee salary and overhead costs into stock compensation, you should multiply the annual rate by about 1.5. Most startups grow fast or die; if you die, you don't have to pay the employee, and if you grow fast, you'll be paying next year's salary out of next year's valuation, which should be 3x this year's. If your valuation grows 3x a year, the total cost in stock of a new hire's salary and overhead is 1.5 years' cost at the present valuation.
How do you calculate the offer percentage for a new hire based on the company's profit goals and valuation?

Let's run through an example. Suppose the company wants to make a "profit" of 50% on the new hire mentioned above. So, subtract a third from 16.7%, and we have 11.1% as his "retail" price. Suppose further that he's going to cost $60k a year in salary and overhead, multiplied by 1.5, which equals $90k total. If the company's valuation is $2 million, $90k is 4.5%. Thus, 11.1% - 4.5% = an offer of 6.6%.
Why is it crucial for early employees to accept lower salaries in a startup?

It is crucial for early employees to accept lower salaries in a startup because this allows the company to allocate more resources towards growth and development. The savings from salaries can be redirected into stock options that could otherwise be given to them.
What should one consider when estimating stock grants for employees?

When estimating stock grants for employees, it is important to recognize that there is a great deal of variability in these numbers. I'm not claiming that stock grants can now be reduced to a formula; ultimately, you always have to make an educated guess. However, it is essential to understand what you are guessing. If you choose a number based on your gut feeling or a table of typical grant sizes supplied by a VC firm, be aware that those are merely estimates.
What formula can be used to evaluate the sensibility of equity-related decisions?

When you make any decision involving equity, run it through the formula 1/(1 - n) to see if it makes sense. You should always feel richer after trading equity. If the trade didn't increase the value of your remaining shares enough to put you net ahead, you wouldn't have (or shouldn't have) done it.
What is the best method to determine the current valuation of a company following its last funding round?

The obvious choice for your present valuation is the post-money valuation of your last funding round. This probably undervalues the company, though, because (a) unless your last round just happened, the company is presumably worth more, and (b) the valuation of an early funding round usually reflects some other contribution by the investors.
