In a notebook, you can guess what a scribble means by looking at the pages around it. During the scrap era, I was constantly finding notes I'd written years before that might say something I needed to remember, if I could only figure out what.
Why does the author bring multiple books on their trips?

As for books, I know the house would probably have something to read. On the average trip, I bring four books and only read one of them because I find new books to read en route. Really, bringing books is insurance.
What does the author suggest about their relationship with books and the motivations behind their reading choices?

I realize this dependence on books is not entirely goodâthat what I need them for is distraction. The books I bring on trips are often quite virtuous, the sort of stuff that might be assigned reading in a college class. But I know my motives aren't virtuous. I bring books because if the world gets boring, I need to be able to slip into another world distilled by some writer. It's like eating jam when you know you should be eating fruit.
What lesson did the author learn about thinking for oneself versus relying on external sources of entertainment?

There is a point where I'll do without books. I was walking in some steep mountains once and decided I'd rather just think, if I was bored, rather than carry a single unnecessary ounce. It wasn't so bad. I found I could entertain myself by having ideas instead of reading other people's. If you stop eating jam, fruit starts to taste better.
What factors contribute to the formation of startup clusters in specific regions?

Startups tend to form in clusters. There are many in Silicon Valley and Boston, while there are few in Chicago or Miami. A country that wants to foster startups will likely need to replicate the factors that contribute to the formation of these clusters.
What factors contribute to the formation of startups in Silicon Valley compared to other countries?

A great university near a town that smart people like contributes to the formation of startups in Silicon Valley. If you set up those conditions within the US, startups will form as inevitably as water droplets condense on a cold piece of metal. However, when I consider what it would take to reproduce Silicon Valley in another country, it's clear the US is a particularly humid environment. Startups condense more easily here.
Why is it unlikely that Japan could successfully replicate Silicon Valley?

For example, I doubt it would be possible to reproduce Silicon Valley in Japan because one of Silicon Valley's most distinctive features is immigration. Half the people there speak with accents, and the Japanese don't like immigration. When they think about how to make a Japanese Silicon Valley, I suspect they unconsciously frame it as how to make one consisting only of Japanese people. This way of framing the question probably guarantees failure.
What are some infrastructural differences between poor and industrialized countries that affect everyday safety?

In poor countries, things we take for granted are missing. A friend of mine visiting India sprained her ankle falling down the steps in a railway station. When she turned to see what had happened, she found the steps were all different heights. In industrialized countries, we walk down steps our whole lives and never think about this because there's an infrastructure that prevents such a staircase from being built.
What factors may limit the speed of economic evolution?
I suspect there is some speed limit to the evolution of an economy. Economies are made up of people, and attitudes can only change a certain amount per generation.
How does the suppression of dissent impact innovation and creativity in technology?

The suppression of dissent can lead to factories for building things designed elsewhere, but can it also provide the designers? Can imagination flourish where people can't criticize the government? Imagination means having odd ideas, and it's hard to have odd ideas about technology without also having odd ideas about politics. In any case, many technical ideas do have political implications. So if you squash dissent, the back pressure will propagate into technical fields.
What do the actions of Diogenes and Feynman reveal about the nature of individualism and defiance against authority?

The actions of Diogenes and Feynman reveal a profound sense of individualism and defiance against authority. You see it in Diogenes telling Alexander to get out of his light and, two thousand years later, in Feynman breaking into safes at Los Alamos.
Which European university is most frequently recognized by American computer science professors for its excellence in technology?

You need a great university to seed a Silicon Valley, and so far there are few outside the U.S. I asked a handful of American computer science professors which universities in Europe were most admired, and they all basically said "Cambridge," followed by a long pause while they tried to think of others. There don't seem to be many universities elsewhere that compare with the best in America, at least in technology.
What are the implications of government policies aimed at equalizing university quality in Germany and the Netherlands?

In some countries, this is the result of a deliberate policy. The German and Dutch governments, perhaps from fear of elitism, try to ensure that all universities are roughly equal in quality. The downside is that none are especially good. The best professors are spread out instead of being concentrated as they are in the US. This probably makes them less productive because they don't have good colleagues to inspire them. It also means no one university will be good enough to act as a mecca, attracting talent from abroad and causing startups to form around it.
How does the competition among US universities influence their quality compared to government-controlled institutions?

Itâs natural for US universities to compete with one another because so many are private. To reproduce the quality of American universities, you probably also have to reproduce this competition. If universities are controlled by the central government, log-rolling will pull them all toward the mean: the new Institute of X will end up at the university in the district of a powerful politician, instead of where it should be.
What challenges do startups in Europe face due to labor laws?

One of the biggest obstacles to creating startups in Europe is the attitude toward employment. The famously rigid labor laws hurt every company, but startups especially, because startups have the least time to spare for bureaucratic hassles.
What is the relationship between job security and employee performance across different professions?

The problem is more than just that some startups might have a problem firing someone they needed to. Across industries and countries, there's a strong inverse correlation between performance and job security. Actors and directors are fired at the end of each film, so they have to deliver every time. Junior professors are fired by default after a few years unless the university chooses to grant them tenure. Professional athletes know they'll be pulled if they play badly for just a couple of games. At the other end of the scale (at least in the US) are auto workers, New York City schoolteachers, and civil servants, who are all nearly impossible to fire. The trend is so clear that you'd have to be willfully blind not to see it.
How does viewing work as a series of different types of activities rather than a lifetime commitment to one employer influence the decision to start a business?

Even in the US, most kids graduating from college still think they're supposed to get jobs, as if you couldn't be productive without being someone's employee. But the less you identify work with employment, the easier it becomes to start a startup. When you see your career as a series of different types of work, instead of a lifetime's service to a single employer, there's less risk in starting your own company because you're only replacing one segment instead of discarding the whole thing.
What challenges did Steve Wozniak face in leaving his job at HP to fully commit to Apple?

The old ideas are so powerful that even the most successful startup founders have had to struggle against them. A year after the founding of Apple, Steve Wozniak still hadn't quit HP. He still planned to work there for life. When Jobs found someone to give Apple serious venture funding on the condition that Woz quit, he initially refused, arguing that he'd designed both the Apple I and the Apple II while working at HP, and there was no reason he couldn't continue.
What challenges do entrepreneurs face when trying to start a business in certain countries?

One of the biggest challenges entrepreneurs face when trying to start a business in certain countries is the effort required just to establish a company. A friend of mine started a company in Germany in the early 90s and was shocked to discover, among many other regulations, that you needed $20,000 in capital to incorporate. That's one reason I'm not typing this on an Apfel laptop. Jobs and Wozniak couldn't have come up with that kind of money in a company financed by selling a VW bus and an HP calculator. We couldn't have started Viaweb either.
What factors contribute to the fragility of young startups?

Young startups are fragile for several reasons. They are often started by individuals who may lack financial resources and confidence; they typically begin in marginal spaces and during spare time; they are initiated by people who are supposed to be engaged in other activities; and although they are businesses, their founders often know little about business operations. A society that trims its margins sharply will kill them all.
What strategy do successful startups use to launch their initial product?

What sustains a startup in the beginning is the prospect of getting their initial product out. The successful ones, therefore, make the first version as simple as possible. In the US, they usually begin by making something just for the local market.
Why might a startup face more challenges in a small country compared to a larger market like America?

A startup might face more challenges in a small country compared to a larger market like America because, in America, the local market consists of 300 million people. It wouldn't work as well in Sweden. In a small country, a startup has a harder task: they have to sell internationally from the start.
How does language diversity in the EU impact the competitiveness of software startups compared to those in the US?

The EU was designed partly to simulate a single, large domestic market. The problem is that the inhabitants still speak many different languages. So, a software startup in Sweden is still at a disadvantage relative to one in the US because they have to deal with internationalization from the beginning. It's significant that the most famous recent startup in Europe, Skype, worked on a problem that was intrinsically international.
What are the potential implications of the increasing dominance of English in Europe over the next few decades?

However, for better or worse, it looks as if Europe will, in a few decades, speak a single language. When I was a student in Italy in 1990, few Italians spoke English. Now, all educated people seem to be expected toâand Europeans do not like to seem uneducated. This is presumably a taboo subject, but if present trends continue, French and German will eventually go the way of Irish and Luxembourgish: they'll be spoken in homes and by eccentric nationalists.
What factors contribute to the ease of starting a startup in America compared to other countries?

Startups are easier to start in America because funding is easier to get. There are now a few VC firms outside the US, but startup funding doesn't only come from VC firms. A more important source, because it's more personal and comes earlier in the process, is money from individual angel investors. Google might never have gotten to the point where they could raise millions from VC funds if they hadn't first raised a hundred thousand from Andy Bechtolsheim. And he could help them because he was one of the founders of Sun. This pattern is repeated constantly in startup hubs. It's this pattern that contributes significantly to the ease of starting a startup in America compared to other countries.
What is the key to fostering a successful startup ecosystem?

The good news is that all you have to do to get the process rolling is get those first few startups successfully launched. If they stick around after they get rich, startup founders will almost automatically fund and encourage new startups.
How do private universities contribute to the availability of venture capital in America?

America's private universities are one reason there's so much venture capital. A lot of the money in VC funds comes from their endowments. So, another advantage of private universities is that a good chunk of the country's wealth is managed by enlightened investors.
How does the career decision-making process in the US differ from that in European countries?

Compared to other industrialized countries, the US is disorganized about routing people into careers. For example, in America, people often don't decide to go to medical school until they've finished college. In Europe, they generally decide in high school.
What underlying belief about individual roles in society influences the European approach to vocational training?

The European approach reflects the old idea that each person has a single, definite occupationâwhich is not far from the idea that each person has a natural "station" in life. If this were true, the most efficient plan would be to discover each person's station as early as possible so they could receive the training appropriate to it.
What motivates many students to enroll in CS PhD programs in the US, despite the primary focus on research?

For example, in theory, the purpose of a PhD program is to train you to do research. But fortunately, in the US, this is another rule that isn't very strictly enforced. In the US, most people in CS PhD programs are there simply because they wanted to learn more. They haven't decided what they'll do afterward. So, American grad schools spawn a lot of startups because students don't feel they're failing if they don't go into research.
How might poor public school systems unintentionally prepare students for higher education?

Those worried about America's "competitiveness" often suggest spending more on public schools. But perhaps America's lousy public schools have a hidden advantage. Because they're so bad, the kids adopt an attitude of waiting for college. I did; I knew I was learning so little that I wasn't even learning what the choices were, let alone which to choose. This is demoralizing, but it does at least make you keep an open mind.
How do American attitudes towards entrepreneurship compare to those in India and China?

American attitudes towards entrepreneurship are often characterized by a greater willingness to take risks. Americans are said to be more entrepreneurial and less afraid of failure. However, this entrepreneurial spirit is not exclusive to the United States; Indians and Chinese also exhibit strong entrepreneurial tendencies, perhaps even more so than Americans.
What is the author's perspective on the perceived lack of energy in Europeans?
Some say Europeans are less energetic, but I don't believe it. I think the problem with Europe is not that they lack balls, but that they lack examples.
How have historical events influenced the perception of ambition in Europe compared to the United States?

I admit there seem to be different attitudes toward ambition in Europe and the US. In the US, it's okay to be overtly ambitious, and in most of Europe, it's not. But this can't be an intrinsically European quality; previous generations of Europeans were as ambitious as Americans. What happened? My hypothesis is that ambition was discredited by the terrible things ambitious people did in the first half of the twentieth century. Now swagger is out. (Even now, the image of a very ambitious German presses a button or two, doesn't it?)
What are the commuting challenges faced by workers in Silicon Valley?

To start with, Silicon Valley is too far from San Francisco. Palo Alto, the original ground zero, is about thirty miles away, and the present center is more like forty. So, people who come to work in Silicon Valley face an unpleasant choice: either live in the boring sprawl of the valley proper or live in San Francisco and endure an hour commute each way.
What transportation preferences should be considered when designing a town to attract Silicon Valley-type individuals?

The kind of people you want to attract to your Silicon Valley like to get around by train, bicycle, and on foot. So if you want to beat America, design a town that puts cars last. It will be a while before any American city can bring itself to do that.
What are the challenges politicians face when setting capital gains tax rates to support startups?

To encourage startups, politicians should consider a low rate on capital gains. However, they are caught between a rock and a hard place: if they set the capital gains rate low, they risk being accused of creating "tax breaks for the rich," but if they set it high, they may starve growing companies of investment capital. As Galbraith said, politics is a matter of choosing between the unpalatable and the disastrous. Many governments experimented with the disastrous in the twentieth century; now the trend seems to be toward the merely unpalatable.
How can smarter immigration policies contribute to economic growth and innovation in the US?
Smarter immigration policies can significantly contribute to economic growth and innovation in the US. There are huge gains to be made here, as Silicon Valleys are made of people, remember.
What challenges do companies in Silicon Valley face regarding the limitations of their operating platform?

Companies in Silicon Valley are all too aware of the shortcomings of their operating platform, much like a company whose software runs on Windows. However, there is little they can do about it; they are hostages of the platform.
What impact would a more open immigration policy for skilled individuals have on the technology sector?

America's immigration system has never been well run, and since 2001 there has been an additional admixture of paranoia. What fraction of the smart people who want to come to America can even get in? I doubt even half. This means that if you made a competing technology hub that let in all smart people, you'd immediately get more than half the world's top talent, for free.
What are the challenges faced by individuals without a college degree when trying to obtain an H1B visa or apply for U.S. citizenship?

If you don't have a college degree, you can't get an H1B visa, the type usually issued to programmers. But a test that excludes Steve Jobs, Bill Gates, and Michael Dell can't be a good one. Plus, you can't get a visa for working on your own company, only for working as an employee of someone else's. And if you want to apply for citizenship, you daren't work for a startup at all, because if your sponsor goes out of business, you have to start over.
How could American immigration policy be improved to attract talented individuals?

American immigration policy keeps out most smart people and channels the rest into unproductive jobs. It would be easy to do better. Imagine if, instead, we treated immigration like recruitingâif we made a conscious effort to seek out the smartest people and get them to come to our country.
What are the potential benefits for a country that successfully implements a favorable immigration system?
A country that gets immigration right would have a huge advantage. At this point, you could become a mecca for smart people simply by having an immigration system that lets them in.
What factors contribute to creating a successful startup ecosystem without compromising a country's integrity?

To create a successful startup ecosystem without compromising a country's integrity, several factors come into play. Great universities, livable towns, civil liberties, flexible employment laws, immigration policies that allow smart people to enter, and tax laws that encourage growth are all essential. It's not as if you have to risk destroying your country to create a Silicon Valley; these are all good things in their own right.
What impact might the rise of startups have on traditional businesses and economic progress?

The rise of startups may encourage individuals to create their own companies rather than work for someone else's. I'm not sure that will happen, but it's where the trend points now. If that is the future, places that don't have startups will be a whole step behind, much like those that missed the Industrial Revolution.
How did England's wealth in the 18th century compare to that of India in the mid-20th century?

On the verge of the Industrial Revolution, England was already the richest country in the world. As far as such things can be compared, per capita income in England in 1750 was higher than India's in 1960.
What historical event demonstrates the impact of government control on industrialization in China compared to Europe?
During the Ming Dynasty, China turned its back on industrialization at the command of the court. One of Europe's advantages was that it had no government powerful enough to do that.
What is the approximate percentage of the world population represented by Japanese and Jewish people?
This is not a remark about the qualities of these groups, just their sizes. Japanese people are only about 2% of the world population, and Jews are about 0.2%.
How did Europeans perceive their experiences before and after the summer of 1914?

For most of the twentieth century, Europeans looked back on the summer of 1914 as if they had been living in a dream world. It seems more accurate (or at least as accurate) to call the years after 1914 a nightmare than to call those before a dream. A lot of the optimism Europeans consider distinctly American is simply what they too were feeling in 1914.
At what income tax rate does tax avoidance become significantly serious for individuals?

The point where things start to go wrong seems to be about 50%. Above that, people get serious about tax avoidance. The reason is that the payoff for avoiding tax grows hyperexponentially (x/1-x for 0 < x < 1). If your income tax rate is 10%, moving to Monaco would only give you 11% more income, which wouldn't even cover the extra cost. If it's 90%, you'd get ten times as much income. And at 98%, as it was briefly in Britain in the 70s, moving to Monaco would give you fifty times as much income. It seems quite likely that European governments of the 70s never drew this curve.
How has the importance of geography in the development of cities changed over the past few decades?

That's a striking departure from the past. Up until a couple of decades ago, geography was destiny for cities. All great cities were located on waterways because cities made money by trade, and water was the only economical way to ship.
What factors contribute to the success of startup hubs in the US?

Observation bears this out: within the US, towns have become startup hubs if and only if they have both rich people and nerds. Few startups happen in Miami, for example, because although it's full of rich people, it has few nerds. It's not the kind of place that nerds like.
What are the challenges faced by entrepreneurs in Pittsburgh and Ithaca?

I grew up in Pittsburgh and went to college at Cornell, so I can answer for both. The weather is terrible, particularly in winter, and there's no interesting old city to make up for it, as there is in Boston. Rich people don't want to live in Pittsburgh or Ithaca. So, while there are plenty of hackers who could start startups, there's no one to invest in them.
Why are startup investors considered essential for the success of new technology ventures?

Startup investors are considered essential for the success of new technology ventures because they are a distinct type of wealthy individual who often have significant experience in the technology business. This experience helps them pick the right startups and enables them to supply valuable advice and connections in addition to funding. Furthermore, their personal stake in the outcome ensures that they pay close attention to the ventures they invest in.
Why might bureaucrats struggle in startup investing compared to seasoned professionals?

Though indeed, most things bureaucrats do, they do badly. We just don't usually notice because they only have to compete against other bureaucrats. But as startup investors, they'd have to compete against pros with a great deal more experience and motivation.
Why do corporations with in-house VC groups restrict them from making independent investment decisions?

Even corporations that have in-house VC groups generally forbid them from making their own investment decisions. Most are only allowed to invest in deals where some reputable private VC firm is willing to act as lead investor.
What factors attract tech talent and investors to a particular location?

You need the people. If you could attract a critical mass of nerds and investors to live somewhere, you could reproduce Silicon Valley. Both groups are highly mobile; they'll go where life is good. So, what makes a place good to them?
Why are great universities considered essential for attracting smart individuals and technology hubs in the US?

Smart people tend to gravitate towards other smart people, which is why great universities are essential for attracting intelligent individuals. In particular, these institutions serve as a magnet for talent. While there could be other ways to attract them, universities have proven to be indispensable. Within the US, there are no technology hubs without first-rate universitiesâor at least, first-rate computer science departments.
What factors are essential for establishing a successful innovation hub similar to Silicon Valley?

To establish a successful innovation hub similar to Silicon Valley, you not only need a university, but one of the top handful in the world. It has to be good enough to act as a magnet, drawing the best people from thousands of miles away. That means it has to stand up to existing magnets like MIT and Stanford.
What factors contribute most to attracting high-quality faculty to a university?

Attracting high-quality faculty to a university hinges on several key factors. My professor friends, when deciding where they'd like to work, consider one thing above all: the quality of the other faculty. What attracts professors is good colleagues. If you managed to recruit, en masse, a significant number of the best young researchers, you could create a first-rate university from nothing overnight. You could do that for surprisingly little. If you paid 200 people hiring bonuses of $3 million apiece, you could put together a faculty that would bear comparison with any in the world. From that point, the chain reaction would be self-sustaining. So whatever it costs to establish a mediocre university, for an additional half billion or so, you could have a great one.
What factors contribute to a university's ability to foster startup growth in its surrounding community?

To spawn startups, a university has to be in a town that has attractions other than the university. It has to be a place where investors want to live and where students want to stay after they graduate.
What qualities do startup investors typically seek in a city?

Startup investors typically seek qualities in a city that align with their interests and preferences. They often favor cities that are vibrant and innovative, as many startup investors are tech enthusiasts themselves. Their tastes are not entirely mainstream; while they appreciate cities that are popular tourist destinations, such as San Francisco, Boston, and Seattle, they tend to shy away from other major tourist spots like New York, Los Angeles, and Las Vegas.
What is the significance of attracting the "creative class" for a city's prosperity?

There has been a lot written lately about the "creative class." The thesis seems to be that as wealth derives increasingly from ideas, cities will prosper only if they attract those who have them. That is certainly true; in fact, it was the basis of Amsterdam's prosperity 400 years ago.
What are some lifestyle preferences shared by nerd culture and the creative class?

Nerd culture shares many lifestyle preferences with the creative class in general. For example, they prefer well-preserved old neighborhoods instead of cookie-cutter suburbs, and they favor locally-owned shops and restaurants over national chains. Like the rest of the creative class, they want to live somewhere with personality.
What factors contribute to a town's unique personality and appeal to the creative class?

What exactly is personality? I think it's the feeling that each building is the work of a distinct group of people. A town with personality is one that doesn't feel mass-produced. So, if you want to make a startup hubâor any town to attract the "creative class"âyou probably have to ban large development projects. When a large tract has been developed by a single organization, you can always tell.
What factors contribute to the personality of a town, and how can modern towns achieve a similar character?

Most towns with personality are old, but they don't have to be. Old towns have two advantages: they're denser because they were laid out before cars, and they're more varied because they were built one building at a time. You could have both now. Just have building codes that ensure density and ban large-scale developments.
Why is it important for governments to avoid directly trying to create innovation hubs like Silicon Valley?

A corollary is that you have to keep out the biggest developer of all: the government. A government that asks, "How can we build a Silicon Valley?" has probably ensured failure by the way they framed the question. You don't build a Silicon Valley; you let one grow.
What are the contrasting feelings experienced by residents of New York according to the paragraph?

If you've lived in New York, you know where these facial expressions come from. It's the kind of place where your mind may be excited, but your body knows it's having a bad time. People don't so much enjoy living there as endure it for the sake of the excitement. And if you like certain kinds of excitement, New York is incomparable. It's a hub of glamour, a magnet for all the shorter half-life isotopes of style and fame.
What is the perspective of "nerds" regarding the appeal of living in New York City?

Nerds don't care about glamour, so to them, the appeal of New York is a mystery. People who like New York will pay a fortune for a small, dark, noisy apartment in order to live in a town where the cool people are really cool. A nerd looks at that deal and sees only: pay a fortune for a small, dark, noisy apartment.
What factors influence the cost of living in a town with highly intelligent residents compared to more glamorous locations?
You pay a premium to live in a town where the smart people are really smart, but you don't have to pay as much for that. It's supply and demand: glamour is popular, so you have to pay a lot for it.
What are some preferred environments and activities for individuals who identify as nerds?

Most nerds like quieter pleasures. They prefer cafes instead of clubs, used bookshops instead of fashionable clothing shops, hiking instead of dancing, and sunlight instead of tall buildings. A nerd's idea of paradise is Berkeley or Boulder.
What characteristics make a city appealing to young entrepreneurs and startup founders?

It's the young nerds who start startups, so it's those specifically that the city has to appeal to. The startup hubs in the US are all young-feeling towns. This doesn't mean they have to be new. Cambridge has the oldest town plan in America, but it feels young because it's full of students.
What factors contribute to the successful establishment of a startup ecosystem similar to Silicon Valley?

To create a successful startup ecosystem similar to Silicon Valley, it is essential to avoid a large, existing population of stodgy individuals. It would be a waste of time to try to reverse the fortunes of a declining industrial town like Detroit or Philadelphia by encouraging startups, as those places have too much momentum in the wrong direction. Instead, it is better to start with a blank slate in the form of a small town. Or, even better, choose a town that already attracts young people.
What qualities make the Bay Area an ideal location for startups?

The Bay Area has been a magnet for the young and optimistic for decades, even before it became associated with technology. It is a place where people go in search of something new, and it has become synonymous with California's eccentricity. There is still a lot of that spirit present. If you wanted to start a new fadâa new way to focus one's "energy," for example, or a new category of things not to eatâthe Bay Area would be the place to do it. A place that tolerates oddness in the search for the new is exactly what you want in a startup hub, because economically, that's what startups are. Most good startup ideas seem a little crazy; if they were obviously good ideas, someone would have done them already.
How does the relationship between technology and liberalism manifest in US cities?

The connection between technology and liberalism is evident in US cities. Without exception, the high-tech cities in the US are also the most liberal. However, it's not because liberals are smarter that this is so. It's because liberal cities tolerate odd ideas, and smart people, by definition, have odd ideas.
What characteristics might limit a town's potential to become a successful startup hub?

A town that gets praised for being "solid" or representing "traditional values" may be a fine place to live, but it's unlikely to succeed as a startup hub. The characteristics that contribute to this limitation include a lack of innovation, resistance to change, and a culture that does not encourage risk-taking or entrepreneurship.
What characteristics do successful startup hubs share that help attract young people?

To attract the young, a town must have an intact center. In most American cities, the center has been abandoned, and the growth, if any, is in the suburbs. Most American cities have been turned inside out. But none of the startup hubs has: not San Francisco, not Boston, or Seattle. They all have intact centers.
Which US cities are suggested as potential new Silicon Valleys and why?

Within the US, the two cities I think could most easily be turned into new Silicon Valleys are Boulder and Portland. Both have the kind of effervescent feel that attracts the young. They're each only a great university short of becoming a Silicon Valley, if they wanted to.
What factors contributed to the establishment of Silicon Valley in Palo Alto?

A great university near an attractive town. Is that all it takes? That was all it took to make the original Silicon Valley. Silicon Valley traces its origins to William Shockley, one of the inventors of the transistor. He did the research that won him the Nobel Prize at Bell Labs, but when he started his own company in 1956, he moved to Palo Alto to do it. At the time, that was an odd thing to do. Why did he? Because he had grown up there and remembered how nice it was. Now Palo Alto is suburbia, but then it was a charming college townâa charming college town with perfect weather and San Francisco only an hour away.
How did Shockley Semiconductor influence the development of major technology companies in Silicon Valley?

The companies that rule Silicon Valley now are all descended in various ways from Shockley Semiconductor. Shockley was a difficult man, and in 1957 his top peopleâ"the traitorous eight"âleft to start a new company, Fairchild Semiconductor. Among them were Gordon Moore and Robert Noyce, who went on to found Intel, and Eugene Kleiner, who founded the VC firm Kleiner Perkins. Forty-two years later, Kleiner Perkins funded Google, and the partner responsible for the deal was John Doerr, who came to Silicon Valley in 1974 to work for Intel.
What role does the history of successful startups play in fostering the growth of new companies in Silicon Valley?

Although many of the newest companies in Silicon Valley don't produce anything made of silicon, there always seem to be multiple links back to Shockley. There's a lesson here: startups beget startups. People who work for startups start their own. People who get rich from startups fund new ones. I suspect this kind of organic growth is the only way to produce a startup hub because it's the only way to grow the expertise you need.
What are the key factors influencing the growth of a startup community in relation to a university?

The growth of a startup community in relation to a university has two important implications. The first is that you need time to grow a Silicon Valley. The university could be created in a couple of years, but the startup community around it has to grow organically. The cycle time is limited by the time it takes for a company to succeed, which probably averages about five years.
What role did Shockley Semiconductor play in the development of new technology?

Shockley Semiconductor, though itself not very successful, was significant in the development of new technology. It brought a critical mass of experts in an important new technology together in a place they liked enough to stay.
How did the structure of companies in Silicon Valley during Shockley's era differ from the modern startup model?

One of Silicon Valley's biggest advantages is its venture capital firms. This was not a factor in Shockley's day because VC funds didn't exist. In fact, Shockley Semiconductor and Fairchild Semiconductor were not startups at all in our sense; they were subsidiaries of Beckman Instruments and Fairchild Camera and Instrument, respectively. Those companies were apparently willing to establish subsidiaries wherever the experts wanted to live.
Why do venture investors prefer to fund startups located near them?

Venture investors, however, prefer to fund startups within an hour's drive. For one, they're more likely to notice startups nearby. When they do notice startups in other towns, they prefer them to move. They don't want to have to travel to attend board meetings, and in any case, the odds of succeeding are higher in a startup hub.
How do venture firms influence the formation and growth of startups?

The centralizing effect of venture firms is a double one: they cause startups to form around them, and those startups draw in more startups through acquisitions. Although the first may be weakening because it's now so cheap to start some startups, the second seems as strong as ever. Three of the most admired "Web 2.0" companies were started outside the usual startup hubs, but two of them have already been reeled in through acquisitions.
What factors could allow a new tech hub to compete with or surpass Silicon Valley?

Such centralizing forces make it harder for new Silicon Valleys to get started, but by no means is it impossible. Ultimately, power rests with the founders. A startup with the best people will beat one with funding from famous VCs, and a startup that is sufficiently successful would never have to move. So, a town that could exert enough pull over the right people could resist and perhaps even surpass Silicon Valley.
How many individuals are suggested as potentially sufficient to transform Buffalo into a significant startup hub?

It's interesting to consider how low this number could be made. I suspect five hundred would be enough, even if they could bring no assets with them. Probably just thirty, if I could pick them, would be enough to turn Buffalo into a significant startup hub.
How does the funding process for academic research differ from that of startups?

Bureaucrats manage to allocate research funding moderately well, but only because (like an in-house VC fund) they outsource most of the work of selection. A professor at a famous university who is highly regarded by his peers will get funding, pretty much regardless of the proposal. That wouldn't work for startups, whose founders aren't sponsored by organizations and are often unknowns.
How does the startup landscape in New York compare to that of Boston in terms of quantity and industry focus?

Startups are more prevalent in Boston than in New York, with less than a tenth as many per capita in New York. The focus of New York startups tends to be in fields like finance and media, which are generally considered less technical compared to the industries prevalent in Boston.
Who contributed feedback or support in the drafting process of this work?

To Chris Anderson, Trevor Blackwell, Marc Hedlund, Jessica Livingston, Robert Morris, Greg McAdoo, Fred Wilson, and Stephen Wolfram for reading drafts of this work, and to Ed Dumbill for inviting me to speak.
What is the importance of releasing a minimal version of a product early in the development process?

By "release early," I don't mean you should release something full of bugs, but that you should release something minimal. Users hate bugs, but they don't seem to mind a minimal version 1 if there's more coming soon.
Why is it important for startups to release their initial software version quickly?

There are several reasons it pays to get version 1 done fast. One is that this is simply the right way to write software, whether for a startup or not. I've been repeating that since 1993, and I haven't seen much since to contradict it. I've seen a lot of startups die because they were too slow to release stuff, and none because they were too quick.
Why is it risky for web startups to make assumptions about their users' preferences?

Now, a web startup may have almost half a million unique visitors a month. Who are all those people? They have no idea. No web startup does. And since you don't know your users, it's dangerous to guess what they'll like. It's better to release something and let them tell you.
What benefits did Wufoo gain by releasing their form-builder before the complete database?

Wufoo took this to heart and released their form-builder before the underlying database. You can't even drive the thing yet, but 83,000 people came to sit in the driver's seat and hold the steering wheel. Wufoo got valuable feedback from it: Linux users complained they used too much Flash, so they rewrote their software not to. If they'd waited to release everything at once, they wouldn't have discovered this problem until it was more deeply wired in.
Why is it important for startups to prioritize a quick initial release, even without users?

Even if you have no users, it is still important to release quickly because, for a startup, the initial release acts as a shakedown cruise. If anything major is brokenâif the idea's no good, for example, or the founders hate one anotherâthe stress of getting that first version out will expose it. And if you have such problems, you want to find them early.
What is the impact of releasing a project early on the motivation and urgency of the team?

Perhaps the most important reason to release early, though, is that it makes you work harder. When you're working on something that isn't released, problems are intriguing. In something that's out there, problems are alarming. There is a lot more urgency once you release. And I think that's precisely why people put it off. They know they'll have to work a lot harder once they do.
What is an important consideration to keep in mind when adopting the "release early" strategy?
Of course, "release early" has a second component, without which it would be bad advice. If you're going to start with something that doesn't do much, you better improve it fast.
How does regular practice in a skill, like running or hacking, influence motivation and creativity?

As with exercise, improvements beget improvements. If you run every day, you'll probably feel like running tomorrow. But if you skip running for a couple of weeks, it will be an effort to drag yourself out. So it is with hacking: the more ideas you implement, the more ideas you'll have. You should make your system better at least in some small way every day or two.
Why is continuous improvement on a website important for user engagement?

Continuous improvement on a website is important for user engagement because it serves not only as a means of development but also as a form of marketing. Users love a site that's constantly improving, and in fact, they expect it to evolve. Imagine visiting a site that seemed very good, and then returning two months later to find that not one thing had changed. Wouldn't it start to seem lame?
How can a company foster customer loyalty and reduce the need for advertising?

Customers will like you even better when you improve in response to their comments because they are used to companies ignoring them. If you're the rare exceptionâa company that actually listensâyou'll generate fanatical loyalty. You won't need to advertise because your users will do it for you.
Why do people often become complacent with existing products and overlook potential improvements?

People often become complacent with existing products and overlook potential improvements because they get used to how things are. Once a product surpasses the stage where it has glaring flaws, users start to acclimate to it, and gradually whatever features it possesses become its identity. For example, I doubt many people at Yahoo (or Google, for that matter) realized how much better webmail could be until Paul Buchheit showed them.
What mindset can help enhance creativity and drive continuous improvement in your work?

I think the solution is to assume that anything you've made is far short of what it could be. Force yourself, as a sort of intellectual exercise, to keep thinking of improvements. Ok, sure, what you have is perfect. But if you had to change something, what would it be?
What are the two reasons someone might think their product is finished?
If your product seems finished, there are two possible explanations: (a) it is finished, or (b) you lack imagination. Experience suggests (b) is a thousand times more likely.
What is the key principle that drives the success of startups?

Improving constantly is an instance of a more general rule: make users happy. One thing all startups have in common is that they can't force anyone to do anything. They can't force anyone to use their software, and they can't force anyone to do deals with them. A startup has to sing for its supper. That's why the successful ones make great things. They have to, or die.
What role do users play in the success or failure of a startup?

When you're running a startup, you feel like a little bit of debris blown about by powerful winds. The most powerful wind is users. They can either catch you and loft you up into the sky, as they did with Google, or leave you flat on the pavement, as they do with most startups. Users are a fickle wind, but more powerful than any other. If they take you up, no competitor can keep you down.
Why is it important to design a website for casual visitors rather than just for those who are highly engaged?

I like the wind metaphor because it reminds you how impersonal the stream of traffic is. The vast majority of people who visit your site will be casual visitors. It's for them that you have to design your site. The people who really care will find what they want by themselves.
What mindset do most web visitors have when navigating online content?

The median visitor will arrive with their finger poised on the Back button. Think about your own experience: most links you follow lead to something disappointing. Anyone who has used the web for more than a couple of weeks has been conditioned to expect that many online contents may not meet their expectations.
What are the benefits of enterprise content management solutions for businesses?

Enterprise content management solutions for businesses enable organizations to unify people, content, and processes to minimize business risk, accelerate time-to-value, and sustain lower total cost of ownership.
Why is it important to have a clear and compelling description of your company for various stakeholders?

A clear and compelling description of your company is important not just for users, but for all stakeholders: investors, acquirers, partners, reporters, potential employees, and even current employees. You probably shouldn't even start a company to do something that can't be described compellingly in one or two sentences.
What strategy should you use to maximize visitor engagement on your website?

The other thing I repeat is to give people everything you've got right away. If you have something impressive, try to put it on the front page, because that's the only one most visitors will see. Though indeed there's a paradox here: the more you push the good stuff toward the front, the more likely visitors are to explore further.
What is a key principle in fiction writing that can also apply to effectively communicating the purpose of a website?

One of the standard pieces of advice in fiction writing is "show, don't tell." Don't say that a character's angry; have him grind his teeth or break his pencil in half. Nothing will explain what your site does so well as using it.
What is the importance of measuring conversion rates on a website?

The industry term here is "conversion." The job of your site is to convert casual visitors into usersâwhatever your definition of a user is. You can measure this in your growth rate. Either your site is catching on, or it isn't, and you must know which. If you have decent growth, you'll win in the end, no matter how obscure you are now. And if you don't, you need to fix something.
What common advice do entrepreneurs often receive regarding their worries in a startup environment?

Another thing I find myself saying a lot is, "Don't worry." Actually, it's more often, "Don't worry about this; worry about that instead." Startups are right to be paranoid, but they sometimes fear the wrong things.
Why should startups not be overly concerned about competition from big companies like Google?

A lot of startups worry, "What if Google builds something like us?" Actually, big companies are not the ones you have to worry aboutânot even Google. The people at Google are smart, but no smarter than you; they're not as motivated because Google is not going to go out of business if this one product fails. Even at Google, they have a lot of bureaucracy to slow them down.
What type of competition poses a greater threat to startups than established companies like Google?
What you should fear, as a startup, is not the established players, but other startups you don't know exist yet. They're far more dangerous than Google because, like you, they're cornered animals.
What should entrepreneurs consider regarding competition when pursuing a new idea?

Entrepreneurs should consider not only what competitors are currently doing but also what they might be doing in the future. A corollary is that you shouldn't relax just because you have no visible competitors yet. No matter what your idea is, there's someone else out there working on the same thing.
Why might the increasing number of startups not indicate a saturated market for new businesses?

That's the downside of it being easier to start a startup: more people are doing it. But I disagree with Caterina Fake when she says that makes this a bad time to start a startup. More people are starting startups, but not as many more as could. Most college graduates still think they have to get a job. The average person can't ignore something that's been beaten into their head since they were three just because serving web pages recently got a lot cheaper.
What are the main reasons startups fail, and which one is considered the most detrimental?

Competitors are not the biggest threat to startups. Way more startups hose themselves than get crushed by competitors. There are a lot of ways to do it, but the three main ones are internal disputes, inertia, and ignoring users. Each is, by itself, enough to kill you. But if I had to pick the worst, it would be ignoring users. If you want a recipe for a startup that's going to die, here it is: a couple of founders who have some great idea they know everyone is going to love, and that's what they're going to build, no matter what.
What do successful companies do when their initial business plans fail?

Almost everyone's initial plan is broken. If companies stuck to their initial plans, Microsoft would be selling programming languages, and Apple would be selling printed circuit boards. In both cases, their customers told them what their business should beâand they were smart enough to listen.
What principle suggests that real-world discoveries can surpass human creativity in both art and innovation?

As Richard Feynman said, the imagination of nature is greater than the imagination of man. You'll find more interesting things by looking at the world than you could ever produce just by thinking. This principle is very powerful. It's why the best abstract painting still falls short of Leonardo, for example. And it applies to startups too. No idea for a product could ever be so clever as the ones you can discover by smashing a beam of prototypes into a beam of users.
What is the most important quality for a startup founder according to the author's experience?

I now have enough experience with startups to be able to say what the most important quality is in a startup founder, and it's not what you might think. The most important quality in a startup founder is determination. Not intelligenceâdetermination.
Why do venture capitalists prefer to invest in student-led startups over those founded by professors in the software industry?

Time after time, VCs invest in startups founded by eminent professors. This may work in biotech, where a lot of startups simply commercialize existing research, but in software, you want to invest in students, not professors. Microsoft, Yahoo, and Google were all founded by people who dropped out of school to do it. What students lack in experience, they more than make up for in dedication.
What is more detrimental to a person's well-being: losing cognitive ability or losing commitment?
You can lose quite a lot in the brains department, and it won't kill you. But lose even a little bit in the commitment department, and that will kill you very rapidly.
What are some of the unique challenges faced by startup founders compared to regular employees?

Running a startup is like walking on your hands: it's possible, but it requires extraordinary effort. If an ordinary employee were asked to do the things a startup founder has to, they would be very indignant. Imagine if you were hired at some big company, and in addition to writing software ten times faster than you'd ever had to before, they expected you to answer support calls, administer the servers, design the website, cold-call customers, find the company office space, and go out and get everyone lunch.
What challenges do entrepreneurs face when building a startup compared to working in a larger company?

Building a startup presents unique challenges compared to working in a larger company. Entrepreneurs must navigate a backdrop of constant disasters, which demands a high level of determination. In a startup, there's always some disaster happening, so if you're the least bit inclined to find an excuse to quit, there's always one readily available.
How does a lack of commitment impact success in startups?

A lack of commitment can significantly impact success in startups. If you lack commitment, chances are it will have been hurting you long before you actually quit. Everyone who deals with startups knows how important commitment is, so if they sense you're ambivalent, they won't give you much attention. If you lack commitment, you'll just find that, for some mysterious reason, good things happen to your competitors but not to you. It will seem to you that you're unlucky.
What attitude towards commitment can hinder a startup's chances of attracting investors or acquirers?

At Y Combinator, we sometimes mistakenly fund teams who have the attitude that they're going to give this startup thing a shot for three months, and if something great happens, they'll stick with itâ"something great" meaning either that someone wants to buy them or invest millions of dollars in them. But if this is your attitude, "something great" is very unlikely to happen to you, because both acquirers and investors judge you by your level of commitment.
What factors influence an acquirer's decision to purchase a company?

An acquirer's decision to purchase a company is influenced by several factors. If an acquirer thinks you're going to stick around no matter what, they'll be more likely to buy you. This is because if they don't buy you and you do stick around, you'll probably grow, your price will go up, and they'll be left wishing they'd bought you earlier. The same applies to investors. What really motivates investors, even big VCs, is not the hope of good returns, but the fear of missing out.
How can you effectively communicate your determination to secure funding for your project?
If you make it clear that you are going to succeed no matter what, and the only reason you need them is to make it happen a little faster, you are much more likely to get funding.
What qualities should an entrepreneur possess to succeed in a startup?

You have to be the right kind of determined, though. I carefully chose the word "determined" rather than "stubborn," because stubbornness is a disastrous quality in a startup. You have to be determined but flexible, like a running back. A successful running back doesn't just put his head down and try to run through people. He improvises: if someone appears in front of him, he runs around them; if someone tries to grab him, he spins out of their grip; he'll even run in the wrong direction briefly if that will help. The one thing he'll never do is stand still.
Do you believe there is still potential for innovation in social networking despite current market saturation?

I was talking recently to a startup founder about whether it might be good to add a social component to their software. He said he didn't think so because the whole social thing was tapped out. Really? So in a hundred years, the only social networking sites will be Facebook, MySpace, Flickr, and Del.icio.us? Not likely.
What mindset prevents us from recognizing potential innovations in seemingly saturated markets?

The reason we don't see the opportunities all around us is that we adjust to however things are and assume that's how things have to be. For example, it would seem crazy to most people to try to make a better search engine than Google. Surely that field, at least, is tapped out. Really? In a hundred yearsâor even twentyâare people still going to search for information using something like the current Google? Even Google probably doesn't think that.
What is the argument against the belief that there is a limit to the number of startups in an economy?

In particular, I don't think there's any limit to the number of startups. Sometimes you hear people saying, "All these guys starting startups now are going to be disappointed. How many little startups are Google and Yahoo going to buy, after all?" That sounds cleverly skeptical, but I can prove it's mistaken. No one proposes that there's some limit to the number of people who can be employed in an economy consisting of big, slow-moving companies with a couple thousand people each. Why should there be any limit to the number who could be employed by small, fast-moving companies with ten each? It seems to me the only limit would be the number of people who want to work that hard.
How should startup founders manage their inherent optimism?

Startup founders are naturally optimistic; they wouldn't pursue this path otherwise. However, you should treat your optimism the way you'd treat the core of a nuclear reactor: as a source of power that's also very dangerous. You have to build a shield around it, or it will fry you.
Why is adaptability crucial in a startup environment?

Adaptability is crucial in a startup environment because you tend to be pushing the limits of whatever you're doing. Things don't happen in the smooth, predictable way they do in the rest of the world. Changes occur suddenly, and usually for the worse.
Why is it important to maintain a cautious outlook when negotiating deals for your startup?

Shielding your optimism is nowhere more important than with deals. If your startup is doing a deal, just assume it's not going to happen. The VCs who say they're going to invest in you aren't. The company that says they're going to buy you isn't. The big customer who wants to use your system in their whole company won't. Then, if things work out, you can be pleasantly surprised.
Why is it beneficial to continue exploring other options even after agreeing to a deal?

Even if you ultimately do the first deal, it will be to your advantage to have kept looking because you'll get better terms. Deals are dynamic; unless you're negotiating with someone unusually honest, there's not a single point where you shake hands and the deal's done. There are usually a lot of subsidiary questions to be cleared up after the handshake, and if the other side senses weaknessâif they sense you need this dealâthey will be very tempted to screw you in the details.
What is the key strategy for achieving success in a startup?

The key strategy for achieving success in a startup is to focus on the goal of getting lots of users and keep walking swiftly toward it while investors and acquirers scurry alongside, trying to wave money in your face.
What do startup founders often say about the challenges of starting a new company?

Starting a startup sounds pretty stressful. It is. When I talk to the founders of the companies we've funded, they all say the same thing: "I knew it would be hard, but I didn't realize it would be this hard."
What is the primary economic perspective on startups according to the author?

Economically, a startup is best seen not as a way to get rich, but as a way to work faster. You have to make a living, and a startup is a way to get that done quickly, instead of letting it drag on through your whole life.
What insights does the paragraph provide about the value of life and the perception of time?

We take it for granted most of the time, but human life is fairly miraculous. It is also palpably short. You're given this marvelous thing, and then poof, it's taken away. You can see why people invent gods to explain it. But even to people who don't believe in gods, life commands respect. There are times in most of our lives when the days go by in a blur, and almost everyone has a sense, when this happens, of wasting something precious. As Ben Franklin said, if you love life, don't waste time, because time is what life is made of.
What is the main value of startups according to the paragraph?

So no, there's nothing particularly grand about making money. That's not what makes startups worth the trouble. What's important about startups is the speed. By compressing the dull but necessary task of making a living into the smallest possible time, you show respect for life, and there is something grand about that.
What is a more effective strategy for startups to avoid failure when launching a product?

Startups can fail by releasing products that are full of bugs and not fixing them quickly enough. However, I don't know of any that have failed from releasing something stable but minimal very early and then promptly improving it.
What do users prioritize when evaluating the quality of a website?

Users prioritize the rate of improvement when evaluating the quality of a website. A website is different from a book, movie, or desktop application in this respect. Users judge a site not as a single snapshot, but as an animation with multiple frames. Of the two, I'd say the rate of improvement is more important to users than where you currently are.
Why is it important to allow users to try a website without requiring registration?

Similarly, don't make users register to try your site. Maybe what you have is so valuable that visitors should gladly register to get at it. But they've been trained to expect the opposite. Most of the things they've tried on the web have been disappointingâespecially those that required registration.
Why do venture capitalists focus on identifying and investing in high-potential startups?

VCs have rational reasons for behaving this way. They don't make their money (if they make money) off their median investments. In a typical fund, half the companies fail, most of the rest generate mediocre returns, and one or two "make the fund" by succeeding spectacularly. So if they miss just a few of the most promising opportunities, it could hose the whole fund.
What did Socrates imply about the importance of self-reflection in the human experience?

Plato quotes Socrates as saying, "the unexamined life is not worth living." Part of what he meant was that the proper role of humans is to think, just as the proper role of anteaters is to poke their noses into anthills.
What philosophical question does the paragraph raise about the concept of purpose in life?

Now we'd give a different answer. At least, someone Socrates's age would. We'd ask why we even suppose we have a "purpose" in life. We may be better adapted for some things than others; we may be happier doing things we're adapted for; but why assume purpose?
How has the perception of humanity's place in the universe evolved throughout history?

The history of ideas is a history of gradually discarding the assumption that it's all about us. No, it turns out, the Earth is not the center of the universe â not even the center of the solar system. No, it turns out, humans are not created by God in his own image; they are just one species among many, descended not merely from apes, but from microorganisms. Even the concept of "me" turns out to be fuzzy around the edges if you examine it closely.
What concept did Richard Dawkins introduce that challenges the notion of human centrality in the universe?

The idea that we're the center of things is difficult to discard. So difficult that there's probably room to discard more. Richard Dawkins made another step in that direction only in the last several decades with the idea of the "selfish gene," which challenges the notion of human centrality in the universe by suggesting that genes, rather than individuals or species, are the primary units of selection in evolution.
What realization did the author come to about human existence and reproduction after reading a particular book?

No, it turns out we're not even the protagonists; we're just the latest model vehicle our genes have constructed to travel around in. And having kids is our genes heading for the lifeboats. Reading that book snapped my brain out of its previous way of thinking the way Darwin's must have when it first appeared.
What should you consider when seeking new discoveries that challenge conventional beliefs?

To discover things that have been overlooked until now, one really good place to look is in our blind spot: in our natural, naive belief that it's all about us. And expect to encounter ferocious opposition if you do.
What is the significance of the phrase "never attribute to malice what can be explained by incompetence"?

The phrase "never attribute to malice what can be explained by incompetence" is significant because it encourages us to consider that not all negative actions are driven by ill intent; sometimes, they stem from a lack of skill or understanding. Although the origin of the phrase is unknown, it conveys a powerful idea about human behavior and decision-making. Its more general version serves as a reminder to approach situations with empathy and to avoid jumping to conclusions about others' motives.
What is the argument for the patentability of software in relation to physical inventions?

One thing I do feel pretty certain of is that if you're against software patents, you're against patents in general. Gradually, our machines consist more and more of software. Things that used to be done with levers, cams, and gears are now done with loops, trees, and closures. There's nothing special about physical embodiments of control systems that should make them patentable, and the software equivalent not.
Why is the term "algorithm" avoided in patent applications?

Patent lawyers still have to pretend that's what they're doing when they patent algorithms. You must not use the word "algorithm" in the title of a patent application, just as you must not use the word "essays" in the title of a book. If you want to patent an algorithm, you have to frame it as a computer system executing that algorithm. Then it's mechanical; phew. The default euphemism for algorithm is "system and method." Try a patent search for that phrase and see how many results you get.
What are the main challenges facing the patent office in relation to software patents?

I think the problem is more with the patent office than the concept of software patents. Whenever software meets government, bad things happen because software changes fast and government changes slowly. The patent office has been overwhelmed by both the volume and the novelty of applications for software patents, and as a result, they've made a lot of mistakes.
What is a major issue with the patent granting process at the USPTO?

The most common issue is granting patents that shouldn't be granted. To be patentable, an invention has to be more than new; it also has to be non-obvious. This, especially, is where the USPTO has been dropping the ball. Slashdot has an icon that expresses the problem vividly: a knife and fork with the words "patent pending" superimposed.
What perception do Slashdot readers have about stories related to patents?

Slashdot readers have a negative perception of stories related to patents. They now take it for granted that a story about a patent will be about a bogus patent. That's how bad the problem has become.
What is the issue with Amazon's one-click patent, according to critics?

The problem with Amazon's notorious one-click patent, for example, is not that it's a software patent, but that it's obvious. Any online store that kept people's shipping addresses would have implemented this. The reason Amazon did it first was not that they were especially smart, but because they were one of the earliest sites with enough clout to force customers to log in before they could buy something.
What concerns do hackers have about the USPTO's understanding of software patents?

We, as hackers, know the USPTO is letting people patent the knives and forks of our world. The problem is, the USPTO is not made up of hackers. They're probably good at judging new inventions for casting steel or grinding lenses, but they don't understand software yet.
What challenges does the patent office face in keeping up with rapidly evolving technology?

At this point, an optimist would be tempted to add, "but they will eventually." Unfortunately, that might not be true. The problem with software patents is an instance of a more general one: the patent office takes a while to understand new technology. If so, this problem will only get worse because the rate of technological change seems to be increasing. In thirty years, the patent office may understand the sort of things we now patent as software, but there will be other new types of inventions they understand even less.
What distinguishes Amazon's enforcement of its patent from the defensive use of patents by other companies like Microsoft?

Where Amazon went over to the dark side was not in applying for the patent, but in enforcing it. A lot of companies (Microsoft, for example) have been granted large numbers of preposterously over-broad patents, but they keep them mainly for defensive purposes. Like nuclear weapons, the main role of big companies' patent portfolios is to threaten anyone who attacks them with a counter-suit. Amazon's suit against Barnes & Noble was thus the equivalent of a nuclear first strike.
How did Amazon's legal actions regarding the one-click patent impact its reputation?

That suit probably hurt Amazon more than it helped them. Barnes & Noble was a lame site; Amazon would have crushed them anyway. To attack a rival they could have ignored, Amazon put a lasting black mark on their own reputation. Even now, I think if you asked hackers to free-associate about Amazon, the one-click patent would turn up in the first ten topics.
What are the two different interpretations of the question regarding the morality of applying for patents within the current legal system?

There are really two variants of that question, and people answering it often aren't clear in their own minds which they're answering. There's a narrow variant: is it bad, given the current legal system, to apply for patents? And also a broader one: is it bad that the current legal system allows patents?
What were the societal norms regarding self-defense in preindustrial societies like medieval Europe?

In preindustrial societies like medieval Europe, when someone attacked you, you didn't call the policeâthere were no police. When attacked, you were supposed to fight back, and there were conventions about how to do it. Was this wrong? That's two questions: was it wrong to take justice into your own hands, and was it wrong that you had to? We tend to say yes to the second, but no to the first. If no one else will defend you, you have to defend yourself.
What role do patents play in the competitive landscape of business?

Patents play a crucial role in the competitive landscape of business. Just as checking is an integral part of hockey, patents are essential in the business arena. If a company refuses to utilize patents effectively, it risks losing its competitive edge. Under the present rules, patents are part of the game.
Why is patent infringement typically not a concern for funded startups?

We tell the startups we fund not to worry about infringing patents because startups rarely get sued for patent infringement. There are only two reasons someone might sue you: for money or to prevent you from competing with them. Startups are too poor to be worth suing for money. In practice, they don't seem to get sued much by competitors, either. They don't get sued by other startups because (a) patent suits are an expensive distraction, and (b) since the other startups are as young as they are, their patents probably haven't issued yet.
Why might established software companies choose to acquire startups rather than pursue legal action against them?

Established software companies might choose to acquire startups rather than pursue legal action against them because, in the software business, startups do not seem to get sued much by established competitors. Despite all the patents Microsoft holds, I don't know of an instance where they sued a startup for patent infringement. Companies like Microsoft and Oracle don't win by winning lawsuits; that's too uncertain. They win by locking competitors out of their sales channels. If you do manage to threaten them, they're more likely to buy you than sue you.
What does it indicate about a company's market position when they resort to filing patent lawsuits against smaller competitors?

When you read of big companies filing patent suits against smaller ones, it's usually a big company on the way down, grasping at straws. For example, Unisys's attempts to enforce their patent on LZW compression illustrate this trend. When you see a big company threatening patent suits, it's a signal to sell. When a company starts fighting over intellectual property, it's a sign they've lost the real battle for users.
What does it indicate about a company's competitive position when it resorts to threatening patent lawsuits?

A company that sues competitors for patent infringement is like a defender who has been beaten so thoroughly that he turns to plead with the referee. You don't do that if you can still reach the ball, even if you genuinely believe you've been fouled. So, a company threatening patent suits is a company in a weakened competitive position.
What was the response of the VP from the larger company after being told their patent on online ordering was considered invalid?

When we were working on Viaweb, a bigger company in the e-commerce business was granted a patent on online ordering, or something like that. I got a call from a VP there asking if we'd like to license it. I replied that I thought the patent was completely bogus and would never hold up in court. "Ok," he replied. "So, are you guys hiring?"
What is the recommended approach to dealing with patent infringement concerns for startups?

In other words, no one will sue you for patent infringement until you have money, and once you have money, people will sue you whether they have grounds to or not. So I advise fatalism. Don't waste your time worrying about patent infringement. You're probably violating a patent every time you tie your shoelaces. At the start, at least, just worry about making something great and getting lots of users. If you grow to the point where anyone considers you worth attacking, you're doing well.
Why do we recommend that startups apply for patents?

We do advise the companies we fund to apply for patents, but not so they can sue competitors. Successful startups either get bought or grow into big companies. If a startup wants to grow into a big company, they should apply for patents to build up the patent portfolio they'll need to maintain an armed truce with other big companies. If they want to get bought, they should apply for patents because patents are part of the mating dance with acquirers.
What factors influence acquirers' decisions to buy startups instead of building their own solutions?

Most startups that succeed do so by getting bought, and most acquirers care about patents. Startup acquisitions are usually a build-vs-buy decision for the acquirer: should we buy this little startup or build our own? Two factors, especially, make them decide not to build their own: if they already have a large and rapidly growing user base, and if they have a fairly solid patent application on critical parts of their software.
Why might large companies opt to acquire technology rather than develop it in-house?

One reason large companies might prefer to acquire technology rather than develop it in-house is that if they built their own, they might screw it up. However, few big companies are smart enough yet to admit this to themselves.
