It's usually the acquirer's engineers who are asked how hard it would be for the company to build their own, and they tend to overestimate their abilities.
What is the impact of patents on the software industry, according to the author's observations?

Frankly, it surprises me how small a role patents play in the software business. It's kind of ironic, considering all the dire things experts say about software patents stifling innovation, but when one looks closely at the software business, the most striking thing is how little patents seem to matter.
What legal actions can companies take against competitors in response to perceived technological advancements?

In other fields, companies regularly sue competitors for patent infringement. For example, the airport baggage scanning business was for many years a cozy duopoly shared between two companies, InVision and L-3. In 2002, a startup called Reveal appeared, with new technology that let them build scanners a third the size. They were sued for patent infringement before they'd even released a product.
What is an example of a major company filing a patent lawsuit against a smaller startup, and what might have motivated that decision?

You rarely hear that kind of story in our world. The one example I've found is, embarrassingly enough, Yahoo, which filed a patent suit against a gaming startup called Xfire in 2005. Xfire doesn't seem to be a very big deal, and it's hard to say why Yahoo felt threatened. Xfire's VP of engineering had worked at Yahoo on similar stuffâin fact, he was listed as an inventor on the patent Yahoo sued overâso perhaps there was something personal about it. My guess is that someone at Yahoo goofed. At any rate, they didn't pursue the suit very vigorously.
Why might patents in software be considered less valuable compared to patents in other engineering fields?

One reason is that software is so complicated that patents by themselves are not worth very much. I may be maligning other fields here, but it seems that in most types of engineering, you can hand the details of some new technique to a group of medium-high quality people and get the desired result. For example, if someone develops a new process for smelting ore that gets a better yield, and you assemble a team of qualified experts and tell them about it, they'll be able to achieve the same yield. This doesn't seem to work in software. Software is so subtle and unpredictable that "qualified experts" don't get you very far.
Why might a team of qualified experts struggle against a team of less experienced but highly motivated individuals in software development?

That's why we rarely hear phrases like "qualified expert" in the software business. What that level of ability can get you is, say, to make your software compatible with some other piece of softwareâin eight months, at enormous cost. To do anything harder, you need individual brilliance. If you assemble a team of qualified experts and tell them to make a new web-based email program, they'll get their asses kicked by a team of inspired nineteen-year-olds.
What makes design a skill that can be developed and understood, similar to how electricity was once perceived?

Design is a definite skill. It's not just an airy intangible. Things always seem intangible when you don't understand them. Electricity seemed an airy intangible to most people in 1800. Who knew there was so much to know about it? So it is with design. Some people are good at it, and some people are bad at it, and there's something very tangible they're good or bad at.
Why is design particularly important in software development compared to physical product development?

The reason design counts so much in software is probably that there are fewer constraints than on physical products. Building physical products is expensive and dangerous. The space of possible choices is smaller; you tend to have to work as part of a larger group, and you're subject to a lot of regulations. You don't have any of that if you and a couple of friends decide to create a new web-based application.
What factors contribute to the success of small software companies against larger competitors beyond patents?

Because there's so much scope for design in software, a successful application tends to be way more than the sum of its patents. What protects little companies from being copied by bigger competitors is not just their patents, but the thousand little things that the big company will get wrong if they try.
How do startups typically compete with established companies in the software industry?

The second reason patents don't count for much in our world is that startups rarely attack big companies head-on, the way Reveal did. In the software business, startups beat established companies by transcending them. Startups don't build desktop word processing programs to compete with Microsoft Word.
How do large companies typically respond to startup competition, and what implications does this have for the startups?

Fortunately for startups, big companies are extremely good at denial. If you take the trouble to attack them from an oblique angle, they'll meet you halfway and maneuver to keep you in their blind spot. To sue a startup would mean admitting it was dangerous, and that often means seeing something the big company doesn't want to see. IBM used to sue its mainframe competitors regularly, but they didn't bother much about the microcomputer industry because they didn't want to see the threat it posed. Companies building web-based apps are similarly protected from Microsoft, which even now doesn't want to imagine a world in which Windows is irrelevant.
What potential consequences could Microsoft face if they decided to challenge Linux on patent grounds?

Steve Ballmer coyly left open the possibility of attacking Linux on patent grounds. But I doubt Microsoft would ever be so stupid. They'd face the mother of all boycotts, and not just from the technical community in general; a lot of their own people would rebel.
What factors contribute to the principle-driven behavior of good hackers in the software industry?

Good hackers care a lot about matters of principle, and they are highly mobile. If a company starts misbehaving, smart people won't work there. For some reason, this seems to be more true in software than in other businesses. I don't think it's because hackers have intrinsically higher principles so much as that their skills are easily transferable. Perhaps we can split the difference and say that mobility gives hackers the luxury of being principled.
How does Google's "don't be evil" policy impact its corporate culture and decision-making?

Google's "don't be evil" policy may, for this reason, be the most valuable thing they've discovered. It's very constraining in some ways. If Google does do something evil, they get doubly whacked for it: once for whatever they did, and again for hypocrisy. But I think it's worth it. It helps them to hire the best people, and it's better, even from a purely selfish point of view, to be constrained by principles than by stupidity.
Why is there limited legal action among software companies despite the prevalence of patents?

I'm not sure what the proportions are of the preceding three ingredients, but the custom among the big companies seems to be not to sue the small ones, and the startups are mostly too busy and too poor to sue one another. So, despite the huge number of software patents, there's not a lot of suing going on, with one exception: patent trolls.
How do patent trolls resemble historical practices of wealth extraction from merchants?

What companies like Forgent do is actually the proto-industrial way. In the period just before the Industrial Revolution, some of the greatest fortunes in countries like England and France were made by courtiers who extracted some lucrative right from the crownâlike the right to collect taxes on the import of silkâand then used this to squeeze money from the merchants in that business. So when people compare patent trolls to the mafia, they're more right than they know, because the mafia too are not merely bad, but bad specifically in the sense of being an obsolete business model.
What challenges do big companies face when dealing with patent trolls, and how might the legal landscape change in response?

Patent trolls seem to have caught big companies by surprise. In the last couple of years, they've extracted hundreds of millions of dollars from them. Patent trolls are hard to fight precisely because they create nothing. Big companies are safe from being sued by other big companies because they can threaten a counter-suit. But because patent trolls don't make anything, there's nothing they can be sued for. I predict this loophole will get closed fairly quickly, at least by legal standards. It's clearly an abuse of the system, and the victims are powerful.
What is the basis for most people's opinions on the subject, according to the author?

One thing I can say is that 99.9% of the people who express opinions on the subject do so not based on such research, but out of a kind of religious conviction. At least, that's the polite way of putting it; the colloquial version involves speech coming out of organs not designed for that purpose.
What is the purpose of obtaining a patent?

The purpose of obtaining a patent is to encourage innovation. You don't get a patent for nothing. In return for the exclusive right to use an idea, you have to disclose the details of that idea to the public.
How did the establishment of patents reflect the evolution of societal structures and the role of central governments in protecting individual rights?

Before patents, people protected ideas by keeping them secret. With patents, central governments said, in effect, if you tell everyone your idea, we'll protect it for you. There is a parallel here to the rise of civil order, which happened at roughly the same time. Before central governments were powerful enough to enforce order, rich people had private armies. As governments got more powerful, they gradually compelled magnates to cede most responsibility for protecting them. (Magnates still have bodyguards, but no longer to protect them from other magnates.)
What are the potential drawbacks of implementing a "need to know" policy in organizations?

Even worse than the spectacular abuses might be the overall decrease in efficiency that would accompany increased secrecy. As anyone who has dealt with organizations that operate on a "need to know" basis can attest, dividing information up into little cells is terribly inefficient. The flaw in the "need to know" principle is that you don't have access to all the information necessary to make informed decisions.
How do patents impact innovation in the software industry, particularly for startups?

In the software business, I know from experience whether patents encourage or discourage innovation, and the answer is the type that people who like to argue about public policy least like to hear: they don't affect innovation much, one way or the other. Most innovation in the software business happens in startups, and startups should simply ignore other companies' patents. At least, that's what we advise, and we bet money on that advice.
What is the primary purpose of patents for startups in the context of acquisition?

The primary purpose of patents for startups, in the context of acquisition, is as an element of the mating dance with acquirers. There, patents do help a little. They encourage innovation indirectly, as they give more power to startups, which is where, pound for pound, the most innovation happens. However, even in the mating dance, patents are of secondary importance; it matters more to create something great and attract a lot of users.
What questions should corporate development teams consider when evaluating potential projects with developers?
Instead of the canonical "Could you build this?" maybe the corporate development team should be asking "Will you build this?" or even "Why haven't you already built this?"
Why is it difficult to assess the quality of design skills in the industry?

Design ability is so hard to measure that you can't even trust the design world's internal standards. You can't assume that someone with a degree in design is any good at design, or that an eminent designer is any better than his peers. If that worked, any company could build products as good as Apple's just by hiring sufficiently qualified designers.
How can big technology companies effectively combat patent trolls without relying on government intervention?

If big companies don't want to wait for the government to take action, there is a way to fight back themselves. For a long time, I thought there wasn't because there was nothing to grab onto. But there is one resource patent trolls need: lawyers. Big technology companies, between them, generate a lot of legal business. If they agreed among themselves never to do business with any firm employing anyone who had worked for a patent troll, either as an employee or as outside counsel, they could probably starve the trolls of the lawyers they need.

How does the proposed search result sorting method differ from traditional methods used by search engines and advertisers?

The idea is basically that you sort search results not in order of textual "relevance" (as search engines did then) nor in order of how much advertisers bid (as Overture did), but in order of the bid times the number of transactions. How can search results be improved to avoid prioritizing low-quality sites that bid the highest?

If you just order the results in order of bids, you can make the search results useless because the first results could be dominated by low-quality sites that bid the most. However, if you order results by bid multiplied by transactions, far from selling out, you're getting a more accurate reflection of quality.
What was the prevailing focus in online advertising in 1998 compared to the excitement surrounding shopping searches?

In 1998, the prevailing focus in online advertising was on selling banner ads. While everyone is focused on different approaches now, few were aware of this back then. We were quite excited when we figured out what seemed to us the optimal way of doing shopping searches.
What unexpected action did the speaker take during their meeting with Jerry Yang from Yahoo?

We did it because it seems like such a great hack. There are thousands of smart people who could start companies and don't, and with a relatively small amount of force applied at just the right place, we can spring on the world a stream of new startups that might otherwise not have existed.
What is a more realistic approach to dealing with procrastination?

Most people who write about procrastination discuss how to cure it. But this is, strictly speaking, impossible. There are an infinite number of things you could be doing. No matter what you work on, you're not working on everything else. So the question is not how to avoid procrastination, but how to procrastinate well.
What are the different types of procrastination and how can they be classified?

There are three variants of procrastination, depending on what you do instead of working on something: you could work on (a) nothing, (b) something less important, or (c) something more important. That last type, Iâd argue, is good procrastination.
What is the typical behavior of the "absent-minded professor"?

The "absent-minded professor" is someone who forgets to shave, eat, or even look where he's going while he's thinking about some interesting question. His mind is absent from the everyday world because it's hard at work in another.
What distinguishes type-C procrastinators from others?

Type-C procrastinators are distinguished by their tendency to prioritize larger, more significant tasks over smaller ones. That's the sense in which the most impressive people I know are all procrastinators: they put off working on small stuff to work on big stuff.
What types of tasks are considered "small stuff" that are unlikely to be remembered after one's death?

What is "small stuff?" Roughly, it refers to work that has zero chance of being mentioned in your obituary. It's hard to say at the time what will turn out to be your best work (will it be your magnum opus on Sumerian temple architecture, or the detective thriller you wrote under a pseudonym?), but there's a whole class of tasks you can safely rule out: shaving, doing your laundry, cleaning the house, writing thank-you notesâanything that might be called an errand.
Why might it be necessary to be assertive or ruthless when trying to accomplish important tasks?

Being assertive or ruthless can be necessary when trying to accomplish important tasks. The people who want you to do the errands may not think it's good, but you probably have to annoy them if you want to get anything done. Even the mildest-seeming people, if they want to do real work, often have a certain degree of ruthlessness when it comes to avoiding errands.
What are the consequences of procrastinating on certain types of errands?

Some errands, like replying to letters, go away if you ignore them (perhaps taking friends with them). Others, like mowing the lawn or filing tax returns, only get worse if you put them off. In principle, it shouldn't work to put off the second kind of errand. You're going to have to do whatever it is eventually. Why not (as past-due notices are always saying) do it now?
Why might it be beneficial to postpone errands in favor of focusing on a creative project?

The reason it pays to put off even those errands is that real work needs two things errands don't: big chunks of time and the right mood. If you get inspired by some project, it can be a net win to blow off everything you were supposed to do for the next few days to work on it. Yes, those errands may cost you more time when you finally get around to them. But if you get a lot done during those few days, you will be net more productive.
What is the significance of uninterrupted work time in achieving creative success?

In fact, it may not be a difference in degree, but a difference in kind. There may be types of work that can only be done in long, uninterrupted stretches, when inspiration hits, rather than dutifully in scheduled little slices. Empirically, it seems to be so. When I think of the people I know who've done great things, I don't imagine them dutifully crossing items off to-do lists. I imagine them sneaking off to work on some new idea.
How does interrupting someone with synchronous tasks affect their productivity?

Conversely, forcing someone to perform errands synchronously is bound to limit their productivity. The cost of an interruption is not just the time it takes, but that it breaks the time on either side in half. You probably only have to interrupt someone a couple of times a day before they're unable to work on hard problems at all.
What impact do early hires have on the productivity and focus of a startup?

Early hires are most productive at the very beginning when they're just a couple of guys in an apartment. The main reason may be that there's no one to interrupt them yet. In theory, it's good when the founders finally get enough money to hire people to do some of the work for them. But it may be better to be overworked than interrupted. Once you dilute a startup with ordinary office workersâwith type-B procrastinatorsâthe whole company starts to resonate at their frequency. They're interrupt-driven, and soon you are too.
What common distractions do people use to avoid pursuing their creative goals?

Errands are so effective at killing great projects that a lot of people use them for that purpose. Someone who has decided to write a novel, for example, will suddenly find that the house needs cleaning. People who fail to write novels don't do it by sitting in front of a blank page for days without writing anything. They do it by feeding the cat, going out to buy something they need for their apartment, meeting a friend for coffee, and checking email. "I don't have time to work," they say. And they don't; they've made sure of that.
What is a suggested remedy for feeling unmotivated or creatively blocked when lacking a dedicated workspace?
A suggested remedy for feeling unmotivated or creatively blocked when lacking a dedicated workspace is to visit the places where famous people worked and see how unsuitable they were.
What is the most deceptive form of procrastination and why is it considered dangerous?
The most dangerous form of procrastination is unacknowledged type-B procrastination because it doesn't feel like procrastination. You're "getting things done," just the wrong things.
What is the relationship between to-do lists and type-B procrastination?

Any advice about procrastination that concentrates on crossing things off your to-do list is not only incomplete but positively misleading if it doesn't consider the possibility that the to-do list is itself a form of type-B procrastination. In fact, "possibility" is too weak a word. Nearly everyone's is. Unless you're working on the biggest things you could be working on, you're type-B procrastinating, no matter how much you're getting done.
What challenging question should ambitious individuals confront, despite its discomfort?

Most people will shy away from this question. I shy away from it myself; I see it there on the page and quickly move on to the next sentence. Hamming used to go around actually asking people this, and it didn't make him popular. But it's a question anyone ambitious should face.
What challenges do young professionals and graduate students often face regarding their work preferences?

When you're young, especially, you often find yourself working on stuff you don't really likeâbecause it seems impressive, for example, or because you've been assigned to work on it. Most grad students are stuck working on big problems they don't really like, and grad school is thus synonymous with procrastination.
Why do people often prefer to tackle smaller problems over larger ones in their work?

Even when you like what you're working on, it's easier to get yourself to work on small problems than big ones. Why is it so hard to work on big problems? One reason is that you may not get any reward in the foreseeable future. If you work on something you can finish in a day or two, you can expect to have a nice feeling of accomplishment fairly soon. If the reward is indefinitely far in the future, it seems less real.
What psychological barrier often prevents individuals from pursuing large projects?

Another reason people don't work on big projects is, ironically, fear of wasting time. What if they fail? Then all the time they spent on it will be wasted. (In fact, it probably won't be, because work on hard projects almost always leads somewhere.)
What emotional experience does one encounter when confronted with overwhelming criticism or pressure?

Thereâs an almost physical pain in facing them. Itâs like having a vacuum cleaner hooked up to your imagination. All your initial ideas get sucked out immediately, and you donât have any more, and yet the vacuum cleaner is still sucking.
How should one approach tackling a significant challenge without becoming overwhelmed?

You can't look at a big problem too directly in the eye. You have to approach it somewhat obliquely. But you have to adjust the angle just right: you have to be facing the big problem directly enough that you catch some of the excitement radiating from it, but not so much that it paralyzes you. You can tighten the angle once you get going, just as a sailboat can sail closer to the wind once it gets underway.
What strategies can help individuals tackle large projects effectively?

To tackle large projects effectively, individuals can employ several strategies. First, it can be helpful to work on small tasks that could grow into larger projects. Alternatively, one might take on successively larger tasks or share the workload with collaborators. It's important to recognize that relying on these strategies is not a sign of weakness; in fact, some of the best work has been accomplished this way.
Why do some successful individuals feel guilty about neglecting smaller tasks?

When I talk to people who've managed to make themselves work on big things, I find that they all blow off errands and all feel guilty about it. I don't think they should feel guilty. There's more to do than anyone could manage. So, someone doing the best work they can is inevitably going to leave a lot of errands undone. It seems a mistake to feel bad about that.
How can one effectively overcome procrastination?

I think the way to "solve" the problem of procrastination is to let delight pull you instead of making a to-do list push you. Work on an ambitious project you really enjoy, and sail as close to the wind as you can, and you'll leave the right things undone.

At most startups ten years ago, software development meant ten programmers writing code in C++. Now, the same work might be done by one or two using Python or Ruby.

Why do venture capitalists sometimes face challenges in investing the full amount they wish into startups?

What impact has the Sarbanes-Oxley Act had on public companies and their corporate officers?

The Sarbanes-Oxley Act, passed after the Bubble, drastically increases the regulatory burden on public companies. What concerns are raised about the effectiveness of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act in attracting qualified CFOs to public companies?

You might think that responsible corporate governance is an area where you can't go too far. But you can go too far in any law, and this remark convinced me that Sarbanes-Oxley must have. How has the Sarbanes-Oxley Act influenced the behavior of venture capitalists and the path to success for startups?

Largely because of Sarbanes-Oxley, few startups go public now. For all practical purposes, succeeding now equals getting bought. Why are acquirers increasingly choosing to buy startups directly instead of waiting for venture capitalists to invest?

What stage of funding do companies prefer to acquire startups, and why is this strategy considered effective?

What challenges do ordinary employees face when considering startup acquisitions at companies like Google?

Why are startups considered fragile and important for economic growth?

What are the potential consequences of neglecting or harming the startup industry compared to more established industries?

Why do venture capitalists typically restrict founders from receiving financial compensation until a company is sold or goes public?

Why might allowing founders to sell stock early be beneficial for a company's risk alignment with venture capitalists?

Allowing founders to sell a little stock early would generally be better for the company because it would cause the founders' attitudes toward risk to be aligned with the VCs'. Why are many founders choosing to sell their companies early rather than pursue Series A funding?

How did the arrangement with angel investors benefit both the founders and the investors in the startup?

Why are competitors usually not as threatening to startups as they might appear?

Why should startups prioritize experimentation with their software design over addressing scalability, internationalization, and security in the initial stages?

Why do startups often outperform larger companies in innovation?

How does Y Combinator's approach to startup investment differ from that of traditional incubators?

What is the author's perspective on the effectiveness of incubators for startups?

What factors influence the attitudes of founders, nature or nurture?

As with most nature/nurture questions, the answer is probably: some of each. However, my main conclusion from the summer is that there's more environment in the mix than most people realize. I could see that from how the founders' attitudes were shaped by their surroundings.
How did the individuals adapt to their newfound freedom after years of following directives?

During the summer, most were emerging from twenty or so years of being told what to do. They seemed a little surprised at having total freedom, but they grew into it really quickly; some of these guys now seem about four inches taller (metaphorically) than they did at the beginning of the summer.
How might the definition of "hacker" evolve in the next twenty years according to the author?

If I'm right, "hacker" will mean something different in twenty years than it does now. Increasingly, it will mean the people who run the company. Y Combinator is just accelerating a process that would have happened anyway. Power is shifting from the people who deal with money to the people who create technology, and if our experience this summer is any guide, this will be a good thing.
Who designed the 30-foot table used by the 2005 summer founders and Smartleaf co-founders Mark Nitzberg and Olin Shivers?
The 30-foot table used by the 2005 summer founders and Smartleaf co-founders Mark Nitzberg and Olin Shivers was designed by Kate Courteau. Photo by Alex Lewin.
What are the two primary methods proposed to address economic inequality?

Suppose you wanted to get rid of economic inequality. There are two ways to do it: give money to the poor or take it away from the rich. But they amount to the same thing because if you want to give money to the poor, you have to get it from somewhere. You can't get it from the poor, or they just end up where they started. You have to get it from the rich.
How can we effectively reduce poverty without redistributing wealth from the rich?

There is, of course, a way to make the poor richer without simply shifting money from the rich. You could help the poor become more productive â for example, by improving access to education. Instead of taking money from engineers and giving it to checkout clerks, you could enable people who would have become checkout clerks to become engineers.
What is necessary to effectively reduce economic inequality beyond simply improving the living standards of the poor?

To effectively reduce economic inequality, it is not enough to simply raise the living standards of the poor. What if one of your newly minted engineers gets ambitious and goes on to become another Bill Gates? Economic inequality will be as bad as ever. If you actually want to compress the gap between rich and poor, you have to push down on the top as well as pushing up on the bottom.
How does the relationship between risk and reward affect people's willingness to take risks in betting?

The problem is that risk and reward have to be proportionate. A bet with only a 10% chance of winning has to pay more than one with a 50% chance of winning, or no one will take it. So, if you lop off the top of the possible rewards, you thereby decrease people's willingness to take risks.
How do high tax rates impact entrepreneurial risk-taking?

High tax rates significantly impact entrepreneurial risk-taking by making certain classes of risks no longer worth pursuing if the maximum return is decreased. One reason high tax rates are disastrous is that this class of risks includes starting new companies.
What are the main reasons why startups face high failure rates?

Startups are intrinsically risky. A startup is like a small boat in the open sea. One big wave and you're sunk. A competing product, a downturn in the economy, a delay in getting funding or regulatory approval, a patent suit, changing technical standards, the departure of a key employee, the loss of a big account â any one of these can destroy you overnight. It seems only about 1 in 10 startups succeeds.
What return on investment did your startup achieve for its first round of outside investors?

Our startup paid its first round of outside investors 36x, which meant, with current US tax rates, that it made sense to invest in us if we had better than a 1 in 24 chance of succeeding. That sounds about right. That's probably roughly how we looked when we were a couple of nerds with no business experience operating out of an apartment.
What alternative sources of capital could support new companies if private funding is limited?

There might be alternative sources of capital for new companies if private funding is limited. For instance, why not have the government or some large, almost-government organization like Fannie Mae do the venture investing instead of private funds?
Why might it be ineffective to expect government employees to take risks?
Iâll tell you why that wouldnât work: because then youâre asking government or almost-government employees to do the one thing they are least able to doâtake risks.
What is the fundamental difference between decision-making in government bureaucracy and venture investing?

As anyone who has worked for the government knows, the important thing is not to make the right choices, but to make choices that can be justified later if they fail. If there is a safe option, that's the one a bureaucrat will choose. But that is exactly the wrong way to do venture investing. The nature of the business means that you want to make terribly risky choices if the upside looks good enough.
How can the potential for profit influence investors' perceptions of startups led by younger entrepreneurs?

The potential for profit influences investors' perceptions of startups led by younger entrepreneurs by making them focus on the upside: they get a percentage of the fund's gains. This perspective helps overcome their understandable fear of investing in a company run by individuals who look like (and perhaps are) college students.
How would the behavior of venture capitalists change if they were not allowed to profit from their investments?

If VCs weren't allowed to get rich, they'd behave like bureaucrats. Without hope of gain, they'd have only fear of loss. And so they'd make the wrong choices. They'd turn down the nerds in favor of the smooth-talking MBA in a suit because that investment would be easier to justify later if it failed.
Why are founders and early employees essential to the success of startups, regardless of changes in venture funding?

But even if you could somehow redesign venture funding to work without allowing VCs to become rich, there's another kind of investor you simply cannot replace: the startup's founders and early employees.
What is the significance of time and ideas in the context of investment?

What they invest is their time and ideas. But these are equivalent to money; the proof is that investors are willing (if forced) to treat them as interchangeable, granting the same status to "sweat equity" and the equity they've purchased with cash.
How does the relationship between risk and reward affect decisions on where to invest time?

The fact that you're investing time doesn't change the relationship between risk and reward. If you're going to invest your time in something with a small chance of succeeding, you'll only do it if there is a proportionately large payoff.
What motivated the author to pursue entrepreneurship instead of seeking employment in a stable organization?

Like many startup founders, I did it to get rich. But not because I wanted to buy expensive things. What I wanted was security. I wanted to make enough money that I didn't have to worry about money. If I'd been forbidden to make enough from a startup to do this, I would have sought security by some other means: for example, by going to work for a big, stable organization from which it would be hard to get fired. Instead of busting my ass in a startup, I would have tried to get a nice, low-stress job at a big research lab or tenure at a university.
What do individuals tend to do in societies where personal risk is not incentivized?

In societies where personal risk is not incentivized, individuals tend to seek security by embedding themselves in large organizations. If they cannot ensure their own safety, the next best option is to establish a stable position within a structure where their status primarily depends on the organization rather than personal risk-taking.
Why are founders considered irreplaceable compared to investors in a startup?

Even if we could somehow replace investors, I don't see how we could replace founders. Investors mainly contribute money, which in principle is the same no matter what the source. But the founders contribute ideas. You can't replace those.
How does economic inequality influence the startup ecosystem?

Economic inequality is not just a consequence of startups; it's the engine that drives them, in the same way a fall of water drives a water mill. People start startups in the hope of becoming much richer than they were before. If your society tries to prevent anyone from being much richer than anyone else, it will also prevent one person from being much richer at time t2 than at time t1.
Why are startups essential for the long-term sustainability of established companies?

New technology and new jobs both come disproportionately from new companies. Indeed, if you don't have startups, pretty soon you won't have established companies either; just as, if you stop having kids, pretty soon you won't have any adults.
How does a reduction in investors' appetite for risk impact the growth potential of promising startups?

Indeed, it may be that reducing investors' appetite for risk doesn't merely kill off larval startups but kills off the most promising ones especially. Startups yield faster growth at greater risk than established companies. Does this trend also hold among startups? That is, are the riskiest startups the ones that generate the most growth if they succeed? I suspect the answer is yes. And that's a chilling thought because it means that if you cut investors' appetite for risk, the most beneficial startups are the first to go.
Could taxing surplus wealth while allowing wealth accumulation through startups help reduce economic inequality?
Not all rich people got that way from startups, of course. What if we let people get rich by starting startups but taxed away all other surplus wealth? Wouldn't that at least decrease inequality?
How has the relationship between wealth and power evolved over the past century?

We don't need to prevent people from being rich if we can prevent wealth from translating into power. And there has been progress on that front. Before he died of drink in 1925, Commodore Vanderbilt's wastrel grandson Reggie ran down pedestrians on five separate occasions, killing two of them. By 1969, when Ted Kennedy drove off the bridge at Chappaquiddick, the limit seemed to be down to one. Today it may well be zero. But what's changed is not variation in wealth. What's changed is the ability to translate wealth into power.
What does a computer security expert consider the most crucial measure for preventing unauthorized access?

A friend of mine who knows a lot about computer security says the single most important step is to log everything. Back when he was a kid trying to break into computers, what worried him most was the idea of leaving a trail. He was more inconvenienced by the need to avoid that than by any obstacle deliberately put in his path.
What strategy can be implemented to reduce the secret connection between wealth and power without harming the economy?

Like all illicit connections, the connection between wealth and power flourishes in secret. Exposing all transactions will greatly reduce it. Log everything. That's a strategy that already seems to be working, and it doesn't have the side effect of making your whole country poor.
What is a more effective approach to achieving a fairer world than directly targeting wealth?
If you try to attack wealth, you end up nailing risk as well, and with it, growth. If we want a fairer world, I think we're better off attacking one step downstream, where wealth turns into power.
What metrics do investors use to define success for startups?

Success here is defined from the initial investors' point of view: either an IPO or an acquisition for more than the valuation at the last round of funding. The conventional 1 in 10 success rate is suspiciously neat, but conversations with VCs suggest it's roughly correct for startups overall. Top VC firms expect to do better.
How does the prevalence of systems of seniority relate to wealth variation in a non-corrupt country or organization?

Conjecture: The variation in wealth in a non-corrupt country or organization will be inversely proportional to the prevalence of systems of seniority. If you suppress variation in wealth, seniority will become correspondingly more important. So far, I know of no counterexamples, though in very corrupt countries, you may get both simultaneously. (Thanks to Daniel Sobral for pointing this out.)
What is the main argument for embracing risk-taking in startups?
What you do in a startup is compress a lifetime's worth of work into a few years. It seems as dumb to discourage that as to discourage risk-taking.
Who contributed feedback and insights for the essay on venture investing?

I would like to thank Chris Anderson, Trevor Blackwell, Dan Giffin, Jessica Livingston, and Evan Williams for reading drafts of this essay, and Langley Steinert, Sangam Pant, and Mike Moritz for providing information about venture investing.
How has the approach to career progression and job security changed for the current generation compared to thirty years ago?

Thirty years ago, one was supposed to work one's way up the corporate ladder. That's less the rule now. Our generation wants to get paid up front. Instead of developing a product for some big company in the expectation of getting job security in return, we develop the product ourselves, in a startup, and sell it to the big company. At the very least, we want options.
How do economic statistics fail to accurately represent wealth disparities in socialist countries?

Economic statistics are misleading because they ignore the value of safe jobs. An easy job from which one can't be fired is worth money; exchanging the two is one of the commonest forms of corruption. A sinecure is, in effect, an annuity. Except sinecures don't appear in economic statistics. If they did, it would be clear that in practice socialist countries have nontrivial disparities of wealth, because they usually have a class of powerful bureaucrats who are paid mostly by seniority and can never be fired.
What factors contribute to the value of a position on the corporate ladder in large companies?

While not a sinecure, a position on the corporate ladder is genuinely valuable because big companies try not to fire people and promote from within based largely on seniority. A position on the corporate ladder has a value analogous to the "goodwill" that is a very real element in the valuation of companies. It means one can expect future high-paying jobs.
What factors contributed to the success of corporate raiders in the 1980s?

The corporate ladder was one of the reasons the early corporate raiders were so successful. It's not only economic statistics that ignore the value of safe jobs; corporate balance sheets do too. One reason it was profitable to carve up 1980s companies and sell them for parts was that they hadn't formally acknowledged their implicit debt to employees who had done good work and expected to be rewarded with high-paying executive jobs when their time came.
What criticism does Gordon Gekko have regarding the management structure of the company, and what alternative perspective might explain the presence of numerous vice presidents?
Gordon Gekko ridicules a company overloaded with vice presidents. However, the company may not be as corrupt as it seems; those VPs' cushy jobs were probably payment for work done earlier.
What are the drawbacks of the old job promotion system compared to the new model?

The old job promotion system has several drawbacks compared to the new model. For one thing, it seems like a bad plan to treat jobs as rewards. Plenty of good engineers were made into bad managers that way. Additionally, the old system meant people had to deal with a lot more corporate politics in order to protect the work they'd invested in a position on the ladder.
How has the rise of open source impacted companies' use of Windows servers?

Lately, companies have been paying more attention to open source. Ten years ago, there seemed a real danger that Microsoft would extend its monopoly to servers. It seems safe to say now that open source has prevented that. A recent survey found that 52% of companies are replacing Windows servers with Linux servers.
What percentage of server operators are currently using Windows, and what must they justify in comparison to major tech companies?

52% of server operators are currently using Windows. At this point, anyone proposing to run Windows on servers should be prepared to explain what they know about servers that Google, Yahoo, and Amazon don't.
What key lessons can businesses learn from the open source movement beyond just the software itself?

The biggest lesson businesses can learn from the open source movement is not just about Linux or Firefox, but about the forces that produced them. Ultimately, these will affect a lot more than what software you use.
How do blogging and open source projects ensure quality and compete with professional efforts?

Like open source, blogging is something people do themselves, for free, because they enjoy it. Like open source hackers, bloggers compete with people working for money and often win. The method of ensuring quality is also the same: Darwinian. Companies ensure quality through rules to prevent employees from screwing up. But you don't need that when the audience can communicate with one another. People just produce whatever they want; the good stuff spreads, and the bad gets ignored. And in both cases, feedback from the audience improves the best work.
How has the advent of the Web influenced collaboration and the willingness to work for free in blogging and open source?

The advent of the Web has significantly influenced collaboration and the willingness to work for free in blogging and open source. People have always been willing to do great work for free, but before the Web, it was harder to reach an audience or collaborate on projects.
What parallels can be drawn between societal views on work and diet as societies become wealthier?

As societies get richer, they learn something about work that's a lot like what they learn about diet. We know now that the healthiest diet is the one our peasant ancestors were forced to eat because they were poor. Like rich food, idleness only seems desirable when you don't get enough of it. I think we were designed to work, just as we were designed to eat a certain amount of fiber, and we feel bad if we don't.
What is the historical connotation of the term "amateur" and how has its perception changed over time?

The term "amateur" refers to people who work for the love of it. The word now has such bad connotations that we forget its etymology, though it's staring us in the face. "Amateur" was originally rather a complimentary word. However, the thing to be in the twentieth century was professional, which amateurs, by definition, are not.
What is a key insight from the open source movement regarding motivation in the workplace?

A key insight from the open source movement regarding motivation in the workplace is that people working for love often surpass those working for money. Users don't switch from Explorer to Firefox because they want to hack the source; they switch because it's a better browser.
What challenge does Microsoft face in maintaining its market dominance in browsers and operating systems?

It's not that Microsoft isn't trying. They know controlling the browser is one of the keys to retaining their monopoly. The problem is the same they face in operating systems: they can't pay people enough to build something better than a group of inspired hackers will build for free.
What is the author's perspective on the concept of professionalism and its historical significance?

I suspect professionalism was always overratedânot just in the literal sense of working for money, but also in connotations like formality and detachment. Inconceivable as it would have seemed in, say, 1970, I think professionalism was largely a fashion, driven by conditions that happened to exist in the twentieth century.
What factors contribute to the perception of superiority between professional journalists and amateur commentators?

The narrowness of such channels made professionals seem superior to amateurs. There were only a few jobs as professional journalists, for example, so competition ensured the average journalist was fairly good. In contrast, anyone can express opinions about current events in a bar. As a result, the average person expressing his opinions in a bar sounds like an idiot compared to a journalist writing about the subject.
What factors contribute to the perception that blogs may not pose a significant threat to traditional media?

On the web, the barrier for publishing your ideas is even lower. You don't have to buy a drink, and they even let kids in. Millions of people are publishing online, and the average level of what they're writing, as you might expect, is not very good. This has led some in the media to conclude that blogs don't present much of a threatâthat blogs are just a fad.
What issue arises from the print media's use of the term "blogger" to describe online publishers?

Actually, the fad is the word "blog," at least the way the print media now use it. What they mean by "blogger" is not someone who publishes in a weblog format, but anyone who publishes online. That's going to become a problem as the Web becomes the default medium for publication. So I'd like to suggest an alternative word for someone who publishes online. How about "writer?"
What are traditional print media competing against in the digital age?

In the old world of channels, it meant something to talk about average quality because that's what you were getting, whether you liked it or not. But now you can read any writer you want. So the average quality of writing online isn't what the print media are competing against. They're competing against the best writing online. And, like Microsoft, they're losing.
What happens to professionals who rely on an oligopoly in their industry?

When professionals rely on an oligopoly in their industry, they often sink into bad habits that are hard to overcome when competition arises. As in software, when professionals produce subpar work, it's not surprising if amateurs can do better. Live by the channel, die by the channel: dependence on an oligopoly can lead to complacency and a decline in quality.
What are some characteristics of the work environment in a startup compared to a traditional office?

Things are different in a startup. Often, a startup begins in an apartment. Instead of matching beige cubicles, they have an assortment of furniture they bought used. They work odd hours, wearing the most casual of clothing. They look at whatever they want online without worrying whether it's "work safe." The cheery, bland language of the office is replaced by wicked humor. And you know what? The company at this stage is probably the most productive it's ever going to be.
What is a key drawback of traditional office work hours according to the author?

To me, the most demoralizing aspect of the traditional office is that you're supposed to be there at certain times. There are usually a few people in a company who really have to, but the reason most employees work fixed hours is that the company can't measure their productivity.
What are the implications of measuring work output on traditional work schedules?

If you could measure how much work people did, many companies wouldn't need any fixed workday. You could just say: this is what you have to do. Do it whenever you like, wherever you like. If your work requires you to talk to other people in the company, then you may need to be here a certain amount; otherwise, we don't care.
What is the company's approach to work hours and employee productivity?

Our company's approach to work hours is quite flexible; there are no fixed office hours. Personally, I never showed up before 11 in the morning. However, this flexibility is not about being benevolent. We communicate to our employees that we expect them to be productive and get a lot done. It's important to us that they don't try to mislead us by simply being present for long hours without delivering results.
What are the negative impacts of the facetime model on productivity in large organizations?

The problem with the facetime model is not just that it's demoralizing, but that the people pretending to work interrupt the ones actually working. I'm convinced the facetime model is the main reason large organizations have so many meetings. Per capita, large organizations accomplish very little. And yet all those people have to be on site at least eight hours a day. When so much time goes in one end and so little achievement comes out the other, something has to give. And meetings are the main mechanism for taking up the slack.
What emotions or thoughts did the author experience during meetings at their nine to five job?

For one year, I worked at a regular nine to five job, and I remember well the strange, cozy feeling that comes over one during meetings. I was very aware, because of the novelty, that I was being paid for programming. It seemed just amazing, as if there was a machine on my desk that spat out a dollar bill every two minutes no matter what I did, even while I was in the bathroom! But because the imaginary machine was always running, I felt I always ought to be working. And so meetings felt wonderfully relaxing. They counted as work, just like programming, but they were so much easier. All you had to do was sit and look attentive.
What are the hidden costs of frequent meetings and email communication in the workplace?

Meetings are like an opiate with a network effect. So is email, on a smaller scale. In addition to the direct cost in time, there's the cost of fragmentationâbreaking people's days up into bits too small to be useful.
What experiment could companies conduct to assess their employees' reliance on communication?

You can see how dependent you've become on something by removing it suddenly. So for big companies, I propose the following experiment: set aside one day where meetings are forbiddenâwhere everyone has to sit at their desk all day and work without interruption on things they can do without talking to anyone else. Some amount of communication is necessary in most jobs, but I'm sure many employees could find eight hours' worth of stuff they could do by themselves. You could call it "Work Day."
Why might someone feel guilty about engaging in reflective thinking during work hours?

The other problem with pretend work is that it often looks better than real work. When I'm writing or hacking, I spend as much time just thinking as I do actually typing. Half the time I'm sitting, drinking a cup of tea, or walking around the neighborhood. This is a critical phaseâthis is where ideas come fromâand yet I'd feel guilty doing this in most offices, with everyone else looking busy.
Why are open source projects and blogging valuable for understanding the quality of work?

It's hard to see how bad some practices are until you have something to compare them to. And that's one reason open source, and even blogging in some cases, is so important. They show us what real work looks like.
Why are the new startups expected to work from their apartments instead of traditional office spaces?

We're funding eight new startups at the moment. A friend asked what they were doing for office space and seemed surprised when I said we expected them to work out of whatever apartments they found to live in. But we didn't propose that to save money. We did it because we want their software to be good. Working in informal spaces is one of the things startups do right without realizing it. As soon as you get into an office, work and life start to drift apart.
How do open source and blogging demonstrate the value of grassroots innovation?

The third big lesson we can learn from open source and blogging is that ideas can bubble up from the bottom instead of flowing down from the top. Open source and blogging both work bottom-up: people make what they want, and the best stuff prevails.
What are the two main forces that influence design in the channel era?

There are two forces that together steer design: ideas about what to do next and the enforcement of quality. In the channel era, both flowed down from the top. For example, newspaper editors assigned stories to reporters and then edited what they wrote.
How do open source and blogging challenge traditional notions of quality and idea enforcement?

Open source and blogging show us that things don't have to work that way. Ideas and even the enforcement of quality can flow bottom-up. In both cases, the results are not merely acceptable but better. For example, open source software is more reliable precisely because it's open source; anyone can find mistakes.
What concerns does the author express about publishing essays with limited online visibility?

That hadn't been online. Once an essay has had a couple thousand page views, I feel reasonably confident about it. But these had had literally orders of magnitude less scrutiny. It felt like releasing software without testing it.
How has the transition to online publishing changed perceptions of traditional manuscript review processes?

The transition to online publishing has significantly altered perceptions of traditional manuscript review processes. In the past, if you managed to get ten people to read a manuscript, you considered yourself lucky. However, having become accustomed to online publishing, the old method now seems alarmingly unreliable, akin to navigating by dead reckoning after becoming used to GPS.
Why did the author prefer the idea of their work being rejected by the magazine editor?

That seemed suitable for a magazine, so I sent it to an editor I know. As I was waiting to hear back, I found to my surprise that I was hoping they'd reject it. Then I could put it online right away. If they accepted it, it wouldn't be read by anyone for months, and in the meantime, I'd have to fight word by word to save it from being mangled by some twenty-five-year-old copy editor.
What are some common barriers that innovative employees face when trying to implement their ideas within a company?

Innovative employees often face significant barriers when trying to implement their ideas within a company. They are eager to build great things for the companies they work for, but more often than not, management won't let them. How many of us have heard stories of employees going to management and saying, "Please let us build this thing to make money for you," only to be met with a "no"? The most famous example is probably Steve Wozniak, who originally wanted to build microcomputers for his then-employer, HP, but they turned him down. On the blunderometer, this episode ranks with IBM accepting a non-exclusive license for DOS. I believe this happens all the time; we just don't hear about it usually because, to prove oneself right, one often has to quit and start their own company, like Wozniak did.
What are the key lessons that open source and blogging can teach businesses about productivity and management?

So these, I think, are the three big lessons open source and blogging have to teach businesses: (1) that people work harder on stuff they like, (2) that the standard office environment is very unproductive, and (3) that bottom-up often works better than top-down.
How might the traditional employer-employee relationship evolve in a future influenced by open source and blogging principles?

So what will business look like when it has assimilated the lessons of open source and blogging? I think the big obstacle preventing us from seeing the future of business is the assumption that people working for you have to be employees. But think about what's going on underneath: the company has some money, and they pay it to the employee in the hope that he'll make something worth more than they paid him. Well, there are other ways to arrange that relationship. Instead of paying the guy money as a salary, why not give it to him as investment? Then, instead of coming to your office to work on your projects, he can work wherever he wants on projects of his own.
What are the challenges and frustrations associated with customer service and management roles?

I dislike being on either end of it. I'll work my ass off for a customer, but I resent being told what to do by a boss. Being a boss is also horribly frustrating; half the time it's easier just to do stuff yourself than to get someone else to do it for you. I'd rather do almost anything than give or receive a performance review.
Why is employment considered a unique economic relationship compared to other business transactions?

Nothing shows more clearly that employment is not an ordinary economic relationship than companies being sued for firing people. In any purely economic relationship, you're free to do what you want. If you want to stop buying steel pipe from one supplier and start buying it from another, you don't have to explain why. No one can accuse you of wrongdoing.
What factors contribute to the dissatisfaction of employees in a seemingly secure and well-compensated job environment?

Next time you're in a moderately large city, drop by the main post office and watch the body language of the people working there. They have the same sullen resentment as children made to do something they don't want to. Their union has exacted pay increases and work restrictions that would have been the envy of previous generations of postal workers, and yet they don't seem any happier for it. It's demoralizing to be on the receiving end of a paternalistic relationship, no matter how cozy the terms. Just ask any teenager.
What emotional challenges do entrepreneurs face when dealing with the problems their startups aim to solve?
The thought of our startups keeps me up at night. All the pain of whatever problem you're trying to solve is still there. But the pain hurts less when it isn't mixed with resentment.
What impact did working at Yahoo after its acquisition of the startup have on your behavior and work experience?

I had the misfortune to participate in what amounted to a controlled experiment to prove that. After Yahoo bought our startup, I went to work for them. I was doing exactly the same work, except with bosses. To my horror, I started acting like a child. The situation pushed buttons I'd forgotten I had.
What is a key benefit of pursuing investment opportunities instead of traditional employment?
The big advantage of investment over employment, as the examples of open source and blogging suggest, is that people working on projects of their own are enormously more productive.
How does Google foster a creative and engaging work environment for its employees?

Google is a rare example of a big company in tune with the forces I've described. They've tried hard to make their offices less sterile than the usual cube farm. They give employees who do great work large grants of stock to simulate the rewards of a startup. They even let hackers spend 20% of their time on their own projects.
What is the author's perspective on the potential for more individuals to pursue entrepreneurship after leaving school?

So am I claiming that no one is going to be an employee anymoreâthat everyone should go and start a startup? Of course not. But more people could do it than do it now. At the moment, even the smartest students leave school thinking they have to get a job.
What is a more advantageous path for ambitious individuals seeking to create value?
Actually, what they need to do is make something valuable. A job is one way to do that, but the more ambitious ones will ordinarily be better off taking money from an investor than an employer.
What is the most challenging aspect of developing a successful product?

The first phase of that is mostly product creationâthat is, hacking. That's the hard part. It's a lot harder to create something people love than to take something people love and figure out how to make money from it.
What factors might influence a person's decision to start a startup?
Another factor that keeps people away from starting startups is the risk. Someone with kids and a mortgage should think twice before doing it. However, most young hackers have neither.
What are the benefits of pursuing independent projects compared to traditional employment?

Pursuing independent projects, as the examples of open source and blogging suggest, can be more enjoyable, even if you fail. You'll be working on your own thing instead of going to an office and doing what you're told. There may be more pain in your own company, but it won't hurt as much.
How is the relationship between employers and employees evolving due to open source and blogging?

The greatest effect, in the long run, of the forces underlying open source and blogging may be the final ditching of the old paternalistic employer-employee relationship, replacing it with a purely economic one between equals.
What misconception about changing an operating system was highlighted in a Forrester Research survey?

A survey by Forrester Research, reported in the cover story of Business Week on January 31, 2005, highlighted a misconception that one must replace the actual server in order to switch the operating system.
What happened to the article I submitted after a delay in sending the final version?
They accepted the article, but I took so long to send them the final version that, by the time I did, the section of the magazine they'd accepted it for had disappeared in a reorganization.
What role do PR firms play in shaping the news stories we encounter in traditional media?

One of the most surprising things I discovered during my brief business career was the existence of the PR industry, lurking like a huge, quiet submarine beneath the news. Of the stories you read in traditional media that aren't about politics, crimes, or disasters, more than half probably come from PR firms.
Why did you decide to allocate your startup's entire marketing budget to PR instead of traditional advertising?

I know because I spent years hunting such "press hits." Our startup spent its entire marketing budget on PR; at a time when we were assembling our own computers to save money, we were paying a PR firm $16,000 a month. And they were worth it. PR is the news equivalent of search engine optimization; instead of buying ads, which readers ignore, you get yourself inserted directly into the stories.
What was the author's impression of the PR agency they recommended to a startup founder in 1997?

In 1997, I got a call from another startup founder considering hiring them to promote his company. I told him they were PR gods, worth every penny of their outrageous fees. And we weren't the only ones they did great things for. But I remember thinking his company's name was odd. Why call an auction site "eBay"?
Why do the best PR firms prioritize honesty and valuable information in their communications with reporters?

PR is not dishonest. Not quite. In fact, the reason the best PR firms are so effective is precisely that they aren't dishonest. They give reporters genuinely valuable information. A good PR firm won't bug reporters just because the client tells them to; they've worked hard to build their credibility with reporters, and they don't want to destroy it by feeding them mere propaganda.
How do effective flatterers and successful PR firms manipulate perceptions without resorting to falsehoods?

A good flatterer doesn't lie but tells his victim selective truths (e.g., "What a nice color your eyes are"). Good PR firms use the same strategy: they give reporters stories that are true, but whose truth favors their clients.
What factors influenced the media coverage of small merchants competing with larger companies?

For example, our PR firm often pitched stories about how the Web let small merchants compete with big ones. This was perfectly true. However, the reason reporters ended up writing stories about this particular truth, rather than some other one, was that small merchants were our target market, and we were paying the piper.
What is the main reason top reporters may not respond well to story pitches?

The weak point of top reporters is not laziness, but vanity. You don't pitch stories to them; you have to approach them as if you were a specimen under their all-seeing microscope and make it seem as if the story you want them to run is something they thought of themselves.
What strategy did the team use to position themselves as a significant player in the online store market?

Our greatest PR coup was a two-part one. We estimated, based on some fairly informal math, that there were about 5,000 stores on the Web. We got one paper to print this number, which seemed neutral enough. But once this "fact" was out there in print, we could quote it to other publications and claim that with 1,000 users, we had 20% of the online store market.
How do media reports often misrepresent the sources of information regarding criminal cases?

Reporters like definitive statements. For example, many of the stories about Jeremy Jaynes's conviction say that he was one of the 10 worst spammers. This "fact" originated in Spamhaus's ROKSO list, which I think even Spamhaus would admit is a rough guess at the top spammers. The first stories about Jaynes cited this source, but now it's simply repeated as if it were part of the indictment.
How do PR firms craft messages to meet the demands of reporters?

PR firms craft messages to meet the demands of reporters by providing statements that are clear and impactful. Reporters prefer concise and compelling phrases over vague descriptions. For example, instead of saying someone is a "fairly big spammer," they would rather have a definitive statement like "top ten." PR firms understand this need and tailor their messages accordingly to ensure they resonate with the media.
How do PR firms create the illusion of trends in media coverage?

Where the work of PR firms really does get deliberately misleading is in the generation of "buzz." They usually feed the same story to several different publications at once. When readers see similar stories in multiple places, they think there is some important trend afoot, which is exactly what they're supposed to think.
How did public relations impact the launch success of Windows 95?

When Windows 95 was launched, people waited outside stores at midnight to buy the first copies. None of them would have been there without PR firms, which generated such a buzz in the news media that it became self-reinforcing, like a nuclear chain reaction.
How can one identify the influence of PR firms in trend articles?

Trend articles like this are almost always the work of PR firms. Once you know how to read them, it's straightforward to figure out who the client is. With trend stories, PR firms usually line up one or more "experts" to talk about the industry generally. In this case, we get three: the NPD Group, the creative director of GQ, and a research director at Smith Barney.
What impact did The Men's Wearhouse's advertising campaign have on media coverage?

Not surprisingly, considering The Men's Wearhouse was at that moment running ads saying, "The Suit is Back," this led to a successful press hitâa wire service article whose first sentence is your own ad copy.
How can you track down additional press coverage related to a specific PR pitch?

The secret to finding other press hits from a given pitch is to realize that they all started from the same document back at the PR firm. Search for a few key phrases and the names of the clients and the experts, and you'll turn up other variants of this story.
What is the proposed term for the phenomenon of identifying patterns in trend stories promoted by PR firms?

Now that so many news articles are online, I suspect you could find a similar pattern for most trend stories placed by PR firms. I propose we call this new sport "PR diving," and I'm sure there are far more striking examples out there than this clump of five stories.
What insights did you gain about press hits and media articles after hiring a PR firm?

After spending years chasing them, it's now second nature for me to recognize press hits for what they are. But before we hired a PR firm, I had no idea where articles in the mainstream media came from. I could tell a lot of them were not credible, but I didn't realize why.
What additional question should critical readers ask beyond evaluating the author's truthfulness?

Remember the exercises in critical reading you did in school, where you had to look at a piece of writing and step back and ask whether the author was telling the whole truth? If you really want to be a critical reader, it turns out you have to step back one step further and ask not just whether the author is telling the truth, but also what perspectives or biases might be influencing their narrative.
Why do readers tend to trust bloggers more than traditional print publications?

Online, the answer tends to be a lot simpler. Most people who publish online write what they write for the simple reason that they want to. You can't see the fingerprints of PR firms all over the articles, as you can in so many print publicationsâwhich is one of the reasons, though they may not consciously realize it, that readers trust bloggers more than traditional print publications.
What does a newspaper employee believe about the current state of print media?

I was talking recently to a friend who works for a big newspaper. He thought the print media were in serious trouble and that they were still mostly in denial about it. "They think the decline is cyclic," he said. "Actually, it's structural."
What is the value of online writing compared to traditional media?

Whatever its flaws, the writing you find online is authentic. It's not mystery meat cooked up out of scraps of pitch letters and press releases, and pressed into molds of zippy journalese. It's people writing what they think.
How has your perspective on writing for publication changed in recent years?

I used to think of writing for publication as merely a means of conveying information. However, I didn't realize until the last few years that writing for publication didn't have to mean writing that way. I discovered that you could write as candidly and informally as you would if you were writing to a friend.
What challenges do PR firms face in adapting to the rise of blogs and online media?

PR professionals fear bloggers for the same reason readers like them. This indicates that there may be a struggle ahead. As this new kind of writing draws readers away from traditional media, we should be prepared for whatever PR mutates into to compensate. When I think about how hard PR firms work to score press hits in traditional media, I can't imagine they'll work any less hard to feed stories to bloggers, if they can figure out how.
Why do advertisers pay less for ads in free publications?

Advertisers pay less for ads in free publications because they assume readers ignore something they get for free. This is why so many trade publications nominally have a cover price and yet give away free subscriptions with such abandon.
What was the estimated number of computers infected by the Internet worm of 1988, and how was this estimate derived?

The most striking example I know of this type is the "fact" that the Internet worm of 1988 infected 6,000 computers. I was there when it was cooked up, and this was the recipe: someone guessed that there were about 60,000 computers attached to the Internet, and that the worm might have infected ten percent of them.
Why are some research groups at prestigious institutions like MIT choosing to switch to Macs?

Some research groups at prestigious institutions like MIT are gradually switching to Macs. My friend Robert said his whole research group at MIT recently bought themselves PowerBooks. These guys are not the graphic designers and grandmas who were buying Macs at Apple's low point in the mid-1990s. They're about as hardcore OS hackers as you can get.
What was the perception of the Mac computer among hackers in the mid-90s?
For most of us, it's not a switch to Apple, but a return. Hard as this was to believe in the mid-90s, the Mac was, in its time, the canonical hacker's computer.
What was the impact of the introduction of the Macintosh computer on students' perceptions of computing technology?

In the fall of 1983, the professor in one of my college CS classes got up and announced, like a prophet, that there would soon be a computer with half a MIPS of processing power that would fit under an airline seat and cost so little that we could save enough to buy one from a summer job. The whole room gasped. And when the Mac appeared, it was even better than we'd hoped. It was small and powerful and cheap, as promised. But it was also something we'd never considered a computer could be: fabulously well-designed and user-friendly.
What was a common resource among hackers interested in developing software for the Mac during the mid to late 1980s?

In the mid to late 1980s, all the hackers I knew were either writing software for the Mac or wanted to. Every futon sofa in Cambridge seemed to have the same fat white book lying open on it. If you turned it over, it said "Inside Macintosh."
What was your impression of the Apple store in Cambridge after the changes with OS X?

With OS X, the hackers are back. When I walked into the Apple store in Cambridge, it was like coming home. Much had changed, but there was still that Apple coolness in the air, that feeling that the show was being run by someone who really cared, instead of random corporate deal-makers.
What role do research labs and computer science departments play in the evolution of technology?

Research labs and computer science departments play a small, but important role that is out of proportion to their size. When it comes to computers, what hackers are doing now, everyone will be doing in ten years. Almost all technology, from Unix to bitmapped displays to the Web, became popular first within CS departments and research labs, and gradually spread to the rest of the world.
What technological advancement in the 1980s did the speaker believe would be a significant investment opportunity?

I remember telling my father back in 1986 that there was a new kind of computer called a Sun that was a serious Unix machine, but so small and cheap that you could have one of your own to sit in front of, instead of sitting in front of a VT100 connected to a single central Vax. Maybe, I suggested, he should buy some stock in this company. I think he really wishes he'd listened.
What innovative technology did Koling develop in 1994 to communicate with his girlfriend in Taiwan, and how is it relevant today?
