In 1994, my friend Koling wanted to talk to his girlfriend in Taiwan, and to save long-distance bills, he wrote some software that would convert sound to data packets that could be sent over the Internet. We weren't sure at the time whether this was a proper use of the Internet, which was still then a quasi-government entity. What he was doing is now called VoIP, and it is a huge and rapidly growing business.
What factors influenced the decision of Bricklin and Frankston to develop VisiCalc for the Apple II?

They tend to write it first for whatever computer they personally use, and software sells hardware. Many, if not most, of the initial sales of the Apple II came from people who bought one to run VisiCalc. Bricklin and Frankston wrote VisiCalc for the Apple II because they personally liked it. They could have chosen any machine to make into a star.
What factors are important for attracting hackers to develop software for your hardware?
To attract hackers to write software that will sell your hardware, you have to make it something that they themselves use. It's not enough to make it "open"; it has to be open and good.
What unique position does Apple hold in the market regarding its customer demographics?

Apple holds a unique position in the market as it is popular at both the low end and the high end, but not in the middle. My seventy-year-old mother has a Mac laptop, and my friends with PhDs in computer science also use Mac laptops. However, Apple's overall market share remains small.
Why is writing considered essential for generating new ideas?

I think it's far more important to write well than most people realize. Writing doesn't just communicate ideas; it generates them. If you're bad at writing and don't like to do it, you'll miss out on most of the ideas that writing would have generated.
What are some effective strategies for improving writing and editing skills?

If you say anything mistaken, fix it immediately. Ask friends which sentence you'll regret most. Go back and tone down harsh remarks. Publish stuff online, because an audience makes you write more and thus generate more ideas. Print out drafts instead of just looking at them on the screen. Use simple, Germanic words. Learn to distinguish surprises from digressions. Learn to recognize the approach of an ending, and when one appears, grab it.
What opportunity did the author receive related to a venture capital fund?

A couple of months ago, I got an email from a recruiter asking if I was interested in being a "technologist in residence" at a new venture capital fund. I think the idea was to play Karl Rove to the VCs' George Bush.
What underlying factor contributes to the behavior of venture capitalists?

A few days ago, it hit me that there's a reason VCs are the way they are. It's not so much that the business attracts jerks, or even that the power they wield corrupts them. The real problem is the way they're paid.
What are the financial incentives and operational challenges faced by venture capitalists when managing large funds?

Like the managers of mutual funds or hedge funds, VCs get paid a percentage of the money they manage: about 2% a year in management fees, plus a percentage of the gains. So they want the fund to be hugeâhundreds of millions of dollars, if possible. But that means each partner ends up being responsible for investing a lot of money. And since one person can only manage so many deals, each deal has to be for multiple millions of dollars.
Why do venture capitalists take a long time in their decision-making process?

Venture capitalists take a long time to make decisions because they conduct extensive due diligence, which can feel as invasive as a body cavity search. With so much at stake, they have to be paranoid.
Why do venture capitalists often steal ideas from founders?

It explains why they steal your ideas. Every founder knows that VCs will tell your secrets to your competitors if they end up investing in them. It's not unheard of for VCs to meet you when they have no intention of funding you, just to pick your brain for a competitor. This prospect makes naive founders clumsily secretive. Experienced founders treat it as a cost of doing business. Either way, it sucks. But again, the only reason VCs are so sneaky is the giant deals they do. With so much at stake, they have to be devious.
Why do venture capitalists often take an active role in the management of the companies they invest in?

Venture capitalists often take an active role in the management of the companies they invest in because they want to be on the board not just to advise, but also to monitor the company's progress. They may even install a new CEO who, while having extensive business experience, is also closely aligned with their interests. These newly installed CEOs often play something of the role of a political commissar in a Red Army unit. With so much at stake, VCs can't resist micromanaging the companies they invest in.
What are the potential downsides of large venture capital investments for startups?

The huge investments themselves are something founders would dislike if they realized how damaging they can be. VCs don't invest $x million because that's the amount you need, but because that's the amount the structure of their business requires them to invest. Like steroids, these sudden huge investments can do more harm than good. Google survived enormous VC funding because it could legitimately absorb large amounts of money; they had to buy a lot of servers and a lot of bandwidth to crawl the whole Web. Less fortunate startups just end up hiring armies of people to sit around having meetings.
What are the implications of high valuations for founders in a startup?

High valuations often result from significant investments, which are necessary to keep founders engaged. While many founders may perceive a high valuation as a positive development, it's important to remember that a high valuation is not inherently beneficial. You cannot "eat" paper; the true value of a high valuation can only be realized if the founders can achieve the necessary business milestones to capitalize on it.
What challenges do founders face when trying to achieve a liquidity event after raising venture capital?

Founders face significant challenges when trying to achieve a liquidity event after raising venture capital. One major issue is that the higher the company's valuation, the narrower the options become for executing a liquidity event. Many founders might be willing to sell their company for $15 million, but venture capitalists who have just invested at a pre-money valuation of $8 million are unlikely to accept that. This situation puts founders in a difficult position, as they are essentially rolling the dice again, whether they like it or not.
How did the author react to a competitor's significant fundraising success in 1997?

Back in 1997, one of our competitors raised $20 million in a single round of VC funding. This was, at the time, more than the valuation of our entire company. Was I worried? Not at all: I was delighted. It was like watching a car you're chasing turn down a street that you know has no outlet.
Why didn't the investors consider buying the company for $20 million?

Their smartest move at that point would have been to take every penny of the $20 million and use it to buy us. We would have sold. Their investors would have been furious, of course. But I think the main reason they never considered this was that they never imagined we could be had so cheap. They probably assumed we were on the same VC gravy train they were.
How did limited spending impact a company's ability to sell itself compared to its competitors?

In fact, we only spent about $2 million in our entire existence, and that gave us flexibility. We could sell ourselves to Yahoo for $50 million, and everyone was delighted. If our competitor had done that, the last round of investors would presumably have lost money. I assume they could have vetoed such a deal. But no one those days was paying a lot more than Yahoo. So unless their founders could pull off an IPO (which would be difficult with Yahoo as a competitor), they had no choice but to ride the thing down.
What are some common negative traits associated with venture capitalists based on their behavior?
Add up all the evidence of VCs' behavior, and the resulting personality is not attractive. In fact, it's the classic villain: alternately cowardly, greedy, sneaky, and overbearing.
What was the author's initial perception of venture capitalists?

I used to take it for granted that VCs were like this. Complaining that VCs were jerks used to seem as naive to me as complaining that users didn't read the reference manual. Of course, VCs were jerks. How could it be otherwise?
What distinguishes the best venture capitalists in their approach to investment opportunities?

The very best VCs don't have to act like VCs. They get the pick of all the best deals, so they don't have to be so paranoid and sneaky. Instead, they can choose those rare companies, like Google, that will actually benefit from the giant sums they're compelled to invest.
What is a common criticism VCs have about the current funding landscape?
VCs often complain that in their business, there's too much money chasing too few deals. Few realize that this also describes a flaw in the way funding works at the level of individual firms.
What analogy is used to describe the experience of undergoing due diligence by venture capitalists?

Due diligence tends to be like a body cavity search by someone with a faulty knowledge of human anatomy. After a while, we were quite sore from VCs attempting to probe our nonexistent database orifice.
What operating system do you use for data storage and why?

No, we don't use Oracle. We just store the data in files. Our secret is to use an OS that doesn't lose our data. Which OS? FreeBSD. Why do you use that instead of Windows NT? Because it's better, and it doesn't cost anything.
Why do adults often ask high school students about their future plans?

I'll start by telling you something you don't have to know in high school: what you want to do with your life. People are always asking you this, so you think you're supposed to have an answer. But adults ask this mainly as a conversation starter. They want to know what sort of person you are, and this question is just to get you talking. They ask it the way you might poke a hermit crab in a tide pool to see what it does.
What is the most important step to take when considering future career options in high school?

If I were back in high school and someone asked about my plans, I'd say that my first priority was to learn what the options were. You don't need to be in a rush to choose your life's work. What you need to do is discover what you like. You have to work on stuff you like if you want to be good at what you do.
Why is it difficult for individuals to determine their true career interests?

It might seem that nothing would be easier than deciding what you like, but it turns out to be hard, partly because it's difficult to get an accurate picture of most jobs. Being a doctor is not the way it's portrayed on TV. Fortunately, you can also watch real doctors by volunteering in hospitals.
What challenges do rapidly changing job markets present for career planning?

The challenges presented by rapidly changing job markets for career planning include the emergence of jobs that do not yet exist. Most of the work I've done in the last ten years didn't exist when I was in high school. The world changes fast, and the rate at which it changes is itself speeding up. In such a world, it's not a good idea to have fixed plans.
What is the criticism of the common graduation speech theme that encourages students to pursue their original dreams?

Every May, speakers all over the country fire up the Standard Graduation Speech, the theme of which is: don't give up on your dreams. I know what they mean, but this is a bad way to put it because it implies you're supposed to be bound by some plan you made early on. The computer world has a name for this: premature optimization. It is synonymous with disaster. These speakers would do better to say simply, don't give up.
What is the main message about potential and perception of successful individuals in the paragraph?

What they really mean is, don't get demoralized. Don't think that you can't do what other people can. And I agree you shouldn't underestimate your potential. People who've done great things tend to seem as if they were a race apart. Most biographies only exaggerate this illusion, partly due to the worshipful attitude biographers inevitably sink into, and partly because, knowing how the story ends, they can't help streamlining the plot till it seems like the subject's life was a matter of destiny, the mere unfolding of some innate genius. In fact, I suspect if you had the sixteen-year-old Shakespeare or Einstein in school with you, they'd seem impressive, but not totally unlike your other friends.
What psychological reasoning do people often use to explain the achievements of geniuses?

This is an uncomfortable thought. If they were just like us, then they had to work very hard to do what they did. And that's one reason we like to believe in genius. It gives us an excuse for being lazy. If these individuals were able to achieve what they did only because of some magic "Shakespeareness" or "Einsteinness," then it's not our fault if we can't do something as good.
What approach do successful people often take when pursuing their objectives?
I think the solution is to work in the other direction. Instead of working back from a goal, work forward from promising situations. This is what most successful people actually do anyway.
What is an alternative approach to planning for the future compared to the traditional graduation-speech method?

In the graduation-speech approach, you decide where you want to be in twenty years and then ask: what should I do now to get there? I propose instead that you don't commit to anything in the future but just look at the options available now and choose those that will give you the most promising range of options afterward.
What are the advantages of majoring in math compared to majoring in economics for a college freshman?

Suppose you're a college freshman deciding whether to major in math or economics. Well, math will give you more options; you can go into almost any field from math. If you major in math, it will be easy to get into grad school in economics, but if you major in economics, it will be hard to get into grad school in math.
What metaphor can be used to illustrate the importance of maintaining a favorable position in pursuing goals?

Flying a glider is a good metaphor here. Because a glider doesn't have an engine, you can't fly into the wind without losing a lot of altitude. If you let yourself get far downwind of good places to land, your options narrow uncomfortably. As a rule, you want to stay upwind. So I propose that as a replacement for "don't give up on your dreams": stay upwind.
How can one identify valuable opportunities in a professional environment?

Look for smart people and hard problems. Smart people tend to clump together, and if you can find such a clump, it's probably worthwhile to join it. However, it's not straightforward to find these, because there is a lot of faking going on.
What factors contribute to the perceived complexity of academic papers across different university departments?

To a newly arrived undergraduate, all university departments look much the same. The professors all seem forbiddingly intellectual and publish papers unintelligible to outsiders. However, while in some fields the papers are unintelligible because they're full of hard ideas, in others they're deliberately written in an obscure way to seem as if they're saying something important. This may seem a scandalous proposition, but it has been experimentally verified in the famous studies.
What does the incident involving a physicist submitting nonsensical work to a literary theory journal reveal about the standards of academic publishing in the humanities?

The affair began when a physicist, suspecting that the papers published by literary theorists were often just intellectual-sounding nonsense, deliberately wrote a paper full of intellectual-sounding nonsense and submitted it to a literary theory journal, which published it.
What is the relationship between overcoming worries and experiencing joy?

Overcoming worries can lead to experiencing joy. While it may seem grim to suggest that we should worry, it's not as bad as it sounds. In fact, it's exhilarating to overcome those worries. You don't see faces much happier than those of people winning gold medals. And do you know why they're so happy? It's the relief that comes from conquering their fears and challenges.
What is the key difference between high school students and adults, according to the author's perspective?

If you'd asked me in high school what the difference was between high school kids and adults, I'd have said it was that adults had to earn a living. Wrong. It's that adults take responsibility for themselves. Making a living is only a small part of it. Far more important is to take intellectual responsibility for oneself.
How would you approach high school differently if given a second chance?

If I had to go through high school again, I'd treat it like a day job. I don't mean that I'd slack in school. Working at something as a day job doesn't mean doing it badly; it means not being defined by it. I mean I wouldn't think of myself as a high school student, just as a musician with a day job as a waiter doesn't think of himself as a waiter. And when I wasn't working at my day job, I'd start trying to do real work.
What do people commonly regret about their high school experience?

When I ask people what they regret most about high school, they nearly all say the same thing: that they wasted so much time. If you're wondering what you're doing now that you'll regret most later, that's probably it.
What types of skills or knowledge are often not reflected in college applications?

It's not about getting something done. What I mean by getting something done is learning how to write well, or how to program computers, or what life was really like in preindustrial societies, or how to draw the human face from life. This sort of thing rarely translates into a line item on a college application.
How do prep schools enhance a student's admissions prospects compared to public schools?

Few parents would pay so much for their kids to go to a school that didn't improve their admissions prospects. Prep schools openly say this is one of their aims. But what that means, if you stop to think about it, is that they can hack the admissions process: that they can take the very same kid and make him seem a more appealing candidate than he would if he went to the local public school.
What did the discovery of a teacher using Cliff's Notes suggest about the value of grades in that class?
When I discovered that one of our teachers was using Cliff's Notes, it seemed par for the course. Surely, it meant nothing to get a good grade in such a class.
What is the best way to handle setbacks or unfair situations?

In retrospect, this was stupid. It was like someone getting fouled in a soccer game and saying, "Hey, you fouled me, that's against the rules," and walking off the field in indignation. Fouls happen. The thing to do when you get fouled is not to lose your cool. Just keep playing.
What is a more productive approach to dealing with authority in a school setting?

Rebellion is almost as stupid as obedience. In either case, you let yourself be defined by what they tell you to do. The best plan, I think, is to step onto an orthogonal vector. Don't just do what they tell you, and don't just refuse to. Instead, treat school as a day job. As day jobs go, it's pretty sweet. You're done at 3 o'clock, and you can even work on your own stuff while you're there.
What factors should one consider when determining their career path?

What is your real job supposed to be? Unless you're Mozart, your first task is to figure that out. What are the great things to work on? Where are the imaginative people? And most importantly, what are you interested in? The word "aptitude" is misleading because it implies something innate. The most powerful sort of aptitude is a consuming interest in some question, and such interests are often acquired tastes.
How has the concept of "passion" been misrepresented in popular culture?

A distorted version of this idea has filtered into popular culture under the name "passion." I recently saw an ad for waiters saying they wanted people with a "passion for service." The real thing is not something one could have for waiting on tables, and "passion" is a bad word for it. A better name would be "curiosity."
How does the nature of curiosity change from childhood to adulthood, particularly in ambitious individuals?

Children are curious, but the curiosity I mean has a different shape from that of kids. Child curiosity is broad and shallow; they ask "why" at random about everything. In most adults, this curiosity dries up entirely. It has to: you can't get anything done if you're always asking "why" about everything. However, in ambitious adults, instead of drying up, curiosity becomes narrow and deep. The mud flat morphs into a well.
How can curiosity influence one's approach to learning and problem-solving?

Curiosity turns work into play. For Einstein, relativity wasn't a book full of hard stuff he had to learn for an exam; it was a mystery he was trying to solve. So it probably felt like less work to him to invent it than it would seem to someone now to learn it in a class.
What misconception about discipline in education does the author challenge in the paragraph?

One of the most dangerous illusions you get from school is the idea that doing great things requires a lot of discipline. Most subjects are taught in such a boring way that it's only by discipline that you can flog yourself through them. So I was surprised when, early in college, I read a quote by Wittgenstein saying that he had no self-discipline and had never been able to deny himself anything, not even a cup of coffee.
How does self-discipline contribute to achieving great things, according to the author's experience with running and work?

I'm not saying you can get away with zero self-discipline. You probably need about the same amount you need to go running. I'm often reluctant to go running, but once I do, I enjoy it. And if I don't run for several days, I feel ill. It's the same with people who do great things. They know they'll feel bad if they don't work, and they have enough discipline to get themselves to their desks to start working. But once they get started, interest takes over, and discipline is no longer necessary.
What was Shakespeare's attitude towards writing, according to the paragraph?
Do you think Shakespeare was gritting his teeth and diligently trying to write great literature? Of course not. He was having fun. That's why he's so good.
What mindset or attitude is essential for producing impactful work, according to the example of Einstein?

If you want to do good work, what you need is a great curiosity about a promising question. The critical moment for Einstein was when he looked at Maxwell's equations and said, "What the hell is going on here?"
Why does it take so long to develop a meaningful research question in a subject like mathematics?

It can take years to zero in on a productive question because it can take years to figure out what a subject is really about. To take an extreme example, consider math. Most people think they hate math, but the boring stuff you do in school under the name "mathematics" is not at all like what mathematicians do.
What was G. H. Hardy's attitude towards math in high school and how did it change over time?

The great mathematician G. H. Hardy said he didn't like math in high school either. He only took it up because he was better at it than the other students. Only later did he realize math was interesting; only later did he start to ask questions instead of merely answering them correctly.
How can one approach tasks like writing a paper to make them more engaging and meaningful?

When a friend of mine used to grumble because he had to write a paper for school, his mother would tell him to find a way to make it interesting. That's what you need to do: find a question that makes the world interesting. People who do great things look at the same world everyone else does, but notice some odd detail that's compellingly mysterious.
What are some examples of challenging conventional thinking in different fields?

Not only in intellectual matters, but also in practical applications, challenging conventional thinking can lead to significant changes. Henry Ford's great question was, "Why do cars have to be a luxury item? What would happen if you treated them as a commodity?" Similarly, Franz Beckenbauer's question was, in effect, "Why does everyone have to stay in his position? Why can't defenders score goals too?"
How can a sixteen-year-old begin the process of discovering significant questions?

If it takes years to articulate great questions, what do you do now, at sixteen? Work toward finding one. Great questions don't appear suddenly; they gradually congeal in your head. And what makes them congeal is experience. So the way to find great questions is not to search for them â not to wander about thinking, "What great discovery shall I make?" You can't answer that; if you could, you'd have made it.
What is the best approach to generate big ideas according to the experiences of notable figures like Einstein, Ford, and Beckenbauer?

The best approach to generate big ideas, according to the experiences of notable figures like Einstein, Ford, and Beckenbauer, is not to hunt for big ideas, but to put in a lot of time on work that interests you, and in the process, keep your mind open enough that a big idea can take root. Einstein, Ford, and Beckenbauer all used this recipe. They all knew their work like a piano player knows the keys. So when something seemed amiss to them, they had the confidence to notice it.
What strategies can one use to choose and pursue personal projects effectively?

Put in time how and on what? Just pick a project that seems interesting: to master some chunk of material, to make something, or to answer some question. Choose a project that will take less than a month, and make it something you have the means to finish. Do something hard enough to stretch you, but only just, especially at first. If you're deciding between two projects, choose whichever seems most fun. If one blows up in your face, start another. Repeat till, like an internal combustion engine, the process becomes self-sustaining, and each project generates the next one. (This could take years.)
What are the benefits of keeping a project secret and involving a select group of friends?

It may be just as well not to do a project "for school," if that will restrict you or make it seem like work. Involve your friends if you want, but not too many, and only if they're not flakes. Friends offer moral support (few startups are started by one person), but secrecy also has its advantages. There's something pleasing about a secret project. And you can take more risks because no one will know if you fail.
How should one approach a project that doesn't initially align with their goals?

Don't worry if a project doesn't seem to be on the path to some goal you're supposed to have. Paths can bend a lot more than you think. So let the path grow out of the project. The most important thing is to be excited about it, because it's by doing that you learn.
What are some unseemly motivations that can drive individuals to pursue ambitious goals?

Don't disregard unseemly motivations. One of the most powerful is the desire to be better than other people at something. Hardy said that's what got him started, and I think the only unusual thing about him is that he admitted it. Another powerful motivator is the desire to do or know things you're not supposed to. Closely related is the desire to do something audacious. Sixteen-year-olds aren't supposed to write novels. So if you try, anything you achieve is on the plus side of the ledger; if you fail utterly, you're doing no worse than expectations.
What warning does the author give about the influence of admired writing styles on one's own creativity?

Beware of bad models, especially when they excuse laziness. When I was in high school, I used to write "existentialist" short stories like ones I'd seen by famous writers. My stories didn't have a lot of plot, but they were very deep. And they were less work to write than entertaining ones would have been. I should have known that was a danger sign. In fact, I found my stories pretty boring; what excited me was the idea of writing serious, intellectual stuff like the famous writers.
What realization did the author come to about the relationship between fame and the quality of work?

Now I have enough experience to realize that those famous writers actually sucked. Plenty of famous people do; in the short term, the quality of one's work is only a small component of fame. I should have been less worried about doing something that seemed cool and just done something I liked. That's the actual road to coolness anyway.
What is an essential step in undertaking a project that involves learning?

A key ingredient in many projects, almost a project on its own, is to find good books. Most books are bad. Nearly all textbooks are bad. So don't assume a subject is to be learned from whatever book on it happens to be closest. You have to search actively for the tiny number of good books.
How can individuals take charge of their lives regardless of age or external validation?

Your life doesn't have to be shaped by admissions officers; it could be shaped by your own curiosity. It is for all ambitious adults, and you don't have to wait to start. In fact, you don't have to wait to be an adult. There's no switch inside you that magically flips when you turn a certain age or graduate from some institution. You start being an adult when you decide to take responsibility for your life. You can do that at any age.
What challenges do both minors and adults face in their daily lives?

This may sound like nonsense. I'm just a minor, you may think; I have no money, I have to live at home, and I have to do what adults tell me all day long. Well, most adults labor under restrictions just as cumbersome, and they manage to get things done. If you think it's restrictive being a kid, imagine having kids.
What key realization distinguishes adults from high school students, according to the paragraph?

The only real difference between adults and high school kids is that adults realize they need to get things done, and high school kids don't. That realization hits most people around 23. But I'm letting you in on the secret early. So get to work. Maybe you can be the first generation whose greatest regret from high school isn't how much time you wasted.
What experiment can you conduct to assess your dependence on distractions?

To measure how dependent you've become on distractions, try this experiment: set aside a chunk of time on a weekend and sit alone to think. You can have a notebook to write your thoughts down in, but nothing else: no friends, TV, music, phone, IM, email, web, games, books, newspapers, or magazines. Within an hour, most people will feel a strong craving for distraction.
What would happen to parents' decisions about sending their children to prep schools if those schools negatively impacted college admissions but still offered a high-quality education?

The question of parents' decisions about sending their children to prep schools becomes intriguing when considering the impact on college admissions. Suppose prep schools provided the same superior education but had a tiny (0.001) negative effect on college admissions. How many parents would still choose to send their kids to them? While these schools generally offer a better education, the potential negative effect on college admissions could significantly influence parents' choices.
How does the educational background of public school students impact their performance in college compared to their private school peers?

The educational background of public school students impacts their performance in college compared to their private school peers. While some may argue that private school students are better college candidates, this seems empirically false. What you learn in even the best high school is rounding error compared to what you learn in college. Public school students arrive at college with a slight disadvantage, but they start to pull ahead in their sophomore year.
What factors contribute to the lack of accountability and competition in high school education?

There are simply no outside forces pushing high schools to be good. The air traffic control system works because planes would crash otherwise. Businesses have to deliver because otherwise competitors would take their customers. But no planes crash if your school is inadequate, and it has no competitors. High school isn't evil; it's random; but random is pretty bad.
What did Samuel Johnson imply about the motivations behind writing?

Samuel Johnson implied that the motivations behind writing are often financial, stating, "No man but a blockhead ever wrote except for money." While many hope he was exaggerating, it suggests that a significant number of great works were created primarily to make money.
What might happen if adults were placed in a high school environment and subjected to its rules?

I wonder if they'd like it if you did. You may be loud and disorganized, but you're very docile compared to adults. If you actually started acting like adults, it would be just as if a bunch of adults had been transposed into your bodies. Imagine the reaction of an FBI agent, taxi driver, or reporter to being told they had to ask permission to go to the bathroom, and only one person could go at a time. To say nothing of the things you're taught. If a bunch of actual adults suddenly found themselves trapped in high school, the first thing they'd do is form a union and renegotiate all the rules with the administration.

To Ingrid Bassett, Trevor Blackwell, Rich Draves, Dan Giffin, Sarah Harlin, Jessica Livingston, Jackie McDonough, Robert Morris, Mark Nitzberg, Lisa Randall, and Aaron Swartz for reading drafts of this, and to many others for talking to me about high school.
What was your Italian friend's reaction to her train journey from Boston to Providence?

A few years ago, an Italian friend of mine traveled by train from Boston to Providence. She had only been in America for a couple of weeks and hadn't seen much of the country yet. She arrived looking astonished. "It's so beautiful!" she exclaimed, clearly impressed by the scenery along the way.
How do travel depictions of America often contrast with the realities of its urban environments?

People from other rich countries can scarcely imagine the squalor of the man-made bits of America. In travel books, they show you mostly natural environments: the Grand Canyon, whitewater rafting, and horses in a field. If you see pictures with man-made things in them, it will be either a view of the New York skyline shot from a discreet distance or a carefully cropped image of a seacoast town in Maine.
In which fields does the author suggest that a non-systematic approach is more effective?

This works well in some fields and badly in others. I suspect it works in movies and software because they're both messy processes. "Systematic" is the last word I'd use to describe the way these fields operate.
How do software developers approach the coding process?

Software developers approach the coding process by writing software. Code is not something they assemble painstakingly after careful planning, like the pyramids. It's something they plunge into, working fast and constantly changing their minds, like a charcoal sketch.
Why is it important to prioritize speed over meticulousness in software development?

In software development, paradoxical as it sounds, good craftsmanship means working fast. If you work slowly and meticulously, you merely end up with a very fine implementation of your initial, mistaken idea. Working slowly and meticulously is premature optimization. It is better to get a prototype done fast and see what new ideas it gives you.
How does the filmmaking process compare to software development in terms of imperfections and execution?

The filmmaking process is quite similar to software development. Every movie is a Frankenstein, full of imperfections and usually quite different from what was originally envisioned. However, it is interesting and is often finished fairly quickly.
What factors contribute to success in the car industry compared to industries like software or movies?

Success in the car industry is influenced by several factors that differ from those in software or movies. Cars, like cities, are inherently physical products, which imposes more constraints on innovation. If the car business operated like software or movies, one could easily surpass competitors by creating a car that weighed only fifty pounds or folded up to the size of a motorcycle for parking convenience. However, in the automotive sector, success is less about dramatic innovations and more about good taste and attention to detail.
Why do some Americans struggle to appreciate the concept of "taste" in design?

The trouble is, the very word "taste" sounds slightly ridiculous to American ears. It seems pretentious, frivolous, or even effeminate. Blue staters think it's "subjective," and red staters think it's for sissies. So anyone in America who really cares about design will be sailing upwind.
What has shifted in the perception of the US car industry's issues over the past two decades?

Twenty years ago, we used to hear that the problem with the US car industry was the workers. We don't hear that anymore now that Japanese companies are building cars in the US. The problem with American cars is bad design. You can see that just by looking at them.
What is the main criticism of the design process for this car compared to American cars today?
The main criticism of the design process for this car, compared to American cars today, is that it was designed by marketing people instead of designers.
What cultural factors contribute to the superior quality of Japanese car manufacturing?

Why do the Japanese make better cars than us? Some say it's because their culture encourages cooperation. That may come into it, but in this case, it seems more to the point that their culture prizes design and craftsmanship.
What values are prioritized in certain industries over design and craftsmanship?

We don't especially prize design or craftsmanship here. What we like is speed, and we're willing to do something in an ugly way to get it done fast. In some fields, like software or movies, this is a net win.
What common factor influences the design quality in American software, movies, and Japanese cars?

But it's not just that software and movies are malleable mediums. In those businesses, the designers (though they're not generally called that) have more power. Software companies, at least successful ones, tend to be run by programmers. And in the film industry, though producers may second-guess directors, the director controls most of what appears on the screen. And so American software and movies, and Japanese cars, all have this in common: the people in charge care about designâthe former because the designers are in charge, and the latter because the whole culture cares about design.
Why are American car companies struggling to maintain market share despite their marketing strategies?

American car companies are struggling to maintain market share despite their marketing strategies because they rely on what marketing people think consumers want rather than following their own internal design compass, as Henry Ford did. This approach is not working, and American cars continue to lose market share. The reason is that customers often do not want what they think they want.
Why is relying on focus groups for car design considered a short-term strategy?

Relying on focus groups for car design is considered a short-term strategy because letting focus groups design your cars for you only wins in the short term. In the long term, it pays to bet on good design. The focus group may say they want the meretricious feature du jour, but what they want even more is to imitate sophisticated buyers, and they, though a small minority, really do care about good design. Eventually, the pimps and drug dealers notice that the doctors and lawyers have switched from Cadillac to Lexus and do the same.
What sets Apple apart from other American companies in the consumer electronics market?

Apple is an interesting counterexample to the general American trend. If you want to buy a nice CD player, you'll probably buy a Japanese one. But if you want to buy an MP3 player, you'll probably buy an iPod. What happened? Why doesn't Sony dominate MP3 players? Because Apple is in the consumer electronics business now, and unlike other American companies, they're obsessed with good design. Or more precisely, their CEO is.
What role does a great designer play in exceeding unrecognized expectations?
For it to surprise me, it must be satisfying expectations I didn't know I had. No focus group is going to discover those. Only a great designer can.
What are the advantages of the just-do-it model in wealth generation and innovation?

The just-do-it model does have advantages. It seems the clear winner for generating wealth and technical innovations (which are practically the same thing). I think speed is the reason. It's hard to create wealth by making a commodity. The real value is in things that are new, and if you want to be the first to make something, it helps to work fast. For better or worse, the just-do-it model is fast, whether you're Dan Bricklin writing the prototype of VisiCalc in a weekend or a real estate developer building a block of shoddy condos in a month.
Can we balance the need for individualism and innovation in technology with the creation of pleasant living environments?

If I had to choose between the just-do-it model and the careful model, I'd probably choose just-do-it. But do we have to choose? Could we have it both ways? Could Americans have nice places to live without undermining the impatient, individualistic spirit that makes us good at software? Could other countries introduce more individualism into their technology companies and research labs without having it metastasize as strip malls? I'm optimistic. It's harder to say about other countries, but in the US, at least, I think we can have both.
What factors influence Japan's approach to building and city planning?

Japan is prone to earthquakes, so buildings are traditionally seen as temporary; there is no grand tradition of city planning like the one Europeans inherited from Rome. The other cause is the notoriously corrupt relationship between the government and construction companies.
What common bias do political writers exhibit when analyzing election outcomes?

People who write about politics, whether on the left or the right, have a consistent bias: they take politics seriously. When one candidate beats another, they look for political explanations. The country is shifting to the left or the right. That sort of shift can certainly be the result of a presidential election, which makes it easy to believe it was the cause.
What factors influenced your decision to vote for Bill Clinton over George H.W. Bush?

When I think about why I voted for Clinton over the first George Bush, it wasn't because I was shifting to the left. Clinton just seemed more dynamic. He seemed to want the job more. Bush seemed old and tired. I suspect it was the same for a lot of voters.
How did charisma influence the political fortunes of Al Gore compared to George Bush and Bob Dole in the 2000 election?

He was just more charismatic than George Bush or (God help us) Bob Dole. In 2000, we practically got a controlled experiment to prove it: Gore had Clinton's policies, but not his charisma, and he suffered proportionally.
Why did Nixon choose not to participate in televised debates against Humphrey?
Nixon knew he had less charisma than Humphrey and thus simply refused to debate him on TV. He knew he couldn't afford to let the two of them be seen side by side.
How did television influence the type of candidates in political elections, particularly in the context of Kennedy's campaign?
Undoubtedly, TV helped Kennedy, so historians are correct in regarding this election as a watershed. TV required a new kind of candidate; there would be no more Calvin Coolidges.
How has charisma influenced the outcomes of presidential elections since the advent of television?

One would like to believe elections are won and lost on issues, if only fake ones like Willie Horton. And yet, if they are, we have a remarkable coincidence to explain. In every presidential election since TV became widespread, the apparently more charismatic candidate has won. Surprising, isn't it, that voters' opinions on the issues have lined up with charisma for 11 elections in a row?
What factor do major parties rely on to influence election outcomes when they strategically adjust their message on key issues?

I'm not saying that issues don't matter to voters. Of course they do. But the major parties know so well which issues matter, how much to how many voters, and adjust their message so precisely in response that they tend to split the difference on the issues, leaving the election to be decided by the one factor they can't control: charisma.
What might have changed the outcome of the 2004 election for the Democrats?

If the Democrats had been running a candidate as charismatic as Clinton in the 2004 election, he would have won. And we would be reading that the election was a referendum on the war in Iraq, instead of that the Democrats are out of touch with evangelical Christians in middle America.
What slogan did the Clinton campaign use to emphasize the importance of economic issues in the 1992 election?
During the 1992 election, the Clinton campaign staff had a big sign in their office saying, "It's the economy, stupid." Perhaps it was even simpler than they thought.
What criteria do scientists use to determine whether a theory should be considered, even if it appears implausible?
As for it being impossible, I reply: here's the data; here's the theory; the theory explains the data 100%. To a scientist, at least, that means it deserves attention, however implausible it seems.
Why do politicians focus on the electoral vote rather than the popular vote during elections?

Politicians focus on the electoral vote rather than the popular vote during elections because the electoral vote ultimately decides the election outcome. While it is true that Gore won the popular vote, candidates campaign for the electoral vote to secure victory. If Bush had been campaigning for the popular vote, he would presumably have received more of it. (Thanks to judgmentalist for this point.)
What percentage of individuals without TV access cited financial reasons, and how might this relate to their susceptibility to charisma?
Source: Nielsen Media Research. Of the remaining 13%, 11% didn't have TV because they couldn't afford it. I'd argue that the missing 11% were probably also the 11% most susceptible to charisma.
What does the theory suggest about the electability of charismatic candidates with controversial pasts?

One implication of this theory is that parties shouldn't be too quick to reject candidates with skeletons in their closets. Charismatic candidates will tend to have more skeletons than squeaky-clean dullards, but in practice, that doesn't seem to lose elections. The current Bush, for example, probably did more drugs in his twenties than any preceding president, and yet managed to get elected with a base of evangelical Christians. All you have to do is say you've reformed and stonewall about the details.
Who contributed feedback on the drafts and clarified a historical error in the text?

I would like to thank Trevor Blackwell, Maria Daniels, Jessica Livingston, Jackie McDonough, and Robert Morris for reading drafts of this, and to Eric Raymond for pointing out that I was wrong about 1968.
What discrepancies were observed between exit polls and actual election results in the 2004 Ohio presidential election?

In Ohio, which Kerry ultimately lost 49-51, exit polls gave him a 52-48 victory. This wasn't just random error; in every swing state, they overestimated the Kerry vote. In Florida, which Bush ultimately won 52-47, exit polls predicted a dead heat.
What concerns are raised about the integrity of exit poll data in relation to actual election returns?

These are not early numbers. They're from about midnight Eastern time, long after polls closed in Ohio and Florida. And yet, by the next afternoon, the exit poll numbers online corresponded to the returns. The only way I can imagine this happening is if those in charge of the exit polls cooked the books after seeing the actual returns. But that's another issue.
What psychological phenomenon might explain why candidates with a comfortable lead in polls can still lose an election?

What happened? The source of the problem may be a variant of the Bradley Effect. This term was invented after Tom Bradley, the Black mayor of Los Angeles, lost an election for governor of California despite a comfortable lead in the polls. Apparently, voters were afraid to say they planned to vote against him, lest their motives be (perhaps correctly) suspected.
How do pollsters address non-responses when trying to achieve a random sample?

Pollsters address non-responses by noting the age, race, and sex of individuals who do not respond to their questions. This is important because, to achieve a truly random sample, pollsters often select every 20th person leaving a polling place and ask who they voted for. However, not everyone is willing to answer. If pollsters simply ignore those who do not respond, their sample would no longer be random. Therefore, they make educated guesses about how non-respondents might have voted based on the demographic information they collect.
Why might some voters have hesitated to openly disclose their support for Bush in this election?

There is often a difference between who people vote for and whether they're willing to talk about it. But this year, there may have been a significant number of those who voted for Bush who didn't want to say so.
Why might individuals provide answers that differ from their true beliefs when asked about sensitive topics like gay marriage?

They know what they believe, but they also know what they're supposed to believe. So, when a stranger (for example, a pollster) asks them their opinion about something like gay marriage, they will not always say what they really think.
Why might exit polls underestimate the true conservativeness of ordinary voters in a liberal-leaning environment?

When the values of the elite are liberal, polls will tend to underestimate the conservativeness of ordinary voters. This seems to me the leading theory to explain why the exit polls were so far off this year. NPR values suggested one ought to vote for Kerry. So all the people who voted for Kerry felt virtuous for doing so and were eager to tell pollsters they had. No one who voted for Kerry did it as an act of quiet defiance.
Why is it important to understand the process of writing rather than just the final product?

As E. B. White said, "good writing is rewriting." I didn't realize this when I was in school. In writing, as in math and science, they only show you the finished product. You don't see all the false starts. This gives students a misleading view of how things get made.
Why might writers be hesitant to share early drafts of their work?

Part of the reason it happens is that writers don't want people to see their mistakes. However, I'm willing to let people see an early draft if it will show how much you have to rewrite to shape an essay into its final form.
What are some categories of cuts identified in the writing process?
There seem to be several categories of cuts: things I got wrong, things that seem like bragging, flames, digressions, stretches of awkward prose, and unnecessary words.
Why did you discard more ideas in the early stages of your project?
I discarded more ideas from the beginning. That's not surprising; it takes a while to hit your stride. There are more digressions at the start because I'm not sure where I'm heading.
What realization did the author have about their school writing and its connection to their current work?

It hadn't occurred to me until then that those horrible things we had to write in school were even connected to what I was doing now. But sure enough, I thought, they did call them "essays," didn't they?
What are the author's views on the writing assignments given in school?

Well, they're not. Those things you have to write in school are not only not essays; they're one of the most pointless of all the pointless hoops you have to jump through in school. I worry that they not only teach students the wrong things about writing but also put them off writing entirely.
How has the focus of writing instruction shifted in schools across the country?

The teaching of writing has gotten mixed together with the study of literature. And so, all over the country, students are writing not about how a baseball team with a small budget might compete with the Yankees, or the role of color in fashion, or what constitutes a good dessert, but about symbolism in Dickens.
What does the author suggest about the nature of original thought during periods of conflict?

What little original thought there was took place in lulls between constant wars and had something of the character of the thoughts of parents with a new baby. The most amusing thing written during this period, Liudprand of Cremona's Embassy to Constantinople, is, I suspect, mostly inadvertently so.
How might the arrival of aliens impact the field of scholarship and our understanding of knowledge?

If aliens were to arrive, they would presumably know a few things we don't. Immediately, Alien Studies would become the most dynamic field of scholarship: instead of painstakingly discovering things for ourselves, we could simply absorb everything they had discovered. This scenario is reminiscent of Europe in 1200 when classical texts began to circulate. These texts contained not just new answers, but new questions. (If anyone proved a theorem in Christian Europe before 1200, for example, there is no record of it.)
What role did intellectual archaeology play in the development of education during its early centuries?

For a couple of centuries, some of the most important work being done was intellectual archaeology. Those were also the centuries during which schools were first established. Since reading ancient texts was the foundation of education, intellectual archaeology played a crucial role in shaping curricula and teaching methods in these early educational institutions.
How has the focus of classical scholarship evolved from the early era to the modern era?

Classical scholarship has also changed. In the early era, philology actually mattered. The texts that filtered into Europe were all corrupted to some degree by the errors of translators and copyists. Scholars had to figure out what Aristotle said before they could figure out what he meant. But by the modern era, such questions were answered as well as they were ever going to be. And so, the study of ancient texts became less about ancientness and more about texts.
What is a proposed change to university education that aligns with student interests and needs?

I have no illusions about how eagerly this suggestion will be adopted. Public schools probably couldn't stop teaching English even if they wanted to; they're probably required to by law. But here's a related suggestion that goes with the grain instead of against it: that universities establish a writing major. Many of the students who now major in English would major in writing if they could, and most would be better off.
How can traditional English classes negatively impact a student's love for reading?

Indeed, English classes may even be harmful. In my case, they were effectively aversion therapy. Want to make someone dislike a book? Force him to read it and write an essay about it. And make the topic so intellectually bogus that you could not, if asked, explain why one ought to write about it. I love to read more than anything, but by the end of high school, I never read the books we were assigned. I was so disgusted with what we were doing that it became a point of honor for me to write nonsense at least as good as the other students' without having more than glanced over the book to learn the names of the characters and a few random events in it.
What challenges did the author face in understanding the expectations of English classes in college?

I hoped this might be fixed in college, but I found the same problem there. It was not the teachers; it was English. We were supposed to read novels and write essays about them. About what, and why? No one seemed to be able to explain. Eventually, by trial and error, I found that what the teacher wanted us to do was pretend that the story had really taken place and to analyze, based on what the characters said and did (the subtler clues, the better), what their motives must have been. One got extra credit for motives having to do with class, as I suspect one must now for those involving gender and sexuality. I learned how to churn out such stuff well enough to get an A, but I never took another English class.
What is the difference between a thesis and a dissertation?
Most people treat the words "thesis" and "dissertation" as interchangeable, but originally, at least, a thesis was a position one took, and the dissertation was the argument by which one defended it.
What is the fundamental approach to starting an essay according to the paragraph?

Figure out what? You don't know yet. And so you can't begin with a thesis, because you don't have one and may never have one. An essay doesn't begin with a statement but with a question. In a real essay, you don't take a position and defend it. You see a door that's ajar, and you open it and walk in to see what's inside.
Why is writing important for understanding and developing ideas?

If all you want to do is figure things out, why do you need to write anything, though? Why not just sit and think? Well, there precisely is Montaigne's great discovery. Expressing ideas helps to form them. Indeed, "helps" is far too weak a word.
What is a common issue found in blog entries regarding their conclusions?

This seems to be a common problem. It's practically the standard ending in blog entriesâwith the addition of a "heh" or an emoticon, prompted by the all-too-accurate sense that something is missing.
What distinguishes the writing styles of staff writers from outside writers in newsmagazines?

The writing styles of staff writers and outside writers in newsmagazines are distinct. Outside writers tend to supply editorials of the defend-a-position variety, which make a beeline toward a rousing (and foreordained) conclusion. In contrast, staff writers feel obliged to write something more nuanced and balanced, often exploring various angles of a story rather than pushing a singular viewpoint.
What is the main purpose of an essay compared to defend-a-position writing?

The main purpose of an essay, compared to defend-a-position writing, is to search for truth rather than to assert a predetermined stance. In defend-a-position writing, you already know where you're going and want to go straight there, often blustering through obstacles and hand-waving your way across swampy ground. However, in an essay, the process is more exploratory; it is acceptable, and even expected, for the writing to meander. An essay should be interesting and reflect a genuine inquiry into the subject matter, making it suspicious if it does not meander.
How does the author describe their approach to writing this essay?

In fact, what you do (or what I do) is somewhere between a river and a Roman road-builder. I have a general idea of the direction I want to go in, and I choose the next topic with that in mind. This essay is about writing, so I do occasionally yank it back in that direction, but it is not all the sort of essay I thought I was going to write about writing.
What is the author's perspective on the purpose and nature of essays?

Err on the side of the river. An essay is not a reference work. It's not something you read looking for a specific answer and feel cheated if you don't find it. I'd much rather read an essay that went off in an unexpected but interesting direction than one that plodded dutifully along a prescribed course.
What emotions did the speaker experience regarding travel before overcoming their fear of flying?
I was afraid of flying for a long time and could only travel vicariously. When friends came back from faraway places, it wasn't just out of politeness that I asked them about their experiences.
How do you prepare for experiencing new places?

Indeed, you can ask it in real time. Now, when I go somewhere new, I make a note of what surprises me about it. Sometimes, I even make a conscious effort to visualize the place beforehand, so I'll have a detailed image to compare with reality.
What type of facts are considered the most valuable and why?

Facts that contradict things you thought you knew are considered the most valuable. They are like a food that's not merely healthy but counteracts the unhealthy effects of things you've already eaten.
What approach should writers take to effectively engage their readers?

Use yourself as a proxy for the reader. You should only write about things you've thought about a lot. Anything you come across that surprises you, someone who has thought about the topic a lot, will probably surprise most readers.
What does the comparison between Milton's "Paradise Lost" and the Aeneid reveal about the perception of their complexity and readability?

The other extreme, the work that seems formidable from the moment it's created (indeed, is deliberately intended to be), is represented by Milton. Like the Aeneid, Paradise Lost is a rock imitating a butterfly that happened to get fossilized. Even Samuel Johnson seems to have balked at this; on the one hand, paying Milton the compliment of an extensive biography, and on the other, writing of Paradise Lost that "none who read it ever wished it longer."
What was your experience with stock valuation during the Internet Bubble while working at Yahoo?

I had a front-row seat for the Internet Bubble because I worked at Yahoo during 1998 and 1999. One day, when the stock was trading around $200, I sat down and calculated what I thought the price should be. The answer I got was $12. I went to the next cubicle and told my friend Trevor. "Twelve!" he said. He tried to sound indignant, but he didn't quite manage it. He knew as well as I did that our valuation was crazy.
How did Yahoo's business model contribute to the perception of profitability in internet companies during the dot-com bubble?

Yahoo was a special case. It was not just our price-to-earnings ratio that was bogus; half our earnings were too. Not in the Enron way, of course. The finance guys seemed scrupulous about reporting earnings. What made our earnings bogus was that Yahoo was, in effect, the center of a Ponzi scheme. Investors looked at Yahoo's earnings and said to themselves, "Here is proof that Internet companies can make money." So they invested in new startups that promised to be the next Yahoo. And as soon as these startups got the money, what did they do with it? They bought millions of dollars' worth of advertising on Yahoo to promote their brand. The result: a capital investment in a startup this quarter shows up as Yahoo earnings next quarterâstimulating another round of investments in startups.
How much was Yahoo worth after six years of development, despite market fluctuations?

Notice, though, that even with all the fat trimmed off its market cap, Yahoo was still worth a lot. Even at the morning-after valuations of March and April 2001, the people at Yahoo had managed to create a company worth about $8 billion in just six years.
What role does a core element of truth play in the formation of economic bubbles?

The fact is, despite all the nonsense we heard during the bubble about the "new economy," there was a core of truth. You need that to get a really big bubble: you need to have something solid at the center so that even smart people are sucked in. (Isaac Newton and Jonathan Swift both lost money in the South Sea Bubble of 1720.)
What is the danger of dismissing all trends from the tech Bubble according to the author?

Now the pendulum has swung the other way. Now anything that became fashionable during the Bubble is ipso facto unfashionable. But that's a mistakeâan even bigger mistake than believing what everyone was saying in 1999. Over the long term, what the Bubble got right will be more important than what it got wrong.
How might the market's understanding of valuing emerging companies evolve over time?

It may take a while for the market to learn how to value such companies, just as it had to learn to value common stocks in the early 20th century. However, markets are good at solving that kind of problem. I wouldn't be surprised if the market ultimately did a better job than VCs do now.
What role did organized public finance play in the Mississippi and South Sea Bubbles?

The same thing happened during the Mississippi and South Sea Bubbles. What drove them was the invention of organized public finance (the South Sea Company, despite its name, was really a competitor of the Bank of England). That did turn out to be a big deal in the long run.
What common mistake do investors make when trying to capitalize on emerging trends?

Recognizing an important trend turns out to be easier than figuring out how to profit from it. The mistake investors always seem to make is to take the trend too literally. Since the Internet was the big new thing, investors supposed that the more "Internettish" the company, the better. Hence, such parodies as Pets.com.
What types of companies typically profit the most from major economic trends?

In fact, most of the money to be made from big trends is made indirectly. It was not the railroads themselves that made the most money during the railroad boom, but the companies on either side, like Carnegie's steelworks, which made the rails, and Standard Oil, which used railroads to get oil to the East Coast, where it could be shipped to Europe.
What impact do you anticipate the Internet will have on businesses in the future?

I think the Internet will have great effects, and what we've seen so far is nothing compared to what's coming. However, most of the winners will only indirectly be Internet companies; for every Google, there will be ten JetBlues.
What is the historical significance of new forms of communication in impacting society?

The Internet will have great effects because new forms of communication always do. They happen rarely (until industrial times, there were just speech, writing, and printing), but when they do, they always cause a big splash.
How has the Internet changed the way consumers access information and make choices compared to the traditional economy?

The specific argument, or one of them, is that the Internet gives us more choices. In the "old" economy, the high cost of presenting information to people meant they had only a narrow range of options to choose from. The tiny, expensive pipeline to consumers was tellingly named "the channel." Control the channel, and you could feed them what you wanted, on your terms. It was not just big corporations that depended on this principle; labor unions, the traditional news media, and the art and literary establishments did as well. Winning depended not on doing good work, but on gaining control of some bottleneck.
Why is it difficult for Google to maintain its dominance in the search engine market?

Admittedly, Google is an extreme case. It's very easy for people to switch to a new search engine. It costs little effort and no money to try a new one, and it's easy to see if the results are better. And so Google doesn't maintain its dominance as effectively as it might like.
How has the Internet changed the way new creators can establish their reputation and succeed in their fields?

The exciting thing about the Internet is that it's shifting everything in that direction. The hard part, if you want to win by making the best stuff, is the beginning. Eventually, everyone will learn by word of mouth that you're the best, but how do you survive to that point? It is in this crucial stage that the Internet has the most effect. First, the Internet lets anyone find you at almost zero cost. Second, it dramatically speeds up the rate at which reputation spreads by word of mouth. Together, these mean that in many fields the rule will be: Build it, and they will come. Make something great and put it online. That is a big change from the recipe for winning in the past century.
What qualities are most important for a CEO, particularly regarding age and experience?

A 26-year-old may not be very good at managing people or dealing with the SEC; those require experience. But those are also commodities, which can be handed off to some lieutenant. The most important quality in a CEO is his vision for the company's future. What will they build next? In that department, there are 26-year-olds who can compete with anyone.
How has the role of a company president evolved in relation to technology and technical expertise since 1970?

In 1970, a company president meant someone in his fifties, at least. If he had technologists working for him, they were treated like a racing stable: prized, but not powerful. But as technology has grown more important, the power of nerds has grown to reflect it. Now it's not enough for a CEO to have someone smart he can ask about technical matters. Increasingly, he has to be that person himself.
How has the role of founders in startups changed in relation to traditional CEO positions influenced by venture capitalists?

As always, business has clung to old forms. VCs still seem to want to install a legitimate-looking talking head as the CEO. But increasingly, the founders of the company are the real powers, and the grey-headed man installed by the VCs is more like a music group's manager than a general.
What fashion changes occurred among powerful individuals in New York during the late 1990s?

In New York, the Bubble had dramatic consequences: suits went out of fashion. They made one seem old. So in 1998, powerful New York types were suddenly wearing open-necked shirts, khakis, and oval wire-rimmed glasses, just like guys in Santa Clara.
What is the criticism of formality in professional settings according to the paragraph?

The problem with formality is that dressing up is not so much bad in itself. The issue lies in the receptor it binds to: dressing up is inevitably a substitute for good ideas. It is no coincidence that technically inept business types are known as "suits."
What distinguishes nerds in their approach to technology and problem-solving?

A nerd, in other words, is someone who concentrates on substance. So what's the connection between nerds and technology? Roughly that you can't fool mother nature. In technical matters, you have to get the right answers. If your software miscalculates the path of a space probe, you can't finesse your way out of trouble by saying that your code is patriotic, avant-garde, or any of the other dodges people use in nontechnical fields.
How has the perception of "nerds" changed from the 1980s to today?

Nerds are already a lot cooler than they were when I was a kid. When I was in college in the mid-1980s, "nerd" was still an insult. People who majored in computer science generally tried to conceal it. Now, women ask me where they can meet nerds. (The answer that springs to mind is "Usenix," but that would be like drinking from a firehose.)
What impact could changes in stock option regulations have on technical innovation?

What makes the nerds rich, usually, is stock options. Now there are moves afoot to make it harder for companies to grant options. To the extent there's some genuine accounting abuse going on, by all means, correct it. But don't kill the golden goose. Equity is the fuel that drives technical innovation.
What are the benefits of providing options to employees in a company?

Options are a good idea because (a) they're fair, and (b) they work. Someone who goes to work for a company is, one hopes, adding to its value, and it's only fair to give them a share of it. And as a purely practical measure, people work harder when they feel they have a stake in the company's success.
What does the misuse of stock options by a few individuals during economic booms suggest about the overall validity of stock options as a financial instrument?

The fact that a few crooks during the bubble robbed their companies by granting themselves options doesn't mean options are a bad idea. During the railroad boom, some executives enriched themselves by selling watered stockâby issuing more shares than they said were outstanding. But that doesn't make common stock a bad idea. Crooks just use whatever means are available.
What are the potential pitfalls of using stock options as a form of employee compensation?

If there is a problem with options, it's that they reward slightly the wrong thing. Not surprisingly, people do what you pay them to. If you pay them by the hour, they'll work a lot of hours. If you pay them by the volume of work done, they'll get a lot of work done (but only as you defined work). And if you pay them to raise the stock price, which is what options amount to, they'll raise the stock price.
What mindset shift did the author experience while working at Yahoo regarding their focus on ideas versus investor perception?
I found that when I was at Yahoo, I couldn't help thinking, "How will this sound to investors?" when I should have been thinking, "Is this a good idea?"
How has the definition and purpose of startups changed over time?

One thing most people learned about for the first time during the Bubble was the startup created with the intention of selling it. Originally, a startup meant a small company that hoped to grow into a big one. But increasingly, startups are evolving into a vehicle for developing technology on spec.
What is the relationship between employee compensation and productivity in startups?

Employees seem to be most productive when they're paid in proportion to the wealth they generate. And the advantage of a startupâindeed, almost its raison d'Ãªtreâis that it offers something otherwise impossible to obtain: a way of aligning compensation with individual contributions to the company's success.
Why do large companies often prefer acquiring startups for technology rather than developing it internally?

In many businesses, it just makes more sense for companies to get technology by buying startups rather than developing it in-house. You pay more, but there is less risk, and risk is what big companies don't want. It makes the people developing the technology more accountable because they only get paid if they build the winner. And you end up with better technology, created faster, because things are made in the innovative atmosphere of startups instead of the bureaucratic atmosphere of big companies.
What strategy did Viaweb employ to align with its goal of being sold to a larger company?

Our startup, Viaweb, was built to be sold. We were open with investors about that from the start. We were careful to create something that could slot easily into a larger company. That is the pattern for the future.
What was the author's impression of Silicon Valley during the tech boom of the late 1990s?

The Bubble was a California phenomenon. When I showed up in Silicon Valley in 1998, I felt like an immigrant from Eastern Europe arriving in America in 1900. Everyone was so cheerful, healthy, and rich. It seemed a new and improved world.
Is Silicon Valley truly experiencing a decline, or does it still retain its vibrant energy and potential?

The press, ever eager to exaggerate small trends, now gives one the impression that Silicon Valley is a ghost town. Not at all. When I drive down 101 from the airport, I still feel a buzz of energy, as if there were a giant transformer nearby. Real estate is still more expensive than just about anywhere else in the country. The people still look healthy, and the weather is still fabulous. The future is there. (I say "there" because I moved back to the East Coast after Yahoo. I still wonder if this was a smart idea.)
What city is predicted to be the source of new wealth over the next fifty years?
Silicon Valley may not be the next Paris or London, but it is at least the next Chicago. For the next fifty years, that's where new wealth will come from.
What was the rationale behind high price to earnings ratios during the Bubble, and what trend is anticipated for the future?

During the Bubble, optimistic analysts justified high price-to-earnings ratios by claiming that technology would dramatically increase productivity. They were wrong about the specific companies, but not so wrong about the underlying principle. I think one of the big trends we'll see in the coming century is a huge increase in productivity.
How does technology impact productivity levels?

Technology impacts productivity levels significantly. It acts as a lever; it doesn't just add to productivity, it multiplies it. If the current range of productivity is 0 to 100, introducing a multiple of 10 increases the range from 0 to 1000.
What are the potential advantages of running a small company with a focus on outsourcing?

One upshot of this is that the companies of the future may be surprisingly small. I sometimes daydream about how big you could grow a company (in revenues) without ever having more than ten people. What would happen if you outsourced everything except product development? If you tried this experiment, I think you'd be surprised at how far you could get. As Fred Brooks pointed out, small groups are intrinsically more productive because the internal friction in a group grows as the square of its size.
What impact does increasing company size have on productivity, according to recent management perspectives?

Until quite recently, running a major company meant managing an army of workers. Our standards about how many employees a company should have are still influenced by old patterns. Startups are perforce small because they can't afford to hire a lot of people. But I think it's a big mistake for companies to loosen their belts as revenues increase.
