The question is not whether you can afford the extra salaries; can you afford the loss in productivity that comes from making the company bigger?
How do historical job-killing innovations correlate with current employment levels?

The prospect of technological leverage will, of course, raise the specter of unemployment. I'm surprised people still worry about this. After centuries of supposedly job-killing innovations, the number of jobs is within ten percent of the number of people who want them. This can't be a coincidence. There must be some kind of balancing mechanism.
What factors are anticipated to influence success in the coming century?

When one looks over these trends, is there any overall theme? There does seem to be: that in the coming century, good ideas will count for more. That 26-year-olds with good ideas will increasingly have an edge over 50-year-olds with powerful connections. That doing good work will matter more than dressing upâor advertising, which is the same thing for companies. That people will be rewarded a bit more in proportion to the value of what they create.
What impact would an increased rate of acceptance for good ideas have on the economy?

If so, this is good news indeed. Good ideas always tend to win eventually. The problem is that it can take a very long time. It took decades for relativity to be accepted and the greater part of a century to establish that central planning didn't work. So even a small increase in the rate at which good ideas win would be a momentous changeâbig enough, probably, to justify a name like the "new economy."
How can we determine if a stock was overvalued?

To determine if a stock was overvalued, we must consider that the value of a stock is based on its future earnings. However, you can't tell if it was overvalued until you see what the earnings turn out to be. While certain famous Internet stocks were almost certainly overvalued in 1999, it is still hard to say for sure whether, for example, the Nasdaq index was.
What was the revenue estimate for Google based on their IPO filing?
The revenue estimate for Google, based on their IPO filing, is $1.35 billion for the first half of 2004, as reported in their filing.
What is the typical structure of an essay as learned in high school?

The typical structure of an essay, as learned in high school, includes a topic sentence, an introductory paragraph, supporting paragraphs, and a conclusion. The conclusion summarizes the main points, such as the character of Ahab in "Moby Dick."
What is a key distinction between real essays and typical school assignments?

The most obvious difference between real essays and the things one has to write in school is that real essays are not exclusively about English literature. Certainly, schools should teach students how to write. But due to a series of historical accidents, the teaching of writing has gotten mixed together with the study of literature. And so, all over the country, students are writing not about how a baseball team with a small budget might compete with the Yankees, or the role of color in fashion, or what constitutes a good dessert, but about symbolism in Dickens.
What was the impact of rediscovering classical knowledge on European scholarship around the year 1100?

Around 1100, Europe at last began to catch its breath after centuries of chaos, and once they had the luxury of curiosity, they rediscovered what we call "the classics." The effect was rather as if we were visited by beings from another solar system. These earlier civilizations were so much more sophisticated that for the next several centuries, the main work of European scholars, in almost every field, was to assimilate what they knew.
Why is the study of modern texts often viewed differently from the study of ancient texts in scholarship?

The time was then ripe for the question: if the study of ancient texts is a valid field for scholarship, why not modern texts? The answer, of course, is that the original raison d'Ãªtre of classical scholarship was a kind of intellectual archaeology that does not need to be done in the case of contemporary authors. But for obvious reasons, no one wanted to give that answer. The archaeological work being mostly done, it implied that those studying the classics were, if not wasting their time, at least working on problems of minor importance.
What were some of the early institutions that introduced courses in modern English literature?

The study of modern literature began with some resistance at first. The first courses in English literature seem to have been offered by the newer colleges, particularly American ones. Dartmouth, the University of Vermont, Amherst, and University College, London taught English literature in the 1820s.
When were the first professors of English literature appointed at Harvard and Oxford?
Harvard didn't have a professor of English literature until 1876, and Oxford not until 1885. (Oxford had a chair of Chinese before it had one of English.)
What influence did the German educational model have on the development of modern universities in the US?

What tipped the scales, at least in the US, seems to have been the idea that professors should do research as well as teach. This idea (along with the PhD, the department, and indeed the whole concept of the modern university) was imported from Germany in the late 19th century. Beginning at Johns Hopkins in 1876, the new model spread rapidly.
What are the limitations of having English professors teach writing in the late 19th century?

In the late 19th century, the teaching of writing was inherited by English professors. This had two drawbacks: (a) an expert on literature need not himself be a good writer, any more than an art historian has to be a good painter, and (b) the subject of writing now tended to be literature, since that's what the professor was interested in.
How did the curriculum changes in the 19th century influence the writing practices of high school students?

High schools imitate universities. The seeds of our miserable high school experiences were sown in 1892, when the National Education Association formally recommended that literature and composition be unified in the high school course. The writing component of the 3 Rs then morphed into English, with the bizarre consequence that high school students now had to write about English literatureâto write, without even realizing it, imitations of whatever English professors had been publishing in their journals a few decades before.
Why might students perceive the study of classical scholarship as a disconnected and unimportant exercise?

It's no wonder if this seems to the student a pointless exercise because we're now three steps removed from real work: the students are imitating English professors, who are imitating classical scholars, who are merely the inheritors of a tradition growing out of what was, 700 years ago, fascinating and urgently needed work.
What was the primary focus of medieval universities, and how did their approach to education influence the development of argumentative skills?

It is often mistakenly believed that medieval universities were mostly seminaries. In fact, they were more like law schools. In our tradition, lawyers are advocates, trained to take either side of an argument and make as good a case for it as they can. Whether cause or effect, this spirit pervaded early universities. The study of rhetoric, the art of arguing persuasively, constituted a third of the undergraduate curriculum. After the lecture, the most common form of discussion was the disputation. This is at least nominally preserved in our present-day thesis defense: most people treat the words thesis and dissertation as interchangeable, but originally, at least, a thesis was a position one took and the dissertation was the argument by which one defended it.
What are the limitations of defending a position in a legal dispute when seeking the truth?

Defending a position may be a necessary evil in a legal dispute, but it's not the best way to get at the truth, as I think lawyers would be the first to admit. It's not just that you miss subtleties this way. The real problem is that you can't change the question.
What is the purpose of a conclusion in a high school essay?

The purpose of a conclusion in a high school essay is often misunderstood. This principle is built into the very structure of the things they teach you to write in high school. The topic sentence is your thesis, chosen in advance; the supporting paragraphs are the blows you strike in the conflict, and the conclusionâuh, what is the conclusion? I was never sure about that in high school. It seemed as if we were just supposed to restate what we said in the first paragraph, but in different enough words that no one could tell. Why bother? But when you understand the origins of this sort of "essay," you can see where the conclusion comes from. It's the concluding remarks to the jury.
What should be prioritized in writing to ensure it is effective and convincing?

Good writing should be convincing, certainly, but it should be convincing because you got the right answers, not because you did a good job of arguing. When I give a draft of an essay to friends, there are two things I want to know: which parts bore them and which seem unconvincing. The boring bits can usually be fixed by cutting. But I don't try to fix the unconvincing bits by arguing more cleverly. I need to talk the matter over.
What is the relationship between clarity in communication and the pursuit of truth in writing?

At the very least, I must have explained something badly. In that case, in the course of the conversation, I'll be forced to come up with a clearer explanation, which I can just incorporate into the essay. More often than not, I have to change what I was saying as well. But the aim is never to be convincing per se. As the reader gets smarter, convincing and true become identical, so if I can convince smart readers, I must be near the truth.
What is the initial approach one should take when starting to write an essay?

Figure out what? You don't know yet. And so you can't begin with a thesis because you don't have one and may never have one. An essay doesn't begin with a statement but with a question. In a real essay, you don't take a position and defend it. You notice a door that's ajar, and you open it and walk in to see what's inside.
What role does writing play in the development of ideas according to Montaigne?

If all you want to do is figure things out, why do you need to write anything, though? Why not just sit and think? Well, there precisely is Montaigne's great discovery. Expressing ideas helps to form them. Indeed, "helps" is far too weak a word. Most of what ends up in my essays I only thought of when I sat down to write them. That's why I write them.
What is the difference between writing for school and writing a personal essay?
In the things you write in school, you are, in theory, merely explaining yourself to the reader. In a personal essay, you're writing for yourself. You're thinking out loud.
How does having an audience impact the quality of writing?

Having an audience impacts the quality of writing significantly. Just as inviting people over forces you to clean up your apartment, writing something that other people will read compels you to think more critically. It does matter to have an audience. The things I've written just for myself are no good; they tend to peter out. When I run into difficulties, I find I conclude with a few vague questions and then drift off to get a cup of tea.
Why do staff writers for newsmagazines often avoid taking a definitive stance on controversial issues?

Many published essays peter out in the same way, particularly those written by the staff writers of newsmagazines. Outside writers tend to supply editorials of the defend-a-position variety, which make a beeline toward a rousing (and foreordained) conclusion. But the staff writers feel obliged to write something "balanced." Since they're writing for a popular magazine, they start with the most radioactively controversial questions, from whichâbecause they're writing for a popular magazineâthey then proceed to recoil in terror. Abortion, for or against? This group says one thing. That group says another. One thing is certain: the question is a complex one. (But don't get mad at us. We didn't draw any conclusions.)
What is the primary purpose of writing and publishing an essay?

An essay has to come up with answers. They don't always, of course. Sometimes you start with a promising question and get nowhere, but those you don't publish. Those are like experiments that get inconclusive results. An essay you publish ought to tell the reader something he didn't already know.
What is the significance of the Meander River's winding path?

The Meander (aka Menderes) is a river in Turkey. As you might expect, it winds all over the place. But it doesn't do this out of frivolity. The path it has discovered is the most economical route to the sea.
What guiding principle does the essayist follow when deciding the direction of their writing?

The river's algorithm is simple. At each step, flow down. For the essayist, this translates to: flow interesting. Of all the places to go next, choose the most interesting. One can't have quite as little foresight as a river. I always know generally what I want to write about, but not the specific conclusions I want to reach; from paragraph to paragraph, I let the ideas take their course.
What strategy does the author use when they encounter a creative block in their writing?

This doesn't always work. Sometimes, like a river, one runs up against a wall. Then I do the same thing the river does: backtrack. At one point in this essay, I found that after following a certain thread, I ran out of ideas. I had to go back seven paragraphs and start over in another direction.
What is the relationship between an essay and the process of refining thoughts in writing?

Fundamentally, an essay is a train of thoughtâbut a cleaned-up train of thought, as dialogue is cleaned-up conversation. Real thought, like real conversation, is full of false starts. It would be exhausting to read. You need to cut and fill to emphasize the central thread, like an illustrator inking over a pencil drawing. But don't change so much that you lose the spontaneity of the original.
What is the role of surprise in the design of interfaces and essays?

So what's interesting? For me, interesting means surprise. Interfaces, as Geoffrey James has said, should follow the principle of least astonishment. A button that looks like it will make a machine stop should make it stop, not speed up. Essays should do the opposite; they should aim for maximum surprise.
What is an effective way to learn about travel experiences from others?

I was afraid of flying for a long time and could only travel vicariously. When friends came back from faraway places, it wasn't just out of politeness that I asked what they saw. I really wanted to know. I found the best way to get information out of them was to ask what surprised them. How was the place different from what they expected? This is an extremely useful question. You can ask it of the most unobservant people, and it will extract information they didn't even know they were recording.
What makes surprises particularly valuable in terms of knowledge and understanding?

Surprises are things that you not only didn't know, but that contradict things you thought you knew. Therefore, they're the most valuable sort of fact you can get. They're like a food that's not merely healthy but counteracts the unhealthy effects of things you've already eaten.
What is the key to finding engaging topics in essay writing?

How do you find surprises? Well, therein lies half the work of essay writing. (The other half is expressing yourself well.) The trick is to use yourself as a proxy for the reader. You should only write about things you've thought about a lot. And anything you come across that surprises you, who have thought about the topic a lot, will probably surprise most readers.
What can make even mundane jobs, like working in fast food, seem interesting?

What should you think about? My guess is that it doesn't matterâthat anything can be interesting if you get deeply enough into it. One possible exception might be things that have deliberately had all the variation sucked out of them, like working in fast food. In retrospect, was there anything interesting about working at Baskin-Robbins? Well, it was interesting how important color was to the customers. Kids a certain age would point into the case and say that they wanted yellow. Did they want French Vanilla or Lemon? They would just look at you blankly. They wanted yellow. And then there was the mystery of why the perennial favorite Pralines 'n' Cream was so appealing. (I think now it was the salt.)
How do fathers and mothers differ in their approach to buying ice cream for their children?

The difference in the way fathers and mothers buy ice cream for their kids is notable: fathers act like benevolent kings bestowing largesse, while mothers appear harried, often giving in to pressure. So, yes, there does seem to be some material even in fast food.
How does the narrator's perception of their past experiences change with time?

I didn't notice those things at the time, though. At sixteen, I was about as observant as a lump of rock. I can see more now in the fragments of memory I preserve from that age than I could see at the time, with it all happening live right in front of me.
What is the significance of questioning the relationship between humor and misfortune?

I find it especially useful to ask why about things that seem wrong. For example, why should there be a connection between humor and misfortune? Why do we find it funny when a character, even one we like, slips on a banana peel? There's a whole essay's worth of surprises there, for sure.
How can skepticism contribute to recognizing flaws in established systems, such as education?

If you want to notice things that seem wrong, you'll find a degree of skepticism helpful. I take it as an axiom that we're only achieving 1% of what we could. This helps counteract the rule that gets beaten into our heads as children: that things are the way they are because that is how things have to be. For example, everyone I've talked to while writing this essay felt the same about English classesâthat the whole process seemed pointless. But none of us had the courage at the time to hypothesize that it was, in fact, all a mistake. We all thought there was just something we weren't getting.
Why is humor important in presenting good ideas?

Humor is important in presenting good ideas because it captures attention and engages the audience. I have a hunch you want to pay attention not just to things that seem wrong, but to things that seem wrong in a humorous way. I'm always pleased when I see someone laugh as they read a draft of an essay. But why should I be? I'm aiming for good ideas. Why should good ideas be funny? The connection may be surprise. Surprises make us laugh, and surprises are what one wants to deliver.
What is the primary benefit of keeping a notebook, according to the author?

I write down things that surprise me in notebooks. I never actually get around to reading them and using what I've written, but I do tend to reproduce the same thoughts later. So the main value of notebooks may be what writing things down leaves in your head.
What are some effective strategies for discovering unexpected connections between different fields?

One of the keys to finding unexpected connections is to study lots of different things. Some of the most interesting surprises arise from the intersections between various fields. For example, jam, bacon, pickles, and cheese, which are among the most pleasing of foods, were all originally intended as methods of preservation. So were books and paintings.
How can gradual changes in habits or appearance lead to unexpected outcomes over time?

What began as combing his hair a little carefully over a thin patch has gradually, over 20 years, grown into a monstrosity. Gradualness is very powerful. And that power can be used for constructive purposes too: just as you can trick yourself into looking like a freak, you can trick yourself into creating something so grand that you would never have dared to.
What is the author's perspective on traditional essay writing and expectations?

"See what you can extract from a frivolous question? If there's one piece of advice I would give about writing essays, it would be: don't do as you're told. Don't believe what you're supposed to. Don't write the essay readers expect; one learns nothing from what one expects. And don't write the way they taught you to in school."
How has the traditional gatekeeping in essay writing impacted the diversity of perspectives presented in publications?

It used to be that only a tiny number of officially approved writers were allowed to write essays. Magazines published few of them and judged them less by what they said than by who wrote them; a magazine might publish a story by an unknown writer if it was good enough, but if they published an essay on a specific topic, it had to be by someone who was at least forty and whose job title included that topic. This is a problem because there are a lot of things insiders can't say precisely because they're insiders.
How has the Internet transformed the way we evaluate written content?

The Internet is changing that. Anyone can publish an essay on the Web, and it gets judged, as any writing should, by what it says, not who wrote it. Who are you to write about X? You are whatever you wrote.
What historical event may have contributed to a decline in scientific scholarship in Europe during the 14th century?

A historical event that may have contributed to a decline in scientific scholarship in Europe during the 14th century is the plague of 1347. There was a sudden drop-off in scholarship just as Europeans finished assimilating classical science. The trend in scientific progress matches the population curve.
What factors contributed to philology's dominance over literature in early academic circles?
At first, literature took a back seat to philology, which (a) seemed more serious and (b) was popular in Germany, where many of the leading scholars of that generation had been trained.
Who was the first professor of English at Harvard University?
Francis James Child, who had been Boylston Professor of Rhetoric at Harvard since 1851, became in 1876 the university's first professor of English.
Why was the study of rhetoric considered essential in the classical education of landowners' sons?

The study of rhetoric was inherited directly from Rome, where it was considered the most important subject. It would not be far from the truth to say that education in the classical world meant training landowners' sons to speak well enough to defend their interests in political and legal disputes.
What was the controversial statement made about the availability of programmers for Python versus Java projects?
"I made a statement that upset a lot of people: that you could get smarter programmers to work on a Python project than you could to work on a Java project."
What is the Python paradox in relation to hiring programmers?

The Python paradox, for lack of a better name, suggests that if a company chooses to write its software in a comparatively esoteric language, they'll be able to hire better programmers because they'll attract only those who cared enough to learn it. For programmers, the paradox is even more pronounced: the language to learn, if you want to get a good job, is a language that people don't learn merely to get a job.
Why might a programmer prioritize the aesthetics of source code when choosing a programming language?

A friend of mine who knows nearly all the widely used languages uses Python for most of his projects. He says the main reason is that he likes the way source code looks. That may seem a frivolous reason to choose one language over another, but it is not so frivolous as it sounds: when you program, you spend more time reading code than writing it. You push blobs of source code around the way a sculptor does blobs of clay. So a language that makes source code ugly is maddening to an exacting programmer, as clay full of lumps would be to a sculptor.
What qualities do programming languages that are created and used by passionate programmers tend to have?

Programming languages created and used by passionate programmers tend to share certain qualities. They are often designed with care and attention to detail, similar to languages like Ruby, Icon, Joy, J, Lisp, and Smalltalk. These languages are typically developed by individuals who truly care about programming, which often results in better functionality and user experience.
What evidence illustrates the significant disparity in talent between top performers and their average counterparts in various fields?

When people care enough about something to do it well, those who do it best tend to be far better than everyone else. There's a huge gap between Leonardo and second-rate contemporaries like Borgognone. You see the same gap between Raymond Chandler and the average writer of detective novels. A top-ranked professional chess player could play ten thousand games against an ordinary club player without losing once.
Why do we view income inequality differently than success in other specialized skills like chess or writing?

Like chess, painting, or writing novels, making money is a very specialized skill. But for some reason, we treat this skill differently. No one complains when a few people surpass all the rest at playing chess or writing novels, but when a few people make more money than the rest, we get editorials saying this is wrong.
What are the reasons the author believes making money is treated differently, and how do they challenge common perceptions about income variation?

I think there are three reasons we treat making money as different: the misleading model of wealth we learn as children, the disreputable way in which, until recently, most fortunes were accumulated, and the worry that great variations in income are somehow bad for society. As far as I can tell, the first is mistaken, the second outdated, and the third empirically false. Could it be that, in a modern democracy, variation in income is actually a sign of health?
What common misconception do children have about the origins of electricity and wealth?

When I was five, I thought electricity was created by electric sockets. I didn't realize there were power plants out there generating it. Likewise, it doesn't occur to most kids that wealth is something that has to be generated; it seems to be something that flows from parents.
How do children typically misunderstand the concept of wealth?

Because of the circumstances in which they encounter it, children tend to misunderstand wealth. They confuse it with money. They think that there is a fixed amount of it. And they think of it as something that's distributed by authorities (and so should be distributed equally), rather than something that has to be created (and might be created unequally).
What distinguishes wealth from money in the context of assessing a country's prosperity?

Wealth is not money. Money is just a convenient way of trading one form of wealth for another. Wealth is the underlying stuffâthe goods and services we buy. When you travel to a rich or poor country, you don't have to look at people's bank accounts to tell which kind you're in. You can observe the quality of life, the availability of goods and services, and the overall living conditions.
What is the relationship between individual effort and the creation of wealth?

Where does wealth come from? People make it. This was easier to grasp when most people lived on farms and made many of the things they wanted with their own hands. Then you could see in the house, the herds, and the granary the wealth that each family created. It was obvious then, too, that the wealth of the world was not a fixed quantity that had to be shared out, like slices of a pie. If you wanted more wealth, you could make it.
How do individuals typically contribute to wealth creation in modern economies?

This is just as true today, though few of us create wealth directly for ourselves (except for a few vestigial domestic tasks). Mostly, we create wealth for other people in exchange for money, which we then trade for the forms of wealth we want.
Why might there be an argument for the equal distribution of wealth among children?
Because kids are unable to create wealth, whatever they have has to be given to them. And when wealth is something you're given, then of course it seems that it should be distributed equally.
What does the paragraph suggest about the nature of wealth and personal responsibility in adulthood?

In the real world, you can't keep living off your parents. If you want something, you either have to make it or do something of equivalent value for someone else in order to get them to give you enough money to buy it. In the real world, wealth is (except for a few specialists like thieves and speculators) something you have to create, not something that's distributed by Daddy. And since the ability and desire to create it vary from person to person, it's not made equally.
What factors contribute to the income disparity between top actors and B-list actors?

Top actors make significantly more money than B-list actors because they are often better at delivering what audiences want. While B-list actors may possess similar charisma, when people go to the theater and look at the list of movies playing, they tend to seek that extra oomph that big stars provide.
What analogy is drawn between discussions of salaries and historical debates about the shape of the Earth?
Editorials about athletes' or CEOs' salaries remind me of early Christian writers arguing from first principles about whether the Earth was round, when they could just walk outside and check.
How does the concentration of skill and determination in a single individual impact their success compared to a larger group?

These things don't scale linearly. Perhaps the CEO or the professional athlete has only ten times (whatever that means) the skill and determination of an ordinary person. But it makes all the difference that it's concentrated in one individual.
What does it mean to label certain jobs as overpaid or underpaid in a free market economy?

When we say that one kind of work is overpaid and another underpaid, what are we really saying? In a free market, prices are determined by what buyers want. People like baseball more than poetry, so baseball players make more than poets. To say that a certain kind of work is underpaid is thus identical to saying that people want the wrong things.
Is it fair to label people's preferences for entertainment and food as unjust?

Then you're saying that it's unjust that people want the wrong things. It's lamentable that people prefer reality TV and corndogs to Shakespeare and steamed vegetables, but unjust? That seems like saying that blue is heavy, or that up is circular.
What does the use of the term "unjust" reveal about the speaker's perspective on wealth distribution?

The appearance of the word "unjust" here is the unmistakable spectral signature of the Daddy Model. Why else would this idea occur in this odd context? Whereas if the speaker were still operating on the Daddy Model and saw wealth as something that flowed from a common source and had to be shared out, rather than something generated by doing what other people wanted, this is exactly what you'd get on noticing that some people made much more than others.
Why do we view significant wealth disparities as concerning throughout human history?

The second reason we tend to find great disparities of wealth alarming is that, for most of human history, the usual way to accumulate a fortune was to steal it: in pastoral societies, by cattle raiding; in agricultural societies, by appropriating others' estates in times of war and taxing them in times of peace.
How did the distribution of confiscated estates in England evolve from the 1060s to the 1530s?

In conflicts, those on the winning side would receive the estates confiscated from the losers. In England in the 1060s, when William the Conqueror distributed the estates of the defeated Anglo-Saxon nobles to his followers, the conflict was military. By the 1530s, when Henry VIII distributed the estates of the monasteries to his followers, it was mostly political.
How did rulers in organized societies like China generate wealth through their governance?

In more organized societies, like China, the ruler and his officials used taxation instead of confiscation. But here too, we see the same principle: the way to get rich was not to create wealth, but to serve a ruler powerful enough to appropriate it.
What factors contributed to the emergence of the middle class in Europe during the feudal period?

The emergence of the middle class in Europe during the feudal period was a significant change. Now we think of the middle class as people who are neither rich nor poor, but originally they were a distinct group. In a feudal society, there were just two classes: a warrior aristocracy and the serfs who worked their estates. The middle class was a new, third group who lived in towns and supported themselves by manufacturing and trade.
What social changes occurred in towns during the tenth and eleventh centuries that allowed them to gain power over local feudal lords?
Starting in the tenth and eleventh centuries, petty nobles and former serfs banded together in towns that gradually became powerful enough to ignore the local feudal lords.
What were the key differences in economic incentives between the middle class and serfs in medieval society?

Like serfs, the middle class made a living largely by creating wealth. (In port cities like Genoa and Pisa, they also engaged in piracy.) But unlike serfs, they had an incentive to create a lot of it. Any wealth a serf created belonged to his master. There was not much point in making more than you could hide. Whereas the independence of the townsmen allowed them to keep whatever wealth they created.
How did the Industrial Revolution influence perceptions of wealth creation and corruption in England?

It was not until the Industrial Revolution that wealth creation definitively replaced corruption as the best way to get rich. In England, at least, corruption only became unfashionable (and in fact only started to be called "corruption") when there began to be other, faster ways to get rich.
How did the emergence of the middle class change the dynamics of wealth creation in the economy?

With the rise of the middle class, wealth stopped being a zero-sum game. Jobs and Wozniak didn't have to make us poor to make themselves rich. Quite the opposite: they created things that made our lives materially richer. They had to, or we wouldn't have paid for them.
Why do many people harbor suspicions towards wealthy individuals?

Many people harbor suspicions towards wealthy individuals because, for most of the world's history, the main route to wealth was through theft. This historical context leads us to be wary of rich people. Idealistic undergraduates often find their unconsciously preserved childhood model of wealth confirmed by eminent writers of the past. It is a case of the mistaken meeting the outdated.
What did Balzac imply about the origins of great fortunes in the context of his time?

"Behind every great fortune, there is a crime," Balzac wrote. Except he didn't. What he actually said was that a great fortune with no apparent cause was probably due to a crime well enough executed that it had been forgotten. If we were talking about Europe in 1000, or most of the third world today, the standard misquotation would be spot on. But Balzac lived in nineteenth-century France, where the Industrial Revolution was well advanced. He knew you could make a fortune without stealing it. After all, he did himself, as a popular novelist.
How has the nature of work opportunities for high school students changed over time?

Iâve seen the level of technology grow visibly in my own time. In high school, I made money by mowing lawns and scooping ice cream at Baskin-Robbins. This was the only kind of work available at the time. Now high school kids can write software or design websites. But only some of them will; the rest will still be scooping ice cream.
How did advancements in technology in the 1980s impact personal computing and freelance work?

I remember very vividly when, in 1985, improved technology made it possible for me to buy a computer of my own. Within months, I was using it to make money as a freelance programmer. A few years before, I couldn't have done this. A few years before, there was no such opportunity.
Why might companies prefer to produce mass-market cars over custom-made ones?

Cars are a good example of why companies might prefer to produce mass-market vehicles over custom-made ones. It's possible to buy expensive, handmade cars that cost hundreds of thousands of dollars, but there is not much point. Companies make more money by building a large number of ordinary cars than a small number of expensive ones. Therefore, a company making a mass-produced car can afford to spend a lot more on its design. If you buy a custom-made car, something will always be breaking. The only point of buying one now is to advertise that you can.
How has the advancement in watch technology affected the relationship between price and performance?

Consider watches. Fifty years ago, by spending a lot of money on a watch, you could get better performance. When watches had mechanical movements, expensive watches kept better time. Not anymore. Since the invention of the quartz movement, an ordinary Timex is more accurate than a Patek Philippe costing hundreds of thousands of dollars.
What are some drawbacks of owning a mechanical watch compared to a quartz watch?

Indeed, as with expensive cars, if you're determined to spend a lot of money on a watch, you have to put up with some inconvenience to do it. As well as keeping worse time, mechanical watches have to be wound.
How has the perception of brand value changed in relation to wealth and technology over time?

The only thing technology can't cheapen is brand, which is precisely why we hear ever more about it. Brand is the residue left as the substantive differences between rich and poor evaporate. However, what label you have on your stuff is a much smaller matter than having it versus not having it. In 1900, if you kept a carriage, no one asked what year or brand it was. If you had one, you were rich. And if you weren't rich, you took the omnibus or walked. Now, even the poorest Americans drive cars, and it is only because we're so well trained by advertising that we can even recognize the especially expensive ones.
How does demand influence the development and pricing of technology in various industries?

The same pattern has played out in industry after industry. If there is enough demand for something, technology will make it cheap enough to sell in large volumes, and the mass-produced versions will be, if not better, at least more convenient.
Why do wealthy individuals often choose to work despite having the financial means to avoid it?

The rich spend their time more like everyone else, too. Bertie Wooster seems long gone. Now, most people who are rich enough not to work do anyway. It's not just social pressure that makes them; idleness is lonely and demoralizing.
How have social expectations regarding friendships changed for women after marriage from the 19th century to today?

In 1880, it may be found necessary, in some cases, for a mistress to relinquish, on assuming the responsibility of a household, many of those friendships commenced in the earlier part of her life. A woman who married a rich man was expected to drop friends who didn't share her social status. You would seem a barbarian if you behaved that way today, and you would also have a very boring life. People still tend to segregate themselves somewhat, but much more on the basis of education than wealth.
What does the author suggest about the relationship between income variation and technological innovation in modern society?

I would like to propose an alternative idea: that in modern society, increasing variation in income is a sign of health. Technology seems to increase the variation in productivity at faster than linear rates. If we don't see corresponding variation in income, there are three possible explanations: (a) that technical innovation has stopped, (b) that the people who would create the most wealth aren't doing it, or (c) that they aren't getting paid for it.
How has the ability to accumulate wealth varied throughout different historical periods and locations?

At various times and places in history, the ability to accumulate a fortune by creating wealth has been turned on and off. In Northern Italy in 800, it was off (warlords would steal it). In Northern Italy in 1100, it was on. In Central France in 1100, it was off (still feudal). In England in 1800, it was on. In England in 1974, it was off (98% tax on investment income). In the United States in 1974, it was on. We've even had a twin study: West Germany, on; East Germany, off. In every case, the creation of wealth seems to appear and disappear like the noise of a fan as you switch on and off the prospect of keeping it.
What are the economic consequences of suppressing income variations in society?

If you suppress variations in income, whether by stealing private fortunes, as feudal rulers used to do, or by taxing them away, as some modern governments have done, the result always seems to be the same: society as a whole ends up poorer.
What is the author's perspective on the importance of absolute poverty versus relative poverty in societal living conditions?

If I had a choice of living in a society where I was materially much better off than I am now, but was among the poorest, or in one where I was the richest, but much worse off than I am now, I'd take the first option. If I had children, it would arguably be immoral not to. It's absolute poverty you want to avoid, not relative poverty. If, as the evidence so far implies, you have to have one or the other in your society, take relative poverty.
Why is the discussion around wealth often contentious among certain groups?

Part of the reason this subject is so contentious is that some of those most vocal on the subject of wealthâuniversity students, heirs, professors, politicians, and journalistsâhave the least experience creating it. (This phenomenon will be familiar to anyone who has overheard conversations about sports in a bar.)
Why might individuals perceive the distribution of resources by a central authority as unfair compared to voluntary exchanges in the economy?

Individuals might perceive the distribution of resources by a central authority as unfair compared to voluntary exchanges in the economy because resources are doled out according to some abstract notion of fairness (or randomly, in the case of heirs), rather than being given by other people in return for something they wanted. As a result, it may seem to them unfair that things don't work the same way in the rest of the economy.
What was the median total compensation for S&P 500 CEOs in 2002?
According to a study by the Corporate Library, the median total compensation, including salary, bonus, stock grants, and the exercise of stock options, of S&P 500 CEOs in 2002 was $3.65 million.
How do the average salaries of NBA and MLB players in the early 2000s compare to the average annual wage in the US?

The average NBA player's salary during the 2002-03 season was $4.54 million, and the average Major League Baseball player's salary at the start of the 2003 season was $2.56 million. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the mean annual wage in the US in 2002 was $35,560.
What were the costs associated with different types of labor and services in ancient Rome?

A servant girl cost 600 sestertii (Martial vi.66), while Columella (iii.3.8) states that a skilled vine-dresser was worth 8,000 sestertii. A doctor, P. Decimus Eros Merula, paid 50,000 sestertii for his freedom (Dessau).
What was the highest price ever paid for a slave according to historical records, and who was the notable individual involved?

The highest price ever paid for a slave, according to historical records, was 700,000 sestertii for the linguist (and presumably teacher) Daphnis. This amount was noted in vii.39, but it is mentioned that this price had since been exceeded by actors buying their own freedom.
How does the Daddy Model's perception of hard work differ from the reality of measuring value in work?

One of the biggest divergences between the Daddy Model and reality is the valuation of hard work. In the Daddy Model, hard work is in itself deserving. In reality, wealth is measured by what one delivers, not how much effort it costs. If I paint someone's house, the owner shouldn't pay me extra for doing it with a toothbrush.
What actions and qualities contributed to Thomas Lord Roos's rise in favor during the reign of Henry VIII?

From the beginning of the reign, Thomas Lord Roos was an assiduous courtier of the young Henry VIII and was soon to reap the rewards. In 1525, he was made a Knight of the Garter and given the Earldom of Rutland. In the thirties, his support of the breach with Rome, his zeal in crushing the Pilgrimage of Grace, and his readiness to vote the death penalty in the succession of spectacular treason trials that punctuated Henry's erratic matrimonial progress made him an obvious candidate for grants of monastic property.
What is the timekeeping accuracy of a Timex compared to a high-end mechanical watch like the Patek Philippe 10 Day Tourbillon?
A Timex will gain or lose about 0.5 seconds per day. The most accurate mechanical watch, the Patek Philippe 10 Day Tourbillon, is rated at -1.5 to +2 seconds. Its retail price is about $220,000.
Which vehicle is more expensive, a 1989 Lincoln Town Car limousine or a 2004 Mercedes S600 sedan?

If asked to choose which was more expensive, a well-preserved 1989 Lincoln Town Car ten-passenger limousine ($5,000) or a 2004 Mercedes S600 sedan ($122,000), the average Edwardian might well guess wrong.
Why is it important to consider real income when discussing income trends?

To say anything meaningful about income trends, you have to talk about real income, or income as measured by what it can buy. However, the usual way of calculating real income ignores much of the growth in wealth over time because it depends on a consumer price index created by bolting end to end a series of numbers that are only locally accurate and that don't include the prices of new inventions until they become so common that their prices stabilize.
What trade goods from the present would be most valuable if transported back to specific years in the past?

Another approach would be to ask, if you were going back to the year X in a time machine, how much would you have to spend on trade goods to make your fortune? For example, if you were going back to 1970, it would certainly be less than $500, because the processing power you can get for $500 today would have been worth at least $150 million in 1970. The function goes asymptotic fairly quickly, because for times over a hundred years or so, you could get all you needed in present-day trash. In 1800, an empty plastic drink bottle with a screw top would have seemed a miracle of workmanship.
How can admissions processes improve their security measures?

Perhaps the designers of admissions processes should take a lesson from the example of computer security and, instead of just assuming that their system can't be hacked, measure the degree to which it is.
How do the meanings of "hacker" differ between the popular press and the programming community?

To the popular press, "hacker" means someone who breaks into computers. Among programmers, it means a good programmer. However, the two meanings are connected. To programmers, "hacker" connotes mastery in the most literal sense: someone who can make a computer do what they wantâwhether the computer wants to or not.
What are the different meanings of the term "hack" and how are they perceived?

To add to the confusion, the noun "hack" also has two senses. It can be either a compliment or an insult. It's called a hack when you do something in an ugly way. However, when you do something so clever that you somehow beat the system, that's also called a hack. The word is used more often in the former than the latter sense, probably because ugly solutions are more common than brilliant ones.
What is the relationship between ugly and imaginative solutions in the context of rule-breaking?

Believe it or not, the two senses of "hack" are also connected. Ugly and imaginative solutions have something in common: they both break the rules. There is a gradual continuum between rule-breaking that's merely ugly (using duct tape to attach something to your bike) and rule-breaking that is brilliantly imaginative (discarding Euclidean space).
What historical examples illustrate that hacking has existed long before the advent of modern computers?

Hacking predates computers. When he was working on the Manhattan Project, Richard Feynman used to amuse himself by breaking into safes containing secret documents. This tradition continues today. When we were in grad school, a hacker friend of mine who spent too much time around MIT had his own lock-picking kit. (He now runs a hedge fund, a not unrelated enterprise.)
What challenges do individuals face when explaining their motives for hacking to law enforcement?

It is sometimes hard to explain to authorities why one would want to do such things. Another friend of mine once got in trouble with the government for breaking into computers. This had only recently been declared a crime, and the FBI found that their usual investigative technique didn't work. Police investigation apparently begins with a motive. The usual motives are few: drugs, money, sex, revenge. Intellectual curiosity was not one of the motives on the FBI's list. Indeed, the whole concept seemed foreign to them.
How does the attitude of disobedience in hackers relate to their programming skills?

Those in authority tend to be annoyed by hackers' general attitude of disobedience. But that disobedience is a byproduct of the qualities that make them good programmers. They may laugh at the CEO when he talks in generic corporate newspeak, but they also laugh at someone who tells them a certain problem can't be solved. Suppress one, and you suppress the other.
How can imitating the attitudes of successful hackers hinder innovation among young programmers?

This attitude is sometimes affected. Young programmers may notice the eccentricities of eminent hackers and decide to adopt some of their own in order to seem smarter. The fake version is not merely annoying; the prickly attitude of these posers can actually slow the process of innovation.
Why do hackers view measures like copyrights and patents as a threat to their work?

To prevent copying, show any hacker a lock and his first thought is how to pick it. But there is a deeper reason that hackers are alarmed by measures like copyrights and patents. They see increasingly aggressive measures to protect "intellectual property" as a threat to the intellectual freedom they need to do their job. And they are right.
How do hackers contribute to the development of the next generation of computer technology?

It is by poking about inside current technology that hackers get ideas for the next generation. No thanks, intellectual homeowners may say, we don't need any outside help. But they're wrong. The next generation of computer technology has oftenâperhaps more often than notâbeen developed by outsiders.
What operating system was created as an alternative to Multics by two individuals who found it overly complex?

In Los Altos, at about the same time, the powers that be were cooperating to develop the official next generation operating system, Multics. But two guys who thought Multics excessively complex went off and wrote their own. They gave it a name that was a joking reference to Multics: Unix.
How do recent intellectual property laws impact innovation and the development of new technology?

The latest intellectual property laws impose unprecedented restrictions on the sort of poking around that leads to new ideas. In the past, a competitor might use patents to prevent you from selling a copy of something they made, but they couldn't prevent you from taking one apart to see how it worked. The latest laws make this a crime. How are we to develop new technology if we can't study current technology to figure out how to improve it?
What are the potential consequences of strict intellectual property laws in the digital age?

Data is, by definition, easy to copy, and the Internet makes copies easy to distribute. So it is no wonder companies are afraid. But, as so often happens, fear has clouded their judgment. The government has responded with draconian laws to protect intellectual property. They probably mean well, but they may not realize that such laws will do more harm than good.
What cultural traits contribute to the prominence of hacking and innovation in America compared to other countries?

What is a recurring theme in human history regarding people's beliefs?

It seems to be a constant throughout history: in every period, people believed things that were just ridiculous and believed them so strongly that you would have gotten in terrible trouble for saying otherwise.

The other alternative would be that you independently considered every question and came up with the exact same answers that are now considered acceptable. Back in the era of terms like "well-adjusted," the idea seemed to be that there was something wrong with you if you thought things you didn't dare say out loud. This seems backward. What types of statements tend to provoke strong reactions from people?

Of course, we're not just looking for things we can't say. We're looking for things we can't say that are true, or at least have enough chance of being true that the question should remain open. If Galileo had said that people in Padua were ten feet tall, he would have been regarded as a harmless eccentric. Saying the earth orbited the sun was another matter. The Church knew this would set people thinking.
How might perceptions of controversial statements change over time?

Certainly, as we look back on the past, this rule of thumb works well. A lot of the statements people got in trouble for seem harmless now. How can one identify unconventional truths in controversial opinions?
To find them, keep track of opinions that get people in trouble, and start asking, "Could this be true?" Ok, it may be heretical (or whatever the modern equivalent is), but might it also be true?
How have labels like "heresy" and "blasphemy" historically impacted the acceptance of new ideas?

Another approach is to follow that word, "heresy." How has the term "defeatist" been historically weaponized in political discourse?

What can the use of specific labels by politicians indicate about their arguments and the nature of their disagreements?

The use of specific labels by politicians can indicate the nature of their arguments and disagreements. What is the benefit of brainstorming ideas without filtering them?

Just start listing ideas at random? Yes, because they won't really be random. The ideas that come to mind first will be the most plausible ones. They'll be things you've already noticed but didn't let yourself think.
What does research on radiologists' eye movements suggest about the subconscious processing of information?

In 1989, some clever researchers tracked the eye movements of radiologists as they scanned chest images for signs of lung cancer. They found that even when the radiologists missed a cancerous lesion, their eyes had usually paused at the site of it. Part of their brain knew there was something there; it just didn't percolate all the way up into conscious knowledge. I think many interesting heretical thoughts are already mostly formed in our minds. If we turn off our self-censorship temporarily, those will be the first to emerge.
What can we learn about our current taboos by examining past societal norms?

If we could look into the future, it would be obvious which of our taboos they'd laugh at. We can't do that, but we can do something almost as good: we can look into the past. Another way to figure out what we're getting wrong is to look at what used to be acceptable and is now unthinkable.
How does the perception of our intelligence and morality compare to that of past generations according to historical perspectives?

What can we learn by comparing contemporary ideas to those of historical cultures?

Here is another source of interesting heresies: compare present ideas against those of various past cultures and see what you get. Some will be shocking by present standards, but which might also be true?
How do societal taboos influence the way we present ideas to children?

Kids' heads are repositories of all our taboos. It seems fitting to us that kids' ideas should be bright and clean. The picture we give them of the world is not merely simplified to suit their developing minds, but sanitized as well to suit our ideas of what kids ought to think.
Why do parents avoid using profanity around their children despite it being a common part of adult language?

Parents often avoid using profanity around their children, even though it is a common part of adult language. They believe it is not fitting for children to use the whole language, as we prefer to maintain a sense of innocence in children.
What insights can be gained by comparing the experiences of a worldly individual with those of a sheltered teenager?

How do we get at these ideas? By the following thought experiment. How can understanding the creation of taboos help us recognize contemporary moral fashions?

I can think of one more way to figure out what we can't say: to look at how taboos are created. How do moral fashions arise, and why are they adopted? If we can understand this mechanism, we may be able to see it at work in our own time.
How do moral fashions differ from ordinary fashions in their origins?

Moral fashions don't seem to be created the way ordinary fashions are. Ordinary fashions seem to arise by accident when everyone imitates the whim of some influential person. When there's something we can't say, it's often because some group doesn't want us to.
Why did Galileo face persecution for his scientific beliefs while Copernicus did not?

The irony of Galileo's situation was that he got in trouble for repeating Copernicus's ideas, while Copernicus himself did not face persecution. What role do competing ideas play in framing historical conflicts?

Most struggles, whatever they are really about, will be cast as struggles between competing ideas. What motivates early adopters and later followers in the adoption of moral fashions?

Although moral fashions tend to arise from different sources than fashions in clothing, the mechanism of their adoption seems much the same. What are conventional-minded people afraid of saying?

What motivates you to explore things that are considered forbidden?

Third, I do it because it's good for the brain. To do good work, you need a brain that can go anywhere. And you especially need a brain that's in the habit of going where it's not supposed to.

"Closed thoughts and an open face. Smile at everyone, and don't tell them what you're thinking. This was wise advice. How can metaphor be used effectively to critique organizations or actions without directly naming them?

How can humor serve as a tool to challenge serious societal issues or ideologies?

Best of all, probably, is humor. Zealots, whatever their cause, invariably lack a sense of humor. They can't reply in kind to jokes. What historical factors contributed to Holland's reputation as a tolerant society and a center of scholarship?

Holland is often cited as an example of a tolerant society due to its long tradition of comparative open-mindedness. What challenges arise from the relationship between software development and academic publishing in the tech field?
