In software, this kind of bug is the hardest to find and also tends to have the worst consequences. The traditional "break everything and then filter out the bugs" approach inherently yields a lot of compound bugs. Software that's released in a series of small changes inherently tends not to. The floors are constantly being swept clean of any loose objects that might later get stuck in something.
What are the benefits of using functional programming in web-based applications?

Functional programming offers several benefits for web-based applications. It involves avoiding side effects, which can lead to cleaner and more predictable code. While you may encounter functional programming more often in research papers than in commercial software, it proves to be quite useful in web development. Although it can be challenging to write entire programs in a purely functional style, you can implement substantial portions of your code this way. This approach makes those parts of your software easier to test, as they have no state, which is very convenient when you are constantly making and testing small modifications. I wrote much of Viaweb's editor in this style, and we made our scripting language.
How did advanced users at Viaweb perceive and respond to software bugs?

People from the desktop software business will find this hard to credit, but at Viaweb, bugs became almost a game. Since most released bugs involved borderline cases, the users who encountered them were likely to be advanced users pushing the envelope. Advanced users are more forgiving about bugs, especially since you probably introduced them in the course of adding some feature they were asking for. In fact, because bugs were rare and you had to be doing sophisticated things to see them, advanced users were often proud to catch one. They would call support in a spirit more of triumph than anger, as if they had scored points off us.
How did Viaweb approach customer support and feedback?
At Viaweb, support was free because we wanted to hear from customers. If someone had a problem, we wanted to know about it right away so that we could reproduce the error and release a fix.
How did the proximity of developers to customer support at Viaweb impact their ability to address bugs?

At Viaweb, the developers were always in close contact with support. The customer support people were about thirty feet away from the programmers and knew that they could always interrupt anything with a report of a genuine bug. We would leave a board meeting to fix a serious bug.
How did the new customer support approach benefit customers, support staff, and programmers alike?

Our approach to support made everyone happier. The customers were delighted. Just imagine how it would feel to call a support line and be treated as someone bringing important news. The customer support people liked it because it meant they could help the users instead of reading scripts to them. And the programmers liked it because they could reproduce bugs instead of just hearing vague second-hand reports about them.
What role did customer support play in the development and marketing of products after the acquisition by Yahoo?

After we were bought by Yahoo, the customer support people were moved far away from the programmers. It was only then that we realized that they were effectively QA and, to some extent, marketing as well. In addition to catching bugs, they were the keepers of the knowledge of vaguer, bug-like things, like features that confused users. They were also a kind of proxy focus group; we could ask them which of two new features users wanted more, and they were always right.
What are the benefits of having the ability to release software immediately?

Being able to release software immediately is a big motivator. Often, as I was walking to work, I would think of some change I wanted to make to the software and do it that day. This worked for bigger features as well. Even if something was going to take two weeks to write (few projects took longer), I knew I could see the effect in the software as soon as it was done.
How does the process of implementing one idea influence the generation of new ideas in creative projects?

If I'd had to wait a year for the next release, I would have shelved most of these ideas, for a while at least. The thing about ideas, though, is that they lead to more ideas. Have you ever noticed that when you sit down to write something, half the ideas that end up in it are ones you thought of while writing it? The same thing happens with software. Working to implement one idea gives you more ideas. So shelving an idea costs you not only that delay in implementing it but also all the ideas that implementing it would have led to. In fact, shelving an idea probably even inhibits new ideas: as you start to think of some new feature, you catch sight of the shelf and think, "but I already have a lot of new things I want to do for the next release."
What is the relationship between planning and implementation in the context of innovation at Viaweb?

What big companies do instead of implementing features is plan them. At Viaweb, we sometimes ran into trouble on this account. Investors and analysts would ask us what we had planned for the future. The truthful answer would have been that we didn't have any plans. We had general ideas about things we wanted to improve, but if we knew how, we would have done it already. What were we going to do in the next six months? Whatever looked like the biggest win. I don't know if I ever dared to give this answer, but that was the truth. Plans are just another word for ideas on the shelf. When we thought of good ideas, we implemented them.
What factors contribute to software release reliability in a company with individual code ownership?

At Viaweb, as at many software companies, most code had one definite owner. But when you owned something, you really owned it: no one except the owner of a piece of software had to approve (or even know about) a release. There was no protection against breakage except the fear of looking like an idiot to one's peers, and that was more than enough. I may have given the impression that we just blithely plowed forward writing code. We did go fast, but we thought very carefully before we released software onto those servers. Paying attention is more important to reliability than moving slowly. Because he pays close attention, a Navy pilot can land a 40,000 lb. aircraft at 140 miles per hour on a pitching carrier deck, at night, more safely than the average teenager can cut a bagel.
How does the team size for Web-based software development compare to that of traditional desktop software development?

Fortunately, web-based software does require fewer programmers. I once worked for a medium-sized desktop software company that had over 100 people working in engineering as a whole. Only 13 of these were in product development. All the rest were working on releases, ports, and so on. With web-based software, all you need (at most) are the 13 people because there are no releases, ports, and so on.
What strategy did the founders of Viaweb use to address concerns about their small team size while seeking to attract buyers?

Viaweb was written by just three people. I was always under pressure to hire more because we wanted to get bought, and we knew that buyers would have a hard time paying a high price for a company with only three programmers. Our solution was to hire more people but create new projects for them.
How does the size of a development team impact the efficiency of software development?

Adding people to a project tends to slow it down. The number of possible connections between developers grows exponentially with the size of the group. The larger the group, the more time they'll spend in meetings negotiating how their software will work together, and the more bugs they'll get from unforeseen interactions. Fortunately, this process also works in reverse: as groups get smaller, software development gets exponentially more efficient. I can't remember the programmers at Viaweb ever having an actual meeting. We never had more to say at any one time than we could say as we were walking to lunch.
What challenges do programmers face when they also have to manage system administration duties?

If there is a downside here, it is that all the programmers have to be, to some degree, system administrators as well. When you're hosting software, someone has to be watching the servers, and in practice, the only people who can do this properly are the ones who wrote the software. At Viaweb, our system had so many components and changed so frequently that there was no definite border between software and infrastructure. Arbitrarily declaring such a border would have constrained our design choices. And so, although we were constantly hoping that one day ("in a couple of months") everything would be stable enough that we could hire someone whose job was just to worry about the servers, it never happened.
What are the ongoing responsibilities of developers for web-based software after its initial launch?

Web-based software is never going to be something you write, check in, and go home. It's a live thing, running on your servers right now. A bad bug might not just crash one user's process; it could crash them all. If a bug in your code corrupts some data on disk, you have to fix it. We found that you don't have to watch the servers every minute (after the first year or so), but you definitely want to keep an eye on things you've changed recently. You don't release code late at night and then go home.
How can server-based software enhance our understanding of user behavior compared to traditional methods?

Server-based software enhances our understanding of user behavior compared to traditional methods by providing unprecedented information about their actions. While traditional methods often rely on small, artificial focus groups, server-based software allows you to see every click made by every user. Although you must consider carefully what you are going to analyze to avoid violating users' privacy, even the most general statistical sampling can be very useful in gaining insights into user behavior.
How can monitoring actual users on a server improve optimization decisions compared to relying on benchmarks?

Monitoring actual users on a server allows for more informed optimization decisions compared to relying solely on benchmarks, which are based on simulated users. With server-based software, you can observe real user interactions. To determine what to optimize, simply log into the server and identify what is consuming the most CPU resources. Additionally, you can recognize when to stop optimizing; for instance, we eventually improved the Viaweb editor to the point where it was memory-bound rather than CPU-bound. Since there was little we could do to reduce the size of users' data (at least nothing easy), we understood that further optimization efforts were unnecessary.
How does software efficiency impact the profitability of server-based applications?

Efficiency matters for server-based software because you're paying for the hardware. The number of users you can support per server is the divisor of your capital cost, so if you can make your software very efficient, you can undersell competitors and still make a profit. At Viaweb, we got the capital cost per user down to about $5. It would be less now, probably less than the cost of sending them the first month's bill. Hardware is free now if your software is reasonably efficient.
How did user feedback influence the design and functionality of Viaweb's RTML scripting language?

Watching users can guide you in design as well as optimization. Viaweb had a scripting language called RTML that let advanced users define their own page styles. We found that RTML became a kind of suggestion box because users only used it when the predefined page styles couldn't do what they wanted. Originally, the editor put button bars across the page, but after a number of users used RTML to put buttons down the left side, we adjusted the design to accommodate this feedback.
How did Viaweb enhance user experience and engagement during their online test drive?

Finally, by watching users, you can often tell when they're in trouble. And since the customer is always right, that's a sign of something you need to fix. At Viaweb, the key to getting users was the online test drive. It was not just a series of slides built by marketing people. In our test drive, users actually used the software. It took about five minutes, and at the end of it, they had built a real, working store.
How can improving the test drive experience impact user acquisition for Web-based applications?

The test drive was the way we got nearly all our new users. I think it will be the same for most web-based applications. If users can get through a test drive successfully, they'll like the product. If they get confused or bored, they won't. So anything we can do to get more people through the test drive would increase our growth rate.
How did addressing user confusion during a test drive impact completion rates and revenue growth?

I studied click trails of people taking the test drive and found that at a certain step they would get confused and click on the browser's Back button. (If you try writing web-based applications, you'll find that the Back button becomes one of your most interesting philosophical problems.) So I added a message at that point, telling users that they were nearly finished and reminding them not to click on the Back button. Another great thing about web-based software is that you get instant feedback from changes: the number of people completing the test drive rose immediately from 60% to 90%. And since the number of new users was a function of the number of completed test drives, our revenue growth increased by 50%, just from that change.
How has the perception of software monetization evolved in relation to subscription models?

In the early 1990s, I read an article in which someone said that software was a subscription business. At first, this seemed like a very cynical statement. But later, I realized that it reflects reality: software development is an ongoing process. I think it's cleaner if you openly charge subscription fees instead of forcing people to keep buying and installing new versions so that they'll keep paying you. And fortunately, subscriptions are the natural way to bill for web-based applications.
Why are companies likely to be the primary providers of hosting applications instead of freeware?

Hosting applications is an area where companies will play a role that is not likely to be filled by freeware. Hosting applications involve a lot of stress and incur real expenses. No one is going to want to do it for free.
What are the advantages of Web-based applications for companies in terms of revenue and customer management?

For companies, Web-based applications are an ideal source of revenue. Instead of starting each quarter with a blank slate, you have a recurring revenue stream. Because your software evolves gradually, you don't have to worry that a new model will flop; there never needs to be a new model, per se, and if you do something to the software that users hate, you'll know right away. You have no trouble with uncollectable bills; if someone won't pay, you can just turn off the service. And there is no possibility of piracy.
How can software piracy potentially benefit companies in terms of user base and market standardization?

Some amount of piracy is to the advantage of software companies. If a user really would not have bought your software at any price, you haven't lost anything if he uses a pirated copy. In fact, you gain because he is one more user helping to make your software the standardâor who might buy a copy later, when he graduates from high school.
How do companies utilize price discrimination in relation to software pricing and piracy?

When they can, companies like to do something called price discrimination, which means charging each customer as much as they can afford. Software is particularly suitable for price discrimination because the marginal cost is close to zero. This is why some software costs more to run on Suns than on Intel boxes: a company that uses Suns is not interested in saving money and can safely be charged more. Piracy is effectively the lowest tier of price discrimination. I think that software companies understand this and deliberately turn a blind eye to some kinds of piracy. With server-based software, they are going to have to come up with some other solution.
Why do web-based software products tend to sell better than desktop software?

Web-based software sells well, especially in comparison to desktop software, because it's easy to buy. You might think that people decide to buy something and then buy it as two separate steps. That's what I thought before Viaweb, to the extent I thought about the question at all. In fact, the second step can propagate back into the first: if something is hard to buy, people will change their mind about whether they wanted it. And vice versa: you'll sell more of something when it's easy to buy. I buy more books because Amazon exists. Web-based software is just about the easiest thing in the world to buy, especially if you have just done an online demo. Users should not have to do much more than enter a credit card number. (Make them do more at your peril.)
What are the risks of using Web-based software provided by ISPs as resellers?

Web-based software is sometimes offered through ISPs acting as resellers. This can be a bad idea. You have to administer the servers because you need to be constantly improving both hardware and software. If you give up direct control of the servers, you give up most of the advantages of developing web-based applications.
Who are the primary users of Web-based applications according to the paragraph?

The primary users of Web-based applications are individuals and smaller companies. At Viaweb, they were initially these types of customers, and I believe this will be the rule with Web-based applications. These users are ready to try new things, partly because they are more flexible and partly because they want the lower costs of new technology.
What are the advantages of using web-based applications for large companies?

Web-based applications are often the best solution for large companies, though they may be slow to realize it. The best intranet is the Internet. If a company uses true web-based applications, the software will work better, the servers will be better administered, and employees will have access to the system from anywhere.
What are the potential benefits of outsourcing IT services for companies that rely on Web-based applications?

Outsourcing IT services can provide significant benefits for companies that rely on Web-based applications. Drastic as it sounds, I think this is generally a good idea. Companies are likely to get better service this way than they would from in-house system administrators. System administrators can become cranky and unresponsive because they're not directly exposed to competitive pressure: a salesman has to deal with customers, and a developer has to deal with competitors' software, but a system administrator, like an old bachelor, has few external forces to keep him in line. At Viaweb, we had external forces in plenty to keep us in line. The people calling us were customers, not just co-workers. If a server got wedged, we jumped; just thinking about it gives me a jolt of adrenaline, years later.
How did the introduction of desktop computers impact software development and startup opportunities?

The arrival of desktop computers inspired a lot of new software because writing applications for them seemed an attainable goal to nascent startups. Development was cheap, and the customers would be individual people that you could reach through computer stores or even by mail order.
What impact did VisiCalc have on the adoption of desktop computers?

VisiCalc was the first spreadsheet software. It was written by two individuals working in an attic, and yet it did things no mainframe software could do. VisiCalc was such an advance in its time that people bought Apple IIs just to run it. This marked the beginning of a trend: desktop computers won because startups wrote software for them.
How has the affordability of technology influenced the development and distribution of server-based software by startups?

It looks as if server-based software will be good this time around because startups will write it. Computers are so cheap now that you can get started, as we did, using a desktop computer as a server. Inexpensive processors have eaten the workstation market (you rarely even hear the word now) and are most of the way through the server market; Yahoo's servers, which deal with loads as high as any on the Internet, all have the same inexpensive Intel processors that you have in your desktop machine. And once you've written the software, all you need to sell it is a website. Nearly all our users came directly to our site through word of mouth and references in the press.
What initial challenges did the founders of Viaweb face when starting their company?

Viaweb was a typical larval startup. We were terrified of starting a company, and for the first few months, we comforted ourselves by treating the whole thing as an experiment that we might call off at any moment. Fortunately, there were few obstacles except technical ones. While we were writing the software, our web server was the same desktop machine we used for development, connected to the outside world by a dial-up line. Our only expenses in that phase were food and rent.
What advantages did the web provide for software development compared to traditional desktop software?

I don't think we would have started a startup to write desktop software because desktop software has to run on Windows, and before we could write software for Windows, we'd have to use it. The Web let us do an end-run around Windows and deliver software running on Unix directly to users through the browser. That is a liberating prospect, a lot like the arrival of PCs twenty-five years ago.
How has the perception of dominant technology companies evolved from IBM to Microsoft?

Back when desktop computers arrived, IBM was the giant that everyone was afraid of. It's hard to imagine now, but I remember the feeling very well. Now the frightening giant is Microsoft, and I don't think they are as blind to the threat facing them as IBM was. After all, Microsoft deliberately built their business in IBM's blind spot.
How might the shift to remote server applications impact Microsoft's dominance in the desktop operating system market?

The shift to remote server applications poses a significant challenge for Microsoftâs dominance in the desktop operating system market. I mentioned earlier that my mother doesn't really need a desktop computer, and most users probably don't either. This trend is a problem for Microsoft, and they know it. If applications run on remote servers, no one needs Windows. What will Microsoft do? Will they be able to use their control of the desktop to prevent or constrain this new generation of software?
What future developments in Microsoft's operating system strategy are anticipated regarding server and desktop integration?

My guess is that Microsoft will develop some kind of server/desktop hybrid, where the operating system works together with servers they control. At a minimum, files will be centrally available for users who want that. I don't expect Microsoft to go all the way to the extreme of doing the computations on the server, with only a browser for a client, if they can avoid it. If you only need a browser for a client, you don't need Microsoft on the client, and if Microsoft doesn't control the client, they can't push users towards their server-based applications.
What challenges might Microsoft face in maintaining control over its applications across different client types?

I think Microsoft will have a hard time keeping the genie in the bottle. There will be too many different types of clients for them to control them all. If Microsoft's applications only work with some clients, competitors will be able to trump them by offering applications that work from any client.
How might Microsoftâs role change in the landscape of Web-based applications compared to their dominance in desktop applications?

In a world of Web-based applications, there is no automatic place for Microsoft. They may succeed in making themselves a place, but I don't think they'll dominate this new world as they did the world of desktop applications.
What challenges might established companies face when transitioning to new technologies while trying to protect their existing profitable products?

It's not so much that a competitor will trip them up as that they will trip over themselves. With the rise of Web-based software, they will be facing not just technical problems but their own wishful thinking. What they need to do is cannibalize their existing business, and I can't see them facing that. The same single-mindedness that has brought them this far will now be working against them. IBM was in exactly the same situation, and they could not master it. IBM made a late and half-hearted entry into the microcomputer business because they were ambivalent about threatening their cash cow, mainframe computing. Microsoft will likewise be hampered by wanting to save the desktop. A cash cow can be a damned heavy monkey on your back.
What does the author predict about the future of server-based applications and the potential for startups?

I'm not saying that no one will dominate server-based applications. Someone probably will eventually. But I think that there will be a good long period of cheerful chaos, just as there was in the early days of microcomputers. That was a good time for startups. Lots of small companies flourished and did it by making cool things.
What are the key characteristics of a classic startup?
The classic startup is fast and informal, with few people and little money. Those few people work very hard, and technology magnifies the effect of the decisions they make. If they win, they win big.
What are some unique characteristics of startups focused on developing web-based applications?

In a startup developing web-based applications, everything you associate with startups is taken to an extreme. You can write and launch a product with even fewer people and even less money. You have to be even faster, and you can get away with being more informal. You can literally launch your product as three guys sitting in the living room of an apartment, with a server collocated at an ISP. We did.
How has the culture and environment of software development teams evolved from the 1960s to the present day?

Over time, the teams have gotten smaller, faster, and more informal. In 1960, software development meant a roomful of men with horn-rimmed glasses and narrow black neckties, industriously writing ten lines of code a day on IBM coding forms. In 1980, it was a team of eight to ten people wearing jeans to the office and typing into VT100s. Now, it's a couple of guys sitting in a living room with laptops. (And jeans turn out not to be the last word in informality.)
What are the challenges and pressures faced by startups developing Web-based applications?

Startups are stressful, and this, unfortunately, is also taken to an extreme with Web-based applications. Many software companies, especially at the beginning, have periods where the developers sleep under their desks and so on. The alarming thing about Web-based software is that there is nothing to prevent this from becoming the default. The stories about sleeping under desks usually end: then at last we shipped it, and we all went home and slept for a week. Web-based software never ships. You can work 16-hour days for as long as you want to. And because you can, and your competitors can, you tend to be forced to. You can, so you must. It's Parkinson's Law running in reverse.
How do Web-based applications blur the responsibilities and stresses of programmers and system administrators?

The worst thing is not the hours but the responsibility. Programmers and system administrators traditionally each have their own separate worries. Programmers have to worry about bugs, and system administrators have to worry about infrastructure. Programmers may spend a long day up to their elbows in source code, but at some point, they get to go home and forget about it. System administrators never quite leave the job behind, but when they do get paged at 4:00 AM, they don't usually have to do anything very complicated. With Web-based applications, these two kinds of stress get combined. The programmers become system administrators, but without the sharply defined limits that ordinarily make the job bearable.
How does the shift from desktop to web-based software impact the roles of users and programmers in startups?

The shift from desktop to web-based software impacts the roles of users and programmers in startups significantly. Desktop software forces users to become system administrators, while web-based software shifts that responsibility to programmers. There is less stress in total, but more for the programmers. That's not necessarily bad news; if you're a startup competing with a big company, it's good news. Web-based applications offer a straightforward way to outwork your competitors. No startup asks for more.
What factors contributed to the early excitement and demand for personal computers in the 1970s?

Realizing that they were just good enough, people could combine one of these chips with some memory (256 bytes in the first Altair) and front panel switches to create a working computer. The excitement of being able to have your own computer was so great that there were plenty of people who wanted to buy them, however limited.
What advantages do web applications offer despite their UI limitations?

Web pages weren't designed to be a UI for applications, but they're just good enough. For a significant number of users, software that you can use from any browser will be enough of a win in itself to outweigh any awkwardness in the UI. Maybe you can't write the best-looking spreadsheet using HTML, but you can write a spreadsheet that several people can use simultaneously from different locations without special client software, or that can incorporate live data feeds, or that can page you when certain conditions are triggered. More importantly, you can write new kinds of applications that don't even have names yet. VisiCalc was not merely a microcomputer version of a mainframe application; after all, it was a new type of application.
What are the advantages of using web-based applications over server-based applications that rely on specific clients?

Of course, server-based applications don't have to be web-based. You could have some other kind of client. But I'm pretty sure that's a bad idea. It would be very convenient if you could assume that everyone would install your clientâso convenient that you could easily convince yourself that they all wouldâbut if they don't, you're hosed. Because web-based software assumes nothing about the client, it will work anywhere the web works. That's a big advantage already, and the advantage will grow as new web devices proliferate. Users will like you because your software just works, and your life will be easier because you won't have to tweak it for every new client.
What potential conflict in the tech industry could arise between AOL and Microsoft, and how might it affect the future of web-based applications?

I feel like I've watched the evolution of the Web as closely as anyone, and I can't predict what's going to happen with clients. Convergence is probably coming, but where? I can't pick a winner. One thing I can predict is conflict between AOL and Microsoft. Whatever Microsoft's .NET turns out to be, it will probably involve connecting the desktop to servers. Unless AOL fights back, they will either be pushed aside or turned into a pipe between Microsoft client and server software. If Microsoft and AOL get into a client war, the only thing sure to work on both will be browsing the Web, meaning Web-based applications will be the only kind that work everywhere.
What are the advantages of developing Web-based applications for startups?

Web-based applications offer several advantages for startups. They are cost-effective to develop and easy for even the smallest startup to deliver. While the process can be a lot of work and particularly stressful, this challenge can improve the odds of success for startups. Additionally, web-based applications are resilient; no one can break them without breaking browsing itself. Although the web may not be the only way to deliver software, it is a reliable method that works now and will continue to do so for a long time.
What did E. B. White discover about cows and electrified fences?

E. B. White was amused to learn from a farmer friend that many electrified fences don't have any current running through them. The cows apparently learn to stay away from them, and after that, you don't need the current. "Rise up, cows!" he wrote, "Take your liberty while despots snore!"
What are the two essential principles for achieving success in business?

There are only two things you have to know about business: build something users love and make more than you spend. If you get these two right, you'll be ahead of most startups. You can figure out the rest as you go.
What are the advantages of launching a Web-based application with a limited budget?

Launching a Web-based application with a limited budget has several advantages. You may not at first make more than you spend, but as long as the gap is closing fast enough, you'll be okay. If you start out underfunded, it will at least encourage a habit of frugality. The less you spend, the easier it is to make more than you spend. Fortunately, it can be very cheap to launch a Web-based application. We launched on under $10,000, and it would be even cheaper today. We had to spend thousands on a server and thousands more to get SSL. (The only company selling SSL software at the time was Netscape.) Now you can rent a much more powerful server, with SSL included, for less than we paid for bandwidth alone. You could launch a Web-based application now for less than the cost of a fancy office chair.
What advantages do independent developers have in creating and delivering Web-based applications compared to large corporations like Microsoft?

Don't be intimidated. You can do as much that Microsoft can't as they can do that you can't. And no one can stop you. You don't have to ask anyone's permission to develop Web-based applications. You don't have to do licensing deals, or get shelf space in retail stores, or grovel to have your application bundled with the OS. You can deliver software right to the browser, and no one can get between you and potential users without preventing them from browsing the Web.
What challenges arise when trying to combine hardware and online services in consumer electronics?

This approach has not worked well, partly because you need two different kinds of companies to build consumer electronics and to run an online service, and partly because users hate the idea. Giving away the razor and making money on the blades may work for Gillette, but a razor is a much smaller commitment than a Web terminal. Cell phone handset makers are satisfied to sell hardware without trying to capture the service revenue as well. That should probably be the model for Internet clients too. If someone just sold a nice-looking little box with a Web browser that you could use to connect through any ISP, every technophobe in the country would buy one.
Why are Application Service Providers (ASPs) particularly cautious about security in server-based software?

Application Service Providers (ASPs) are particularly cautious about security in server-based software because compromising a server could cause significant damage. ASPs that want to stay in business are likely to pay careful attention to security to avoid such risks.
What were the perceived shortcomings of using applets for server-based application development?

Applets were perceived as an old-fashioned idea for server-based application development. Downloading programs to run on the client seemed less efficient; it was simpler to run the programs directly on the server. We wasted little time on applets, but countless other startups must have been lured into this tar pit. Few can have escaped alive, or Microsoft could not have gotten away with dropping Java in the most recent version of Explorer.
What is the phenomenon called when fixing one software bug causes another previously hidden bug to become apparent?

The phenomenon is called a "bug where one bug happens to compensate for another." When you fix one bug, the other becomes visible. However, it may seem as if the fix is at fault since that was the last thing you changed.
What programming languages were used to develop the different components of the ordering system and site editor?

The ordering system and image generator were written in C and C++, the manager mostly in Perl, and the editor in Java. Trevor Blackwell wrote the image generator and the manager, which merchants used to retrieve orders, view statistics, and configure domain names, etc. I wrote the editor, which merchants used to build their sites.
What legislation prohibits certain pricing practices among retailers in the U.S.?

A retailer claims that their buying power means lower prices for you; however, I was surprised to find it was outlawed in the U.S. by the Robinson-Patman Act of 1936. This law does not appear to be vigorously enforced.
Why might some clothing brands not prioritize preventing shoplifting among urban youth?
Naomi Klein says that clothing brands favored by "urban youth" do not try too hard to prevent shoplifting because, in their target market, the shoplifters are also the fashion leaders.
What strategy can companies use to enhance competitiveness for non-core jobs?
One possible answer is to outsource any job that's not directly exposed to competitive pressure, because outsourcing it will thereby expose it to competitive pressure.
What motivated Dan and Bob to develop a more powerful version of their prototype despite their other commitments?

Dan and Bob developed a prototype in Basic in a couple of days, then over the course of the next year, they worked together (mostly at night) to make a more powerful version written in 6502 machine language. Dan was at Harvard Business School at the time, and Bob nominally had a day job writing software. "There was no great risk in doing a business," Bob wrote, "If it failed it failed. No big deal."
What qualities would an ideal open-source browser have to compete with Microsoft and support the development of new software?

An ideal open-source browser would keep the next generation of software from being overshadowed by Microsoft. Mozilla is open-source but seems to have suffered from having been corporate software for so long. A small, fast browser that is actively maintained would be a great thing in itself and would probably also encourage companies to build little web appliances.
How could a proper open-source browser influence the evolution of web technologies and improve user interactions with web applications?

A proper open-source browser would influence the evolution of web technologies by allowing HTTP and HTML to continue to evolve, similar to how Perl has. It would greatly enhance web-based applications by enabling them to distinguish between selecting a link and following it; all that would be needed for this is a trivial enhancement of HTTP to allow multiple URLs in a request. Additionally, cascading menus would also be beneficial.
How does the difficulty of server-based software development impact the structure of software companies and their ability to attract talent?

"I would go farther in saying that because server-based software is so hard on the programmers, it causes a fundamental economic shift away from large companies. It requires the kind of intensity and dedication from programmers that they will only be willing to provide when it's their own company. Software companies can hire skilled people to work in a not-too-demanding environment, and can hire unskilled people to endure hardships, but they can't hire highly skilled people to bust their asses. Since capital is no longer needed, big companies have little to bring to the table."
Who contributed feedback and information in the preparation of this paper?

I would like to thank Sarah Harlin, Trevor Blackwell, Robert Morris, Eric Raymond, Ken Anderson, and Dan Giffin for reading drafts of this paper; Dan Bricklin and Bob Frankston for information about VisiCalc; and again Ken Anderson for inviting me to speak at BBN.
What criteria determine the quality of a programming language in the eyes of hackers?
A programming language is considered good in the eyes of hackers if and only if hackers like it, rather than being merely an exercise in denotational semantics or compiler design.
Why is the usability of programming languages compared to the design of shoes?

Between the two, the hacker's opinion is the one that matters. Programming languages are not theorems; they're tools designed for people, and they have to be designed to suit human strengths and weaknesses as much as shoes have to be designed for human feet. If a shoe pinches when you put it on, it's a bad shoe, however elegant it may be as a piece of sculpture.
Why is it still valuable to design good programming languages despite many programmers' inability to distinguish between good and bad ones?

It may be that the majority of programmers can't tell a good language from a bad one. But that's no different from any other tool. It doesn't mean that it's a waste of time to try designing a good language.
What role do expert hackers play in the adoption of programming languages among other programmers?

Expert hackers can tell a good language when they see one, and they'll use it. Expert hackers are a tiny minority, admittedly, but that tiny minority writes all the good software, and their influence is such that the rest of the programmers will tend to use whatever language they use. Often, indeed, it is not merely influence but command: often the expert hackers are the very people who, as their bosses or faculty advisors, tell the other programmers what language to use.
What factors influence the long-term popularity of programming languages?

The opinion of expert hackers is not the only force that determines the relative popularity of programming languagesâlegacy software (COBOL) and hype (Ada, Java) also play a roleâbut I think it is the most powerful force over the long term. Given an initial critical mass and enough time, a programming language probably becomes about as popular as it deserves to be. Popularity further separates good languages from bad ones because feedback from real live users always leads to improvements. Look at how much any popular language has changed during its life. Perl and Fortran are extreme cases, but even Lisp has changed a lot. Lisp 1.5 didn't have macros, for example; these evolved later, after hackers at MIT had spent a couple of years using Lisp to write real programs.
What is the minimum number of users a programming language needs to be considered "real"?

Of course, hackers have to know about a language before they can use it. How are they to hear? From other hackers. But there has to be some initial group of hackers using the language for others even to hear about it. I wonder how large this group has to be; how many users make a critical mass? Off the top of my head, I'd say twenty. If a language had twenty separate users, meaning twenty users who decided on their own to use it, I'd consider it to be real.
What strategies can be employed to attract initial users for a new application?

Attracting initial users for a new application can be challenging. It may be harder to get from zero to twenty users than from twenty to a thousand. One effective strategy to gain those initial twenty users is to use a "trojan horse" approach: provide people with an application they want, which happens to be written in the new language.
What role do popular systems play in the popularity of programming languages?

Let's start by acknowledging one external factor that does affect the popularity of a programming language. To become popular, a programming language has to be the scripting language of a popular system. Fortran and COBOL were the scripting languages of early IBM mainframes. C was the scripting language of Unix, and so, later, was Perl. Tcl is the scripting language of Tk. Java and JavaScript are intended to be the scripting languages of web browsers.
What historical factors contributed to Lisp's limited popularity compared to other programming languages?

Lisp is not a massively popular language because it is not the scripting language of a massively popular system. What popularity it retains dates back to the 1960s and 1970s, when it was the scripting language of MIT. A lot of the great programmers of the day were associated with MIT at some point. In the early 1970s, before C, MIT's dialect of Lisp, called MacLisp, was one of the only programming languages a serious hacker would want to use.
What are the current popular applications that utilize Lisp as a scripting language?

Today, Lisp is the scripting language of two moderately popular systems, Emacs and AutoCAD, and for that reason, I suspect that most of the Lisp programming done today is done in Emacs Lisp or AutoLisp.
What key factors should be considered when designing a popular programming language?

Programming languages don't exist in isolation. To hack is a transitive verb â hackers are usually hacking something â and in practice, languages are judged relative to whatever they're used to hack. So, if you want to design a popular language, you either have to supply more than a language, or you have to design your language to replace the scripting language of some existing system.
What factors contributed to the decline in popularity of Common Lisp?

Common Lisp is unpopular partly because it's an orphan. It did originally come with a system to hack: the Lisp Machine. However, Lisp Machines (along with parallel computers) were steamrolled by the increasing power of general-purpose processors in the 1980s. Common Lisp might have remained popular if it had been a good scripting language for Unix. It is, alas, an atrociously bad one.
Why is it important for a programming language to have a free implementation?
A programming language does need a good implementation, of course, and this must be free. Companies will pay for software, but individual hackers won't, and it's the hackers you need to attract.
What criteria are suggested for a programming language to be considered significant in the hacker community?

A language also needs to have a book about it. The book should be thin, well-written, and full of good examples. K&R is the ideal here. At the moment, I'd almost say that a language has to have a book published by O'Reilly. That's becoming the test of mattering to hackers.
What are the advantages of physical books compared to online documentation?

Physical books have several advantages compared to online documentation. Their format is convenient, and the de facto censorship imposed by publishers serves as a useful, albeit imperfect, filter. Additionally, bookstores are one of the most important places for learning about new languages. While online documentation is valuable, physical books are not yet outmoded.
What do hackers prioritize when choosing a programming language?

One thing hackers prioritize is brevity. Hackers are lazy, in the same way that mathematicians and modernist architects are lazy: they hate anything extraneous. It would not be far from the truth to say that a hacker about to write a program decides what language to use, at least subconsciously, based on the total number of characters they'll have to type. If this isn't precisely how hackers think, a language designer would do well to act as if it were.
Why do some programmers prefer using car and cdr over first and rest in Lisp?

It has sometimes been said that Lisp should use first and rest instead of car and cdr because it would make programs easier to read. Maybe for the first couple of hours. But a hacker can learn quickly enough that car means the first element of a list and cdr means the rest. Using first and rest means 50% more typing. They are also different lengths, meaning that the arguments won't line up when they're called, as car and cdr often are, in successive lines. I've found that it matters a lot how code lines up on the page. I can barely read Lisp code when it is set in a variable-width font, and friends say this is true for other languages too.
What is a disadvantage of strongly typed programming languages in terms of code simplicity?
Brevity is one area where strongly typed languages lose. All other things being equal, no one wants to begin a program with a bunch of declarations. Anything that can be implicit should be.
What are the implications of token length in programming languages like Perl and Common Lisp?

The individual tokens should be short as well. Perl and Common Lisp occupy opposite poles on this question. Perl programs can be almost cryptically dense, while the names of built-in Common Lisp operators are comically long. The designers of Common Lisp probably expected users to have text editors that would type these long names for them. However, the cost of a long name is not just the cost of typing it; there is also the cost of reading it and the cost of the space it takes up on your screen.
What is the main argument regarding programming language design in relation to user freedom and brevity?

There is one thing more important than brevity to a hacker: being able to do what you want. In the history of programming languages, a surprising amount of effort has gone into preventing programmers from doing things considered to be improper. This is a dangerously presumptuous plan. How can the language designer know what the programmer is going to need to do? I think language designers would do better to consider their target user to be a genius who will need to do things they never anticipated, rather than a bumbler who needs to be protected from himself. The bumbler will shoot himself in the foot anyway. You may save him from referring to variables in another package, but you can't save him from writing a badly designed program to solve the wrong problem and taking forever to do it.
What motivates good programmers to engage in risky and unconventional coding practices?

Good programmers often want to do dangerous and unsavory things. By "unsavory," I mean things that go behind whatever semantic facade the language is trying to present: getting hold of the internal representation of some high-level abstraction, for example. Hackers like to hack, and hacking means getting inside things and second-guessing the original designer.
How should developers respond to unanticipated uses of programming languages by users?

When you make any tool, people use it in ways you didn't intend, and this is especially true of a highly articulated tool like a programming language. Many hackers will want to tweak your semantic model in a way that you never imagined. I say, let them; give the programmer access to as much internal stuff as you can without endangering runtime systems like the garbage collector.
How does Lisp's approach to macros reflect its historical flexibility for programmers?

Historically, Lisp has been good at letting hackers have their way. The political correctness of Common Lisp is an aberration. Early Lisps let you get your hands on everything. A good deal of that spirit is, fortunately, preserved in macros. What a wonderful thing it is to be able to make arbitrary transformations on the source code.
What characteristics define a "good" programming language according to the author's perspective?

A really good language should be both clean and dirty: cleanly designed, with a small core of well-understood and highly orthogonal operators, but dirty in the sense that it lets hackers have their way with it. C is like this. So were the early Lisps. A real hacker's language will always have a slightly raffish character.
What characteristics make a programming language appealing to hackers?
To be attractive to hackers, a language must be good for writing the kinds of programs they want to write. And that means, perhaps surprisingly, that it has to be good for writing throwaway programs.
What is a throwaway program and how can it unexpectedly develop into a permanent solution?

A throwaway program is a program you write quickly for some limited task: a program to automate some system administration task, generate test data for a simulation, or convert data from one format to another. The surprising thing about throwaway programs is that, like the "temporary" buildings built at so many American universities during World War II, they often don't get thrown away. Many evolve into real programs, with real features and real users.
What are the potential drawbacks of designing large projects from the outset?

I have a hunch that the best big programs begin life this way, rather than being designed big from the start, like the Hoover Dam. It's terrifying to build something big from scratch. When people take on a project that's too big, they become overwhelmed. The project either gets bogged down, or the result is sterile and wooden: a shopping mall rather than a real downtown, BrasÃ­lia rather than Rome, Ada rather than C.
What is the significance of starting with throwaway programs in the development of large software systems?

Starting with a throwaway program can significantly impact the development of large software systems. This approach is less daunting, and the design of the program benefits from evolution. If one looked closely, it would likely turn out that most large programs were developed this way. Those that evolved in this manner are probably still written in whatever language they were first created in, as it is rare for a program to be ported, except for political reasons. Paradoxically, if you want to create a language that is used for big systems, you must ensure it is suitable for writing throwaway programs, because that is where big systems originate.
How did Perl evolve from a collection of utilities into a popular programming language?

Perl is a striking example of this idea. It was not only designed for writing throwaway programs, but was pretty much a throwaway program itself. Perl began life as a collection of utilities for generating reports and only evolved into a programming language as the throwaway programs people wrote in it grew larger. It was not until Perl 5 (if then) that the language was suitable for writing serious programs, and yet it was already massively popular.
What characteristics should a programming language have to be suitable for creating throwaway programs?

What makes a language good for throwaway programs? To start with, it must be readily available. A throwaway program is something that you expect to write in an hour. So the language probably must already be installed on the computer you're using. It can't be something you have to install before you use it; it has to be there. C was there because it came with the operating system. Perl was there because it was originally a tool for system administrators, and yours had already installed it.
What characteristics make a programming language more accessible and user-friendly?

Being available means more than being installed, though. An interactive language with a command-line interface is more accessible than one that you have to compile and run separately. A popular programming language should be interactive and start up fast.
Why is brevity important in a throwaway program?
Brevity is important in a throwaway program. It is always attractive to hackers, and never more so than in a program they expect to turn out in an hour.
Why are library functions considered important in programming, particularly in languages like Perl?

Library functions are considered important in programming, particularly in languages like Perl, because they allow programmers to utilize pre-written code, enhancing efficiency and brevity. Perl excels in this area due to its extensive libraries for manipulating strings. This class of library functions is especially crucial for throwaway programs, which are often initially created for tasks such as converting or extracting data. Many Perl programs likely begin as just a couple of library calls combined together.
What role will library functions play in the future of programming language design?

I think a lot of the advances that happen in programming languages in the next fifty years will have to do with library functions. I believe future programming languages will have libraries that are as carefully designed as the core language. Programming language design will not be about whether to make your language strongly or weakly typed, or object-oriented, or functional, or whatever, but about how to design great libraries. The kind of language designers who like to think about how to design type systems may shudder at this. It's almost like writing applications! Too bad. Languages are for programmers, and libraries are what programmers need.
What are the key considerations in designing effective programming libraries?

Designing effective programming libraries is challenging. It's not simply a matter of writing a lot of code. Once the libraries get too big, it can sometimes take longer to find the function you need than to write the code yourself. Libraries need to be designed using a small set of orthogonal operators, just like the core language. It ought to be possible for the programmer to guess what library call will do what they need.
What are the limitations of Common Lisp regarding libraries and operating system interaction?

Libraries are one area where Common Lisp falls short. There are only rudimentary libraries for manipulating strings, and almost none for interacting with the operating system. For historical reasons, Common Lisp tries to pretend that the OS doesn't exist. Because you can't communicate with the OS, you're unlikely to be able to write a serious program using only the built-in operators in Common Lisp. You have to use some implementation-specific hacks as well, and in practice, these tend not to provide everything you want. Hackers would think a lot more highly of Lisp if Common Lisp had powerful string libraries and good OS support.
What are the potential issues with prefix notation in programming languages according to the paragraph?

There are two possible problems with prefix notation: that it is unfamiliar to programmers and that it is not dense enough. The conventional wisdom in the Lisp world is that the first problem is the real one. I'm not so sure. Yes, prefix notation makes ordinary programmers panic. But I don't think ordinary programmers' opinions matter. Languages become popular or unpopular based on what expert hackers think of them, and I think expert hackers might be able to deal with prefix notation. Perl syntax can be pretty incomprehensible, but that has not stood in the way of Perl's popularity. If anything, it may have helped foster a Perl cult.
Why do some programmers prefer infix notation over prefix notation?
A more serious problem is the diffuseness of prefix notation. For expert hackers, that really is a problem. No one wants to write (aref a x y) when they could write a[x, y].
What technique can be used to simplify expressions involving data structures?

In this particular case, there is a way to finesse our way out of the problem. If we treat data structures as if they were functions on indexes, we could write (a x y) instead, which is even shorter than the Perl form. Similar tricks may shorten other types of expressions.
How can treating indentation as significant improve code readability and reduce bugs?

Treating indentation as significant can improve code readability and reduce bugs by eliminating the need for excessive parentheses. This approach aligns with how programmers naturally read code; when indentation indicates one meaning and delimiters suggest another, programmers tend to prioritize the indentation. By making indentation significant, we can eliminate this common source of bugs and create shorter, more readable programs.
Why might infix syntax be preferred over prefix syntax in programming, particularly for mathematical expressions?

Infix syntax is sometimes easier to read, especially for mathematical expressions. I have used Lisp my whole programming life, and I still don't find prefix math expressions natural. However, it is convenient, especially when generating code, to have operators that take any number of arguments. Therefore, if we do have infix syntax, it should probably be implemented as some kind of read-macro.
What is the author's perspective on the introduction of additional syntax in Lisp?

I don't think we should be religiously opposed to introducing syntax into Lisp, as long as it translates in a well-understood way into underlying s-expressions. There is already a good deal of syntax in Lisp. It's not necessarily bad to introduce more, as long as no one is forced to use it. In Common Lisp, some delimiters are reserved for the language, suggesting that at least some of the designers intended to have more syntax in the future.
What are the limitations of format strings in Common Lisp regarding syntax integration?

One of the most egregiously unlispy pieces of syntax in Common Lisp occurs in format strings; format is a language in its own right, and that language is not Lisp. If there were a plan for introducing more syntax into Lisp, format specifiers might be able to be included in it. It would be a good thing if macros could generate format specifiers the way they generate any other kind of code.
What does the frequent reference to the section on format in CLTL suggest about Lisp programming practices?
An eminent Lisp hacker told me that his copy of CLTL falls open to the section on format. Mine too. This probably indicates room for improvement. It may also mean that programs do a lot of I/O.
What is the most effective approach to optimizing code performance?

To optimize code performance effectively, it is essential to use a very good profiler rather than relying solely on making the language strongly typed. You do not need to know the type of every argument in every call throughout the program. However, you do need to be able to declare the types of arguments in the bottlenecks. More importantly, you must be able to identify where the bottlenecks are.
What is a common criticism of Lisp regarding performance, and how can it be addressed?

One complaint people have had with Lisp is that it's hard to tell what's expensive. This might be true. It might also be inevitable if you want to have a very abstract language. In any case, I think good profiling would go a long way toward fixing the problem: you'd soon learn what was expensive.
What is the relationship between compiler speed and the effectiveness of profiling tools in programming languages?

Part of the problem here is social. Language designers like to write fast compilers; that's how they measure their skill. They think of the profiler as an add-on, at best. But in practice, a good profiler may do more to improve the speed of actual programs written in the language than a compiler that generates fast code. Here, again, language designers are somewhat out of touch with their users. They do a really good job of solving slightly the wrong problem.
How can an active profiler improve a programmer's ability to identify performance issues in their code?

An active profiler can significantly enhance a programmer's ability to identify performance issues in their code by proactively providing performance data instead of waiting for the programmer to request it. For example, the profiler could highlight bottlenecks in red as the programmer edits the source code. Another approach would be to visually represent what is happening in running programs. This would be particularly beneficial in server-based applications, where multiple programs are running simultaneously. An active profiler could graphically display memory usage as a program runs or even produce sounds that indicate what is occurring.
How can sound serve as an indicator of server issues in a monitoring system?

Sound is a good cue to problems. In one place I worked, we had a big board of dials showing what was happening to our web servers. The hands were moved by little servomotors that made a slight noise when they turned. I couldn't see the board from my desk, but I found that I could tell immediately, by the sound, when there was a problem with a server.
What are the potential advantages of incorporating byte code as an official feature in Lisps?

A number of Lisps now compile into byte code, which is then executed by an interpreter. This is usually done to make the implementation easier to port, but it could be a useful language feature. It might be a good idea to make the byte code an official part of the language and to allow programmers to use inline byte code in bottlenecks. Then, such optimizations would be portable too.
Why is the number of simultaneous users per processor a critical factor for server-based applications?

Users are interested in response time. But another kind of efficiency will be increasingly important: the number of simultaneous users you can support per processor. Many of the interesting applications written in the near future will be server-based, and the number of users per server is the critical question for anyone hosting such applications. In the capital cost of a business offering a server-based application, this is the divisor.
What factors should be considered when optimizing performance for applications with multiple users?

In some applications, the processor will be the limiting factor, and execution speed will be the most important thing to optimize. However, often memory will be the limit; the number of simultaneous users will be determined by the amount of memory needed for each user's data. The programming language can help here too. Good support for threads will enable all the users to share a single heap. It may also help to have persistent objects and/or language-level support for lazy loading.
What factor contributes significantly to the popularity and adoption of a programming language among developers?

The last ingredient a popular language needs is time. No one wants to write programs in a language that might go away, as so many programming languages do. So, most hackers will tend to wait until a language has been around for a couple of years before even considering using it.
Why might an inventor hesitate to act on requests immediately?

Inventors of wonderful new things are often surprised to discover this: you need time to get any message through to people. A friend of mine rarely does anything the first time someone asks him. He knows that people sometimes ask for things that they turn out not to want. To avoid wasting his time, he waits until the third or fourth time he's asked to do something; by then, whoever's asking him may be fairly annoyed, but at least they probably really do want whatever they're asking for.
Why might individuals choose to delay their engagement with new technologies or trends?

Most people have learned to do a similar sort of filtering on new things they hear about. They don't even start paying attention until they've heard about something ten times. They're perfectly justified: the majority of hot new trends do turn out to be a waste of time and eventually go away. By delaying learning VRML, I avoided having to learn it at all.
What challenges do inventors face in getting their innovative ideas accepted by the public?

Anyone who invents something new has to expect to keep repeating their message for years before people will start to get it. We wrote what was, as far as I know, the first web-server-based application, and it took us years to get it through to people that it didn't have to be downloaded. It wasn't that they were stupid; they just had us tuned out.
How can persistence in sharing your story lead to greater visibility and attention from others?

The good news is that simple repetition solves the problem. All you have to do is keep telling your story, and eventually, people will start to hear. It's not when people notice you're there that they pay attention; it's when they notice you're still there.
Why is it beneficial for new technologies to be initially adopted by a small group of early users?

Itâs just as well that it usually takes a while to gain momentum. Most technologies evolve a good deal even after theyâre first launched â programming languages especially. Nothing could be better for a new technology than a few years of being used only by a small number of early adopters. Early adopters are sophisticated and demanding, and quickly flush out whatever flaws remain in your technology. When you only have a few users, you can be in close contact with all of them. And early adopters are forgiving when you improve your system, even if this causes some breakage.
What is the organic growth method of introducing new technology?

There are two ways new technology gets introduced: the organic growth method and the big bang method. The organic growth method is exemplified by the classic seat-of-the-pants, underfunded garage startup. A couple of guys, working in obscurity, develop some new technology. They launch it with no marketing and initially have only a few (fanatically devoted) users. They continue to improve the technology, and meanwhile, their user base grows by word of mouth. Before they know it, they're big.
What is the big bang method in the context of startup development?

The big bang method, in the context of startup development, is exemplified by the VC-backed, heavily marketed startup. They rush to develop a product, launch it with great publicity, and immediately (they hope) have a large user base.
What are the advantages of organic growth compared to the big bang approach in technology development?

Generally, the garage guys envy the big bang guys. The big bang guys are smooth, confident, and respected by the VCs. They can afford the best of everything, and the PR campaign surrounding the launch has the side effect of making them celebrities. The organic growth guys, sitting in their garage, feel poor and unloved. And yet, I think they are often mistaken to feel sorry for themselves. Organic growth seems to yield better technology and richer founders than the big bang method. If you look at the dominant technologies today, you'll find that most of them grew organically.
Why is redesign considered crucial in both writing and software development?

"The best writing is rewriting," wrote E. B. White. Every good writer knows this, and it's true for software too. The most important part of design is redesign. Programming languages, especially, don't get redesigned enough.
What mindset is necessary for writing effective software?

To write good software, you must simultaneously keep two opposing ideas in your head. You need the young hacker's naive faith in his abilities and, at the same time, the veteran's skepticism. You have to be able to think critically while maintaining confidence in your skills.
How can one balance optimism and skepticism when addressing a problem?

The trick is to realize that there's no real contradiction here. You want to be optimistic and skeptical about two different things. You have to be optimistic about the possibility of solving the problem, but skeptical about the value of whatever solution you've got so far.
Why do many creators often doubt the quality of their own work despite positive feedback from others?

People who do good work often think that whatever they're working on is no good. Others see what they've done and are full of wonder, but the creator is full of worry. This pattern is no coincidence; it is the worry that made the work good.
How can balancing hope and worry contribute to the success of a project?

If you can keep hope and worry balanced, they will drive a project forward the same way your two legs drive a bicycle forward. In the first phase of the two-cycle innovation engine, you work furiously on some problem, inspired by your confidence that you'll be able to solve it. In the second phase, you look at what you've done in the cold light of morning and see all its flaws very clearly. But as long as your critical spirit doesn't outweigh your hope, you'll be able to look at your admittedly incomplete system and think, "How hard can it be to get the rest of the way?" thereby continuing the cycle.
Why is it important to maintain an ongoing redesign cycle for software?

Maintaining an ongoing redesign cycle for software is crucial because it ensures that the software continues to meet user needs and adapts to changing requirements. Unlike prose, which can be rewritten repeatedly until it satisfies the writer, software often lacks sufficient redesign efforts. While prose has readers who can provide feedback, software must evolve based on user interactions and technological advancements to remain relevant and effective.
Why are readers generally unbothered by changes made in a rewritten essay?
If a writer rewrites an essay, people who read the old version are unlikely to complain that their thoughts have been broken by some newly introduced incompatibility.
What are the drawbacks of having a design created by a committee?

Everyone knows that it's not a good idea to have a language designed by a committee. Committees yield bad design. But I think the worst danger of committees is that they interfere with redesign. It is so much work to introduce changes that no one wants to bother. Whatever a committee decides tends to stay that way, even if most of the members don't like it.
What challenges arise when redesigning software interfaces created by different developers?

Even a committee of two gets in the way of redesign. This happens particularly in the interfaces between pieces of software written by two different people. To change the interface, both have to agree to change it at once. And so, interfaces tend not to change at all, which is a problem because they tend to be one of the most ad hoc parts of any system.
What design approach can help clarify ownership of interfaces in system architecture?

One solution here might be to design systems so that interfaces are horizontal instead of verticalâso that modules are always vertically stacked strata of abstraction. Then the interface will tend to be owned by one of them. The lower of two levels will either be a language in which the upper is written, in which case the lower level will own the interface, or it will be a slave, in which case the interface can be dictated by the upper level.
What are the key factors that determine whether a programming language, like Lisp, is appealing to hackers?

What all this implies is that there is hope for a new Lisp. There is hope for any language that gives hackers what they want, including Lisp. I think we may have made a mistake in thinking that hackers are turned off by Lisp's strangeness. This comforting illusion may have prevented us from seeing the real problem with Lisp, or at least Common Lisp, which is that it sucks for doing what hackers want to do. A hacker's language needs powerful libraries and something to hack. Common Lisp has neither. A hacker's language is terse and hackable. Common Lisp is not.
What factors are necessary for a new Lisp language to gain popularity among hackers?

The good news is, it's not Lisp that sucks, but Common Lisp. If we can develop a new Lisp that is a real hacker's language, I think hackers will use it. They will use whatever language does the job. All we have to do is make sure this new Lisp does some important jobs better than other languages.
What influence has Lisp had on the development of modern programming languages?

History offers some encouragement. Over time, successive new programming languages have taken more and more features from Lisp. There is no longer much left to copy before the language you've made is Lisp. The latest hot language, Python, is a watered-down Lisp with infix syntax and no macros. A new Lisp would be a natural step in this progression.
What are the perceptions of Lisp compared to Python, and how might that influence its marketing?

I sometimes think that it would be a good marketing trick to call it an improved version of Python. That sounds hipper than Lisp. To many people, Lisp is a slow AI language with a lot of parentheses. Fritz Kunze's official biography carefully avoids mentioning the L-word. But my guess is that we shouldn't be afraid to call the new Lisp Lisp. Lisp still has a lot of latent respect among the very best hackers â the ones who took 6.001 and understood it, for example. And those are the users you need to win.
Why does Eric Raymond suggest learning Lisp, according to "How to Become a Hacker"?
In "How to Become a Hacker," Eric Raymond describes Lisp as something like Latin or Greek â a language you should learn as an intellectual exercise, even though you won't actually use it.
Why is learning Lisp considered beneficial for programmers, even if they don't use it frequently?

Lisp is worth learning for the profound enlightenment experience you will have when you finally get it. That experience will make you a better programmer for the rest of your days, even if you never actually use Lisp itself a lot.
What qualities should a new Lisp possess to appeal to modern hackers?

As long as that idea is still floating around, I think hackers will be receptive enough to a new Lisp, even if it is called Lisp. But this Lisp must be a hacker's language, like the classic Lisps of the 1970s. It must be terse, simple, and hackable. Additionally, it must have powerful libraries for doing what hackers want to do now.
What features could make a new Lisp language appealing to developers?

There's no reason a new Lisp shouldn't have string libraries as good as Perl, and if this new Lisp also had powerful libraries for server-based applications, it could be very popular. Real hackers won't turn up their noses at a new tool that will let them solve hard problems with a few library calls. Remember, hackers are lazy.
What are some potential benefits of implementing core language support for server-based applications?

Implementing core language support for server-based applications could yield significant benefits. For example, it would provide explicit support for programs with multiple users and facilitate data ownership at the level of type tags.
What are the key features of the programming environment described in the paragraph?
