The programming environment is clean and terse. It has an interactive toplevel that starts up fast. You can write programs to solve common problems with very little code. Nearly all the code in any program you write is specific to your application. Everything else has been done for you.
How can the use of big abstractions in programming facilitate rapid development and subsequent optimization?

Using big abstractions, you can write the first version of a program very quickly. Later, when you want to optimize, there's a really good profiler that tells you where to focus your attention. You can make inner loops blindingly fast, even writing inline bytecode if you need to.
How user-friendly is the language for beginners in terms of learning resources?

There are lots of good examples to learn from, and the language is intuitive enough that you can learn how to use it from examples in a couple of minutes. You don't need to look in the manual much. The manual is thin and has few warnings and qualifications.
What are the key features of the programming language's design and its libraries?

The language has a small core and powerful, highly orthogonal libraries that are as carefully designed as the core language. The libraries all work well together; everything in the language fits together like the parts in a fine camera. Nothing is deprecated or retained for compatibility. The source code of all the libraries is readily available. It's easy to talk to the operating system and to applications written in other languages.
How is the structure of the language organized in terms of abstractions?
The language is built in layers. The higher-level abstractions are built in a very transparent way out of lower-level abstractions, which you can access if you want.
What are the principles of flexibility and participation in the design of the programming language described?

Nothing is hidden from you that doesn't absolutely have to be. The language offers abstractions only as a way of saving you work, rather than as a way of telling you what to do. In fact, the language encourages you to be an equal participant in its design. You can change everything about it, including even its syntax, and anything you write has, as much as possible, the same status as what comes predefined.
What challenges did Hart identify in Lisp 1.5 regarding variable handling?

Hart, in 1964, identified challenges in Lisp 1.5 regarding variable handling. What was missing, initially, were ways to avoid variable capture and multiple evaluation; Hart's examples are subject to both.
What does the chief imply about the priorities and interests of fleas compared to medical professionals?

"Look at those goddamn fleas, jabbering about some disease they'll see once in their lifetimes. That's the trouble with fleas; they only like the bizarre stuff. They hate their bread-and-butter cases. That's the difference between us and the fucking fleas. See, we love big juicy lumbar disc herniations, but they hate hypertension...."
What prompted the writing of this essay on Java?
This essay developed out of conversations I've had with several other programmers about why Java seemed suspicious. It's not a critique of Java! It is a case study of hackers' radar.
How did the meaning of the phrase "you can't tell a book by its cover" evolve with changes in book publishing?

The aphorism "you can't tell a book by its cover" originated in times when books were sold in plain cardboard covers, to be bound by each purchaser according to his own taste. In those days, you couldn't tell a book by its cover. However, publishing has advanced since then: present-day publishers work hard to make the cover something you can tell a book by.
What insights has the author gained from their experiences in bookshops and with technology?

I spend a lot of time in bookshops, and I feel as if I have by now learned to understand everything publishers mean to tell me about a book, and perhaps a bit more. The time I haven't spent in bookshops, I've spent mostly in front of computers, and I feel as if I've learned, to some degree, to judge technology by its cover as well. It may be just luck, but I've saved myself from a few technologies that turned out to be real stinkers.
What are the author's initial impressions and concerns about the Java programming language?

So far, Java seems like a stinker to me. I've never written a Java program, never more than glanced over reference books about it, but I have a hunch that it won't be a very successful language. I may turn out to be mistaken; making predictions about technology is a dangerous business. But for what it's worth, as a sort of time capsule, here's why I don't like the look of Java:
What distinguishes a genuine standard from a promoted technology in the programming community?

A genuine standard is distinguished from a promoted technology by the level of hype surrounding it. Real standards don't have to be promoted; no one had to promote C, Unix, or HTML. A real standard tends to be already established by the time most people hear about it. On the hacker radar screen, Perl is as big as Java, or bigger, just on the strength of its own merits.
Why do many developers feel compelled to use Java instead of choosing it willingly?

Many developers feel compelled to use Java instead of choosing it willingly because they are often forced to do so. A lot of the people I know using Java are doing it because they feel they have to. Either it's something they felt they had to do to get funded, or something they thought customers would want, or something they were told to do by management. These are smart people; if the technology was good, they'd have used it voluntarily.
What are some criticisms of Java as a programming language?

Java can be criticized for being bureaucratic. From what little I know about Java, there seem to be a lot of protocols for doing things. Really good languages aren't like that; they let you do what you want and get out of the way.
What factors differentiate programming languages preferred by large organizations from those favored by hackers?

Large organizations have different aims from hackers. They want languages that are believed to be suitable for use by large teams of mediocre programmersâlanguages with features that, like the speed limiters in U-Haul trucks, prevent fools from doing too much damage. Hackers don't like a language that talks down to them; they just want power. Historically, languages designed for large organizations (PL/I, Ada) have lost, while hacker languages (C, Perl) have won. The reason: today's teenage hacker is tomorrow's CTO.
Who tends to favor Java according to the author's perspective?

The wrong people like it. The programmers I admire most are not, on the whole, captivated by Java. Who does like Java? Suits, who don't know one language from another but know that they keep hearing about Java in the press; programmers at big companies, who are amazed to find that there is something even better than C++; and plug-and-chug undergrads, who are ready to like anything that might get them a job (will this be on the test?). These people's opinions change with every wind.
What challenges is Sun facing that could impact its future and the viability of Java?

Sun's business model is being undermined on two fronts. Cheap Intel processors, of the same type used in desktop machines, are now more than fast enough for servers. Additionally, FreeBSD seems to be at least as good an OS for servers as Solaris. Sun's advertising implies that you need Sun servers for industrial-strength applications. If this were true, Yahoo would be first in line to buy Suns; however, when I worked there, the servers were all Intel boxes running FreeBSD. This bodes ill for Sun's future. If Sun runs into trouble, they could drag Java down with them.
What does the Defense Department's preference for Java suggest about its approach to software development?

The Defense Department's preference for Java suggests a cautious and procedural approach to software development. The DoD encourages developers to use Java, which may indicate a reliance on established, traditional programming languages rather than embracing more innovative or flexible options. While the Defense Department does a fine (though expensive) job of defending the country, their culture is heavily focused on plans, procedures, and protocols. This approach contrasts sharply with hacker culture, which values experimentation and agility. Historically, when the DoD has favored a programming language, such as Ada, it has often led to less favorable outcomes in software development.
What are the author's thoughts on the potential quality of Java as a programming language despite its corporate backing and mainstream promotion?

It could be that in Java's case I'm mistaken. It could be that a language promoted by one big company to undermine another, designed by a committee for a "mainstream" audience, hyped to the skies, and beloved of the DoD, happens nonetheless to be a clean, beautiful, powerful language that I would love programming in. It could be, but it seems very unlikely.
How does the portrayal of the justice system on television differ from its reality?

The real world does not work like the version I was shown on TV growing up. The police often arrest the wrong person. Defendants' lawyers are often incompetent, and prosecutors are often motivated more by publicity than justice.
What is the main ethical concern surrounding the death penalty?

The main ethical concern surrounding the death penalty is that some people sentenced to death are innocent. So this is not about whether it's okay to kill killers; this is about whether it's okay to kill innocent people.
What should California voters consider regarding Proposition 62 and Proposition 66?

This year, in California, you have a chance to end this by voting yes on Proposition 62. But beware, because there is another proposition, Proposition 66, whose goal is to make it easier to execute people. So yes on 62, no on 66.
